HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Slide in Oil and Internet Shares Helps Stall Summer Rally

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
A summer rally stalled yesterday as concerns about stock valuations caused investors to sell shares that had strong gains in recent weeks.
Recent high-flying Internet shares and oil producers, weakened by falling crude oil prices, were at the center of the declines. After climbing as much as 59 points, the Dow Jones industrial average closed down 6.73 points, to 9,085.04, with Chevron among the average's leading decliners. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 2.67 points, to 1,154.66, and the Nasdaq composite index slipped 1.36 points, to 1,908.11. 
 The Nasdaq composite index was weighed down by sizable declines in several Internet-related issues.
Lycos, which soared 20 1/2 on Monday after the company announced plans for a 2-for-1 stock split, plunged 14 9/16 yesterday, to 85. The stock had more than tripled this year, to 99 9/16 on Monday from a low of 33 1/8 on Jan. 9.
Other Internet shares, including America Online, Yahoo, Doubleclick and Earthlink, fell sharply. The shares had been rising recently on speculation about potential acquisitions or combinations.
Amazon.com, the Internet bookseller, fell 17 3/8, to 122 1/8. Still, the stock has risen more than 300 percent this year. As a result of such lofty gains, said Charles Pradilla, chief investment strategist at Cowen & Company, Amazon and other Internet shares were poised to fall as investors expressed skepticism about whether the stocks had become too expensive.
"I'm very nervous about it," Mr. Pradilla said about the gains. "Some of these companies are two years away from making money."
But there were some notable gains yesterday. Merrill Lynch rose 3 5/16, to 104 5/16, a 52-week high. The shares moved higher amid speculation that the company would split its stock, which would allow more individual investors to buy shares. Merrill officials declined to comment. Merrill last split its stock on May 30, 1997.
General Electric rose 3/4, to 92 5/8 -- a new high -- as it became the first American company with a market capitalization of more than $300 billion. Its market capitalization, or the value of its outstanding shares multiplied by its stock price, stood at $301.7 billion at the end of trading yesterday. So far this year, G.E. shares have gained more than 26 percent.
Such gains underscored the belief of some analysts that yesterday's declines would be short-lived and that the summer rally would soon resume.
"I don't think the summer rally is over yet," Mr. Pradilla said. His confidence is grounded in the current low interest rates and expectations that corporations will report strong second-quarter earnings.
James M. Griffin, senior vice president in charge of investment strategy at Aeltus Investment Management, said, "We're in a moment of everything going right, and the real risks to this balance are everything overseas" in Asia.
Some analysts, however, think American companies may have already felt the worst sting from Asia.
"I think the third quarter will be an important psychological turning point," said Thomas Galvin, chief investment officer at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. "Beginning in August and September, people will start to value stocks based on 1999 earnings."
And by September, the effect of economic measures enacted by the Japanese Government earlier this year should be apparent, he added.
"By the third quarter, we should have more answers than questions," Mr. Galvin said, "and if investors just think that we've started to hit a bottom, that's all we need to improve. Uncertainty is usually the worst side of the market."
In addition, shares of large domestic banks fell sharply during the fourth quarter of 1997 because of their exposure to Asia. That drag on profits should not happen again this year, he said.

CORRECTION-DATE: July 9, 1998, Thursday

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Paris Aghast at Mere Hint of U.S. Stake in the Tower

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: PARIS, July 7

 BODY:
Sell the Eiffel Tower to the Americans? Mayor Jean Tiberi of Paris was as outraged at the idea today as Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York City might be at a suggestion that the Brooklyn Bridge was for sale.
"There is no risk to the ownership of this monument," Mr. Tiberi assured fellow Gaullists in a stormy City Council meeting this morning, after conservative renegades trying to unseat him spread the alarm that a subsidiary of GMAC, the financial arm of the General Motors Corporation, was on the verge of acquiring operating rights to the tower. 
 "It would be inconceivable and unacceptable for the tower to come under the control of an American group as its subsidiary," Philippe Dominati, another conservative, thundered as the renegades cheered.
GMAC Commercial Mortgage in Horsham, Pa., is indeed interested, along with the Bass brothers of Texas, in buying a 70 percent interest in the state-owned Credit Foncier de France. Credit Foncier owns half of a management company that has a 70 percent interest in the Eiffel Tower's operating company.
According to French law, the tower is the "inalienable" property of the City of Paris, which means aliens of any kind, including Americans, cannot buy it.
"I would imagine whoever is negotiating this for us on the ground is aware of that," said Scott Rombach, GMAC Commercial Mortgage's spokesman in Pennsylvania.
The 984-foot-high latticework tower, the highest in the world when Gustave Eiffel designed it for a centennial exposition in 1889, attracts almost as many tourists as Notre Dame. Its operations include a highly regarded restaurant, the Jules Verne, on its second "floor," and elevators that take tourists up to the most thrilling view in Paris.
Though the tower is not for sale, de Gaulle might have objected to the sale of Credit Foncier itself, which may not be the Eiffel Tower or the Arc de Triomphe but has serious credentials of its own. It was founded by decree of Louis Napoleon and financed Baron Georges-Eugene Haussmann's vast remaking of Paris in the late 19th century, before entering the equally vast market for subsidized housing in the 20th.
But after the property market went sour in the 1990's, Credit Foncier lost $1.9 billion in 1996 and the conservative Government of the day let it be known that it was thinking of breaking it up and selling it.
Employees -- some of them civil servants who had been paid 16 monthly salaries a year, according to French accounts -- held the bank's chairman hostage for a few days in January 1997 in protest, and a few months later, voters threw out the conservatives and elected a Socialist-led Government, which continued to try to find a buyer for Credit Foncier.
GE Capital, a subsidiary of the General Electric Company, decided against a bid, and the bank's unions agitated for a sale to the French post office. Now the question of whether the bank will be sold to GMAC and the Bass group is up to the Minister of the Economy, Finance and Industry, Dominique Strauss-Kahn, who is expected to make a decision later this month.
"The ball is in Dominique Strauss-Kahn's court," Jean-Antoine Giansily, one of the embattled allies of the Mayor, said today. Officials in Mr. Strauss-Kahn's office dismissed the whole matter as political posturing by conservatives desperate to hold onto power in the city but losing their grip after the mayor for nearly two decades, Jacques Chirac, became President of France three years ago.
A leading possible Socialist candidate for the mayor's job in the next election, in 2001, is Mr. Strauss-Kahn. 

CORRECTION-DATE: July 14, 1998, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Wednesday about an American group's proposed acquisition of a stake in Credit Foncier de France, which has an interest in the company that operates the Eiffel Tower, misidentified an American investor. It is the Bass Group, an investment group led by Robert M. Bass -- not the Bass brothers -- that is joining the GMAC Commercial Mortgage Corporation in buying the stake.

HEADLINE: New Low for High-End Hi-Fi

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER 

 BODY:
THE high end is in a funk.
These ought to be glory days for that peculiarly American obsession with the ultimate in stereo equipment. The numbers of the Wall Street and Silicon Valley wealthy multiply daily, seemingly increasing the potential customer base for monaural tube amplifiers at $34,000 a pair, an electrostatic speaker system at $70,000 or a CD player with no integrated circuits for $17,000. 
 But the high end isn't crowing; instead, it is experiencing a kind of existential angst, beset by demographic and economic issues beyond its control and technological trends that threaten its very relevance.
The best audio equipment is largely handmade, and therefore expensive, and the high end has always been a bit of a cult with its own language and customs, something that has scared away new participants. What makes it special is the tireless devotion of its practitioners to innovation and to a level of excellence that is as much art as engineering.
But high-end audio may be the only electronic product whose price has steadily risen in the past two decades, narrowing its potential market to software millionaires and magnates of the Asian tigers, now in eclipse, who made up as much as a third of the market.
"The high end has been preaching to the converted for years and hasn't branched out," said Wayne Garcia, editor-in-chief of Fi, a three-year old magazine devoted to high-end audio. "The traditional two-channel music lover is either aging, burned out or has enough gear and doesn't need to upgrade all the time or has other priorities," he said. "At the same time, the high end hasn't done a good job getting its message across to younger people."
Born in the hobbyist days of what was then called hi-fidelity, high-end audio blossomed in the late 1970's and 80's. Even as stereo equipment became the domain of mass-market consumer-electronics manufacturers, most of them Japanese, scores of small companies sprang up in the United States and Europe to pursue the elusive goal of nearly perfect sound.
Though they remained small businesses, brands like Conrad-Johnson, Martin-Logan and Spectral gained international followings for their exquisite amplifiers and speakers. Spurred on by magazines like Stereophile, The Absolute Sound and Fi, the auteurs of audio aimed to recreate the sound of live music.
While that goal may be forever elusive, a properly set up high-end audio system, using only two channels, can produce a musical experience that is startling real, a sound of a completely different order than that offered by mass-market equipment, albeit for a very few consumers.
A study by the Consumer Electronics Manufacturers Association estimated total United States factory sales for the high-end audio industry in 1997 at about $1.1 billion, out of a total market of about $75.6 billion. But the association did not differentiate between home theater and high-end audio. Many manufacturers say they believe that the industry is far smaller, not more than $500 million, and even that total is spread among literally hundreds of companies. Although sales grew in 1997, many companies have reported declines in 1998, which they attribute primarily to the Asian economic crisis.
Defining the high end is problematic. It's not just a matter of expense because a music lover can easily spend thousands of dollars on flashy gear that no self-respecting audiophile would condescend to listen to. The entry point for a high-end system today is about $10,000 for a CD player, preamplifier, amplifier, speakers and cables, more if the system includes a turntable, tuner or tape deck, less with savvy purchases of used equipment or with equipment built from kits. For an all-out assault on the state of the art, figure some multiple of six figures.
To some extent, the high end's woes reflect the same kind of changes that led to the decline of classical music radio stations. Not so long ago, listening to a broadcast of a symphony was a popular evening's entertainment; now most radio listening is done in cars. Similarly, the audio hobbyist who used to spend hours "tweaking" his system, playing record after record, may now be surfing the Web, even if it is to check in on rec.audio.high-end, a Usenet newsgroup devoted to his old hobby.
"It comes down to how people spend their leisure time," said Wendell Diller, president of Magnepan in White Bear Lake, Minn., a maker of large flat-panel speakers that are much praised in high-end circles. "They can play with a computer, watch a movie, but to sit and listen to music? C'mon, only the die-hard music lovers continue to entertain themselves this way. Although the economy is booming, I hear all my friends in the business saying, 'What's going on here?' "
Jeffrey Labovitz, who manages technology transfer for the University of California at San Francisco, has a roomful of high-end gear, but he has not set foot in an audio store in a few years. "I still have all the equipment, and I listen to it all the time, but I don't read audiophile magazines any more, and I don't hang out at the Audible Difference," he said, referring to a Palo Alto store that has outfitted many Silicon Valley luminaries. Noting the huge cost increase for an incremental improvement in sound, he said, "You reach a certain level and you stop."
Actually the seeming paradox of a healthy economy and a flat high end reflects a long-standing dichotomy in the industry, which has only been exaggerated by three or four decades of rising prices. Just as Porsche designs cars for race drivers but reaps most of its revenues from the merely wealthy, so, too, the high end may be driven by hobbyists and critics, but it survives on sales to successful entrepreneurs and professionals whose level of interest may not match their ability to spend. One does not need to be obsessed to spend $100,000 on a music system, only well-to-do.
But the wealthy have grown less enamored of huge speakers placed well away from walls for the best sound, racks of glowing amplifiers and yards of garden-hose-size interconnect cables. Today the demand is for custom installations that hide all the gear in walls or bespoke cabinetry and, above all, for home theater.
Some retailers are benefiting from this trend, devoting more of their store space to theater systems and reaping good margins from installation work. But the purists find it almost offensive. "It is the middle class, low to middle, who are fascinated with this," said Michael Kay, owner of Lyric Hi-Fi, Manhattan's temple to audio excess. "These people were never high end. They abandon the high end for today's fad, that I can't consider really musical behavior."
With five speakers instead of two and an emphasis on video projection, home theater systems attempt to make viewings comparable to attending screenings at the best cinema, a far different calling than recreating Carnegie Hall or the Village Vanguard in the living room.
"There has been a huge increase in personal wealth, and one of the ways people advertise their wealth to friends and neighbors is putting in a big home theater," said Larry Archibald, publisher of Stereophile, the leading audiophile magazine, which was acquired in May by the Petersen Companies. "Our Guide to Home Theater is seeing big advertising growth, and Stereophile is seeing flatness, and that is what's happening in the stores as well," he said.
While home theater is primarily the domain of big consumer electronics companies like Sony and Pioneer, a number of high-end manufacturers have developed products for this market. These companies say they can apply some of the values of the high end to home theater devices, like using the best components money can buy and building equipment that can be updated rather than replaced as technology improves and standards change.
"It's clearly an opportunity," said John Herron, manager for new product development at Madrigal Audio Laboratories in Middleton, Conn., which produces the ultra-high-end Mark Levinson line. Madrigal, a unit of Harman International, has introduced multichannel amplifiers and a digital surround-sound decoder in its more moderate Proceed line, with prices in the mid-to-high four figures. Some in the high-end industry say music reproduction and home theater are completely different goals. But Mr. Herron said the incompatibility was "not really the nature of the beast, it's the nature of the presentation."
Others disagree, on both esthetic and technical grounds. While home theater stresses dynamic range, the ability to play very loudly and have deep bass, to reproduce all those explosions in "Terminator 2," high-end audio systems are all about high resolution, the ability to recreate the most subtle tonal and spatial details of a musical performance.
High-end advocates also note that both Dolby Digital and Digital Theater Systems, or D.T.S., the two technologies battling for allegiance in home theater sound, employ compression technology that effectively eliminates phase information. Without that information, which delineates the precise timing of musical events, a music system cannot reproduce a three-dimensional sound stage. That is fine for theater systems, which rely on multiple speakers around the room to generate a 3-D effect, but anathema to the reproduction of live music.
"In an absolute all-out audio system, you never want to use compression," said Rick Frier, president of Spectral Inc. a maker of high-end amplifiers, preamps and compact disk players in San Jose, Calif. "That has cleaved the high end and home theater apart." Still, he added, the high end has to find a way to make itself relevant in this market. "Some can do it -- some swallow their pride and make a stab at it -- some say, Over my dead body," he said.
Even some high-end manufacturers who have introduced home theater products have reservations about them. The five channels of audio used in home theater "are going to lead customers to spend much less per channel, and that doesn't bode well for our part of the business," said Lew Johnson, president of Conrad-Johnson, a maker of high-end amplifiers and preamps in Fairfax, Va., that plans to offer a five-channel amplifier in the fall. "If you've got a $25,000 home entertainment budget and you spend $10,000 to $15,000 on a video projection system and spread the rest over five channels instead of two, your budget per channel for amplifiers and speakers is very limited," he said.
Still, there are signs that the high end may thrive again. Mr. Johnson is part of a work group meeting to promote an advanced audio disk based on DVD, which would take advantage of that medium's higher data capacity to offer better sound quality than do current CD's. But that effort comes just as CD sound, driven largely by a technology called HDCD, for high definition compatible digital, is finally approaching audiophile quality. HDCD, commonplace in high-end CD players, is now beginning to appear in mass market machines as well.
Surprisingly, sales of turntables have taken off this year, mirroring a simultaneous rebirth of the vinyl LP. "There is a resurgence," said Mr. Kay, of Lyric. "The small CD's that people buy are convenient, but the fanatic knows better. The analog is still better."
Perhaps more surprising, The Absolute Sound, which went out of business in March 1997 after all but coining the term high end, is back, with a new publisher and new financing. "We do not share this gloomy vision that the high end is dead; there's too much new and lively happening," said Harry Pearson, Absolute Sound's founder and editor. "They're confused, they're worried about surround sound and home theater, but I think the field is hopping."

HEADLINE: Stolen Old Masters Surface in U.S.

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN 

 BODY:
Four long-lost Old Master paintings, among a group of eight that were stolen 30 years ago, are to be presented to the President of Romania at a ceremony in Washington later this month. The President, Emil Constantinescu, is to return the paintings to a medieval castle in the Transylvanian region of Romania from which they disappeared in a brazen theft in 1968.
The Italian and Netherlandish paintings were recovered by the United States Customs Service in the house of a Romanian immigrant in Florida. The immigrant, Mike Oprisi, who gave a dramatic account of having escaped from Romania when it was under Communist rule, said he had had no knowledge that the paintings were stolen and had bought them from a Gypsy in Vienna for $1,200 before coming to the United States. 
 When stolen art is turned over to the law enforcement authorities, suspicion sometimes falls upon the individual returning it as a possible participant in the theft. But Patrick Jones, a spokesman for the United States Customs Service, which now has possession of the paintings, said that although the man's story was unusual, everything that could be checked -- including a bill of sale and customs declaration when the paintings entered the United States -- had been checked and that Customs was not making any charges.
"The individual who gave up the paintings was very cooperative, but of course we could not find anyone to confirm his whole story," Mr. Jones said. "On the other hand, no one ever escaped a Soviet bloc country in front of a crowd."
The United States will hand the four paintings over to Mr. Constantinescu in Washington when he visits the headquarters of the World Bank on July 18.
"President Constantinescu will first meet President Clinton and then accept the artworks," said Cristian Matei, the cultural counselor at the Romanian Embassy in Washington, who has been busy organizing the visit. "We're very pleased that these two events could be combined."
The paintings, which had been reported stolen from the Bruhenthal castle-museum in Sibiu, Romania, include works that art experts believe to be by Titian or an artist in the Venetian school of Titian; Dieric Bouts, the 15th-century Netherlands master, or perhaps his son; Franz van Mieris the Elder, a 17th-century Dutch artist; and Rosalba Carriera, an 18th-century Venetian master, or another artist in the Venetian school.
American art experts who have studied the paintings in recent weeks estimated the collection's to be worth somewhere between $300,000 and more than $1 million. One expert, who died last December shortly after making an appraisal, put the value of the purported Bouts painting, "Man With a Skull," to be worth $1.2 million.
The story began on May 27, 1968, when officials of the Bruhenthal discovered that eight "very valuable paintings by Old Masters," according to their report, had been stolen from the museum overnight. A year later, the Romanian Government issued a circular about the theft, describing the eight paintings in detail, but there was no response.
About this time, the young Mr. Oprisi decided "to seek a new life in the West," as he expressed it in a recent interview.
With only the clothes on his back and about $80 in his pocket, he said, he slipped out of Romania, swam across the Danube, made his way across Yugoslavia to Austria and settled in Vienna, where he claimed political asylum and worked as a tool and die maker.
In Vienna, he said, he met a Gypsy woman who offered to sell him four Old Master paintings. He borrowed money from an aunt living in Ohio and bought the four artworks for $1,200, he recalled.
A few months later, Mr. Oprisi emigrated to the United States and settled in Florida, becoming an American citizen in 1976. In 1996, he said, he noticed on the back of the painting referred to as "Man With a Skull" the seal of the royal Hohenzollern family, to which the King of Romania had belonged.
He showed it to an old friend, Frank Cesar, a Hungarian-born art appraiser and restoration expert who lived in Chazy, N.Y., near Plattsburgh.
Mr. Cesar said he thought the painting was by Dieric Bouts or perhaps one of the master's sons and was worth $1.2 million. Seeking further evaluation, Mr. Cesar sent a photograph of the painting to Jack Kilgore, a Manhattan dealer in Dutch and Flemish Old Master paintings. A short while later, Mr. Cesar died of a heart attack.
Meanwhile, Mr. Kilgore sent the photograph of "Man With a Skull" to the Netherlands Research Institute for Art History in The Hague. The institute quickly identified it as one of the stolen paintings. The Dutch institute then notified Interpol, the international police agency, which in turn alerted the United States Customs Service. They located Mr. Oprisi in Florida.
Vincent A. Rossi, the senior special Customs agent on the case, recalled that he was astounded when Mr. Oprisi volunteered that he had not one but four Old Master works and that he would surrender them all to Customs if it could be established that they were stolen property.
This fact was quickly established by John J. Baratte, a former museum director and art scholar retained by Customs for the job. "This was an easy one," Mr. Baratte said. "I was only trying to match the actual paintings with the fax sent by Interpol, and they were the same."
Mr. Oprisi then signed a statement in which he abandoned ownership, and Customs notified the Romanian Government.
"When I found out there was even a suspicion that the paintings might be stolen," said Mr. Oprisi, "I decided to give them away with no expectation of winning a medal or congratulations or anything. I could fight them by saying the statute of limitations had run, but I didn't want to. I said, 'Take them, and if the Government of Romania wants to repay the $1,200 I spent, I'll accept it, but if they don't want to pay they can have the paintings free.' "
Mr. Oprisi vehemently denies any knowledge of the four paintings that are still missing, including Van Dyck's "Death of Cleopatra" and "Portrait of a Man" by Hans Holbein the Elder.

GRAPHIC: Photo: "Man With a Skull," stolen in 1968, has turned up in Florida. (Gary I. Rothstein for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
The flimsy accounting in nuclear weapons decisions.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
IN September 1951, Senator Brien McMahon laid out the argument for investing heavily in nuclear weapons. "The cost of military firepower based on atomic bombs is hundreds of times cheaper, dollar for dollar, than conventional explosives," he explained.
Nearly a half-century later, scholars at the Brookings Institution have released the first thorough assessment of the cost of nuclear weapons. "Atomic Audit" (Brookings Press) estimates that $5.5 trillion in 1996 dollars has been spent by Washington on building, delivering and defending against The Bomb -- and the meter is still ticking at the rate of $35 billion a year. 
 Just how much money is $5.5 trillion? It's more than has been spent on Medicare and veterans' benefits combined, though $2.3 trillion less than the total outlays on Social Security since 1940. Or, if you prefer the fanciful, $5.5 trillion stacked tightly in bricks made of $1 bills would be enough to build a wall 8.7 feet high around the Equator.
In the icy logic of economics, the benefits may still have exceeded the cost. But the very idea that nukes were initially embraced on such simplistic financial grounds is chilling testament to the sloppiness of military economics.
Senator McMahon, then the chairman of the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy, was right that a one-megaton nuclear weapon cost less than conventional bombs containing two billion pounds of TNT. But in giving short shrift to the expense of delivering the nukes, the Connecticut Democrat missed the forest for the merest of saplings.
The Brookings study, directed by Stephen I. Schwartz, estimates that building the weapons did indeed cost just $409 billion in today's dollars, 2 percent of defense spending from 1940 through 1996. But the delivery systems -- aircraft, missiles and related equipment -- added $3.2 trillion. Targeting nuclear weapons and systems to control their use absorbed $831 billion. Defenses against nuclear attack have swallowed $937 billion. The (largely future) cost of managing nuclear waste and dismantling obsolete weapons is projected at some $400 billion.
What began as a plan to substitute bargain technology for conventional forces took on a life of its own. First with the panicky military buildup during the Korean War. Then with the "missile gap" that became an issue in the 1960 Presidential election and morphed into a race with the Soviet Union for superior delivery systems. Still later, the Reagan Administration explicitly used military spending as a strategy for bankrupting the Evil Empire.
The Pentagon could calculate how many bombs would be needed to destroy Soviet rocket forces or to turn Moscow into a parking lot. But as long as the goal was something other than military victory, nuclear sufficiency was a subjective concept. "The closest to one man who would know what the minimum deterrent is would be Mr. Khrushchev," said Gen. Thomas Powers in 1960, "and frankly I don't think he knows from one week to another."
Not surprisingly, though, everyone seemed to have an opinion. President Lyndon Johnson's Bureau of the Budget, preoccupied with financing the Great Society in 1964, concluded that a force of more than 450 Minuteman missiles was a waste of money. Across the Potomac, the military bureaucracy reckoned the right number was 10,000. Defense Secretary Robert MacNamara settled for an even 1,000 missiles.
With the invention of underwater-launched missiles, the Navy thought a few dozen Polaris subs would deter the Soviet Union. But the Air Force thought otherwise, and Congress conveniently decided that a "triad" of sea- and land-based missiles along with manned bombers was needed to keep the Russians in their trenches.
Defenders of the nuclear establishment point out that, quibbling aside, the American arsenal succeeded in deterring a catastrophic war. But in Mr. Schwartz's opinion, this is an inadequate rationalization.
For one thing, he says, conventional forces backed by a small nuclear force would have cost far less and might have been equally effective. For another, the failure to contain either the size of the arsenal or the uncertainties associated with technological change made conflict more likely. The chances of accidental war, for example, were presumably greater with tens of thousands of delivery systems (rather than, say, hundreds). The adoption of hair-trigger response protocols in reaction to the huge numbers of offensive missiles surely increased risks. And the invention of compact warheads that could fit six to a missile made the verification of negotiated arms limits almost impossible.
However one reads the nuclear record, it is hard to deny that the policy evolved with little regard for other ways the cash could have been spent. Indeed, the scale was so vast that it inspires a variant on Senator Everett Dirksen's hoary quip. A trillion here, a trillion there -- and yes, it did add up to real money.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
A Federal agency starts a paid campaign today to influence young people to stay away from drugs.

BYLINE: By Courtney Kane 

 BODY:
THE White House's drug policy agency will introduce its first paid national advertising today as part of its fight against drug use among adolescents.
President Clinton will join Gen. Barry R. McCaffrey, the director of the Office of National Drug Control Policy, in Atlanta to introduce the campaign, the largest Government-financed social marketing effort to date. It will have an initial budget of $195 million, appropriated by Congress, and will involve television, radio, print, billboards and interactive media. 
 The decision to spend taxpayer money to finance the aggressive anti-drug campaign is a marked change from the Government's longtime policy of watching from the sidelines as advertising and media professionals coordinated unpaid anti-drug messages as public service advertising.
"For the first time we will be able to buy the time slots in the best media vehicles," said Thomas A. Hedrick, vice chairman of the Partnership for a Drug-Free America in New York, "just like Nike or McDonald's or Pepsi does on a regular basis."
The partnership, a nonprofit coalition of advertising and media professionals, has supervised the anti-drug pro bono campaign since 1987. Though the media have donated the equivalent of more than $2.5 billion worth of commercial time and ad space for anti-drug advertising, Mr. Hedrick said, the organization has found it increasingly difficult to reach specific audiences with specific ads because the pro bono campaigns depend on the availability of time and space.
For instance, in a strong economy, exposure in desirable places like popular prime-time TV series is difficult to obtain, and many public service spots are relegated to late-night time slots when few if any of the intended viewers are watching.
"We're going to pay for the precise placement we need to get the right message to the right audience," Mr. Hedrick said, "with enough frequency to change attitudes and, over time, drug behavior."
The national paid campaign comes after a six-month test in 12 cities, including Atlanta, Baltimore, Denver, Hartford, San Diego and Tucson, Ariz. Each year for the next four years, Congress will be asked to appropriate an additional $195 million to continue the campaign. The ads, which will begin appearing today, will be a mix of work already produced for the partnership and new spots.
In an interesting twist, the media that will be selling the paid time and space will be asked for such bonus or in-kind contributions as public service advertising or programs or articles addressing drug issues. For example, a TV network that receives ad dollars for anti-drug commercials may agree to run an episode of a sitcom in which a character confronts the problem of drug abuse or may produce a segment on drug policy for a news magazine show.
In the test markets, Mr. Hedrick said, the media matched the paid ads with bonus contributions.
The television part of the paid campaign is scheduled to appear tonight on the four main broadcast networks -- ABC, CBS, Fox and NBC -- and on CNN. The goal is for anti-drug spots to run about 9:15, Eastern daylight time, on the five networks in a TV tactic known as a roadblock. The Daily Fax edition of Advertising Age said that other cable networks like ESPN2, ESPN News, MTV and VH1 had also committed to run spots at about the same time.
The plans call for ABC to run an anti-heroin commercial recently created for the partnership by Margeotes/Fertitta & Partners in New York. The spot updates the famous "This is your brain on drugs" commercial by showing a woman wrecking a kitchen with a frying pan to simulate the effect that heroin can have on a life.
CBS is scheduled to run a spot aimed at parents that features the actor Carroll O'Connor, whose son died after years of drug abuse. On Fox, teen-age viewers are the intended audience for a commercial with the rap star Chuck D. The spot planned for NBC is aimed at young parents, and the spot on CNN, to run during "Larry King Live," is also aimed at parents, addressing the need to discuss drugs with their children.
The print part of the campaign is set to begin today in big-city newspapers. One hard-hitting ad, titled "Disconnect," is meant to illustrate a generation gap about drugs. A photograph of a woman is accompanied by these words: "My kid doesn't smoke pot. He's either at school, soccer practice, piano lessons or at a friend's house." Underneath is a photograph of a boy, who says, "I usually get stoned at school, after soccer practice, before piano lessons or at my friend's house."
The ads for the paid campaign are being donated by agencies through the partnership, which is serving as an unpaid consultant and will receive no Federal money. Media planning and buying are being handled by Bates USA in New York, part of Cordiant Communications Group P.L.C., and Zenith Media Services in New York, which is owned by Cordiant and Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C.
Though many Americans consider anti-drug advertising a necessary component of the Federal war on drugs, some perceive the ambitious crusade as money ill spent.
Ethan Nadelmann, director of the Lindesmith Center in New York, a drug policy research organization that is part of the Open Society Institute sponsored by the financier George Soros, said: "For the past 10 years, our nation's kids have been bombarded with anti-drug messages, and it is these same kids who are experimenting with more drugs. While these ads are well intended, this money could be better spent on programs that are proven effective in reducing drug use, such as after-school programs and treatment on demand."
Mr. Hedrick, needless to say, disagreed.
"I don't understand how it is a big waste of money," he said. "We have seen in independent research a strong and consistent correlation between exposure of anti-drug messages and improving anti-drug attitudes and behavior."
"There is simply no more cost-effective way" to deter drug use, he added, "than by investing 1 percent of the Federal anti-drug budget in this public-private partnership."
Still, Mr. Hedrick said, "the proof will be in the pudding." The partnership is awaiting the results of research from the 12 test markets, which are expected sometime in the fall, he said. There will also be research to evaluate the effectiveness of the national paid campaign.
Other organizations are also offering their assistance.
The American Advertising Federation in Washington -- which represents agencies, media and marketers -- will serve as a clearinghouse for matching public service advertising in 100 local markets where the paid campaign will appear. And the Advertising Council in New York -- the nonprofit organization that coordinates public service campaigns for the agency and media industries -- will serve as a clearinghouse for matching public service advertising nationally.

HEADLINE: Indonesians Visit U.S. Seeking Help With Debt

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY L. O'BRIEN 

 BODY:
As the Indonesia economy worsens, Government officials embarked yesterday on a campaign aimed at persuading international lenders to repackage up to $9 billion of debt.
An International Monetary Fund official said he was confident that the fund would release about $1 billion in aid to the country next week, but it is uncertain whether other lenders and investors will display the same faith in the country's economy. 
 "The economy is in worse condition than it was in April," said Finance Minister Ginandjar Kartasasmita, after meeting with bankers in New York yesterday. "Our main concern now is to stabilize the economy."
Mr. Ginandjar said Indonesia planned to keep interest rates high to combat inflation and would allow the country's weakest banks to fail as resources were concentrated on a handful of strong banks. He said Indonesia would also continue to liberalize its social policies.
"Indonesia has been portrayed as an outcast country because of our legal system and human rights issues," Mr. Ginandjar said. "We are embarking on a new era that we hope will cause the Western people and the Western media to look more favorably on us."
These are dire times for Indonesia. The damage wrought by the collapse of Indonesia's currency, the rupiah, has been so severe that a senior World Bank official said on Tuesday that Indonesia faced an economic crisis unparalleled in the post-World War II era.
Indonesia expects its economy to contract about 13 percent this year -- the first time the economy has shrunk since 1963. Automobile, electronics and construction output slid in the first half of the year, all of Indonesia's airlines are bankrupt and roughly 80 percent of flights to the country have been canceled.
In starker, more human terms, the World Bank forecasts that 50 million of Indonesia's 200 million people could fall below the poverty line by the end of the year. Government officials acknowledged a widespread concern about people dying from starvation. A severe drought is causing added pain in various parts of the country.
Although the World Bank said riots had disrupted food distribution networks, Mr. Ginandjar said the Government had a "distribution system that is independent" of routes disrupted by riots.
"The question is not the supply but the buying power," Mr. Ginandjar said, adding that the country had a program akin to food stamps that it would use to support those unable to purchase food.
Mr. Ginandjar was at Chase Manhattan Bank in New York to lobby international lenders to reschedule a portion of about $64 billion to $66 billion in debt owed by Indonesian corporations. The lobbying effort will continue to Washington, and on to Frankfurt, Paris, Tokyo, Seoul and Singapore, in the next week.
The Indonesian Government also has $54 billion to $55 billion in debt, but that is not a subject of the current negotiations. Mr. Ginandjar said there were "no problems" with the Government debt but that Indonesia remained open to various ways of restructuring the debt by renegotiating the interest rate or other terms.
While Indonesian ministers and advisers were upbeat about repackaging the private-sector debt, they face a tough challenge convincing lenders and investors that the country can overcome its economic challenges. Investors have cooled to a similar debt repackaging recently undertaken by South Korea, where the economy, while troubled, is considered to have stronger prospects than Indonesia's.
"Everybody wishes that things were better, but people are realistic," said Mark Walker, a lawyer with the New York firm of Cleary, Gottlieb, Steen & Hamilton, who is advising the Indonesian Government. "I sense that people understand why this program and why this proposal make sense."
Mr. Ginandjar said Indonesia "has a fair chance" of getting the battered rupiah, which has been trading recently in a range of 14,000 to 14,500 to the dollar, down to about 10,000 to the dollar by the end of the year.
He also was optimistic that free elections would be held by December 1999 and offered praise for the new Government of President B. J. Habibie, who has been struggling to assert his authority despite calls for an early election.
Although Mr. Ginandjar is considered an ambitious man with his own designs on the Indonesian presidency, he said Mr. Habibie had "done quite a bit in eight weeks," citing Mr. Habibie's acceptance of labor unions and the freeing of political prisoners.
Mr. Ginandjar said elections should not be held any sooner than the end of next year. "To be fair to the new parties, we need to give them time to organize," he said.

HEADLINE: Europe's Clunkers Shift to Fast Lane;
Introduction of the Euro Is Fueling Also-Ran Economies

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: MADRID

 BODY:
When Jose Antonio Santamaria and his family moved into their new condominium in February, they got satellite television along with access to enclosed gardens and a swimming pool.
But they also got a euro-break. Largely because Spain has been accepted into the group of European nations that will adopt the euro as a single currency in January, interest rates here have plunged almost as low as those in Germany. 
 For Mr. Santamaria, that translates into monthly payments that are about $140 lower than he had calculated when construction started three years ago. "It is much cheaper than we had expected," he said. "And with the swimming pool and enclosed garden, the quality of life is better, too."
Like Mr. Santamaria, Spain has not had it this good in years. As much of Europe adopts the euro as a single currency, poorer countries like Spain, Portugal and Ireland are growing much faster than bigger and wealthier ones like France and Germany.
Since 1995, interest rates in Spain and Portugal have plunged to less than 6 percent from 11 percent, largely because interest rates across the "euro zone" are converging down to the levels in Germany. Ireland, with a well-educated work force and relatively flexible work rules, has become an important manufacturing base for American companies exporting to Europe.
The effect within these fast-growing countries has been profound. While Germany and France invest heavily outside their borders, the smaller and poorer countries have become magnets for foreign money. While job creation continues to be stagnant in much of continental Europe, it is speeding up rapidly in places like Spain. And while consumers in Germany anxiously refrain from spending, demand is surging in the poorer countries.
"None of us is going to be the same five years from now -- not us, not France, not Germany," said Rodrigo Rato, Spain's Economics Minister. "We are all moving toward a new era of more competitiveness and more openness."
Ireland, one of the poorest countries in Western Europe in 1990, is rapidly catching up with the rest of Europe in terms of income per person. Its economy is growing by more than 8 percent this year -- compared with about 3 percent for the European Union as a whole. Indeed, with real estate prices soaring and labor shortages cropping up in some areas, the biggest worry among economists is that Ireland is headed toward an overheated economy.
Spain and Portugal are growing at about 4 percent this year -- faster than almost anywhere else on continental Europe. Their stock markets have been among the best performers in Europe as investors bet that interest rates will remain low and stable for years to come.
"It is a gift, essentially, a gift from abroad," said Miguel Sebastian, chief economist at Banco Bilbao Vizcaya in Madrid.
To be sure, part of the current boom is simply catch-up as countries bounce back from past problems, in particular Spain's severe recession in the mid-1990's. Though Spain has generated about 400,000 new jobs since the start of 1997, its official unemployment rate is still 19 percent -- one of the highest in Europe.
"What we are living through now is the rapid correction of past imbalances," said Ignacio Gomez-Montejo, Merrill Lynch's chief equity analyst in Madrid. "We are being rewarded for correcting our mistakes."
Signs of new affluence are visible here. On the outskirts of Madrid, the Las Rosas condominium development is building 10,000 apartments with an average price of about $120,000. Beckoning young families with signs that boast "We are building your dream house," the condominiums are selling quickly.
Meanwhile, the center-right Government of President Jose Maria Aznar has pushed through several reforms aimed at bolstering employment and investment. It has promoted fierce competition in banking and privatized about $25 billion worth of state-owned companies. And soon after taking power in 1996, it drastically cut the tax on capital gains, reducing the top rate to about 20 percent from more than 60 percent. Now, the Government is pushing through a much broader tax reform that would reduce income tax rates by closing loopholes.
The Government, under Mr. Aznar and his predecessor, Felipe Gonzalez, has also made it easier for companies to hire workers on temporary contract. Though full-time jobs are still relatively scarce, temporary jobs have soared. But perhaps the biggest change in Spain is one of outlook: a new willingness of domestic companies to look abroad for opportunities. Since joining the European Union in 1986, the country has steadily increased its volume of trade with the rest of Europe. As recently as 1990, Spanish exports and imports added up to about 40 percent of the country's gross domestic product. Today, foreign trade in both directions adds up to about 70 percent, the lion's share with other European countries.
The new confidence is apparent in Elche, a city on Spain's southern coast that is the heart of its shoe industry. Bolstered by low interest rates and cheap money, nearly 50 companies are building factories and office buildings at the city's newest industrial park.
"Financial costs used to account for about 5 percent of a company's expenses," said Jose Pertusa Romero, a partner in Gesem, a consulting firm in Elche. "But in the last year, interest rates have declined, and those costs have been cut in half."
And though shoes are still the mainstay of the local economy, the business itself has changed. Instead of competing strictly on price, traditional shoemakers are reinventing themselves as designers and marketers of brand names. And they are exporting more.
"It was a revolution, a real shock for the local industry," said Felipe Gonzalez, export manager for Panama Jack Group Internacional S.A., which produces hiking boots and leather casual shoes and began developing its own brand nearly nine years ago.
Juan Peran, the founder of Pikolinos S.A., made a particularly striking odyssey. A small, wiry craftsman who started his company from scratch in the mid-1970's, he spent years stamping out cheap plastic shoes. But five years ago, he began designing and marketing his own line of high-fashion shoes for export.
The strategy has worked. Pikolinos has more than tripled its sales volume since 1992, to 1.1 million pairs of shoes from about 300,000, and the profit for each pair has increased significantly. About 80 percent of the companies sales are to other European countries.
Mr. Peran recently moved the company into a gleaming glass-covered building at the industrial park. Shoe designers work out their ideas by creating three-dimensional models on computers, and robotic cutting machines transfer those ideas into precise strips of leather that are then sewn into prototypes.
"I am still a shoemaker, but this is the way we create about 80 percent of our designs," Mr. Peran said.
One of the biggest differences between countries like Spain and Portugal and Europe's wealthier but slower-growing nations is the pace of job creation. Even though Germany's economy is expanding at one of its fastest rates in years, nearly 3 percent, the number of new jobs has increased only marginally. Over the last several years, the number of jobs in Germany has remained almost flat while the number of unemployed job seekers has steadily increased. Though German job growth has finally picked up in the last few months, unemployment is expected to stay above 10 percent throughout the year.
By contrast, economic growth is bolstering job gains in Spain, Portugal and Ireland. Though Spain's unemployment rate of 19 percent remains one of the highest in Europe, economists and Government agencies calculate that about 400,000 new jobs have been added since the start of 1997, nearly 3 percent, and many others have probably been absorbed in the underground economy.
Portugal has had even greater success. Its unemployment rate has declined to about 6.3 percent from 7.3 percent in 1996 -- about half the level in Germany and France. And Ireland, with employment of 1.3 million, has added 50,000 jobs since 1995.
Though the evidence is mixed, many economists say the penchant toward hiring people in "periphery" countries stems partly from lower wages but perhaps more from greater flexibility, even though labor laws are often just as strict.
In Ireland, economists say the quality of workers is at least as important as the cost of wages.
"Most of the new jobs are coming from knowledge-intensive industries, not labor-intensive industries," said Terry Baker, an economist at the Economic and Social Research Institute in Dublin. Fifty percent of people entering the work force have college educations, and their educations have often been tailored toward technical areas. Ireland's biggest growth areas have been in computer and software companies, from Microsoft to Dell Computer to Intel.
"Irish labor is a good value," said Peter Jarrett, an economist at the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development in Paris, who has studied Ireland closely. "The quality of the educational system is as good as anywhere, and they have really geared it to the needs of the labor market."
Spain has worked to loosen its work rules. Although full-time permanent workers have some of the strongest job-protection laws of any nation, new laws allow companies to hire workers on temporary contracts -- often for years at a time. About one-third of all workers in Spain work on temporary contracts, one of the highest levels in the world and most of the new jobs are being created in the temporary labor market.
But as Europe's previously poor countries become richer, they may well become more like their wealthier neighbors. Even though Ireland has long boasted a devotion to "Anglo-Saxon" principles of light regulation, the country has followed Germany's tradition in reaching broad wage agreements in negotiations between unions, manufacturers and industry. In the most recent one the Government pledged last year to reduce income tax rates while unions agreed to modest wage increases of about 3 percent a year through 2000.
"It's very much on the old German or Scandinavian model, but it seems to have worked very well," Mr. Baker said,
In Spain, the Aznar Government has become a staunch defender of social programs even as it tries to support business.
"The big problem is how you keep social cohesion and at the same time stay ahead of the competition," said Mr. Rato, Spain's Economics Minister. "I don't think Europe is contemplating the American model on social issues. We do look to the American model on questions of competition and promoting capital markets. But on social issues, European society does not envy the Americans."

HEADLINE: Japanese Premier Promises Tax Cut for Long Term, Too

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, July 8

 BODY:
Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto today promised long-term tax cuts beginning next year, but he gave no details about how much the move might fatten pocketbooks or lift the sagging Japanese economy.
The United States and other countries have put enormous pressure on Japan to make permanent tax cuts to stimulate the economy and reduce the risk of a global downturn. Mr. Hashimoto's promise seemed aimed at winning support from Washington and from Japanese voters, who go to the polls on Sunday to choose members of the upper house of Parliament. 
 "Concerning tax-system reform, starting next year we would like to implement tax cuts that will be supported by the public," Mr. Hashimoto said today while campaigning in the central city of Nagoya.
His remark seemed to be an attempt to end days of confusion brought about by his public waffling.
Last Friday he suggested he would consider introducing permanent income tax cuts. Two days later he seemed to backtrack, saying that overall tax reform might not bring about a broad reduction in income taxes.
Mr. Hashimoto has been reluctant to lower the minimum level of taxable income, currently at nearly $24,000. Such a step would bring in more tax revenues but it would be politically risky because it would hurt the poor.
Today's remark, which seemed more forceful, still left many people wondering whether the size of the cuts would be enough to prompt consumers to spend more money. The yen, which had fallen against the dollar throughout the day, weakened slightly, to 139.60 yen, from 138.85 yen, just as Mr. Hashimoto was making his comments.
In April Mr. Hashimoto said the Government would tackle reform of the entire tax system, which many economists say drains a great deal of incentive from employees and businesses to make more money. Economists say they expect to see top rates slide to 50 percent, from 65 percent, on individuals and to 40 percent, from 46 percent, on corporations.
The challenge that Mr. Hashimoto faces, however, is that any tax cuts would have to be financed somehow by a Government that has just declared fiscal austerity to be its medium-term goal. Last fall Mr. Hashimoto pushed through a policy of fiscal austerity, and though he has since stepped back a bit, that principle seems to have kept the Government from spending its way too freely out of the recession.
Earlier this year the Government made $14 billion in income tax rebates, and it plans to make a similar rebate beginning in late summer. It has also said that next year, it will cut income taxes by another $14 billion.
Investors and economists have not been entirely pleased with those cuts, however, because they are one-time reductions that will not necessarily encourage people to spend more. Some members of the governing Liberal Democratic Party, including the secretary general, Koichi Kato, have argued that most of the rebates go into savings rather than being spent, and that it is therefore an ineffective way to stimulate the economy.
"Tax reduction through tax rebates is nothing but giving liquor to an alcoholic," said Teizo Taya, an economist at Daiwa Institute of Research. "That is not going to change the motives of people."

HEADLINE: U.S. Policy on Nigeria Could Hinge on Results of an Autopsy

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 8

 BODY:
The United States said today that it would await the results of the autopsy on Nigeria's most prominent political prisoner, Moshood K. O. Abiola, before it considers resuming its high-level diplomatic efforts to bring democracy to the country.
The sudden death of Mr. Abiola, who was imprisoned in 1994 after apparently winning the democratic presidential election the year before, threw American policy toward Nigeria into confusion and generated debates among critics of the policy. 
 It also overshadowed what State Department officials described as an otherwise successful mission to Nigeria this week by a delegation of senior American diplomats, who pressed the Nigerian junta for democratic reforms and for the release of political prisoners, especially Mr. Abiola.
"I believe that continued and high-level contacts can take place, but I think we all need to wait and see how this autopsy comes out," said Under Secretary of State Thomas R. Pickering, who was meeting with Mr. Abiola in a government guest house in Abuja, the Nigerian capital, when he fell ill on Tuesday.
Mr. Pickering, in a telephone interview from London, where he stopped en route home to Washington, said today that he found Nigeria's new leader, Gen. Abdulsalam Abubakar, to be receptive to American demands for movement toward democratic civilian rule there.
"They were receptive, particularly the head of state," Mr. Pickering said, referring to the general. "He committed himself to professionalize the military and get it back to its professional role in Nigeria -- clear and direct code words for getting the military out of politics."
"I expect they are going to release political prisoners," said Mr. Pickering, a former Ambassador to Nigeria. "It was very clear to me that they were prepared to release Abiola."
Last week the Nigerian Government told Kofi Annan, Secretary General of the United Nations, that all political prisoners, including Mr. Abiola, would be released.
Mr. Pickering said that he had been impressed by the willingness of Nigerian officials to conduct an autopsy with outside doctors present.
"It was a Nigerian Government doctor in attendance who said that everybody must insist on an autopsy," he said.
Mr. Pickering said that while the timing of the death was extraordinary -- the American diplomat traveled with Mr. Abiola to a nearby hospital and watched as doctors tried to revive him -- the 60-year-old multimillionare businessman was known to be in poor health after four years' of often brutal imprisonment.
"He has some record of hypertension," Mr. Pickering said. "Both of his legs were swollen and he showed them to us."
The sudden death of Mr. Abiola prompted calls today from human rights organizations, African scholars and others for a reappraisal of American policy toward the Nigerian junta.
Walter C. Carrington, who was the United States Ambassador to Nigeria from 1993 until last fall, said in an interview that he believed the Clinton Administration should have been tougher in threatening to impose economic sanctions against the country's military leaders.
He said that while serving in Nigeria he was repeatedly rebuffed by the State Department when he recommended that the United States consider freezing the assets of corrupt leaders of the Nigerian Army, who are believed to have stashed millions of dollars in American banks.
He said the State Department's reluctance to offend the junta had less to do with oil -- Nigeria is the fifth-largest supplier of petroleum to the United States -- than with an institutional mindset in the State Department that "we should try to get along with the established leadership in Nigeria and everywhere else."
Mr. Carrington, a lawyer who is now on a fellowship at Harvard University, said that during his four years in Nigeria he had been frustrated by the reluctance of the State Department to throw its full support behind Mr. Abiola during his imprisonment, in part because of long-standing rumors that Mr. Abiola was corrupt and somehow involved in the narcotics trade.
The department, he said, failed to recognize how his years in prison had changed Mr. Abiola.
"The thing about Abiola is that he underwent an epiphany once he went into prison," he said. "I think he grew substantially as a real leader of the democratic movement."
The Rev. Jesse L. Jackson, President Clinton's special envoy to Africa, said that the United States needed to demand the presence of independent medical experts at the autopsy.
"The way he died arouses real suspicion," Mr. Jackson said. "There are questions about whether his death was induced or whether he was simply allowed to rot in prison. These questions are unavoidable and should be addressed directly and frankly by the Nigerian Government."
Mr. Jackson said the United States would now have to step up its campaign to bring democracy to Nigeria, or risk the violent fragmentation of a nation of 110 million people that is torn by tribal and regional rivalries.
"The sheer size of Nigeria is such that we should not move too slowly right now," he said. "If the tension exploded there, it could be even more devastating than Rwanda."

HEADLINE: Scorched and Parched, the South Tallies the Rising Toll of a Drought

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO 

DATELINE: MIAMI, July 8

 BODY:
Although hurricanes and tornadoes sweep through with swaths of utter devastation, the erratic wildfires that have struck Florida since May have been more a menace than a catastrophe.
But with the passage of time, that menace and the drought behind it have wiped out crops and sent up choking clouds of smoke that have emptied beaches and hotels, disrupting the economic pulse of whole communities. 
 With lightning starting 50 new fires today, the onslaught is far from over. As firefighters spend their seventh week taming the worst fires in memory in Florida, state officials have only begun to tally the financial damage and assess long-term effects. As uncertain as the final damage bill is, the one certainty is that Florida is not alone in being hurt.
Severe drought conditions have been ruining crops since March from Texas eastward through Arkansas, Mississippi and Georgia, Federal officials said. At the same time the Midwest, middle Appalachia and New England have been awash in rain, they said.
The Federal Emergency Management Agency said it had spent more than $520 million in grants, loans and other assistance so far this year for states affected by fires, drought, winter storms, flooding and tornadoes.
For agriculture, drought has been a worse problem than flooding, said Albert Peterlin, chief meteorologist with the United States Department of Agriculture, even though damage figures were not yet available.
"The flooding is localized," Mr. Peterlin said. "Water is a thousand small threats. Drought is a big, terrible one."
In hard-hit states like Texas, where farmers say they have lost track of the days when temperatures topped 100 degrees and some are even hoping for a drenching hurricane, state officials estimate the loss to crops this year at $1 billion, with half of that involving the cotton crop alone.
The Texas Agriculture Commissioner, Rick Perry, said the overall economic impact is tripled when equipment dealers and other businesses that rely on agriculture are taken into account.
Some farmers said losses from previous droughts have left them barely able to hold on to their business.
"You have to laugh or cry," said Lynn Bartlett, 32, who grows cotton and peanuts on a 500-acre farm his grandfather started in the 1930's along the northeastern border with Oklahoma. "The dry-land cotton needs rain exactly right now, or it's close to being over."
In northern Florida, only two inches or less of rain fell in May and June compared with a normal 10 to 12 inches. Although only about $175 million of the state's annual $6.2 billion harvest has been lost so far to the record-breaking heat and drought, the weather has all but destroyed crops like corn and hay and inflicted major losses on about 12,000 growers in the Panhandle and north-central region, state Department of Agriculture officials said.
Livestock left hungry by dry pastures are subsisting on hay, which is not expected to last for the winter months when it is normally needed. As a result demand is great.
"We're desperately short of hay," said Terence McElroy, a spokesman for the Florida Department of Agriculture, which is seeking hay suppliers outside the state.
But the worst losses in Florida have come from wildfires that burned about 485,000 acres, more than half of it commercial timberland. About $300 million in timber has been lost and 324 homes have sustained damage estimated at $2.6 million. The price tag for firefighting efforts is now $104 million, state officials said.
Only about 260,000 of the state's 14 million acres of timberland have burned, but affected landowners are now turning to salvage efforts. The lost pine trees, used for paper and building materials, take 15 to 25 years to reach maturity, said Jeff Doran, executive vice president of the Florida Forestry Association, which represents the timber industry.
"You just go back and plant the trees all over again," said Jim Kauffman, land manager of the Jefferson Smurfit Corporation in Fernandina Beach, who expected to salvage less than 10 percent of 16,000 burned acres in Flagler and Volusia counties.
The fires that began burning out of control on Memorial Day have caused no deaths and 104 injuries, mostly to firefighters, because they were concentrated in forests.
Compared with the tornadoes in Central Florida in February that killed more than 40 people, or Hurricane Andrew in 1992, which killed 41 people in Florida and Louisiana, caused $30 billion in damages and still ranks as the nation's most expensive natural disaster, the recent fires have seemed a lesser evil.
But the potential for the fires to reach the scale of a major disaster as the flames moved toward towns and coastal communities last week prompted evacuations that displaced more than 100,000 people and closed major highways.
Tourism in most of the state remains unaffected by the fires, drought and summer heat, state officials said, but smoke has cast an acrid pall over beaches, keeping visitors away from coastal cities like Daytona Beach and Ormond Beach.
"We normally have a 90 to 95 percent occupancy this time of year," said John Connors, president of the Ormond Beach Chamber of Commerce. "There was one hotel I talked to that had only 13 of its 150 rooms occupied."
Scores of small businesses, from restaurants to fireworks stores, lost business because of mandatory evacuations that emptied whole communities like Flagler County last week, or from state health warnings that kept residents indoors.
In Ormond Beach, where 35,000 residents were under evacuation orders for four days, Paul LaRusso, manager of the Bicycle Company, said business was down 30 percent. Many of his customers are avid bicycle racers who left the area to train in other states because of the smoke.
"We normally get 50 to 60 people a day through here," Mr. LaRusso said. "One day I counted seven people in nine hours."
Even now, with communities returning to a semblance of normalcy, Ormond Beach officials say it is hardly business as usual. Judy Sloane, an Ormond Beach city engineer, said routine maintenance work is not being done because the smoke makes work outside difficult. The city has also imposed strict limitations on water use, asking residents to water lawns or gardens only two days a week, to conserve water for firefighters.
The fires have altered the landscape in the parched portions of Florida, but state ecologists said fires are a natural occurrence in the wild and that while some trees may take decades to grow back, much of the vegetation will recover quickly.
The fires have drawn attention to a nationwide problem: the migration of more and more people to forested areas. Residential development has curtailed controlled fires, which burn off dead wood and underbrush that, if left to accumulate, fuel bigger fires, Federal and state forestry officials said.
Federal Forest Service officials say residents who want to live in a rural environment should understand the need for controlled fires and protect their homes by taking such measures as building with fire resistant materials and keeping tall trees at least 40 feet away.
"In that environment, you have to assume the responsibility to make yourself safer," said Milt Williams, a spokesman for the United States Forest Service.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Dow Corning Reaches Deal To Settle Implant Battle
Dow Corning and lawyers for women claiming injury from silicone breast implants have agreed to a $3.2 billion settlement to the nearly 10-year-long battle.
The agreement would allow women seeking damages from the implants to receive money as early as next year and enable Dow Corning, a joint venture between the Dow Chemical and Corning, to emerge from Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. Page A1. 

Tina Brown Leaving The New Yorker
Tina Brown has resigned as editor of The New Yorker to start a company with Miramax Films that will publish a monthly magazine, publish books and produce films and television programming. The announcement came after months of rumors of growing tension between Ms. Brown and Conde Nast Publications, which owns the magazine. A1.
 
S.E.C. in Talks Over Price-Fixing
The Securities and Exchange Commission is negotiating settlements with several stock traders and as many as two dozen brokerage firms after an investigation into possible price-fixing on the Nasdaq stock market, executives at several Wall Street firms said. D2.
 
Nasdaq and S.& P. 500 Set Highs
The Nasdaq composite index soared 27.28 points, to a record 1,935.39. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index also jumped to a new record, 1,166.38, as all major market gauges increased. Investors expect the broad market to fare well in coming weeks because of the favorable interest rates and a less negative earnings picture. D5.
 
The yield on the 30-year bond rose to 5.62 percent, from 5.60 percent Tuesday. D5.
 
Dreyfus Portfolio Manager on Leave
Dreyfus placed the former portfolio manager of two of its mutual funds on "paid administrative leave." Federal and state securities regulators are investigating the manager's personal trading activities. D3.
 
Hashimoto Promises Tax Cuts
Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto of Japan promised long-term tax cuts, but he gave no details on how much the cuts would be. A6.
 
Mexico Reduces Spending Again
Mexico said that it would cut an additional $730 million from federal spending in 1998. The new reductions bring Mexico's cutbacks so far this year to $3.7 billion, closely matching its lost oil revenue. And Finance Minister Angel Gurria said Mexico expects a deficit this year, of about 1.25 percent of economic output. The Mexican Government depends on oil revenue for about a third of its annual income. D6.

SECTION: Section A; Page 27; Column 5; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 705 words

HEADLINE: Essay;
The Eight Yeses

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
To ingratiate himself with the Communist leadership in China, Bill Clinton became the first U.S. President to publicly embrace what Beijing calls "the three noes" -- no support for two Chinas, no independence for Taiwan, no membership of Taiwan in any international organization of sovereign nations.
Our former policy was brilliantly ambiguous: we acknowledged both sides' agreement that there was only one China and called for a peaceful settlement -- which carried an implicit promise to help Taiwan if Beijing launched an invasion. The newly expressed Clinton policy dismays Taiwan because "the three noes" explicitly deny self-determination. 
 Beyond that, Mr. Clinton forked over The Eight Yeses.
1. Yes to the purification of Tiananmen Square. By his ceremonial presence, Clinton helped Jiang scrub away the memory without reversing the verdicts.
2. Yes to China's insistence on exclusivity in the Presidential itinerary. At a time when financially shaky Japan and South Korea were desperate for reassurance, China demanded that the Clinton pilgrimage not be diluted by side trips to U.S. allies. Clinton meekly agreed.
3. Yes to giving China a veto over the American President's visiting party. Three Radio Free Asia journalists were denied visas and in effect bumped off the press plane. When the U.S. press failed to show solidarity, Clinton caved, setting a demeaning precedent.
4. Yes to China's pretense of being an "emerging" country that deserves special treatment in entering the World Trade Organization. By publicly asserting on Shanghai radio that "China is still an emerging economy," Clinton paved the way for a concession that would push the W.T.O. into giving China's powerful economy a competitive edge on subsidized exports.
5. Yes to China's harsh treatment of dissidents. Clinton acceded to China's denial of access to dissidents and made no personal protest at the roundup of protesters. He hailed the "freeing" of Wei Jingsheng and Wang Dan -- as if their forced exile were not a victory for repression.
6. Yes to Jiang's need for superpower support of his new cult of personality. "He has a good imagination . . . vision . . . extraordinary intellect," gushed our President, which can be dismissed as the sort of hyperbole once lavished on Mikhail Gorbachev, but then Clinton blundered by giving America's political endorsement to an autocratic, Communist regime: "China has the right leadership at the right time."
7. Yes to China's decision to delay joining the Missile Technology Control Regime. Jiang wanted more time to sell missiles to countries developing nuclear weapons, and was willing only to "study" Clinton's plea; this was peddled to the traveling press corps as progress.
8. Yes to the "strategic partnership" desired by the Chinese leadership. This naively accepted formulation depresses our Asian allies, which fear China's growing military and economic power, and panics India, which responds to what sounds like Chinese-American hegemony by going nuclear. China may be a lopsided trade partner of the U.S., but to pretend that our geopolitical rival is a "strategic partner" is to eviscerate the meaning of strategy.
In return for accepting the three noes and offering the eight yeses, Mr. Clinton was given the opportunity to tell the Chinese people that we consider the "loss of life" at Tiananmen to be wrong, but it's not for us to impose our views, etc.
In 1969, as Richard Nixon shared with Charles de Gaulle his idea of an opening to China, the French President told him: "Better to deal with the Chinese now, when they need you, than later, when you're forced to because of their strength."
In 1978, the former President recalled that de Gaulle advice, and added to me : "Today it's to our interest to make China strong. When they do become strong enough that they no longer need us, they will have other reasons, ties and so forth, which will enable us to cooperate."
That is what justified Nixon's opening, Carter's normalization and even Clinton's campaign-style visit. Then he added this chilling caveat: "In the long haul, looking way down the line -- this is deep background -- 15 years from now, we may have created a Frankenstein."
