SECTION: Section B; Page 11; Column 4; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 800 words

HEADLINE: Study Rejects New Limits on Helicopters

BYLINE: By AMY WALDMAN 

 BODY:
A draft of the city's first comprehensive analysis of its heliport infrastructure and helicopter activity has concluded that the city should continue its year-old ban on sightseeing flights from the 34th Street Heliport, but it does not call for new regulations on corporate or commercial traffic.
The analysis, which is called the Heliport and Helicopter Master Plan and was provided to community board members this week, immediately drew objections from critics who have lobbied the city to place further restrictions on helicopter flights, which they assert are too noisy and potentially unsafe. The plan, the critics said, broke little new policy ground and did not address issues including when helicopters should be allowed to operate and the altitudes at which they should be allowed to fly. 
 Charles Millard, the president of the Economic Development Corporation, which controls the 34th Street Heliport and commissioned the study, said the city was "in discussion" with the State Department of Transportation about a similar ban on sightseeing flights at the heliport the state owns, at West 30th Street and the Hudson River.
Mr. Millard said the city would carry out a recommendation in the plan to construct fuel tanks at the East 34th Street Heliport as a means of reducing the thousands of helicopter trips across the city to the only existing refueling site, at the West 30th Street Heliport on the Hudson River. The city will also build a noise barrier around the landside perimeter of the East 34th Street Heliport, he said, and it will consider offering financial incentives, like lower landing fees, to helicopter operators that fly quieter new technology, an idea praised by helicopter industry representatives.
A third heliport, at Pier 6 and the Battery, is owned by the Port Authority, which cannot ban sightseeing flights because of Federal restrictions. Those restrictions end in 2005, and at that point, the plan says, the city will ban sightseeing flights from there.
Deputy Mayor Randy Levine said yesterday that the plan tries to balance quality-of-life and economic interests. "We should not have tourist helicopters flying all over New York," he said, "but New York needs flights for commerce."
But the plan quickly brought criticism from advocates of greater restrictions on helicopter traffic. Representative Carolyn B. Maloney, a Manhattan Democrat and a proponent of stricter Federal aviation regulation for helicopters, criticized the plan for not addressing "overflights, minimum heights and curfews."
Joy Held, the founder of the Helicopter Noise Coalition, which represents 18,000 people, said the plan did nothing to reduce sightseeing flights from privately owned heliports, nor did it curb the number of corporate or media flights. "The sum total of this plan is that nothing is changing while the Mayor is claiming victory over the issue," she said.
Mr. Millard pointed out that the city had closed a heliport at East 60th Street at the end of February, and that traffic from the East 34th Street Heliport has been cut by 65 percent since the city ended sightseeing flights from there last August. There have been 41,875 flights so far this year from the three heliports, according to the Economic Development Corporation. In 1996, the latest year for which figures were available, there were 138,104 flights.
The plan does not address media helicopters because none take off from heliports in the city.
Matthew S. Zuccaro, a spokesman for the Eastern Region Helicopter Council, a trade association representing 86 companies, called the plan a "good foundation" for the city's helicopter and heliport operating system. But he agreed that the document set little new policy.
Mr. Zuccaro criticized the city's ban on sightseeing flights and its effort to get the state to do the same. "It seems," he said, "to be politically correct and expedient at this point, based on concerns about noise, to say, 'Okay, we'll just eliminate that segment of the industry.' "
The industry, he said, had made a substantial effort to regulate itself. Sightseeing companies have changed their routes to avoid flying over residential neighborhoods, he said, in addition to increasing the altitudes at which they fly, and stopped flying over Manhattan completely, instead coursing along the Hudson River. Mr. Zuccaro said he was also working on an operations manual for the city's eight news-gathering helicopters.
Mr. Zuccaro praised the city for not carrying out more of the activists' demands. "The Helicopter Noise Coalition," he said, "has indicated that their ultimate and only goal is to close all heliports and eliminate all helicopter traffic in the city, except for emergency flights."
Ms. Held responded, "That is definitely our goal."

HEADLINE: World News Briefs;
U.S. to Send Sudan $16 Million in Food

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 8

 BODY:
The United States announced today that it would provide another 9,390 tons of food, valued at almost $16 million, to combat famine in the southern Sudan.
The Agency for International Development also said it would donate $1.5 million to expand air and road deliveries of food through the United Nations World Food Program and $2 million to the United Nations Children's Fund to support air operations. 
 A 15-year civil war, coupled with drought last year and a further rain failure this year are behind the latest hunger crisis in the southern Sudan, where more than 2.5 million people are in dire need of food aid, according to the World Food Program.
The AID administrator, Brian Atwood, said the latest United States contribution, which brings American aid in the Sudan to more than $75 million this year, would go to meet the most urgent needs of 1.2 million people. Mr. Atwood said that the Sudanese Government, which had earlier announced it would not impede relief efforts, had provided written authorization on Sunday for five additional heavy-lift aircraft.

HEADLINE: Rage of the Rank and File

BYLINE: By Charles R. Morris; Charles R. Morris, a financial consultant, is the author of "The Cost of Good Intentions: New York City and the Liberal Experiment" and a forthcoming history of financial crises.

 BODY:
Punching a police horse in the nose doesn't win you many friends, and the recent mobbing of midtown by angry construction workers is enough to make New Yorkers sympathize with taxi strikes. The taxi drivers, after all, scrape out a living by working incredibly long hours in a nerve-jangling, high-risk occupation. The brawny, well-paid suburbanites who left 18 injured police officers in their wake just don't tweak our innate sense of justice.
But beyond the boorishness, there is sadness. The demonstration wasn't about wages, or working conditions, or job site safety. Instead it was a simple outburst of frustration over the degree to which even New York is no longer a union town. 
 The precipitating issue was the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's hiring of a nonunion contractor for a major renovation job. Public agencies have always been allowed to hire nonunion workers so long as they pay prevailing wages. Until recently, however, it would have been inconceivable to see nonunion workers on big public projects. Numbers are elusive, but even the unions concede that most construction work in New York, especially if rehabilitations are included, is now nonunion.
American unionism was one of the great social movements that shaped our history, a transcendent cause that people got beaten up or died for, much like the civil rights movement. The collective memory of unionists thrills to dramas of torchlit parades, inspiring folk singers, legendary orators. The enemies were exploitative employers, dangerous working conditions, sweatshop wages. The movement was about simple moral imperatives, just like civil rights.
The heyday of construction organizing was about a century ago. Irishmen predominated in the trades, and their unions reflected an ethnic clannishness. Union memberships were passed down like family heirlooms, from father to son, from uncle to cousin. In construction trades, the union hiring hall is the real employer, not the contractor. Builders come and go; the union is the constant.
The union movement was already on the downswing in the late 1960's, when guild-style trade-union exclusionism ran smack into the civil rights demand for integrated work forces. Union resistance was partly just sheer, ugly racism, but partly it was also about losing control over a small, stable part of the universe. Now almost half of all new apprentices are from minority groups. That is both a tribute to the quiet efforts of labor statesmen like the late Peter Brennan and a reflection of generational discontinuities. The sons of plumbers prefer college.
Now, as often as not, unions are thought of as obstructionists, grit in the economic machinery, just one more reason that everything costs so much in New York. And it's true; unions are expensive. Nationwide, construction workers get half again as much as factory workers, and New York construction wages are a third higher yet.
But it's hard to begrudge that an operating engineer can make $100,000 in a good year, when Goldman, Sachs partners may pocket a billion from their company's public stock offering. Operating engineers run the big rigs, the shovels, cranes and bulldozers that delight all of us sidewalk gawkers. What Goldman, Sachs partner can do anything as useful?
More corrosive are the work rules: overtime for any hours outside 8 A.M. and 4 P.M., and the manning rules -- minimum numbers of paid standbys; nonworking, but paid, shop stewards; minimum two-man teams on light jobs; deputy foremen, much else. For years contractors have tried to void a rule requiring pay for mandatory teamsters, whether they show up or not, but that rule stands. The theatrical unions milked the movie industry the same way and chased it from the city. None of this is caused by global competition.
Only the highly skilled trades are heavily unionized now, despite some recent organizing successes among the laborers. Skyscraper buildings need hundreds of ironworkers, operating engineers, industrial-scale plumbers and electricians. Those are the kinds of numbers and skills that can be found only in a hiring hall. But union cards are rarely seen on run-of-the-mill work sites, like middle-income apartment developments. Contractors bring their own workers, not so much for pay savings as for work-rule flexibility.
We're living in an age of the 401(k) and nomadic "knowledge workers," when all the great social movements have ossified -- the New Deal is fossilized in bureaucracy, the civil rights movement fights over quotas, feminism has become political correctness, unionism institutionalized grabbiness. The outpouring of tens of thousands of workers in the union demonstration last week was a brief flicker from a time when big issues could still stir the soul.

ATTRACTIONS
 
Museums and Sites 

AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY, Central Park West at 79th Street. Recently opened, the 11,000-square-foot Hall of Biodiversity, focusing on the variety and interdependence of Earth's living things. "Spirits in Steel: The Art of the Kalabari Masquerade," an exhibition featuring 13 steel sculptures by Sokari Douglas Camp, drawing on themes from her homeland in Nigeria, and 25 Nigerian masks from the museum's collection. On view through Oct. 12. "The Nature of Diamonds," an exhibition exploring various aspects of the mineral, from its geologic origins to its uses in technology and research. Through Aug. 30. Admission is by timed ticket only. "Africa: Explorations and Expeditions," featuring firsthand accounts of European and American exploration, as depicted in selections from the museum's rare-book collection. Through Sept. 30. The Imax films are "Cosmic Voyage" and "Amazon." In the Imax Theater on Fridays and Saturdays at 9 P.M., "U2 in 3-D" and at 10 P.M., "Pink Floyd's 'Dark Side of the Moon' " in 3-D. Tickets: $9. Museum hours: Sundays through Thursdays, 10 A.M. to 5:45 P.M.; Fridays and Saturdays, 10 A.M. to 8:45 P.M. Suggested admission: $8; students and the elderly, $6; children 12 and under, $4.50. A combination ticket including museum admission and one film: $12; students and the elderly, $8.50; children 12 and under, $6.50; under 2, free. Information: (212) 769-5100; to buy tickets by phone: (212) 769-5200.
 
AMERICAN NUMISMATIC SOCIETY, Audubon Terrace, Broadway at 155th Street, Washington Heights. The society has the most extensive coin collection in North America; its library is open to the public. Tomorrow at 11 A.M.: "Solving an Enigma: The Immobilized Types of Sistan's Sasanian Style Coinage," a seminar hosted by Dr. Stuart D. Sears, assistant professor in the department of history, American University in Cairo. Reservations requested. On permanent display is "American Numismatic Design, 1892-1922," which includes all coins issued during this period. Also on view is "The World of Coins," a history since 600 B.C. Free. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 9 A.M. to 4:30 P.M.; Sundays, 1 to 4 P.M. Information: (212) 234-3130.
 
HISTORIC RICHMONDTOWN, Staten Island Historical Society, 441 Clarke Avenue, Richmondtown. More than 25 buildings from the late 17th century to the 19th century, restored and furnished. This village and outdoor museum depicts the history and life of Staten Island and the surrounding region. For the summer season, ending Sept. 6, costumed villagers demonstrate historical trades like tin smithing and dollmaking. The exhibition "Toys!" will be open through the end of the year. Admission for the market is $1 for adults, 50 cents for children. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, 1 to 5 P.M. Regular admission: $4; the elderly and those 6 to 18, $2.50; 5 and under, free. Information: (718) 351-1611.
 
INTREPID SEA-AIR-SPACE MUSEUM, Pier 86, West 46th Street at the Hudson River, Clinton. A converted World War II aircraft carrier with two full decks of displays, including four theme halls: United States Navy Hall, Pioneer Hall, Technologies Hall and Intrepid Hall. "The Spanish-American War," an exhibition featuring pieces of ships that fought in the war, decorative plaques from the U.S.S. Maine, photographs and nautical charts. Through December. "Proudly We Serve," an exhibition about the service of black veterans, with photographs, uniforms, artifacts and models, is on view through December. Also on view is a 1950's French naval fighter jet, the Etendard IV-M, given to the museum by the French Government. Visitors can feel what it is like to fly a tactical mission over the Persian Gulf by using a flight simulator, which recreates five minutes aboard an F-18 Hornet fighter jet. A ride on the simulator is $5; $3 for school groups. "Cold War/Berlin Wall," a permanent exhibition on the historic wall that symbolized the cold war until it came down in November 1989. Today and tomorrow, "Vesselmania," a convergence of seven international NATO touring ships, including crafts from Belgium, Germany and Portugal as well as the United States. Visits are free from 1 to 4 P.M. Hours: Mondays through Fridays, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Saturdays through Sundays, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. Admission: $10; the elderly, veterans, reservists and ages 12 to 17, $7.50; ages 6 to 11, $5; 5 and under, $1; under 2, free; wheelchair patrons, half price. Information: (212) 245-0072.
 
MERCHANT'S HOUSE MUSEUM, 29 East Fourth Street, lower Manhattan. This preserved late Federal brick home with a Greek Revival interior, owned by Seabury Tredwell, a wealthy hardware dealer, was built in 1832. The house holds the original furniture, clothing and personal articles of the Tredwells, who lived there almost 100 years. Hours: Sundays through Thursdays, 1 to 4 P.M. Admission: $3; students and the elderly, $2; children under 13, free. Information: (212) 777-1089.
 
MUSEUM OF JEWISH HERITAGE: A LIVING MEMORIAL TO THE HOLOCAUST, 18 First Place (West Street and Battery Place), Battery Park City. Artifacts, documents, photographs, videotapes and film clips are included in exhibitions on the Holocaust and on Jewish life before and after World War II. "Israel at 50 Years: Diverse Views by Magnum Photographers," featuring 36 images. Through Labor Day. Other exhibitions include "Life a Century Ago," featuring memorabilia from Jewish rituals and celebrations in Europe in the early 1900's; "War Against the Jews," detailing the years 1933 to 1945, and "Jewish Renewal," focusing on life after the Holocaust. Hours: Sundays through Wednesdays and Fridays, 9 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Thursdays, 9 A.M. to 8 P.M.; eve of Jewish holidays, 9 A.M. to 2 P.M.; closed Saturdays. Admission: $7; students and the elderly, $5; 5 and under, free. Some same-day tickets are available at the museum; because of heavy attendance, tickets should be purchased in advance through Ticketmaster: (212) 307-4007. Information: (212) 968-1800.
 
MUSEUM OF TELEVISION AND RADIO, 25 West 52d Street, Manhattan. A collection of taped radio and television broadcasts as well as exhibitions of other media, including drawings, posters and photographs. "A Television Diary: 45 Years of TV Guide Covers." Through Aug. 31. "The Complete and Utter History of Monty Python's Flying Circus." Through Sept. 24. Today at 1 and 6 P.M.; tomorrow and Sunday at 1 P.M.: "Sex and Violence," featuring rare film of the members of the troupe in pre-Python roles and the first and second episodes of the Monty Python's Flying Circus television show; today at 2:30 and 7:30 P.M. and Sunday at 2:30 P.M., "How to Recognize Different Types of Trees From Quite a Long Way Away," and along with related excerpts and rarely seen footage.Through July, screenings of Richard T. Heffron's television movie "See How She Runs" (1978), starring Joanne Woodward. Screenings: Fridays and Thursdays at 2, 4 and 6 P.M.; Sundays, 2 and 4 P.M.; Tuesdays through Wednesdays at 2 and 4 P.M. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, noon to 6 P.M.; Thursdays, noon to 8 P.M. On Fridays, the theater is open until 9 P.M.; closed Mondays and holidays. Admission: $6; students and the elderly, $4; 12 and under, $3. Information: (212) 621-6800.
 
NEW YORK CITY FIRE MUSEUM, 278 Spring Street, SoHo. In a renovated 1904 firehouse is a collection of fire-related art and artifacts from the 18th century to the present, including a firetruck, hose wagons, hats, toys, paintings and hand-drawn pumpers. Also, an exhibition, "Fire Marks: Emblems of Insurance," features a selection of 18th- and 19th-century British and American fire marks from the museum's collection. Insurance agencies would give bonuses to firefighters when they saved the premises of a policyholder. The decorative emblems were used to distinguish policyholders from the uninsured. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. Suggested admission: $4 for adults; $2 for students and the elderly; $1 for children under 12. Information: (212) 691-1303.
 
SOUTH STREET SEAPORT MUSEUM AND MARKETPLACE, South and Fulton Streets, lower Manhattan. The 19th-century port district has restaurants, shops and bars. The museum has three gallery spaces, a children's crafts center and a boat-building center. Exhibitions include "By Appointment to the King: Beken of Cowes, Marine Photographers," yachting images. Through Aug. 31. Also, the ongoing exhibition "Traveling in Style: 20th-Century Ocean Liners." Continuing. Museum hours: daily, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Thursdays, until 8 P.M.; closed Mondays; stores in the marketplace: Mondays through Saturdays, 10 A.M. to 7 P.M.; Sundays, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. Admission to museum: $6; the elderly, $5; students, $4; children 12 and under, $3. Information: the museum, (212) 748-8600; the marketplace, (212) 732-7678.

HEADLINE: New Video Releases

 BODY:

The Winter Guest
Even the sea has frozen solid on the icy winter day that Elspeth (Phyllida Law) drops in unannounced and unwanted on her recently widowed daughter, Frances (Emma Thompson, left, who is actually Ms. Law's daughter). Having resumed life in northern Scotland with her teen-age son (Gary Hollywood), Frances is unreceptive to her mother's emotional support. As a sort of counterpoint, Alan Rickman's solemnly talky film weaves in the stories of three pairs of villagers and ends on a warmly mushy note in, Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times, "a fussy, sentimental exercise in theatrical counterpoint." 

1997. New Line. $101.76. Laser disk, $39.99. 106 minutes. Closed captioned. Release date: Tuesday.
 
Sphere
Yes, that's Sharon Stone as the starchy biochemist Beth Halperin down there in the submersible with the brilliant mathematician (Samuel L. Jackson), the brash astrophysicist (Liev Schreiber) and the reasonable team psychologist (Dustin Hoffman). On the sea bottom is a strange round object that sucks in unsuspecting scientists for some quick mind bending and sends e-mail bulletins about its mood swings. Sounds extraterrestrial, maybe "bigger than Copernicus," as the story hype puts it. Anyway, it all gets checked out in Barry Levinson's "solid thriller with many showy scientific overtones" (Janet Maslin).
1998. Warner. $107.37. Laser disk, $39.98. 133 minutes. Closed captioned. PG-13. Release date: Tuesday.
 
Illtown
If it has no new twist on the old drug-deal-double-cross formula, Nick Gomez's film does present a cool, dreamy gangster's world with intimations of purgatory at every turn.
Dante (Michael Rapaport) and his lover, Micky (Lili Taylor), are routinely peddling the stuff when their former partner, Gabriel (Adam Trese), gets out of jail and, as the characters' names suggest, rakes up memories of past betrayals. With no plot trails to break, Mr. Gomez turns "Illtown" into "a sleek metaphysical experiment in visual style" (Maslin).
1996. Live. $83.33. Laser disk, $39.99. 103 minutes. Closed captioned. R. Release date: Tuesday.
 
Swept From the Sea
Xenophobic Cornish villagers mistake the babbling young man to be a crazy person, but he's really the dashing Ukrainian adventurer Yanko Gooral (Vincent Perez), who's washed ashore after his ship goes down on its way to America. In Beeban Kidron's heavy-handed adaptation of Joseph Conrad's story "Amy Foster," Gooral is nursed to health by a beautiful but strange servant girl (Rachel Weisz). Despite a loud, determinedly romantic symphonic score, Mr. Perez and Ms. Weisz strike sparks like a wet book of matches. Also blame the film's soggy thud on "too much rain, too many shots of the churning sea and far too much music" (Holden).
1997. Columbia Tri-Star. $105.77. Laser disk, $34.95. 115 minutes. Closed captioned. PG-13. Release date: Tuesday.
 
Straight to Video
Other new titles of interest, some of which may have had a theater release at one time or appeared on television.
GREASE. It's summertime in the 50's and the romance is back between the greaser Danny (John Travolta) and the wholesome Sandy (Olivia Newton-John) in a 20th-anniversary reissue of Randall Kleiser's adaptation of the Broadway musical. 1978. Paramount. $14.99 in wide-screen and regular television format. $19.99 for an edition with a CD and a booklet about the production. 110 minutes. PG.
THE FLY. During a matter transference a housefly gets mixed up with a scientist in the teleportation machine, producing a man with a fly's head and a fly with a man's head. It all makes ideal material for Vincent Price, who stars with Herbert Marshall in Kurt Neumann's cult film, with a screenplay by James Clavell. 1958. Fox. $14.99. 90 minutes.
THE FACE OF RUSSIA. In return for its icons, prose and music, Russia borrowed political and economic ideas from the West. James Billington narrates the three-part series shown recently on PBS, which traces the Russians through a thousand years of spiritual development, literature, art and architecture, music and, finally, the films of Sergei Eisenstein and modern media. 1998. Home Vision. Three cassettes, $79.95. 60 minutes each.
A NIGHT IN CASABLANCA. Rick is finished in town and now it's the Marx Brothers' turn as Groucho, Harpo and Chico tangle with war-surplus Nazis. 1946. Warner. $14.99. 85 minutes.

HEADLINE: DuPont Sees Profit Drop and Stock Falls

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WILMINGTON, Del., July 9

 BODY:
E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company said today that it expected its second-quarter earnings to be 10 percent to 15 percent lower than the 99 cents a share it earned in the comparable period last year.
On the New York Stock Exchange, DuPont's shares tumbled $7 each, to $70.125, pulling down the Dow Jones industrial average. 
 DuPont attributed the lowered earnings expectations to problems with its crop protection products business, prompted by the Asian financial crisis and weather and pricing pressures in North America.
Lower oil prices, lower demand in the textile industry and the General Motors strike also contributed to the expected earnings decline, according to the statement from DuPont.
"We find this totally unacceptable," Charles O. Holliday Jr., president and chief executive, said in a telephone news conference. "We find it unacceptable that we didn't see this coming sooner."
He said the company had put into effect a plan to improve performance and productivity.
Although the G.M. strike has not had a major impact on the company, it has affected it broadly, he said, noting DuPont makes more than 40 products for the automotive industry, including paint, plastics and fibers.
Mr. Holliday said that unless energy prices improved, the company would not be able to post a fifth consecutive year of record earnings.
DuPont, which operates in 70 countries, said it will release an earnings statement on July 22.

HEADLINE: Will Asia Turn Against the West?

BYLINE: By Fareed Zakaria; Fareed Zakaria is a managing editor of Foreign Affairs and the author of 'From Wealth to Power: The Unusual Origins of America's World Role'

 BODY:
The fire raging in East Asia today jeopardizes one of the central achievements of postwar American foreign policy -- the stabilization and growth of East Asia. Even more dangerously, if it continues to fester, this crisis could undermine support for an open global economy and economic and political liberalization across the world.
The facts are bleak. In the last two years Indonesia's economy has shrunk by almost 80 percent, Thailand's by 50 percent, South Korea's by 45 percent, Malaysia's by 25 percent. Even islands of prosperity like Hong Kong and Singapore are in deepening recessions. Currencies and stock markets have plunged to unimaginable lows; unemployment and poverty are climbing to new highs. 
 To take the worst example, Indonesia's per capita gross domestic product has dropped from $3,500 to less than $750, wiping out 25 years of economic progress. Some 100 million people -- almost half of that vast country -- have sunk below the poverty level, and fears of a famine are growing. President B. J. Habibie has called on his citizens to fast twice a week to lessen the need to import food. Japan, the only nation that could spur a new round of growth in the region, has now slipped firmly into its second recession in five years.
The Clinton Administration and the International Monetary Fund had an initial strategy to deal with what began as a financial crisis in Thailand in June 1997. First, they assumed it would be temporary, "a few small glitches along the road" in President Clinton's words. Second, they assumed it would be localized. Third, they assumed that the I.M.F. would restore stability.
All three assumptions have been proved wrong. The I.M.F.'s prescriptions have not worked; currencies and stock markets continue to fall. The panic is now a depression and has spread beyond East Asia. Markets as large as Russia and Australia and as distant as Mexico and South Africa have been battered.
If official responses have been inadequate, the reactions of American foreign policy pundits to the crisis have been worse. Much of this commentary has been to note gleefully that Asia's troubles confirm the virtues of the American system and the bankruptcy of "Asian values."
In the late 1940's, as Europe struggled to cope with similar economic hardships, George Marshall warned Americans that "the patient is sinking as the doctors deliberate." Today it is as if the doctors are vivisecting the patient to score points about anatomy.
The prosperity and stability of East Asia are -- were? -- extraordinary achievements. Thirty years ago, most of these countries seemed stuck in the dismal poverty that afflicted the third world, and the region was the most troubled part of the globe.
In Indonesia, more than 300,000 people had died in mob riots after a failed Communist-backed military coup in 1965. Malaysia, in civil war from 1948, lifted its state of emergency only in 1960. China, Taiwan and the Koreas had all been through grueling conflicts in the late 1940's and 1950's. And the Vietnam War was still in full fury.
One generation later, most of these nations had dramatically raised their living standards, substantially alleviating poverty and disease. Many, like Taiwan, South Korea and Malaysia, had begun liberalizing their politics as well. It was the fastest move out of misery in history.
The success of the region owes much to the hard work of its people but also to American foreign policy. The United States fought two wars after 1945 to maintain stability in East Asia. It advocated economic and foreign policies that were adopted in much of the region.
Compared with countries like Brazil, Egypt and India -- whose protectionism and central planning were cheered on by socialist governments and left-wing economists -- East Asian regimes adopted policies that were broadly hospitable to free markets and free trade. They opened themselves up to foreign investment and multinational corporations and allowed the private sector to flourish. Throughout the cold war they were consistently anti-Soviet, banding together to form the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, practically the only pro-American regional grouping in the world outside of NATO. For these policies they became the pariahs of the third world, often branded as American stooges.
In fact the growth and stability of East Asia have been a central achievement of American foreign policy in the post-war era, a living refutation of once fashionable theories about American neo-imperialism, third-world dependence and the necessity for socialism in poor countries.
All this is at risk today. If East Asia does not begin to recover soon, the dangers to its own well-being are obvious, but those to regional stability and American interests are also great. South Korea's growing weakness makes that peninsula even more unstable than it already was (and with 36,000 American troops stationed there, any internal problem will quickly become an international one). Indonesia, a geographic absurdity comprising 2,000 islands and 1,100 dialects, could easily lapse into violence and begin splintering.
The sudden shift in the balance of power away from Japan and toward China will not serve regional peace or American interests. Japan remains the second-largest economy in the world and a liberal democratic partner of the United States. Its decision to stay a nonnuclear and largely nonmilitary power is a cornerstone of East Asian stability.
China, on the other hand, is a rising power in the midst of transforming its entire political and economic system, ruled by a regime seeking legitimacy. Great power transitions are never easy, but it is better when they happen slowly, surely and, in any event, not in an atmosphere of general crisis. To take one example, anger directed against the wealthy Chinese minorities in much of Southeast Asia is growing. Already, more than 1,000 ethnic Chinese were killed last May during riots in Indonesia. One can only hope that Beijing will not feel the need to intervene in this matter.
Most dangerously, however, the continued unraveling of East Asia's economies could derail economic and political liberalization across the globe. East Asia's governments have already tried to quell unrest by sounding more populist and protectionist. Indonesia's President Suharto chose Mr. Habibie as his successor partly because the latter has economic nationalist leanings. Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad of Malaysia had until now practiced a clever form of duplicity, making fiery anti-Western speeches while adopting liberal policies -- usually through his deputy, Anwar Ibrahim. But Mr. Mahathir's talk is now turning into action: he has put an old friend in charge of the economy, slighting Mr. Ibrahim and his reformist agenda. The Prime Minister has also warned of a "guerrilla war" if foreigners try to come in and buy cheap Asian assets. Labor unions and opposition figures in South Korea, Thailand and Indonesia have begun demanding an end to the I.M.F.-forced liberalization.
Beyond East Asia, one can also see people drawing the wrong lessons. In India, Egypt and Mexico, intellectuals and politicians have begun point to East Asia's fate as the reason not to move toward free markets and free trade. Support for liberalization has always been weak in most of the third world. But when a country is growing at 8 percent a year, the opposition to reform is effectively silenced. When growing at 0.8 percent, as Malaysia will probably do this year, opponents are emboldened and their arguments gain currency. If the world appears to be divided once again between the Western nations, all rich, and the non-Western ones, all poor, these fires of resentment will only grow stronger.
What is to be done? The I.M.F.'s initial approach to this crisis was misguided in two vital areas -- its requirements for low government spending and large-scale domestic reform. It treated East Asian countries as if they had the usual developing country disease out-of-control budgets. In fact, most were running budget surpluses, had high domestic savings rates and had little inflation. In this context, an insistence on a tight fiscal policy was unnecessary and probably counterproductive.
On the other hand, the fund's insistence on tight monetary policy high interest rates is an understandable compromise between those who advocate even stronger methods of maintaining the value of currency (linking it inflexibly to the dollar) and those who want deflation. Given the huge devaluations that have already taken place across the region, some measures to restore confidence in East Asian currencies are not just appropriate, they are vital.
The requirements for domestic reform, especially of the financial sector, are of course based on impeccable economic logic. East Asia's economies do indeed practice a form of "crony capitalism" with under-regulated banks and much nepotism.
But as a political matter, was this the time to attempt a radical overhaul? After all, many countries have major inefficiencies in their systems. Were the I.M.F. to focus its gaze on, say, France and Germany (let alone another developing country like Brazil), it would surely find extravagant subsidies, cartels and other market-distorting mechanisms.
The I.M.F.'s reform requirements have only undermined the legitimacy and support of East Asia's governments at a time of acute crisis. If the situation does not improve, we may well see five or six major countries -- including South Korea, which is a member of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development -- default on their foreign debts and impose capital controls on their currency. Say goodbye to globalization.
To be fair, the crisis in East Asia is largely unprecedented. The I.M.F. has already begun to relax its constraints on spending, and Robert Rubin, the United States Treasury Secretary, has called repeatedly for a social safety net in the region. He has also properly identified Japan as the key to reversing the slide. Mexico recovered after its financial crisis of 1994 because of that great sucking sound to the north -- the United States economy buying Mexican goods. East Asia's economies can grow their way out of their current misery only if Japan similarly fuels their export expansion. With Tokyo's economy declining about 3 percent this year, this seems unlikely. But the Japanese can solve this problem by spending and investing some of the vast sums they have, both in public and private hands.
But more than any specific economic policy, the Clinton Administration must fashion an overall political and economic strategy for East Asia. The people of these countries need to be given the sense that economic and political liberalization has not caused their problems, that they are not being abandoned, and that the West -- and in particular the United States -- is ready to help. President Clinton and Mr. Rubin must push for a coordinated strategy of public rhetoric, loans and aid -- involving the major Western powers, the I.M.F. and the World Bank -- to give the people of East Asia a sense of hope. Even if default becomes inevitable, better that it be done in an orderly manner. A retreat is better than a rout.
The United States is associated around the world with the cause of globalization, a connection it should proudly accept. The opening up of the world economy in the last 40 years has led to enormous economic and political progress for hundreds of millions across the globe.
But free markets and free trade are not naturally occurring and self-sustaining. They rest on an edifice of politics. The last great flourishing of the world economy began in the late 19th century, with British power undergirding it. It collapsed in the 1930's, when the liberal capitalist states seemed to be foundering in depression while fascist and communist states were rapidly industrializing. What followed was the breakdown of the world economy, autarky, economic nationalism, increasing political tension and world war. With American leadership, we can make sure that Europe's past will not be East Asia's future.

HEADLINE: New Board Member's Educational Odyssey

BYLINE: By JACQUES STEINBERG 

 BODY:
TERRI THOMSON'S new constituents, the 1.1 million students who attend New York City public schools, may be interested to learn that she often spends her free moments as they do, cramming for exams. Not in algebra or social studies, mind you, but in courses like Protest Movements, Neighborhoods, and Urban Planning.
Besides being one of two new members of the New York City Board of Education, and a longtime vice president of community affairs at Citibank, Ms. Thomson, 49, is a college student six credits away from a bachelor's degree at Queens College. Her dual major is political science and urban studies, with a minor in sign language, and she hopes to graduate in February. 
 Her grade point average? 3.8.
"I blew it," she says, "I was 4.0 for the longest time."
In embarking on a four-year term as a caretaker of and advocate for the country's largest school system, Ms. Thomson possesses little firsthand knowledge of life within public schools. She attended parochial schools, including Bishop Riley High School in Queens and the Thorpe Secretarial School, a now-defunct Roman Catholic school in Manhattan, from which she graduated in 1966. Her two daughters followed a similar route, in what she calls "a personal decision" that was "not a reflection at all on our neighborhood schools" in Flushing.
But what does seem to qualify Ms. Thomson for the board, in addition to two decades as a backstage player inside the city's political theaters, is an empathy for those navigating the dead ends and extended detours of the educational process. She contends that her own educational odyssey -- interrupted by marriage, family and then work, but ultimately resumed at night and on weekends a decade ago -- gives her unique standing to inspire a system from which less than half of the students graduate in four years.
"I'm going slowly, taking my time, fitting it into my schedule," Ms. Thomson said of her college experience the other night, in a telephone call from the weekend home in the Adirondacks that she shares with her husband, Ed, an electrician.
"I don't look back," she added. "I love going to school. I think I will go to school the rest of my life."
Ms. Thomson says that the mind-set that will light her way through 110 Livingston Street, the board's labyrinthine headquarters in Brooklyn, has been influenced by many passages in her life. They include helping her daughters, 26 and 23, acquire the skills to graduate from Williams College and Boston College; stitching together a coalition of parents at the Electchester Co-op in Flushing in the early 1970's to rebuild a rundown playground; building on that experience to attend to constituent concerns in the 1980's as the district administrator for Representative Gary Ackerman, a Democrat from northern Queens, and being the public face of Citibank since the early 1990's in meetings with small-business owners and politicians within the five boroughs.
PERHAPS the element of her background that has most tantalized officials at City Hall, and most unnerved those within the inner circle of Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew, is that she is the daughter of a policeman, Albert Farrell, who retired in 1978 after 25 years. The first major decision that Ms. Thomson will probably have to make is to declare her stance on the Mayor's bid to give the police more responsibility for school safety.
After being stymied for three years by Dr. Crew and an unwavering four-member majority on the seven-member board, Mr. Giuliani is now presented with a wild card in Ms. Thomson. She replaces Carol A. Gresser, one of the most vocal opponents of expanding the police role, and Ms. Thomson has said she has yet to decide on a position. With no shortage of advocates seeking her vote, she says she still needs to spend more time studying the issue.
Asked if growing up in a police officer's home would predispose her, Ms. Thomson spoke cautiously.
"When there is a proposal on the table," she said, "I'll look at it and and see what questions I might have and make an informed decision based on the outreach that I've done."
But anyone who takes her vote for granted would do well to consider her position on publicly financed vouchers that would benefit the same parochial schools she and her children attended. She opposes them, saying that more investment, not less, is needed for public schools.
Ms. Thomson's evenhandedness and modesty are among the qualities that prompted Borough President Claire Shulman to tap her to succeed Ms. Gresser.
Mr. Ackerman, a political ally of Ms. Shulman's, said of Ms. Thomson: "I think she probably gets embarrassed when her name is in the paper. At least she used to."
"She is a workhorse," he added, "not a show horse."
The Rev. Floyd Flake, who resigned from Congress last year after 11 years representing Jamaica, Queens, said he appreciated Ms. Thomson's keen ear for people's concerns. He recalled Citibank's decision not long ago to replace the tellers at its Rochdale branch with bank machines. When Ms. Thomson learned that older people in the neighborhood were terrified of entrusting their life savings to such technology, she prevailed on the bank to install a customer service representative to guide them through the first six months.
"That kind of flexibility," Mr. Flake said, "will be very helpful to her as a member of the board, which can be a place where people dig deep into the cement and are sometimes intractable."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Prices Higher On Treasuries In a Light Day

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices made modest gains yesterday, bolstered by a strong dollar. But trading was light, with many investors waiting for new economic data before making any significant committments.
Japan's plan for tax cuts has disappointed currency traders with its lack of details, and the dollar rose yesterday against the yen and other leading currencies. Also helping the dollar has been concerns that China may devalue its currency. A strong dollar makes dollar-denominated investments like Treasury securities an attractive investment to foreign investors because of the potential gains from currency translation. 
 The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 9/32, to 107 15/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.60 percent, from 5.62 percent on Wednesday.
Treasury prices were held down by competing debt from new corporate and agency issues. Fannie Mae priced for sale $2 billion of 10-year notes yielding 37.5 basis points more than a Treasury security with a similar maturity. (A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.)
With rates now at historic lows, companies and municipalities are taking advantage to raise cash or refinance existing debt to reduce debt service payments. The added supply of debt to the market can often pressure yields to move higher until the glut is absorb by investors.
In the municipal market, the State of New York priced $563.2 million of general obligation refunding bonds yesterday through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. The bonds were initially priced to yield a maximum 5.23 percent for bonds maturing in 2021, with shorter maturities priced to yield from 4 percent in 2000 to 5.20 percent in 2018.
While trading was considered quiet, the talk was that today's report on June producer prices might break the market's inertia.
"Tomorrow's P.P.I. release is projected to show that goods inflation remained quite benign in June, aided in a large measure by depressed energy prices and the turmoil in Asia," said Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, referring to the Producer Price Index.
Mr. Fine expects next week's consumer price report to be subdued and nonthreatening. And that the G.M. strike may be clouding near-term consumption patterns.

HEADLINE: True Grit in the Gritty Inner City;
Some Dreams Come True, but Company Fights for Life

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER 

DATELINE: MILWAUKEE, July 3

 BODY:
When President George Bush dropped in on Steeltech Manufacturing Inc. here in 1992, he told reporters following him on the campaign trail that the newly minted, minority-owned metal-processing company was proof that "the American dream can still come true."
There is impressive evidence today that his faith was justified. Steeltech has moved into a cavernous new manufacturing plant in one of this city's poorest, toughest neighborhoods. Customers praise the quality of its welding and its painting equipment, which can electrically coat larger pieces of steel than any other independent plant in the country. Steeltech has grown to more than 200 employees, many of whom are thrilled to have left behind dead-end minimum-wage jobs or the welfare rolls. 
"This has given people around here hope," said Kim Jordan, 42, a single mother of three who has done everything from welding to helping out in research and development.
Trouble is, the privately held Steeltech is no dream come true for its investors or for customers who had to provide cash and other concessions to keep it afloat. Even though it has finally begun to generate some operating profits, Steeltech has not made payments on more than $30 million in Federal, state, local and private loans since 1996. Milwaukee taxpayers are shelling out $50,000 a month to bondholders to forestall foreclosure.
Still worse, two contracts that have accounted for more than 80 percent of Steeltech's revenue are about to end. Rumors of imminent bankruptcy were swirling until the company recently won a contract to work on the steel roof of Miller Park, the Milwaukee Brewers' new baseball stadium.
"It's been constant firefighting," said Charles Wallace, 52, the company's chairman and chief executive.
The lesson? So far, Steeltech is stark proof that the goal of returning skilled, industrial jobs to blighted inner cities remains a daunting one, even when the economy is booming and many companies are frantically scavenging the nation for skilled -- or simply trainable -- labor.
"You could never sustain an economy on this basis," conceded James Scherer, the administrator following Steeltech's struggles for Milwaukee's Economic Development Commission.
The city is not giving up, though. The shuttering of urban factories over the last two or three decades has been cited by sociologists like William Julius Wilson as the single largest factor in worsening the poverty, crime and drug use that grip many inner-city neighborhoods and strangle once-thriving retail districts. While no one expects these jobs to return on a broad scale, smaller manufacturing companies like Steeltech are seen as important adjuncts to rebuilding a more service-oriented urban economy that can profit from a central location and the labor available in inner cities.
Although Steeltech's wages are at the low end of the industrial scale here, they still offer a better prospect of upward mobility than most entry-level service jobs, such as those at the Walgreen's drugstore that recently opened across the street where clerks start at $6 an hour.
The debate about Steeltech's value might be clearer if it were simple to measure its costs and benefits, but that can't be done.
"It's been good for Milwaukee and it's met its social goals," maintained Paul Hollowell, executive vice president of the Oshkosh Truck Corporation, which ended up as both Steeltech's major customer and a source of working cash. Did Oshkosh benefit? "It's like W. C. Fields said about being tarred and feathered," Mr. Hollowell said, pointing out that Oshkosh wrote off $3.2 million in loans extended to Steeltech. "But for the honor, we'd probably rather not have done it."
Bill Dempsey, director of the Campaign for a Sustainable Milwaukee, a coalition of community and labor groups, argues that Oshkosh clearly benefited because Steeltech helped it maintain its standing as a leading truck supplier to the military. Other Milwaukee businesses made money selling Steeltech goods and services. "The jury is still out," he said, "on whether the Steeltech jobs justify the heavy public investment to create them."
Steeltech's story has unfolded in a era when the number of minority-owned businesses nationwide has been growing. The most recent United States census figures showed a 60 percent increase in such businesses, to 2.15 million, from 1987 to 1992. And Harriet Michel, executive director of the National Minority Supplier Development Council, a New York City-based nonprofit group dedicated to linking major corporations and government purchasing groups with minority-owned companies, says the growth is continuing. "But most of them are professional service companies," she said, "because the start-up costs are cheaper."
When it comes to setting up new businesses in the poorest urban areas, most of the action is in the commercial and service sectors, said Elisabeth Reynolds, vice president of the Initiative for a Competitive Inner City, a Boston-based group working to identify urban business opportunities. Where manufacturing does succeed, it tends to be small and closely integrated with existing activities. Auto company suppliers in Detroit and garment makers in New York are frequently cited examples.
"To create a business out of thin air," she said, "is more risky than building on something that's there."
Steeltech's singular journey began with a broad public-private partnership and a torrent of publicity. The prime mover was Fred Luber, chairman of the Super Steel Products Corporation, who saw a chance to help Oshkosh, one of his major customers, fulfill the Pentagon requirement to set aside a certain amount of business for minority subcontractors to qualify for a $1.4 billion contract to build cargo transport vehicles for the Army.
Steeltech's job, Mr. Luber figured, would be to paint and assemble a newly designed cargo platform to go with the trucks, known as the flat rack. Although the first order was for just 8,000 flatracks, the Army was expected to need 100,000 eventually.
The well-connected Mr. Luber won the backing of figures like John O. Norquist, Milwaukee's popular Mayor, and cajoled numerous public and private groups into going along because of the project's potential social benefits. He and his lawyer were able to recruit black and Hispanic investors to hold a majority of Steeltech's stock by arranging for the company to lend them the money to acquiretheir holdings.
But Steeltech was nearly strangled at birth by its Pentagon contract, which was based on a wildly optimistic guess about the company's overhead. The profit outlook did not begin to improve until 1995, when Steeltech landed a second flatrack contract and a contract to paint Dodge Ram truck frames for the nearby auto components subsidiary of the A. O. Smith Corporation (Smith sold the business last year to Tower Automotive Inc., based in Minneapolis).
Each step forward has been clouded with developments that have made the company a local business soap opera. Relations with Mr. Luber became strained over how costs and equipment were allocated during the first two years that Steeltech operated out of the Super Steel factory. Management turnover -- Mr. Wallace is the fourth chief executive -- and labor tensions became routine. The labor unrest gave the United Electrical Workers the opening it needed to organize the plant after a contentious struggle that hurt Steeltech's local reputation.
Steeltech also lost money in ill-fated efforts to diversify into making jail cells and modules for fast-food restaurants. Part of the problem was that the Oshkosh and Tower contracts occupied too much of its capacity for it to pursue other businesses that might have been more profitable.
Steeltech has also paid a price for pursuing its social mission.
Its founders envisioned stories like that of Shafi Roemel Brooks, who was 40 when he was hired and trained as a painter in 1995, a month after returning home to Milwaukee from five years in a Federal prison in Texas on drug charges.
"I sold drugs from the time I was 14, and if it hadn't been for Steeltech I would probably have gone back to the streets," said Mr. Brooks, who earns $11 an hour and is now married. He says Steeltech made it possible for him to acquire both his first home and a 1997 Chevy Blazer.
Often, though, the results have been disappointing. Absenteeism rates were astronomical in the early years, as workers unused to the discipline of factory life were given multiple chances to shape up. Background checks were perfunctory.
"Some people were attracted thinking they'd get cut slack because it was minority-owned," Ms. Jordan said. Union officials cite one case in which the company allowed an employee who was late 17 times during the 30-day probationary period to become a full-time employee.
Mr. Wallace has tightened standards for reviewing the 2,000 job applicants coming through Steeltech's doors annually. But he still faces high turnover. Many workers tire of the factory's rigors, and others leverage their training into higher-paying jobs at Tower and other local employers. Two-thirds of the hourly work force has been at Steeltech less than two years.
This year, skilled workers have been leaving out of fear about Steeltech's prospects. Steeltech lost the flatrack contract to a San Diego-based subsidiary of Korea's Hyundai, which will build its version of the cargo carrier with Mexican labor in Tijuana, and to Summa Technology Inc. of Huntsville, Ala., which is owned by E. C. Lee, an Asian-American. Summa, which won the part of the contract set aside for minority-owned businesses, plans to make its units with just 85 workers in a new automated factory in Coleman, Ala. Steeltech will make the last of its 16,000 flatracks in the next month.
Making matters worse, Tower is installing its own high-technology paint line. It has given Steeltech notice that it will quit sending Dodge truck frames by early next year. Tower said the Chrysler Corporation had required it to install the new paint line to be eligible to make frames for the new Dodge Ram scheduled for 2002. Tower figures that making the inevitable switch now could save $1.5 million that is currently eaten up trucking frames to Steeltech and repairing the nicks and dents that come with such transfers.
"We're protecting 700 jobs at our plant," said James Lozelle, who oversees Tower's Milwaukee operations.
Steeltech got a crucial lift, though, when it won a $2 million subcontract from Mitsubishi Heavy Industries America to build the roof of the new baseball park. Now, Mr. Wallace said, Steeltech has more than a year's breathing room and a good shot at further work on other contracts with Mitsubishi. Several other irons are in the fire as well, including a potential deal with Caterpillar.
A couple of more new contracts could seal the one thing Steeltech really needs: some kind of agreement from its many creditors to refinance or forgive more than $30 million in debt. Mr. Wallace, who owns the biggest chunk of the 60 percent stake held by minority investors, hopes to complete a package that forgives $3 million in debt and refinances the rest.
It cannot come too soon for Hubert Nelson, his head of marketing. "This can be a profitable $100 million company in five years, but the thing that comes up over and over again with potential clients is, 'Your financial condition scares me,' " said Mr. Nelson, whose marketing resume ranges from Exxon to Miller Brewing. "It's a tough nut to crack."

HEADLINE: The History Behind Trent Lott

 BODY:
Senator Trent Lott's recent condemnation of homosexuality and a variety of anti-gay initiatives in Southern communities point up an important trend in American politics, and a threatening one for advocates of inclusive democracy. Curiously, this more restrictive attitude toward social freedom is linked to a newly expansive exercise of religious freedom. Starting about 20 years ago, evangelical Christians began shedding their traditional aversion to political activism. In the South especially, they have flooded into the electoral process, settling mainly in the Republican Party. In doing it, they have charged and changed American politics as has no other force since the civil rights revolution. They have transformed the Republicans, bringing to the party a potent bloc vote, boundless energy and an unwillingness to compromise on certain domestic social issues.
Suddenly, a party that had been centered on economic issues and anti-Communism, and that first began to court the Southern vote in the days of segregation, found that its best new troops had concerns other than race: prayer in the schools, abortion and opposition to gay rights. Prayer and abortion got more attention in national campaigns, but the anti-gay theme was there from the beginning. In fact, the crusade by Anita Bryant, a devout Southern Baptist, against a gay rights ordinance in Miami in 1977 was an early rising of what came to be called the religious right. 
 The fundamentalists won that contest, reversing the ordinance by referendum, and the two movements -- evangelical Christians and gay rights -- have been in collision ever since. For the Rev. Jerry Falwell and Pat Robertson, who first brought evangelicals back to politics, and for James Dobson, their newest spokesman, Bible values are absolute. If homosexuals are condemned in scripture, as the fundamentalists say they are, then they must be condemned in society as well. The leaders of conservative religious organizations have been pressing the case with Republicans on Capitol Hill lately, and the effect has been plain to see.
Mr. Lott, the Senate majority leader, said last month that homosexuals are sinners. In Greenville, S.C., the pastor of the Choice Hills Baptist Church went him one better. They are "a stench in the nostrils of God," the Rev. Stan Craig declared. As Kevin Sack reported at length in The Times this week, that kind of sentiment has become the fashion among Republican politicians in several South Carolina towns. "The time has come to take a stand," a local school board chairman who was running for state superintendent of education proclaimed. He was talking about banning the Indigo Girls from singing at a high school because of complaints that they were lesbians. He got the Republican nomination. The new Republican mayor of Myrtle Beach won office by campaigning to stop the opening of the city's first gay bar. The bar opened anyway. But near Lancaster, S.C., a lesbian named Regan Wolf was twice beaten unconscious and tied spread-eagled on her porch. "Jesus weren't born for you, faggot," a spray-painted message said.
American history is replete with examples of the connection between the politics of bias and violence. Republican leaders ought to take stock of what is happening in their party leaders' press conferences and in its new areas of grass-roots primacy. The party of Lincoln, which freed the slaves so long ago, should not be sowing the seeds of a new hatred on Southern ground.

HEADLINE: G.E. Posts 13% Rise in 2d-Quarter Profits

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: FAIRFIELD, Conn., July 9

 BODY:
The General Electric Company said today that its second-quarter profit rose 13 percent, driven by record sales at the maker of everything from light bulbs to loans.
Net income rose to $2.45 billion, or 74 cents a diluted share, aided by higher profits from its NBC television network and its aircraft engine unit. G.E.'s revenue rose 14 percent, to $25.1 billion. 
 Under its chairman, John F. Welch Jr., G.E. has built its 12 biggest businesses into market leaders. Meanwhile, G.E. surpassed other old-line manufacturers by pushing into financial services and expanding its business of servicing products.
"The diversity of businesses is working for them," said Russell Leavitt, an analyst at Nationsbanc Montgomery Securities.
G.E.'s earnings were not lowered as much as those at other United States companies by the Asian economic crisis because it makes less than 4 percent of its profit from the region.
G.E., based in Fairfield, was expected to earn 74 cents a diluted share, the average estimate of analysts polled by the First Call Corporation, which tracks company earnings. The company earned $2.16 billion, or 65 cents a diluted share, in the second quarter of 1997 on revenue of $22 billion.
G.E.'s profits have climbed an average of 12 percent a year in the last five years. Investors responded by bidding up the company's shares. On Tuesday, G.E. became the first United States company to reach a market value of more than $300 billion.
G.E.'s profit was led by gains at GE Capital, the company's finance unit, as well as its aircraft engines, medical systems, and transportation units.
Profit at GE Capital rose 17 percent, to $933 million, as sales rose in specialty financing and insurance.

HEADLINE: Senators Back Sale of Wheat To Pakistanis

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 9

 BODY:
Bowing to pressure from farmers, the Senate today unanimously agreed to exempt food exports from sanctions that the United States imposed on India and Pakistan after the two countries conducted nuclear tests in May.
The Senate's vote, 98 to 0, lifts the largest and most painful economic penalty that Washington inflicted and leaves almost no meaningful sanctions in place to punish India and Pakistan for the tests, which drew international opprobrium. 
 Restrictions on military aid remain, but there was never much to begin with. The World Bank has resumed aid to India, with the Administration's support. And India and Pakistan are small markets for American non-farm goods at any rate.
Senators said they are still deeply troubled by the threat of a new arms race. But looking ahead to the November elections, they also have important farming constituents to consider: Foreign grain dealers eagerly lined up to take orders from Pakistan after American farmers were sidelined by the sanctions.
"Whether the Pakistanis buy U.S. wheat, Canadian wheat or some other country's wheat isn't going to make a difference on a dinner table in Islamabad, but it sure will in Topeka," said Senator Mitch McConnell, a Republican of Kentucky who helped write today's bill.
Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority leader, rushed the bipartisan bill to the floor today on short notice, bypassing the usual committee review.
There was reason to hurry. Pakistan plans to buy 350,000 metric tons of wheat next Wednesday. If the sanctions law is not changed by then, American wheat farmers could not bid on the sale, which agricultural experts valued at $37 million.
Wheat prices have plunged to a seven-year low because of excess supply, causing many farmers from the Dakotas to the Pacific Northwest to give up their land, and today a parade of farm-state Senators took to the floor to urge approval.
"Washington State wheat growers need this bill," said Senator Patty Murray, Democrat of Washington. Her state sends 37 percent of its wheat to Pakistan, shipments valued at about $500 million a year.
Senator Ron Wyden, an Oregon Democrat, voiced even more distress: "We in the Pacific Northwest are six days away from disaster."
House Republican leaders have promised to whisk the Senate bill through when the House returns from recess early next week. Mr. Clinton, who had called the Indian tests "a terrible mistake," indicated today that he supports the bill.
The deal nearly fell apart earlier today when Senator John Glenn, the Ohio Democrat who wrote the original sanctions legislation, balked at an early draft that gave President Clinton the authority to exempt other sectors in addition to agriculture.
Supporters of that provision, which would have been effective only through March 1999, said it would have given Mr. Clinton a diplomatic carrot to entice India and Pakistan to sign treaties to restrict their nuclear testing.
"It would have dumped out everything on sanctions, and given the President complete carte blanche without Congress being involved at all," said Mr. Glenn, who voted for the bill once the proposed waiver authority was dropped.
The Arms Export Control Act of 1994 punishes countries that test nuclear tests by cutting off trade credits, private bank loans, support for loans from international institutions and loan guarantees.
But in recent weeks the World Bank has resumed aid to India, with Washington voting in favor. Administration officials cited an exemption in the law for humanitarian aid, a category the White House apparently defines to include most of the bank's activities in India.
The new World Bank loans are aimed at projects to insure that more children complete primary school, to train health workers and to pay for immunization and nutrition services for pre-school children and pregnant and nursing women.
The sanctions that will remain after House action on today's bill include a longstanding provision that cut off all arms sales and military aid to Pakistan after Washington determined in 1990 that Pakistan had nuclear devices. Among other things, it halted the sale of 28 F-16 fighter jets, for which Pakistan had already paid $600 million.
Military sales to India are tiny.
The legislation today, the Farm Export Relief Bill, exempts from the sanctions Government-guaranteed credits to American farmers for food products and fertilizer being sold to India and Pakistan.
"Food should not be a weapon of foreign policy," said Senator Richard G. Lugar, a Republican from Indiana. "When sanctions are unduly rigid and automatic, they become a roadblock to diplomacy."
Indeed, Congress has been having second thoughts lately about the merit of sanctions in general, one of lawmakers' favorite foreign-policy cudgels. Senator McConnell leads an 18-member bipartisan group that is to review the effectiveness of scores of sanctions the United States has imposed over the years; their report is due in September.
Many free-trade advocates, like Senator Chuck Hagel, Republican of Nebraska, argue that unilateral sanctions inflict no pain on their targets, who buy their wares elsewhere, and hurt American businesses in an increasingly global marketplace.
Senator Fred Thompson, a Republican from Tennessee, summed up the reservations of many lawmakers, saying, "We need to keep in mind that while we're bashing sanctions, we've not made a distinction between countries who pose a threat to us and those who do not."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Take Away the 'Acting' Label: Selig Is Baseball's Commissioner

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, July 9

 BODY:
On Bud Selig's 2,130th day as acting commissioner, Major League Baseball club owners looked at him and liked what they saw. So today they elected him quickly and unanimously as the sport's ninth commissioner.
Although Selig will shed the "acting" from his unofficial title Aug. 1, he is not expected to alter the way in which he has performed his role since Sept. 9, 1992, two days after the last commissioner, Fay Vincent, resigned under pressure. Indeed, the owners don't want him to change. 
 "Bud knows how to get things done," said Drayton McLane of Houston, who, with Carl Pohlad of Minnesota, led the effort that persuaded Selig to accept the job. "He is the most effective political leader I have ever met. Every owner trusts him."
Jerry Reinsdorf of the Chicago White Sox had been portrayed by other owners and officials as opposing the idea of an owner being commissioner, but he voted for Selig and said afterward: "I don't think there's anybody in America who could do the job that he can do. The only alternative was bringing in an outsider. That just didn't make any sense at all."
Selig, who will turn 64 on July 30, was elected as quickly as it took the owners to take a roll-call vote, having previously voted to dispense with the requirement that election be done by written ballot. He was elected for a five-year term with his salary to be set by the executive council.
Selig currently earns $2.5 million as council chairman and is expected to begin his full-time job with a salary of at least $3 million a year. As the man in charge for the past 70 months (his tenure matching Lou Gehrig's one-time record for consecutive games played), Selig has already served longer than four of the previous eight commissioners: Peter V. Ueberroth (1,643 days), Gen. William Eckert (1,129), Vincent (1,091) and A. Bartlett Giamatti (154).
As the first team owner to become commissioner, Selig will be replaced as the trustee of his approximately one-third share of the Milwaukee Brewers, before he officially takes office. The club's board of directors is expected to elect Wendy Selig-Prieb, his daughter and current vice president, as president.
Selig said he will move out of his office at County Stadium and open a new office in downtown Milwaukee, dividing his time between there and the commissioner's office on Park Avenue in New York.
Saying he was sensitive to possible conflicts arising from his position as an owner, Selig told a news conference that after 28 years as club president, "It's time for me to go now."
"If I really believed in my heart and mind that I couldn't do this, if I'm not capable of making that very emotional and very sensitive shift, then I should have had the decency to say I just can't do that," he added. "But I know that I can."
Selig's election surprised absolutely no one, not on management's side, not on the players' side.
"For a long time it has been clear that eventually the owners would formally name Bud to be the commissioner," said Donald Fehr, the union chief, whose relationship with Selig has improved since it reached its nadir during the labor dispute in 1994-95.
Even Sue Selig, the new commissioner's wife, said today that she "knew in my heart" probably since the labor dispute was resolved that he would accept the job. Her husband, however, had steadfastly said he did not want the job, although never ruling out that he would take it.
A search committee, meanwhile, considered hundreds of candidates, and Jerry McMorris of Colorado, the chairman, had whittled the list to four names, including Leonard Coleman, the National League president.
But an increasing number of owners told Selig he was the only man for the job. "We've been working on him as long as I can remember," Pohlad said. McLane added, "Bud has stiff-armed us for over a year."
Selig said today that he was driving in his car one day and said to himself, "You're going to do this." He did not say when he had that conversation, but another owner said Selig disclosed his decision in late May or early June.
A key factor in his decision, Selig said, was the presence of Paul Beeston as baseball's chief operating officer for the past year.
"Paul will do much more of the day-to-day, operational things," he said. "I'll do more global things."
Included in the global area is the problem of resolving the economic disparity between large- and small-revenue clubs. That issue and lasting labor peace are the two most important matters facing Selig.
"We need to reduce the acrimony from this equation once and for all," said Selig, who was in charge of the owners' labor committee in the sport's last three work stoppages. "We've never been able to do that. We've had eight work stoppages. We have to make sure that the next generation doesn't have to endure any work stoppages."
The owners have responded positively to Selig's consensus-building style and seem to feel he will be a "safe" commissioner because he never acts in a precipitous or controversial manner.
Jerry Colangelo, managing partner of the Arizona Diamondbacks and the National Basketball Association Phoenix Suns, compared Selig favorably with David Stern, who has been considered the most successful commissioner of a professional league.
"They're two different individuals with different personalities and different methodologies," Colangelo said. "Each in his own way has been very effective."
During Selig's tenure as acting commissioner, the owners have adopted interleague play, three-division leagues and wild-card teams for the playoffs, greatly increased their revenue sharing and approved a limited form of realignment, shifting Selig's Brewers into the N.L.
