HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Japanese Banks Cutting Back on U.S. Presence

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, July 9

 BODY:
Overcome by bad loans in their home country, Japanese banks and other financial institutions are in a broad retreat from the United States market, closing offices and cutting back on their lending to American companies.
The situation represents a sharp reversal from the late 1980's and the early 1990's, when Japanese banks were expanding rapidly in California and elsewhere in the United States, gaining market share by aggressive lending at low rates and even raising some concern that the Japanese would dominate banking as they did consumer electronics. 
 Now, Japanese banks are wary about making new loans or renewing old ones. "Basically they're gone, on the sidelines," said an executive at an American bank in charge of making syndicated loans to corporations who spoke on the condition of anonymity.
Japanese banks accounted for less than 10 percent of the syndicated loans provided to American companies with investment-grade credit ratings in the first quarter of 1998, down from 26 percent in the comparable quarter a year earlier, according to the Loan Pricing Corporation, a market research firm in New York.
Japanese banks are pulling out of the United States altogether or consolidating operations in New York. The number of Japanese banks with offices in New York has fallen to 55 from 70 in the last few years, according to a compilation made in February by Yomiuri Shimbun, a Japanese newspaper. The number with offices in Los Angeles has dropped to 17 from 25, and to 16 from 21 in Chicago.
Some Japanese banks are also selling part of their American operations. Fuji Bank raised about $1 billion by selling a minority stake in Heller Financial Inc., a finance company in Chicago, in an initial public offering at the end of April. In March, Sumitomo Bank sold Sumitomo Bank of California to Zions Bancorp of Utah for $546 million. It also sold off pieces and shut down the rest of its operation that made loans to small and medium-sized businesses.
The Japanese banking crisis is also accelerating the sale of Japanese-owned hotels, office buildings and golf courses in the United States, many of which were bought at exorbitant prices in the late 1980's. Nikko Securities, for instance, just agreed to sell the Watergate Hotel in Washington to the Blackstone Group for $39 million.
"It's like a fire sale," said Shuhei Okuda, president of Mitsui Fudosan U.S.A., the American arm of a Japanese real estate company. "They have to sell, especially when the bank presses the borrowers who own the property to sell and repay the money."
The sharp retreat from lending by Japanese banks has contributed to a modest increase in interest rates paid by American corporate borrowers, bankers and analysts said. Some big financings have taken longer to arrange. Starwood Hotels and Resorts Trust took longer than expected to arrange more than $7 billion in loans to finance its acquisition of the ITT Corporation in part because Japanese banks, which in the past would have provided a big chunk of that money, declined to participate. The delay in financing even prompted speculation that the takeover might fall through.
But by and large, the retreat from the American market by the Japanese banks has had little effect on the American economy because there are many other sources of credit for companies. This contrasts sharply with the situation in Japan and in other parts of Asia, where cutbacks in lending by Japanese banks have contributed to a credit crunch that has driven some companies into bankruptcy and worsened economic downturns.
In the United States, the pullback from lending by Japanese banks has been counterbalanced by financial deregulation in Japan, which has made it easier for Japanese to invest overseas. With the dollar strong and interest rates higher in America than in Japan, Japanese money has moved into American stocks, bonds and banks, helping keep interest rates low and stocks high.
One big fear has not materialized: that the crisis would force Japanese Government and financial institutions to sell off huge portions of their United States Treasury bonds, causing American interest rates to rise and slowing the economy. A hint of such a sale by Japanese Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto caused the United States stock markets to plunge one day last year. But Treasury bonds are still attractive to Japanese and other foreign investors.
The most important effect of the Japanese banking crisis on the United States is likely to come not from cutbacks by Japanese banks in the United States but more indirectly. The banking crisis is plunging Japan into recession, which hurts American exports and also is making it difficult for the rest of ailing Asia to recover. United States officials have said they fear a drastic downturn in Japan could set off a worldwide recession.
Thus far, the most obvious effect in the United States is less lending by Japanese banks. Beset by at least $600 billion in problem loans tied to Japanese real estate, Japanese banks are struggling to maintain capital levels equal to 8 percent of assets, a requirement for international banks. With their capital eroding from loan losses and the weak Japanese stock market, the banks are having to reduce assets, which generally means loans.
"Their capital base is so eroded they have to reduce assets any way they can," said Richard Koo, chief economist for Nomura Research Institute in Tokyo.
In the United States, assets held by Japanese-owned bank branches dropped to $347 billion at the end of 1997 from $404 billion at the end of 1994, according to the Federal Reserve.
Without a big base of dollar-denominated deposits, Japanese banks and other finance companies generally borrow from other banks to obtain the money they then lend out in the United States. But because of fears about the health of the Japanese banking system, Japanese banks have had to pay higher rates for this borrowed money than American or European banks do. The banks can no longer profitably pursue their old strategy of lending at low interest rates to gain market share.
"We're priced out of the market for U.S. companies," said Edward W. Bjelke, executive vice president of Sanwa Bank in New York. The bank's outstanding loans in the United States have fallen to about $40 billion from $72 billion a few years ago, he said. This week, Sanwa said it would liquidate the Sanwa Securities (USA) Company, which has been a dealer of United States Treasury securities, and refocus its investment banking activities on the more profitable derivatives business.
The Mitsui Leasing Capital Corporation, a leasing and finance company in New York that is part of the Mitsui Group, recently laid off four of its six American professionals and is sending four Japanese staff members back home as it reduces its loans and leases and sells real estate in Hawaii and New York.
"We haven't been booking new business," said Jeff Fishman, a vice president who was laid off nine days ago. "We're in a holding pattern right now." Masato Utsumi, the president, said Mitsui Leasing was shifting to higher-risk loans and leasings with potentially better returns because its borrowing costs are now higher.
Two other Japanese leasing companies, Ryoshin Leasing, which is part of the Mitsubishi Group, and Crown Leasing, owned by the troubled Nippon Credit Bank, have shut their American offices entirely.
The Japanese banks pulling out of the American market so far have been mainly smaller, regional banks. The giant nationwide commercial banks are retrenching as well, though they generally are not leaving the United States entirely. Dai-ichi Kangyo Bank recently closed its San Francisco office. Sanwa Bank is shutting offices in Boston, Cleveland and Atlanta.
The head of the Los Angeles office of a big Japanese bank said that with fewer loans being made, decision-making was being concentrated in New York. "In the past, I enjoyed the freedom to develop the business on my own in the 14 Western states," he said.
The beachhead of Japanese banking in the United States has been California, where the Japanese opened retail banking branch networks, not just corporate banking offices like those in New York. By the late 1980's, Japanese banks owned 4 of the 10 largest banks in the state.
But the Japanese banks by and large have performed more poorly than competitors, and fears of Japanese dominance have subsided. The merger of two of the Japanese-owned California banks and the sale of Sumitomo Bank of California leave only two big Japanese-owned banks in the state, both of which are now the focus of speculation that they might be sold.
One is the Unionbancal Corporation, which has about $30 billion in assets and is the third-largest commercial bank in the state, behind BankAmerica and Wells Fargo. With both of those big banks having recently agreed to mergers, Union, which is controlled by Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi, has become the biggest potential takeover candidate for an out-of-state bank looking to expand in California. The other bank is Sanwa Bank California, the state's fourth-largest commercial bank, with assets of $8 billion.
Both banks deny they are for sale and both have been performing better than Sumitomo. Tamio Takakura, president of Sanwa Bank California, said that with the deregulation of financial markets in Japan, the expertise his unit had from operating in the ferociously competitive United States market was more valuable than ever to the parent. The California unit, for instance, is helping to manage mutual funds offered to Japanese consumers.
"We are increasingly becoming a strategic unit for them," said Mr. Takakura, whose 50th-floor office atop one of the fanciest skyscrapers in Los Angeles symbolizes the ambitions Japanese banks once had in the United States. "They're expecting a lot from us, not just earnings."

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Friday about retrenchment by Japanese banks in the United States referred incorrectly to the San Francisco office of Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank. The office remains open. The bank has consolidated back-office operations of the San Francisco office with those in Los Angeles.

SECTION: Section D; Page 3; Column 5; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: Producer Prices Fell in June, Led by Decline in Energy Costs

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 10

 BODY:
Producer prices fell in June for the first time in three months as energy costs retreated, the latest evidence that inflation is not threatening the economy.
The Labor Department said today that producer prices dropped one-tenth of a percent last month. The core rate, which excludes food and energy costs, rose two-tenths of a percent. Absent a 3.2 percent increase in prescription drug costs, the core rate would have risen one-tenth of a percent, a Government spokesman said. 
 In May, producer prices over all and the core rate both increased two-tenths of a percent.
"Inflation is going to stay low as long as Asia remains in a recession," said Suzanne Rizzo, an economist at Maria Fiorini Ramirez Inc., a New York consulting firm. "That creates a huge supply of cheap goods for America consumers and producers, keeping prices down."
That also suggests that Federal Reserve policy makers will hold interest rates steady this year. A Fed governor, Roger Ferguson, hinted as much on Thursday.
"Continued strong economic growth with low inflation is not outside the realm of possibility," he said in a speech at the Atlanta Fed, "and by adopting a cautious policy posture, we may learn more clearly if that possibility is likely or remote."
Asia's economic crisis is contributing to the tame inflation outlook by depressing the value of Pacific Rim currencies against the dollar, sending import prices lower. The crisis has caused the prices of oil, food and other commodities to decline, helping to hold down interest rates in this country.
The June decline represents the first time in three months that producer prices have not risen. Before April, prices had fallen for five consecutive months.
In the year's first half, prices declined at an annual rate of 1.5 percent, compared with a decline of 2.4 percent during the first six months of 1997. Also during the first six months, the core rate rose at a 1.4 percent annual rate, compared with a decline of one-tenth of a percent for the first six months of last year.
By industry, wholesale energy prices fell 1.7 percent during June as the price of petroleum declined 12.3 percent. Crude oil prices have fallen from more than $18 a barrel at the start of the year to as low as $13 in mid-June.
Producer food prices increased one-tenth of a percent in June, and auto prices three-tenths of a percent.
Tobacco prices increased one-tenth of a percent in June. A 3.4 percent tobacco price increase in April accounted for half of that month's increase in producer prices.
Prescription drug prices rose 3.2 percent last month on the heels of May's record 10.7 percent increase.

HEADLINE: Hong Kong Journal;
Latest Letdown: Airport's Nosedive

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, July 10

 BODY:
It could not have had a more auspicious beginning, with inaugural flights by President Jiang Zemin of China and President Clinton, both of whom said they were duly impressed. But then, world leaders don't have to line up at check-in counters, claim their bags or sprint to far-flung gates.
For everybody else who traveled through Hong Kong's lavish new airport this week, the experience was less impressive than bewildering. Planes were delayed, gates were mixed up, baggage was lost, toilets backed up, flight information boards went dark and crates of seafood rotted on the tarmac. 
 To say that Hong Kong International Airport has had a turbulent takeoff does not capture the bizarre string of mishaps that have afflicted this $20 billion project since it opened on Monday. Nor does it evoke the outrage and embarrassment that people here feel about what was supposed to be the pride of Hong Kong -- and has instead become a colossal public-relations nightmare.
"It was complete chaos," said Peter D. Cleary, an American lawyer who has lived in Hong Kong for 14 years and takes pride in its reputation for brisk efficiency. On Monday Mr. Cleary landed at the airport at 10 P.M., was stuck on his plane for nearly two hours while the pilot tried to find a gate, and finally collected his bags at 4:30 A.M., after wandering the terminal for hours.
"I thought it was incredibly shoddy, and I'm not a grouch by nature," Mr. Cleary said. "To call this teething problems is farcical."
Today, under intense public pressure, Hong Kong's chief executive, Tung Chee-hwa, said he would appoint an independent panel to investigate the problems and determine who was responsible. In the meantime, Hong Kong's top civil servant, Anson Chan, pleaded with the public not to be too harsh on the airport managers, as they labored to fix the problems.
But the managers had the extreme misfortune of stumbling the week after Hong Kong's first democratically elected legislature since the handover took office. Grabbing a ripe opportunity for political theater, the lawmakers on Thursday hauled in the chief executive of the Airport Authority, Hank Townsend, for a 90-minute inquisition, during which he was repeatedly urged to resign.
"This was meant to be a first-class project, but it has turned into a ninth-class airport and a disgrace," said Lau Kong-wah, a member of Hong Kong's main pro-Beijing party.
"Our airport has become the laughingstock of the world," Mr. Lau said, shooting a baleful glance at Mr. Townsend, a 65-year-old American executive who came from the Bechtel Corporation.
Mr. Townsend did not return telephone calls, but a spokesman for the airport, Clinton Leeks, apologized for the foul-ups. He added that the problems in the passenger terminal were abating.
The trouble is, people here are not in a generous mood. Hong Kong's economy is sliding into its worst recession since World War II, with soaring unemployment, a swooning stock market and a crashing property market. Aside from a brief burst of enthusiasm during the visits of Mr. Jiang and Mr. Clinton, Hong Kong has had a listless year since it reverted to China last July.
The government clearly hoped the new airport would be a tonic for the city and a symbol of its brighter future. Certainly, the project has an only-in-Hong-Kong feeling to it: Engineers chopped the tops off two small islands, filled in the water between them, and put a massive airport on top. They also built a web of bridges, tunnels, and highways to transport people 21 miles into town.
The government even turned the transition from the old airport to the new one into a sideshow -- with a vast overnight move of equipment through Kowloon that officials delighted in comparing to D-Day.
"The government built up public expectations so much before the event that people were expecting perfection," said Ian K. Perkin, the chief economist at the Hong Kong General Chamber of Commerce.
There was also a whiff of hubris. Malaysia opened a new airport two weeks ago in Kuala Lumpur -- with state-of-the-art technology similar to that in Hong Kong -- and suffered major problems. Yet Hong Kong plowed ahead with its plan to open its airport immediately after the first anniversary of the handover.
Mr. Perkin said the airport fiasco will hurt more than Hong Kong's image. The airport's largest cargo handler said Thursday that it was imposing an eight-day embargo on all imports and exports, except food, medical supplies and newspapers. Mr. Perkin estimated that the embargo would cost Hong Kong nearly $800 million in lost exports.
At a time when people here believe Hong Kong must fight to retain its status as a special city within China, they say it can ill afford such a loss. The prospect of companies bypassing Hong Kong because it does not have convenient transportation facilities is particularly galling to business executives here.
"People feel it is shameful for Hong Kong to have spent so much money and so many years on that project," said Peter Lam, the co-host of "Teacup in the Storm," a popular radio call-in program in Hong Kong. Mr. Lam said he was deluged by calls from listeners eager to fix blame for the troubles. "Callers feel that the Airport Authority has been arrogant," he said.
For all the hand-wringing in Hong Kong, outsiders have been more understanding about the airport's woes. Neil Sogo, a 37-year-old Japanese businessman who arrived here on Wednesday on a flight from Tokyo, said he waited more than an hour for his bags, which he found only after reading a handwritten sign. Still, he said, "I'll give it six months, and come back and try it again later."
Besides, Mr. Sogo added, the line at Immigration was short. "Nobody is coming to Hong Kong," he said with an apologetic smile.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Swamped by Asia's Wake;
Nations That Export Commodities Feel Shock Waves

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Brace yourself. It's time for the Asian aftershocks.
When East Asia was hit by its economic earthquake a year ago, the shock waves quickly reverberated around the globe through the world's hair-trigger stock and currency markets. 
 But the more powerful impact is working through a slower-moving and less visible force: the markets for basic commodities like oil, metals and timber. And that helps explain why the ripples from the Asian financial collapse are continuing to hit hard at countries as far-flung as Canada, Chile, New Zealand and Mexico, yet the effect has remained unexpectedly benign in the United States and Europe.
For nations that depend heavily on selling raw materials and basic goods globally to generate growth and to support their government budgets, the pain has been sharp, contributing to job cutbacks, lower currency values, shortfalls in government revenues and ballooning trade deficits.
Over all, commodity prices are down almost 10 percent since February.
"There is no question that the weakness in certain commodities is reverberating in markets around the world," said Desmond Lachman, managing director of emerging markets economic research at Salomon Smith Barney.
Drops in the prices for copper have hit Zambia and Chile, while New Zealand has felt the impact of lower timber prices. Australia is suffering from a decline in wool prices; Canada bears the pain of lower coal and timber prices.
But the United States and Europe are in significantly different positions than most other countries. Even though exports from Europe and America to Asia have dropped sharply and the United States also sells a lot of its own commodities abroad, their economies are far less dependent on them. In addition, generally affluent consumers in the world's two biggest economic entities have received a big boost -- similar to the effects of a substantial tax cut -- because of the decline in commodity prices. This has largely cushioned the Asian fallout so far here and in much of Europe.
Consider the impact of lower oil prices, which have fallen from a high of $22 a barrel in the last year to a low of $11.56 a barrel last month. While not all of this is a result of the crisis in Asia, a major portion is because the Asian economic engine has stopped racing ahead and has gone into reverse.
That has translated into about $14 billion in lost income this year to major oil producers like Russia, Mexico, Venezuela and the Middle East and a nearly equivalent bonus for energy consumers. For the United States, which produced 6.4 million barrels a day in April but also imported 10.4 million barrels daily, the positive gain for consumers has far outweighed the negative impact on oil drillers.
Allen Sinai, chief global economist at Primark Decision Economics, is forecasting that lost growth from American exports and the substitution of cheaper Asian imports for products made here could cut as much a one full percentage point off the increase in the gross domestic product this year.
But, at the same time, he estimates that the overall decline in oil prices, by putting more money into the pockets of American consumers, will add back much, though probably not all, of the growth lost through worsening foreign trade.
And this is not the only stimulus from Asia. The flight of foreign investors from Asia's problems and into the haven of Treasury bonds has bolstered the dollar and pushed American long-term interest rates to 30-year lows. The near absence of inflation has been helped by lower commodity prices and cheaper import prices. All that has allowed growth to perk along without the inflationary pressures that would have normally forced the Federal Reserve to put on the brakes.
Both low rates and low inflation have helped keep the stock market rally alive, adding to the "wealth effect" from the market rally that the Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, among others, believes has kept the economy strong by stimulating spending.
For the United States, Mr. Sinai said, "It is possible that the positive byproducts could be more than enough to offset the negatives."
But for major commodity producing nations, the cushion has been less comforting.
In Canada, where commodities make up about 40 percent of exports, the Canadian dollar has been bouncing off record lows, largely because of the weakness of commodity prices. While the economy is still forecast to grow around 3 percent this year, Ottawa has abandoned its policy of raising interest rates to support the Canadian dollar. That has helped offset some of the Asian impact, according to Ram Bhagavatula, the chief financial economist at Citibank.
Analysts are forecasting that New Zealand's commodity-sensitive economy could tip into a short recession because of the falloff in the sales of lumber, fish, fruits, vegetables and the like. And if Japan -- one of the principal buyers of New Zealand products -- remains mired in recession, prospects could worsen.
In Australia, the Aussie dollar plunged to a 12-year low in June as new forecasts showed that total commodity exports should fall by 1 percent over the next year, after rising more than 7 percent the previous year. Like Canada, Australia may have enough domestic demand to keep it out of a recession. But some economists are scaling back their growth forecasts.
The continued low level of commodity prices means that many countries -- along with their financial markets -- will probably remain vulnerable to further shocks for some time. Even in Canada and Australia, where no recession is in sight, the weakened currencies will mean growing trade deficits and inflationary pressure as import costs rise.
Money in stock markets around the world can move quickly, often in anticipation of fundamental economic changes expected in the future. But a meaningful rebound in commodity prices will probably wait until the economies of Asia actually turn around and begin to consume more oil, copper, coal, fish and vegetables.
In a recent study, two World Bank economists, Guillermo Perry and Daniel Lederman, discussed the fallout from declining commodity prices, which they called real effects, and the fallout from declines in equity and currency markets, which they called financial effects.
Looking at the impact of Asia's downturn on Latin America, they found that the weakness caused by the real effects from lower commodity prices "may produce an increase in the financial vulnerability of countries."
Sure, there are other factors that explain some of the drop in commodity prices: El Nino and a warm winter contributed to the softness in oil demand, for instance.
But the key factor remains Asia. The International Monetary Fund, in its recent World Economic Outlook, concluded that the drop in primary commodity prices as a group was "to a large degree" a result of the Asian downturn.
Asia has had this impact, the report said, because the region had stopped increasing its consumption of oil, copper, rubber, zinc, nickel, wool and timber. For example, South Korea, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines and Thailand, where the Asian crisis has hit hard, accounted for about a quarter of the growth of demand for copper between 1992 and 1996. With that demand now shrinking, copper prices have dropped almost 35 percent in the last year.
The copper fallout has been felt in Zambia, where the metal accounts for more than 80 percent of export earnings, and in Chile, where copper accounts for 42 percent of export earnings. A major share of Chile's exports go to Asia and the Government estimates that it has lost as much as $500 million in forgone Asian sales.
Last month Chile's Government announced $200 million in new budget cuts that bring the total for the year to $685 million. Interest rates have risen and the peso has fallen to record lows, forcing the central bank to drop policies that limited foreign investment and to use its dollar reserves to defend the peso.
In New Zealand, timber exports, which are about 10 percent of the country's total, collapsed with the weakness in the housing market in Japan, said Mark Benseman, an economist for Merrill Lynch in Auckland. He estimates that about 34 percent of the country's exports -- those going to Australia and Asia -- have been affected by the slump.
In Canada, the Japanese recession has had a stark impact. According to the most recent trade statistics, exports to Japan, measured in Canadian dollars, have fallen 43 percent since April 1997. The decline has been spread over most commodity groups, led by softwood lumber. In the first quarter, exports of coal and related products to Japan fell 84 percent. There also have been significant declines in commodity exports to South Korea and Taiwan.
Over all, the value of agricultural and fishing exports are down 8.5 percent since April 1997 while energy exports are off 17.5 percent and forestry products are down 2.7 percent.
But the biggest impact of all has occurred in the oil markets. Mike Rothman, Merrill Lynch's senior energy analyst, estimates that consumption of oil this year has been cut by as much 300,000 barrels a day in developing Asia and even more by the recession in Japan.
There are 25 countries that count on petroleum revenue for 20 percent or more of their foreign exchange earnings, according to the International Monetary Fund. There are also five oil exporters that count on oil revenues for 40 percent or more of their government budgets.
In Mexico, oil represents only 12 percent of total exports, but it supports 40 percent of Government spending, according to Merrill Lynch. In Venezuela, oil is a double whammy, accounting for 77 percent of exports and 57 percent of Government spending.
The value of the Mexican peso has fallen 10 percent this year. And even though the economy is growing briskly, the Government has just approved a third package of spending cuts, slicing $3.7 billion in all.
In Russia, which is a major exporter of commodities from oil to precious metals, the oil price drop hit in two ways. First, oil accounts for more than 20 percent of export earnings, but Russia has had to cut production by 350,000 barrels a day because the cost to extract and transport the oil is now more than the market price.
In addition, oil prices have foiled, so far, the sale of Rosneft, the last large state-owned oil company, undermining the Government's effort to raise needed cash.
Oil prices have shot up recently on the hope for significant cuts in production. But the two leading commodity indexes, the Commodity Research Bureau/Bridge index of 17 commodities and the Goldman Sachs index of 22 commodities, are only slightly above their recent lows.
And Japan, the key to the revival of the rest of Asia, has yet to prove it can get its economy or its currency back on track. So a commodity upturn is still more of a hope than a reality for the countries that sell them. "The problem we face," said David Bassanese, senior economist at Bankers Trust in Sydney, Australia, "is that the export recovery still hasn't arrived."

HEADLINE: The House and the I.M.F.

 BODY:
Playing politics with the International Monetary Fund may seem good sport to House Republicans, but their games now imperil international financial stability and the future growth of the American economy. When the House returns to work next week, it must approve America's long-delayed $18 billion contribution to the I.M.F.
The fund is the world economy's front-line defense against the financial problems that threaten to spread from Asia's developing countries to Japan, Latin America and now Russia, where President Boris Yeltsin yesterday appealed to Western leaders for swift international assistance. America's own economy risks serious damage if the I.M.F.'s ability to respond to this spreading turbulence is impaired. 
 The Senate has already approved the I.M.F. spending request in full. But in the House it has been blocked by the philosophical misgivings of some Republicans about financial bailouts and the insistence of others on attaching anti-abortion language to any I.M.F. appropriation. Last month, Speaker Newt Gingrich suggested that he would try to get some I.M.F. money through the House this summer. One idea under discussion involves slicing off a $3.5 billion piece of the Administration's request for quick approval while continuing to hold the rest hostage to Republican political demands. That is not much help, since the remaining $14.5 billion is needed for immediate lending.
Approval of that $14.5 billion from the United States would quickly bring in a further $65 billion from other countries under the I.M.F.'s standard payment arrangements. Passing up the chance to have other nations contribute that much money to future bailouts would be irresponsible. The monetary fund's reserves are now perilously low when measured against current lending commitments and will decline even further without timely House action. Mr. Gingrich and the Republican House leadership must end the maneuvering and round up the votes to pass the Administration's full request.

HEADLINE: Fallen Taboo: Frank Talk On Viagra Is About Cost

BYLINE: By MICHAEL M. WEINSTEIN 

 BODY:
Health plans cite lots of reasons for denying coverage of specific drugs and procedures. The procedure can be labeled cosmetic (breast reconstruction) or medically unnecessary (in-vitro fertilization). The remedy might be called experimental (bone marrow transplants) or dangerous (some diet pills). But there is one reason that health plans never cite: cost.
Indeed, Dr. David Eddy, an expert on medical technology who advises many medical organizations including Kaiser Permanente, has coined the term "cost taboo" to express the prevailing notion that costs should not affect treatment decisions. 
 But earlier this month, Kaiser Permanente, the California-based health plan that covers more than nine million people across the country, shattered the cost taboo when it refused to cover Viagra, the wildly popular new pill from Pfizer Inc. that treats male impotence. In doing so, it cited the cost -- and no other factor.
Kaiser's candor was uncharacteristic for health plans, which often restrict or exclude treatments because of costs without saying so.
Kaiser conceded that impotence was a medical condition. It conceded that Viagra was an appropriate medical treatment. Ordinarily, such concessions settle the matter. Cigna, Oxford and several other plans have decided to cover the taking of at least four of the $10 pills a month.
But Kaiser said no. It estimated that this one drug would drive up its pharmaceutical bills by about 10 percent, or about $100 million a year -- far more than it spends on all antiviral drugs, including the expensive drugs used to treat H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS.
The problem for Kaiser is that it has no easy way to distinguish the few males whose impotence is caused by physical malady and the large number of males that it expects will demand Viagra to recapture the sexual frequency of their youth or achieve a frequency they deem desirable.
After a review process involving 40 health care experts inside and outside the organization, Kaiser decided that it would not raise premiums for all its members to pay for treatment of a nonlethal, noncrippling condition that almost all of its members could afford to treat on their own. Instead it will offer corporate purchasers of its health policies an option to cover Viagra at a premium that will compensate for the extra costs. That way other enrollees are spared a financial hit.
Kaiser's announcement was blunt and carefully considered. But was it proper?
Some health care experts think not. Jamie Court, director of Consumers for Quality Care, a watchdog group in Southern California, condemned Kaiser's decision by pointing out that Kaiser was cutting treatment for impotence even as it was increasing its advertising and marketing budgets. The big threat, other critics say, is that American health care will move to a two-tier system, one for those who can afford what they want and a lesser system for everyone else. California officials are investigating whether a state law that requires physicians to make decisions without regard to costs applies to this case.
But other policy experts applaud Kaiser's decision. Dr. Arnold S. Relman, former editor in chief of The New England Journal of Medicine, and Prof. Alain Enthoven of Stanford University, a leading advocate of managed health care markets, welcome Kaiser's assault on the cost taboo because, they say, in a world of limited resources, the act of showering money on hugely expensive treatments of secondary importance denies money for treatments of primary importance.
Though they cannot say so publicly, medical directors of health plans recognize that treatment decisions already reflect costs, even if the plans invoke code words -- experimental, cosmetic or risky -- to mask their motives. Several plans, including those of Prudential Healthcare and Humana Inc., announced that they would not cover Viagra because of concern for its safety, a reason that Dr. Relman dismisses as "hypocritical" because, he said, "We all know it is an economic decision."
Professor Enthoven hopes that Kaiser's frank approach will "provide cover" for health plans to limit costly high-technology treatments that do some good but also threaten to drive insurance premiums to unaffordable levels.
David Eddy points to examples that cry out for cost-sensitive decisions. His research shows that one drug, which would cost several hundred dollars a year, will decrease the chance that a typical 55-year-old woman will suffer a hip fracture by about one in 7,000. One of two liquids that can be used for internal X-rays, when introduced, cost 15 times the alternative, but cut the risk of a nonfatal reaction by only about one in 2,000 patients. New types of Pap smears would about double lab charges but, if done annually, would increase the life expectancy of a woman by only about seven hours.
Dr. Eddy asked "whether health plans should pay for these higher-cost procedures using shared resources, or should patients who want the costlier tests pay the extra money themselves?" In the case of Viagra, Kaiser answered no, deciding that the benefit of the new drug was not worth the increased costs to its members. The risk is that some people, especially the poor, will go without effective treatments of nonlethal problems. The risk in answering "yes" to Dr. Eddy's question -- covering every innovation that works -- is that insurance premiums will soar. Many employers will drop coverage and, as recent surveys document, workers will forgo coverage in exchange for higher wages.
Whatever the pros and cons of Kaiser's decision, it focuses attention on inescapable trade-offs that do, and will, plague every health plan. Should plans cover growth hormones only for children with well-defined genetic miscues or extend treatment to children who are genetically normal but happen to be extremely short? Should health plans cover potentially expensive drugs that might come along to combat memory loss associated with aging?
Beyond these tough questions lurks another. Who should make these coverage decisions? Now, health plans are told to offer complete coverage at affordable prices and, by the way, ignore costs when tailoring policies. Little wonder that they resort to circumlocutions. Another alternative would have government define the basic benefit package, explicitly confronting the trade-off between generous benefits and steeper costs.
The Viagra decision was made easier by the fact that impotence threatens no one's life and the remedy, at $10 a pill, is within the financial reach of most Kaiser members. Even still, reactions were sometimes furious. The cases to come will no doubt grow ever harder.

HEADLINE: Boeing Raises Base Prices of Commercial Jets

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
Seeking to improve its long-term financial performance, the Boeing Company said yesterday that it had increased the base prices of its multimillion-dollar passenger jets by 5 percent, the first such increase since 1975.
But analysts and airlines immediately questioned the impact of the move since nearly all of Boeing's customers pay steep discounts on the company's list prices. 
 "If Boeing was hoping to impress Wall Street, I, for one, am hardly impressed," said Byron Callan, an aerospace analyst with Merrill Lynch in New York.
Boeing said that it had recently begun telling customers that orders negotiated after July 1 would reflect the new prices. Those prices previously ranged from $30.5 million for the 100-seat 717 jetliner to $176.5 million for the largest 747 jumbo jet.
Any new revenue Boeing would receive would not be booked until after 2000 because of the long lead time between ordering and delivering airplanes, the company said.
Boeing, which is the world's largest aerospace company and the country's single largest exporter, has been struggling since last fall to overcome production problems that last year resulted in its first annual loss in 50 years.
Some investors and analysts have criticized the commercial airplane division for cutting its prices too deeply to avoid losing orders to its rival Airbus Industrie, the European consortium. Yesterday's news appears to contradict Boeing's previous contention that the way to improve its profits was to cut costs, not raise prices.
"If you are raising prices, what does that say about your efforts to reduce costs?" Mr. Callan said.
Janice Hayes, a Boeing spokeswoman, said the increases simply brought Boeing's base prices more in line with those of Airbus, which she said were 2 to 6 percent higher than Boeing's.
Boeing also changed the formula it uses to adjust its prices for inflation between the time an airline places its original order and when the aircraft is delivered, a period that can be several years with large orders.
While Ms. Hayes acknowledged that Boeing regularly gave its customers discounts, she said the new base prices would raise the starting point of the negotiations.
But Tony Molinaro, a spokesman for United Airlines, which is about to place an order for short-haul jets, was skeptical. "If they start the negotiation from a higher point, that is their prerogative," he said. "We will see how it competes against Airbus."

HEADLINE: YELTSIN IN APPEAL DIRECTLY TO WEST FOR BILLIONS IN AID

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, July 10

 BODY:
President Boris N. Yeltsin went over the head of the International Monetary Fund today and urged Western leaders to support a multibillion-dollar package of aid to defend Russia's currency.
Russian officials say they are now seeking $20 billion or more, at least $10 billion of which they hope will come from the I.M.F. The total is $5 billion to $10 billion more than the Government previously said it needs, and the request to the fund is about twice what the fund has spoken of providing. 
 The higher request reflects Moscow's anxiety about a rapidly deteriorating economic situation that is threatening not only the stability of the ruble but also the foundations of Russia's political establishment.
In an extraordinary series of appeals, Mr. Yeltsin telephoned President Clinton, President Jacques Chirac of France, Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain and Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany. He also called Michel Camdessus, the director of the I.M.F.
After the call to Mr. Clinton, the Administration expressed support for the beleaguered Yeltsin Government, which has been locked in difficult negotiations with the fund. Washington said Russia needs to take firm measures to deal with its financial crisis, but also indicated that the fund needs to provide substantial loans to calm the financial markets and should keep its demands realistic.
"The United States Government certainly agrees that Russia needs an I.M.F. program that works," the White House spokesman, Michael D. McCurry, said, "one that the Russian Government is both capable of implementing and that addresses the country's most pressing financial and structural problems
"It's time for these negotiations to come to closure."
Moscow and the fund are in some agreement about the direction of economic reform but not the pace. The Russians say their markets are so shaky that they face an emergency and cannot afford long negotiations.
But the fund, having provided much bigger bailouts to Thailand, South Korea and Indonesia in the past year, argues that its funds are depleted and that it has to maintain ample resources for the next crisis. The fund has only $10 billion to $15 billion on hand.
The Yeltsin Government painted a bleak picture of the pressures that have forced it to go hat in hand.
"The situation on financial markets has gotten worse," Prime Minister Sergei Kiriyenko said in the upper house of parliament. "Treasury bill yields are rising. Social tension is also growing. We are ready to consider any proposal, but we simply cannot fail to repay treasury bills," which represent money that the Government has borrowed from the buyers of the bills.
President Yeltsin spoke in even starker terms of social tensions, and warned against any "extremist" plans to exploit the financial crisis to dislodge him from power. In recent days, there have been repeated calls for Mr. Yeltsin's resignation, including from coal miners protesting over lack of pay. So far, however, there have not been any dramatic challenges to Mr. Yeltsin.
"We have enough force to cut short any extremist plans to seize power," Mr. Yeltsin said in an address to senior military officers.
Today's focus, however, was not so much on challenges to the President authority as on the economic assistance the Kremlin says is needed to maintain stability.
The loans that Mr. Yeltsin is seeking would be used for two purposes. The main one is to shore up the reserves of the Central Bank to permit it to buy rubles and maintain the currency's value. Another aim is to restructure the short-term loans that Russia has been forced to take at high interest rates.
The Russians are negotiating with several sources, seeking $10 billion to $12 billion from the fund, $1 billion from the World Bank, $800 million from Japan and $10 billion from commercial banks.
But putting together the package has proved to be very difficult. For one thing, the fund has made it clear that it will not disburse new loans unless Russia cuts its budget deficit and wins support for tax reform and revenue-raising measures in the Communist-dominated parliament. The parliament is to debate Mr. Yeltsin's plan next week.
In his talk with President Clinton, Mr. Yeltsin spoke of the difficulties he faced in winning support for his deficit-cutting measures and tax reforms from the Communists. He also underscored the steps he was taking to deal with the problem, including trying to collect taxes from Gazprom, Russia's biggest company.
Mr. Yeltsin did not ask for direct American assistance, but his aides have been looking to the United States Treasury for help.
"The U.S. Treasury Department is pushing the I.M.F. to get a swift but firm agreement in order to avoid devaluing the ruble," said Anders Aslund, an expert on the Russian economy at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace. "The Treasury Department understands how dangerous an economic meltdown in Russia would be."
John Odling-Smee, a senior I.M.F. official, arrived here for talks today, stirring expectations that a preliminary deal might be struck this weekend on expanded assistance. But initial discussions with Anatoly B. Chubais, the chief Russian representative, did not go entirely smoothly: Mr. Odling-Smee reportedly argued that the Government's revenue projections were off by $5 billion, Russian officials said.
Not all the difficulties have been with the fund; there have been problems with commercial banks as well. The Russians would like to use the funds they borrow without restriction, but some banks are insisting the funds be used to buy back the Russian treasury bills the banks hold.
Much depends on the Russian parliament, and today Prime Minister Kiriyenko strove to build support in the upper house. "We must pool our efforts," he said. "Failing that, we will be responsible for ruining the country."
The upper house, more pliant than the lower chamber, gave its support.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Optimism on Earnings Bolsters Stock Market
Optimism about earnings prospects returned to the stock market, driving the major market measures higher. Investors were particularly upbeat about the outlooks for banks and other financial companies and for consumer goods companies. 
 After falling on Thursday on DuPont's warning about second-quarter earnings, the Dow Jones industrial average gained 15.96 points in a seesaw session, closing at 9,105.74. American Express, Procter & Gamble and J. P. Morgan led the advance. For the week, the Dow was up 80.48 points. The Nasdaq set its third consecutive record, climbing 3.22 points, to 1,943.04, The Nasdaq was up 2.6 percent for the week. Page D3.
 
Russia Seeks Expanded Assistance
President Boris N. Yeltsin urged Western leaders to support a multibillion-dollar package of financial assistance to defend the ruble. Russian officials said they were now seeking assistance of $20 billion or more, at least $10 billion of which it hopes would come from the International Monetary Fund. The request reflects Moscow's concerns about its rapidly deteriorating economy. A1.

Boeing Raises Jet Prices by 5%
Boeing increased the base prices of its multimillion-dollar passenger jets by 5 percent, the first such increase since 1975. But analysts and airlines immediately questioned the impact of the move since nearly all of Boeing's customers pay steep discounts on the company's list prices. D14.
 
Producer Prices Fell in June
Producer prices fell in June for the first time in three months as energy costs retreated, the latest evidence that inflation is not a threat. The Labor Department said that producer prices dropped one-tenth of 1 percent. The core rate, which excludes food and energy costs, rose two-tenths of 1 percent. D3.
 
Speculation Grows About Rubin
Rumors have circulated on Wall Street before that Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin is thinking of stepping down. But now speculation is coming from some of the Secretary's Cabinet colleagues. Right or wrong, it is accepted wisdom among them that he is planning to leave by the end of the year. A8.
 
Texas Fund Sheds Disney Stock
The Texas Board of Education voted to sell its $46.4 million of stock in the Walt Disney Company after complaints about sex and violence in films produced by the company's Miramax Films unit. D2.

I.R.S. Reports Show Flaws
The Internal Revenue Service released an internal report that found widespread overzealousness in the way the agency seized property from delinquent taxpayers. The agency also issued a review that repeated earlier findings that the I.R.S. had put statistical enforcement goals ahead of insuring that taxpayers were treated fairly during audits. A7.
 
Jobs Dispute Looms at U.P.S.
In a move that threatens to reopen a dispute that led to a strike last summer, United Parcel Service told the teamsters' union that it would not create 2,000 full-time jobs as promised in a settlement that ended the strike. D3.
 
Bond Prices Follow Dollar Down
Treasury prices slipped lower in thin trading, hurt by a weaker dollar. The yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond rose to 5.62 percent from 5.60 percent. D3.
 
Inquiry Vowed on Hong Kong Airport
Hong Kong's chief executive, Tung Chee-hwa, said he would appoint an independent panel to investigate the problems that have plagued Hong Kong's new $20 billion airport. A4.

HEADLINE: Washington Memo;
The Rumors Grow: Rubin Will Leave

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 10

 BODY:
On Wall Street, Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin is probably the only member of the Clinton Administration described in consistently admiring terms.
So it is no wonder that every time a rumor surges through the markets that Mr. Rubin, who grew up on the Street, is thinking of stepping down, traders tremble at their terminals. And there have been plenty of such rumors over the last four years. 
 These days, though, the rumors are emanating not from the trading floors but from some of the Secretary's Cabinet colleagues. Right or wrong, it is accepted wisdom among them that he is planning to leave Washington by the end of the year.
"The week after the midterm elections," predicted one.
"He wanted to go months ago," insisted another, "but he couldn't resign while Asia was coming unhinged."
A third said it was widely assumed that Mr. Rubin would leave although no one had heard that from him directly.
Inside the Treasury, midlevel officials are already handicapping the chances of prospective successors, particularly those of Mr. Rubin's deputy, Lawrence H. Summers, the onetime Harvard economist who is clearly tempering his quick tongue and toning up his sometimes haphazard attire to appear more, well, Rubinesque.
Mr. Summers does not have a lock on the job. Some give an edge to James A. Johnson, the longtime Washington power broker and departing head of Fannie Mae, the federally chartered home mortgage association. There is also lingering talk of Franklin D. Raines, who recently resigned as director of the White House Office of Management and Budget to succeed Mr. Johnson. Mr. Raines was reportedly eager to leave the Administration but might find Treasury irresistible if President Clinton asked.
Mr. Rubin hates to travel, and some view his recent journey surveying the economic devastation in Asia and a weeklong trip to Africa that begins on Saturday as farewell tours.
The Secretary himself is not exactly clarifying the situation. Talking to him about his future is a bit like trying to extract from him an inkling of when the United States might next intervene in the currency markets. Good luck.
He will tell you what his wife, Judy, thinks: Her dislike of Washington and its pretensions is legendary, and she has voted with her feet for the last five and a half years, remaining in New York. (Mr. Rubin travels frequently between the two cities, by either shuttle or executive jet.)
He might also muse, but briefly, about the merits of staying or going, about his continuing fascination with this moment of bewildering global market instability and about the personal toll of what he terms a difficult life style.
"There are a lot of important and interesting issues I'd like to be involved in going forward," he said. "On the other hand, there are countervailing considerations."
Then, borrowing terminology from the deliberate obfuscation he employed last week in talking about when to prop up the Japanese yen, he added, "I'll do what seems to be appropriate and not do what doesn't seem appropriate."
His closest confidants say Mr. Rubin will decide in the next few months, perhaps while fly-fishing this summer. Some in the Administration believe that he can be persuaded to remain with some combination of Presidential arm-twisting and fears that his departure could further unnerve edgy markets. In fact, his aides try to dissuade reporters from writing about the rumors of his departure at all, for fear that the articles alone could uncork the Dow.
"Mr. Rubin has become the market," one top Japanese diplomat complained the other day during a visit to Washington, arguing that the Secretary's thumbs up or thumbs down on Japan's latest economic contortions was the only signal investors were looking for.
All this argues in favor of Mr. Summers's candidacy. He has long played the role of Mr. Rubin's alter ego and debating partner, and has become an increasingly fervent believer in the Rubin world view that the power of markets must be respected by governments.
But Mr. Summers's relationship over the years with Vice President Al Gore has reportedly been rocky, and Mr. Gore will presumably have a major voice in who sets economic policy during his run for the Presidency. Further, Mr. Summers angered many in Congress during the bailout of Mexico with his lectures about America's responsibilities as the guardian of the global economy.
Since then, however, the Deputy Secretary has become a much more careful political animal. He also got a major boost recently when Mr. Rubin talked to The New Yorker about what a fine Treasury Secretary he would make someday, comments that added fuel to the latest round of Rubin rumors.
There is another reason Mr. Rubin might go: Much of the time, the Treasury Secretary's job is not much fun these days.
Twice in the last two months, Federal judges have rejected the Treasury's effort to create a "protective function privilege" for the Secret Service that would have kept Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater independent counsel, from questioning agents who guard Mr. Clinton about what they might have seen occur between the President and Monica S. Lewinsky.
Then there was the embarrassment of the hearings on the Internal Revenue Service that resulted in legislation forcing the Treasury to share authority over the I.R.S. with an outside board. Mr. Rubin and Mr. Summers made clear their distaste for the bill last fall, then did a complete turnabout when the inevitability of its adoption became clear.
But Mr. Rubin's biggest frustration has been the unwillingness of Congress to increase the American contribution to the International Monetary Fund, the international agency battling the global economic contagion sweeping from Asia to Russia to Latin America.
"His patience with the Hill is a lot thinner than it was," one aide noted recently.
Still, as another Administration official who works with Mr. Rubin often points out, reading his mind is like forecasting the markets, and just as risky.
"He loves his job," this official said. "He remains fascinated by what he does and shows no sign of any intellectual apathy. You can't say that about many people in Washington."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, left, conferring with aides, including Deputy Secretary Lawrence H. Summers, second from left, and the Secretary's chief of staff, Michael Froman, right. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Minor Loans Giving Major Help;
Microcredit Catches On With Entrepreneurs in Need

BYLINE: By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
When Eddy and Ivette Alvarez went into business together almost five years ago, they had skills: Mr. Alvarez knew how to make plaster statues, and Mrs. Alvarez knew how to paint them.
They also had a product: a small copy of the Infant of Prague, the statue of the baby Jesus that some believe works miracles. 
 But they did not have money, at least not enough to buy plaster. Even if they had had the know-how to borrow from a bank, they had nothing to put up as collateral.
Today, Mr. and Mrs. Alvarez, who met a decade ago while working at a figurine factory, have a workshop of their own in East Williamsburg, Brooklyn, where they and five employees turn out thousands of plaster statues of everything from coiled cobras to Indian chiefs, along with dozens of different religious figures. They can do so, Mrs. Alvarez said, thanks to several small loans they have received from an organization called Accion New York, based in Williamsburg.
Accion makes tiny loans -- as little as $1,000 -- to impoverished entrepreneurs including seamstresses, hairdressers, grocers and bakers, many of them in the Spanish-speaking enclave in Williamsburg. By helping people to become self-employed, Accion hopes to help not just individuals, but also a whole community.
This kind of loan program is known as microcredit, and it has helped combat poverty in developing countries like India and Ecuador, according to the World Bank. While variations of the concept have occasionally been tried, with limited success, in developed countries, microcredit is now winning a growing number of converts in the United States, especially in New York. Philanthropists who have made their fortunes from Wall Street are particularly attracted to the idea of giving "a hand up, not a handout" to budding entrepreneurs.
Among the efforts they are supporting is the first significant foray into the United States by Grameen Bank, which started the microcredit movement two decades ago in Bangladesh. Grameen, which has opened a mutual fund to raise money from Americans, has just signed contracts to manage its first two programs in the United States, in Harlem and Tulsa, Okla.
But as Accion and other groups like it have found, it is not so simple to adapt a program designed for Bangladeshi villages to the very different cultural and economic situation in the United States. Although there are a lot of microcredit programs in America -- as many as 300, by one count -- only a few have made more than a handful of loans.
Even programs like Accion, the largest in New York City, are struggling to get big enough to make a real difference. Lenders have sometimes had trouble reaching potential clients, and it is also much harder to keep tabs on a borrower in New York City than in a rural village.
"We haven't been able to grow as fast as we want," said Robin A. E. Ratcliffe, a vice president of Accion International, which runs several programs in the United States based on its much larger program in Latin America. "Some people thought that you could take that model, go clunk and make it work here," she said, "but that is not our experience."
In principle, microcredit programs are simple. Borrowers take out very small, very short-term loans; if they repay the loans on time, they become eligible for bigger ones. The loans, which might be as small as $5 in Africa but in the United States tend to start at $500 or $1,000, might help a villager buy chickens to start an egg business, or a city dweller to buy vegetables to sell on a street corner.
Many programs use what is known as peer lending, in which first-time borrowers form a group that takes responsibility for the repayment of all its members' loans.
In fact, few people default. At Accion International, for example, the default rate is just above 2 percent. Because almost all the money gets repaid, it can be reused, making microcredit programs very cost-effective, proponents say. Some programs even make enough money from their lending to cover their costs.
The concept is being promoted by the Clinton Administration, and more than a thousand people working in the field met late last month in Manhattan at the second annual "summit meeting" on the movement.
It has also been embraced on Wall Street, which is becoming a source of both expertise and financial backing. Terri Ludwig, the president of Accion New York, is a former executive at Credit Suisse First Boston, the big investment bank; her boss, Michael Chu, who runs Accion International, is a former limited partner in the investment firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company.
The Bankers Trust Corporation, which caters to companies and wealthy individuals, has set up a fund that last month made its first loans to microcredit lenders, including Accion New York. The $500,000 in the fund came from the bank and some of its well-to-do customers.
"I don't believe in the old social system," said Scott Reardon, a venture capitalist and chairman of the Bankers Trust fund. "The reason I want to do this is that it allows me and my family to contribute in a way I am highly confident will work."
Some of the success stories are striking. When Carlos Aldana came to the United States from Ibague, Colombia, 11 years ago, he worked at three jobs, including delivering packages, he said recently through a translator. His first $1,000 loan from Accion helped him buy a van to make deliveries; later, larger loans helped him buy a tiny cafe in Corona, Queens, and to expand the production of corn cakes known as arepas.
Today, Mr. Aldana employs 11 workers in his arepa factory, where with the help of some small machines they turn out 7,000 corn cakes a day, he said. His latest $15,000 loan helped him buy equipment that should let him double production of the arepas, which he sells to supermarkets and bodegas for $1.50 for package of five.
The factory runs 24 hours a day, and Mr. Aldana is there at least 15 of those hours, he said. His wife and two youngest children, age 8 and 6, are often there, too; his eldest son, who is 18, is a student at the University of Colombia in Bogota.
"It's very important, what Accion does," Mr. Aldana said. "For banks, it's very hard to see small-business men -- they are too strong with their rules and regulations."
Banks are generally not in the business of writing tiny loans, because they are as expensive to process -- and far less profitable -- than larger loans. And bankers can be reluctant to base their lending on a borrower's character, rather than collateral. Major banks generally do not make business loans for less than $25,000.
Some Asian and Caribbean immigrants raise money for their businesses through so-called lending circles. Members of these circles agree to contribute a set amount each month into a pot, and each month a different member gets to use all the money in the pot. Immigrants from Korea, Vietnam, Trinidad, Jamaica, Barbados and Ethiopia all have similar programs, said Ivan Light, a professor at the University of California at Los Angeles, who has studied informal credit networks.
But many would-be entrepreneurs turn to loan sharks. Adalberto Espinal, who runs a bodega in Williamsburg, said loan sharks charge $200 a month on a $1,000 loan -- an interest rate of 140 percent a year. He turned instead to Accion to borrow so that he could keep the store shelves well stocked; he used up his $14,000 savings to make a down payment on the store, which the previous owner lost because of his heavy debts to loan sharks.
Accion charges 16 percent a year, which is more than an established business might pay, but less than many Americans pay on their credit cards. In 1997, the New York program had 344 active borrowers who took out $1.4 million in loans.
Ms. Ludwig, the program's chief executive, says she thinks that it should be far larger. "In New York City, 26 percent of the population is living in poverty," she said. A program like hers has the potential, she said, "to make an impact in an economically viable way, to get at the root of the problem."
But there are challenges to running a program in New York, challenges that are not faced by lenders in rural villages. Getting the word out about the program is difficult; many potential borrowers, especially women, do not think of the baby-sitting or cleaning they do to make a little extra cash as a formal business, Ms. Ludwig said. So she is trying to work with organizations like churches and job-training programs that might send borrowers her way.
Meanwhile, the borrowers she has are not all within walking distance, as they might be in a developing country; she has assigned one person to do most of the on-site inspections of potential borrowers' businesses, so that her two loan officers do not spend all their time on the subway.
And because people are more mobile here, they seem to find it a little easier to walk away from their loans. Accion New York, for example, has had the most trouble with its loans to taxi and livery drivers because they move around so much, said Evelyn Lassalle, one of the loan officers.
Accion is also trying to use American methods to its advantage. Ms Ludwig's former colleagues on Wall Street have donated computers, which should make loans easier to analyze. Last year, the program became the first microcredit organization to sell a package of loans to an investor, a transaction that is common on Wall Street but almost unknown elsewhere.
"We need to reinvent the whole approach so as to develop a new U.S. model," said Mr. Chu, the president of Accion International.
But the founders of the microcredit movement worry that Americans have already tampered too much with the original model. That is one of the reasons Grameen has decided to manage some programs here, said Alex Counts, director of the Grameen Foundation in Washington.
For one thing, some American programs -- though not Accion -- tend to emphasize formal training over lending, Mr. Counts said. "It's very typical, and close to universal, to require 10 weeks of business training before you can talk about getting a loan," he said. "People who are running a business or are serious about starting one don't have time for that."
Mrs. Alvarez certainly does not. She and her husband used to work until 3 in the morning making statues, she said; now that they have hired employees, they have to work only from 8 in the morning until 10 at night.
But she is not complaining. She and her husband are now starting to save to buy a house, she said. "And we started with zip."

HEADLINE: Political Briefing;
Illinois Democrats Spur Their Candidate

BYLINE: By B. Drummond Ayres Jr. 

 BODY:
Some leading Democrats in Illinois are worried that Representative Glenn Poshard's campaign for governor is flagging, and they have begun urging him to pick up the pace and sharpen his attack.
A few weeks ago, State Representative Carol Ronen of Chicago, a member of the Democratic State Central Committee, sent Mr. Poshard a letter in which she warned that many liberal voters in the Chicago area, often the key to Democratic success in statewide races in Illinois, "might fail to support your candidacy without some assurance that you are interested in their votes and open to their concerns." 
 She urged Mr. Poshard, a social moderate from rural southeastern Illinois, to "reassure voters that you are in the mainstream, not on the fringe," by forcefully speaking out for family planning, early childhood education and health care, "reasonable" gun controls and strong anti-discrimination laws.
At about the same time, a number of the state's top Democratic campaign consultants and union representatives, along with some aides from various state legislative offices, sent Mr. Poshard a similar message. They warned that if he did not move more aggressively, there was no chance he could overtake the Republican nominee, Secretary of State George Ryan, and end 22 years of Republican occupation of the Illinois executive mansion.
Mr. Ryan, a mainstream Republican, is much better financed than Mr. Poshard, who refuses -- to the despair of some supporters -- to take money from political action committees. Further, Mr. Ryan faced no serious primary opposition, while Mr. Poshard struggled through a divisive primary against tough black and staunchly liberal opponents.
Responding to his critics a few days ago, Mr. Poshard said he was trying to "build back bridges" after the primary and had begun to buy advertising time on television and radio. He also said he would reconsider his opposition to building a third major airport south of Chicago -- opposition that has disappointed many unemployed blacks in that area, along with their Congressman, Representative Jesse L. Jackson Jr.

HEADLINE: Japan's Political System Freezes Out Reformers

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Recent articles about Japan's economic crisis have called attention to the fact that Japanese political leaders lack the power to change Government policy radically. As a July 9 front-page article on Japan observes, Japanese bureaucrats hold much of the power that in other countries is wielded by elected officials. This is partly because the prime minister can appoint only Cabinet leaders and cannot remove the bureaucrats below them. Prefectural governors can make less than a handful of appointments. 
 The United States has rightly been criticized for relying too much on the spoils system; political appointments abound at every level of government. Although this can lead to the appointment of unqualified people, it also means that a change in political leadership can result in changes in the bureaucratic leadership that will allow for the implementation of new policy. This does not happen when Japan elects new leaders.
ANTHONY A. CUPAIUOLO
White Plains, July 9, 1998
 
The writer is director of the Edwin G. Michaelian Institute for Public Policy and Management, Pace University.

HEADLINE: Beliefs

BYLINE: By Peter Steinfels 

 BODY:
Religious ideas, leaders, organizations and appeals have been an integral part of American reform politics. Turn-of-the-century progressives and even many socialists were imbued by liberal Christianity and influenced by the Social Gospel movement. The labor movement and the welfare state drew heavily on Jewish and Roman Catholic communal traditions. Black churches were the birthplaces and command centers of the civil rights movement.
Now an eminent philosopher, whose maternal grandfather, Walter Rauschenbusch, was the theological genius of the Social Gospel, has issued a vigorous plea for the reconstitution of a broad, pragmatic and reformist left in the United States. And one of the most interesting things about this plea is the place it makes -- or does not make -- for religion. 
 "Achieving Our Country" (Harvard University Press, 1998) is the plea, and its author is Richard Rorty, a scholar often called the leading gadfly of contemporary philosophy. This may be an understatement, like calling the lethal iceberg the leading gadfly of the Titanic.
The heart of "Achieving Our Country" is Professor Rorty's critique of the "cultural left." Barricaded in the university, this left has isolated itself, he asserts, from the bread-and-butter issues of economic equality and security and the practical political struggles that once occupied the American reform tradition.
Professor Rorty, who is leaving the University of Virginia to become professor of comparative literature at Stanford, sees leftist intellectuals as launching increasingly abstruse and theoretical assaults on the original sins of Western society, from capitalism to heterosexism.
Clearly, controversies are seeded like land mines in every paragraph of this short book. Conservatives have already fumed over Professor Rorty's nearly total silence about conservative ideas, as though it were beyond the thinkable that grappling with them might have anything to do with reconstituting a vital left.
An even more intriguing absence in Professor Rorty's vision of a renewed left is religion. One might say that while "Achieving Our Country" never rules out a place for religious forces in a reformist coalition, it simply does not allude to them. But the truth is still more complicated.
In the book's first chapter, the author expounds a concept of legitimate national pride that he hopes could reanimate a reformist left. This national pride springs from a vision of America that Professor Rorty ascribes to Walt Whitman and John Dewey, a utopian vision in which a nation, free of caste and class, would "replace God as the unconditional object of desire." For the poet and the philosopher, America and democracy meant "a new conception of what it is to be human -- a conception which has no room for obedience to a nonhuman authority."
It requires no complex reasoning to recognize why such an animating vision would create problems for religious believers. Indeed, for Jews, Christians and Muslims, some of this language seems to meet the technical definition of idolatry.
Professor Rorty is not at all unaware of the power of religion as a moral force in the United States. In a recent telephone conversation, he acknowledged that "in the foreseeable future the churches are as likely to be on the right side as the wrong side" in political struggles. But that cannot alter his conviction, he said, that "in the final stages of democracy we won't need religion anymore." He added that such a conviction may be "off-putting, but I deeply believe it -- I find the idea inspiring."
This conviction is, of course, consistent with Professor Rorty's longstanding position that all efforts to seek rational grounding for moral claims, whether in some objective facts "out there,"some common human nature or some universal principles, are futile hangovers from immature longings for religious certitude.
So it is not surprising that religion does appear in "Achieving Our Country" after all -- as a term of condemnation. Whenever Professor Rorty wants to chastise the "cultural left," he accuses it of abandoning secularism, getting religion or turning metaphysical.
What is most interesting about all this is the tone. Despite protestations of pragmatism, there is no sense that Professor Rorty has assessed the realistic prospects of making "Whitmanesque hypersecularism" the centerpiece for building a broad reformist coalition in the United States.
Nor is there any sense that the author has decided to rally academic leftists at the cost of alienating religious ones, who might understandably resist enlisting in a battalion that has already emblazoned religion's epitaph on its banners. Instead, the anti-religious sentiments of "Achieving Our Country" are matter-of-fact, presented in the untroubled tone that people often use in criticizing a group they cannot imagine is even in the room.
Is this the reality? Does religion -- except in a negative sense -- simply fall outside the horizons of discussions about the intellectual left and its future? Perhaps not too much should be concluded from a one-of-a-kind thinker like Richard Rorty. It is interesting, however, that when asked whether anyone else had raised questions about his book's treatment of religion, Professor Rorty said no.

CORRECTION-DATE: July 13, 1998, Monday
