HEADLINE: Young, Vulnerable And Violated In the New South Africa

BYLINE: By Suzanne Daley; Donna Ferrato, a New York-based photographer, is the founder of the nonprofit foundation Domestic Abuse Awareness. Suzanne Daley is the Johannesburg bureau chief of The New York Times.

 BODY:
The girl in the plain dress stares at the floor. She pulls on the ends of her short-cropped hair. She twists her feet.
Inside the police office at Baragwanath Hospital on the edge of Soweto, the sprawling black township, it is time for Masindi, 9 years old and small for her age, to tell her story. The police officer presses. What happened after you got him the cigarettes? 
 "He grabbed me and started to do these funny things to me," she says.
And then? "He forced me to lie down on the bed."
And then? "He took out his penis."
These days there is a steady stream of children -- boys and girls -- coming through the doors of this drab barracks-like building, where doctors and social workers examine abused children and police officers begin the long and often unsuccessful process of trying to get a conviction.
The children usually arrive dressed in their Sunday best, the hair ribbons and the starched shirts contrasting sharply with the sordid details and the pain they describe. Some are too young to talk; it is torn flesh and venereal disease that tell the story.
A growing incidence of rape -- child rape in particular -- is one of the ugliest aspects of the new South Africa. Reported cases of sexual assault against children under the age of 18 have more than doubled in four years, to 20,333 in 1996 from 9,786 cases in 1993. And experts believe the actual numbers are far higher. South Africa may have the highest incidence of reported rape in the world -- 120.6 rapes for every 100,000 women in 1997, compared with 71 in the United States in 1996.
There are any number of reasons for the explosion of sexual assault. The success of the liberation movement left thousands of young men without a cause, uneducated, unemployed and accustomed to violence. At the same time, the breakdown of the apartheid laws triggered widespread migration, with millions of blacks flocking from the homelands to squatter camps in the cities. Privacy is nonexistent among the shacks, alcoholism is rampant and law enforcement erratic. And it is difficult for even the most attentive mother to watch over her children.
Moreover, women traditionally are held in low regard, and children, in general, are taught to be extremely submissive to adults, even strangers. In recent years, the fear of AIDS has also made young girls attractive to predatory men; for a time, there was even a rumor that sex with a virgin would cure the disease.
The workers at Baragwanath complain that they have never seen so many young victims of rape, and that it wears on them. "Sometimes it is just too much for us," says Rexina Maruping, the chief nurse. "These are very hard times."
The police are so understaffed that an accused rapist may not be arrested until months after the crime is reported -- and the victim may live near him and see him every day. One 1996 study found that nearly two-thirds of suspected offenders were never prosecuted. Of those, only 7 percent went to prison.
Soweto police officers arrest child rapists in weekly roundups. In a convoy of unmarked cars, they speed through the dusty streets in the dead of night, rousting whole families to drag out the accused. Arriving late at night improves the chances of catching the suspect at home.
On a recent night's sweep, each officer had more than 80 assigned cases, and the team picked up 10 men in five hours. One was accused of raping his 2-year-old daughter, and one was a teen-ager accused, with six classmates, of beating and raping his 12-year-old cousin and leaving her for dead, half-buried in a fresh grave. But most were neighbors of the victims.
In many ways, Masindi's case is typical. Her mother, who is separated from her father and is struggling to raise three children, works as a maid four days a week, traveling more than an hour to her job. She earns about $4 a day, $1 of which pays for transportation. While she is gone, Masindi is more or less on her own.
The man Masindi says raped her and left her with syphilitic ulcers so severe that she could hardly walk was an unemployed neighbor known as Banny, who befriended her over a long period of time and gave her food. Masindi's mother, barely literate and a recent arrival from a village in the hills of Kwazulu Natal, says she never suspected trouble. She was glad that someone was taking an interest in her child. "I am thinking he likes Masindi," she says. "This is good."
Six months after his arrest, Banny remains in jail, awaiting trial in September. Masindi, meanwhile, is having trouble at school. She is forgetful and sometimes has nightmares. She refuses to go out at night.

HEADLINE: Betsy McCaughey Ross Is Not Kidding

BYLINE: By Adam Nagourney; Adam Nagourney is a political reporter for The New York Times.

 BODY:
Betsy McCaughey Ross is settled in the back seat of her Chevrolet Suburban, her stockinged feet curled in a swirl of papers, pumps and candy wrappers, a Hershey bar in one hand, a car phone in the other. She has a question. She has just spoken at a Planned Parenthood meeting in Albany and is now focusing on her next campaign appearance, a speech to the Nassau County Democratic Committee at Hofstra University on Long Island. "What do I say?" she asks an aide back at campaign headquarters, then lets out a sharp burst of awkward laughter.
In truth, the Lieutenant Governor of the State of New York -- and candidate to unseat the Governor (and her boss), George E. Pataki -- sounds more quizzical than worried as her vehicle hurtles down the Thruway. McCaughey Ross presents herself less as a politician than a writer and an academic -- "I believe in the power of ideas," she often says -- but ideas are not on the agenda at the Democratic meeting tonight, and she knows it. Clicking off the phone, she turns to an adviser next to her in the back seat. "I don't think I should give a stump speech with policy in it, do you?" she asks. "Should I give my regular pre-K, H.M.O., pro-choice, economy speech?" As she fidgets in her seat, a bundle of nervous smiles and energy, it soon becomes clear that she does know what to say, and she begins to preview her speech right there. "I believe that every family should have affordable day care for their children so that women have a right and opportunity to succeed in the workplace," McCaughey Ross declares. "Does the Republican Party believe that? No." Her eyes are closed tight and her face is shining as she imagines the audience response. 
 At Hofstra, the auditorium is half-empty. These are Democratic regulars, and their evident lack of enthusiasm at McCaughey Ross's arrival suggests that they know her history: how she ran as a Republican with Pataki in the 1994 campaign and helped topple Mario M. Cuomo. How she battled with Pataki from the outset, quit the Republican Party last September and within months announced that she would run for Governor, eclipsing a cast of Democrats -- including Peter F. Vallone, the New York City Council Speaker; Charles J. Hynes, the Brooklyn District Attorney, and James L. Larocca, a former state transportation and energy commissioner -- whose allegiance to the party was not in doubt.
But here is McCaughey Ross, 49, a woman who has never voted for a Democratic Presidential candidate in her life, unapologetically taking the stage. "I'm proud to be a Democrat and I'm proud to be running as the next Governor of the State of New York," she declares. And then she is off, building into her rhythmic cant. "I believe in fighting discrimination of any kind -- against racism, against religious bigotry, against gays and lesbians. Does the Republican Party believe that? No!" Her thin voice sounds almost lusty as it bounces off the walls. Before long, the crowd is joining her shouts -- "No! No! No!" -- and McCaughey Ross displays her white flash of a smile and thrusts an arm in the air, her diamond-encrusted watch glittering in the spotlight. More than half the audience rises in applause. She strides off the stage, oblivious to the local politicians waiting to speak, and with a jerk of her head, announces to her aides: "Let's go."
There has, in the peculiar history of New York State politics, never been anyone quite like her. A consensus has emerged about this woman, at least in New York's political community, which is that McCaughey Ross is -- to put it directly -- a little loopy. It is a perception that has been explicitly promoted by Pataki's office, which has needed to account for the fact that, were it not for the efforts of Pataki and Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, McCaughey Ross would almost certainly be unknown to most New Yorkers today. (In her more chivalrous moments, Zenia Mucha, Pataki's communications director, describes the Lieutenant Governor as "an irrational person.") And it is a perception that McCaughey Ross has encouraged with her bouts of unorthodoxy: the staff bloodlettings; the fact that she remained standing, rather conspicuously, throughout Pataki's 1996 State of the State speech; her frequent defiance of her sponsors, D'Amato and Pataki; her awkward public bearing.
Still, there is little evidence that this portrait of a loopy lieutenant governor is widely known, much less shared, by voters. It is also not completely accurate. McCaughey Ross may be erratic, and she may be given to bursts of naivete and non sequitur. But she is also singularly intelligent, driven and charming -- and accustomed to getting what she wants.
She has been in politics for only three years, and it was nothing she ever considered, much less aspired to. But she is learning the business. Having seen her opportunity -- a weak field of male Democratic candidates, the stronger ones having been scared off by a formidable Republican incumbent -- she seized it. She now finds herself the only woman in the race, closely identified with the potent issues of health care and auto insurance, her campaign largely financed by her wealthy husband, Wilbur L. Ross Jr., an investment banker. (As of her last financial disclosure, she had raised $2.4 million, $2.25 million of which came from Ross.) Whether it is a result of cold calculation or beginner's luck, there are many political experts who, as of today, believe that she will win the Sept. 15 primary -- even if her prospects of unseating Pataki, like those of all the Democrats, are decidedly bleak.
Governing, though, is another matter. McCaughey Ross may well have the discipline to keep her eccentricities in public check through the comparatively brief span of a campaign. But for a number of reasons -- a management style that can only be described as disruptive, an ignorance of the history and habits of Albany and a lack of grounding in any of the political parties -- McCaughey Ross would seem to be particularly ill suited for the job she is seeking. Even her friends, who have high praise for her intellect and heart, take pause at the thought of Betsy McCaughey Ross running the government of the third-largest state in the union.
"Have I told you about the withhold?
McCaughey Ross, a glass of red wine standing untouched at her elbow, has been talking for nearly half an hour about the regulation of health maintenance organizations. The withhold, it seems safe to say, is an unfamliar term to most voters. (It is the practice by which H.M.O.'s withhold part of a doctor's payment as a means of keeping down costs.) Here at dinner on the Upper East Side, as the details pile on, it becomes easy to appreciate what happened the first time McCaughey Ross had brunch with Joseph L. Bruno, the Senate majority leader. As McCaughey Ross tells the story, she started chatting about health insurance legislation even before a drink had been ordered, and Bruno raised both of his hands. "Just don't talk policy!" he pleaded.
No one who has worked with McCaughey Ross challenges her intellectual rigor or depth. In fact, a complaint made by her ever-changing stable of political advisers is that she spends too much time on policy. "I can't win by just being in places, shaking hands, being a regular pol," McCaughey Ross says. "I'm going to win because of ideas. So it's really important for me to stay home and read the reports and write the policy things and do the ideas."
She has always been this way: studious, competitive, an overachiever. It is sometimes easy to forget -- with her two marriages to investment-banker husbands, with her Park Avenue apartment and tailored suits -- that McCaughey Ross was not born to wealth or success. She grew up in a working-class family in Westport, Conn., to a father who was a janitor and a mother overcome by alcoholism. McCaughey Ross won a boarding-school scholarship, then went on to Vassar College and received her doctorate in constitutional history at Columbia University. In 1972, she married Thomas K. McCaughey, and spent the 1980's raising three daughters, now all in their teens, as well as writing for academic journals and teaching constitutional history at Columbia.
Though McCaughey Ross puts more emphasis on the professional side of her resume, she was arguably more of a socialite than an academic back then. In any event, she says that the prospect of being a "very well cared for, very affluent wife of a Wall Street financier" made her restless. "I just wasn't cut out to be a, I don't know, a plantation madam," she says. McCaughey Ross lets out a gust of self-conscious laughter. "Don't use that word! 'A country-estate lady.' It's not my thing. I like to work hard, I like to be engaged."
By 1992, McCaughey Ross had divorced her husband and joined the Manhattan Institute, a conservative think tank where she began writing articles that contributed to the demise of President Clinton's proposal for universal health care. This accomplishment earned her the attention of Senator D'Amato, who was looking for a woman to run with Pataki in 1994. It is testimony to the haste with which McCaughey Ross was recruited that Pataki was taken aback when his new lieutenant governor started flooding him with single-spaced policy papers (footnotes included), and sharing her often-dissident views with reporters. "I'm the quarterback of this team," Pataki told her brusquely, in one of their only face-to-face meetings. McCaughey Ross's political advisers reminded her that lieutenant governors are meant to be neither seen nor heard. McCaughey Ross ignored their advice, and Pataki ignored his lieutenant governor.
"Don't you think it's odd not to get any answers?" she asks now. "I didn't realize that these memos would antagonize them. I thought they were very helpful." She is not being disingenuous. The result is that the second-ranking official in New York is today almost incidental to its governance. She and Pataki have not had a substantial conversation in more than a year. "I would have liked to have known him better," she says. D'Amato and Pataki are now said by associates to view the recruitment of McCaughey Ross as the single biggest mistake they have ever made in politics. The two men, normally eager to talk to reporters, did not return calls for this article.
McCaughey Ross's defiance earned her a punishing wave of stories and gossip, much of it generated from Republicans, designed to portray her as a buffoon. In that regard, her insistence on directing almost every discussion toward policy seems intended to establish herself intellectually, to rebut the portrayal put forth by those who brought her into politics in the first place. "Have you read my reports?" McCaughey Ross asks in one interview, her voice brittle, repeating a question she has posed before. "I wrote them myself."
The door of the suburban opens at the corner of 11th Avenue and 57th Street, and McCaughey Ross emerges for a sidewalk news conference on her plan to lower auto insurance rates. Suddenly she stops, picking out a dark-eyed young man with a tape recorder who is trying to blend in with the reporters. "I've never met you before! Who are you?" she says, pumping away at his hand, not letting go -- as is her style -- until the encounter turns awkward. He says that his name is Adam, and that he's a college student, and McCaughey Ross responds: "Oh, you're working for one of the other campaigns!" And Adam, looking a little embarrassed at being discovered, acknowledges that he is indeed working for Peter Vallone.
McCaughey Ross has encouraged the perception of herself as a political novice. And in many ways she is. This, after all, is the woman who did not recognize Al D'Amato when she first met him in 1993. The subject of politics often bores her. One day in May, when Stephen J. Sabbeth, the Nassau County Democratic leader, started talking about the coming state Democratic convention, McCaughey Ross distractedly flipped through her black-and-white composition book (which has "Betsy" scribbled on the front). When Sabbeth stopped speaking, she piped up, "It's a beautiful day for a luncheon!"
It is this kind of disconnected behavior that leads many political people to dismiss her. That would be a mistake. In Sabbeth's office, she took close note of a sign on his wall -- First get elected, then do good -- and was soon quoting it approvingly. Indeed, there is ample evidence that she long ago absorbed the wisdom of Sabbeth's sign. She has taken few positions that might be considered electorally problematic. No one is likely to argue against her proposition that auto insurance rates should be lowered, or that people suffering from cancer should not be denied insurance coverage for experimental forms of chemotherapy. Her emphasis on health care, its merits notwithstanding, is clearly a pre-emptive defense against Democratic attacks over her role in undercutting President Clinton's health-care plan -- and an attempt to distance herself from a position that came under attack as intellectually slipshod.
Even in an era of ideologically indistinct politicians, McCaughey Ross stands out: in six years, she has already managed to associate herself with the Conservative, Republican, Democratic and Liberal Parties. Assemblyman Edward C. Sullivan, an Upper West Side Democrat who has endorsed her, calls her "a progressive in formation," while Ann Northrop, a friend since Vassar and a leading AIDS activist, says McCaughey Ross is politically consistent and "the most radical person in the race." McCaughey Ross presents herself as "the most socially progressive" candidate, even though she stood by as Pataki pursued a historically conservative agenda, advocating cuts in welfare, Medicaid and education spending, and the revival of a death penalty. "I think of myself as fiscally responsible and socially liberal," she says. "But more than anything, as an honest, call-them-as-I-see them person. A problem solver. For example, I support gay rights. A lot of people don't. I'm unequivocally pro-choice." There is an unusual amount of antipathy toward McCaughey Ross among her three Democratic rivals, who believe that she is little more than an opportunist. "What is her rationale for running for this job, other than that she doesn't like George Pataki?" asks Charles Hynes. McCaughey Ross dismisses such talk, asserting that the only reason she is running is to serve the people of New York. But this is a woman who became a celebrity literally in the space of the 20 minutes it took her to accept the invitation to run for Lieutenant Governor. By all accounts, including those of the many consultants who say she instructed them specifically to get her name into the newspapers, this is someone who clearly enjoys the attention that comes with high office.
Betsy Mccaughey Ross is sitting alone in her huge, high-ceilinged office in the state Capitol. There is a plate of chicken bones on her otherwise orderly desk. It is lunch; breakfast was a Mounds bar, part of a regular daily diet that she accurately describes as "chicken and chocolate." It is less than a week since McCaughey Ross fired her campaign manager, Robert Becker, producing a round of headlines suggesting again that McCaughey Ross is unstable. Still, she seems startled when the subject is raised. "I wouldn't say anything negative about Robert," she said. "I just think it's inappropriate to criticize employees, no matter what they say. I made the decision that was in the best interest of the campaign." She sits back, looking anxiously at her questioner, as if she were a student awaiting a grade from an instructor. Does she consider herself difficult to work for? "I think -- well, yes," she says. "If I find a letter that has been sitting around for four months, I am not happy!"
Her former staff members, and there are many, say she is a relentless micromanager given to temper explosions, second-guessing, undercutting and disregarding the views of experts. "She was somewhere between difficult and impossible to work for," says Jay Severin, a Republican consultant. "No matter what I did, it wasn't enough."
The issue of her temperament clearly concerns her, and she raises it on her own one afternoon. "I set very high standards," she says. "That's not always true in government. And as you know, I never say anything negative about anyone who has ever worked with me. But I expect the people who have worked with me to share my high moral standards, my commitment to working hard and to producing the best possible product. And if they don't, I wish them well in some other job."
Ultimately, it is this imperious side of McCaughey Ross that most unnerves the politicians who contemplate her as a governor. And it disappoints the political consultants who have spun through her life, able at once to appreciate her political strengths -- her intelligence, her poise -- and the weaknesses that may ultimately be her undoing. "She is 90 percent perfection," says one consultant who worked briefly for her. Still, it is important to remember that the public sees a different McCaughey Ross, the one who brought a skeptical audience in Nassau County to its feet. From that perspective, the campaign by the Republican Party to discredit her might have the opposite effect. She cannot help but exceed the expectations they have set for her.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 24; Column 1; Magazine Desk

HEADLINE: And Luxury for All

BYLINE: By Holly Brubach; Holly Brubach is the style editor of the magazine.

 BODY:
Not all that long ago, the market for luxury goods consisted of people who lived in majestic houses with a full complement of servants, in some time-honored enclave of the privileged: they ordered their trunks from Louis Vuitton, their trousseaus from Christian Dior, their Dom Perignon by the case. Their taste was like their politics -- conservative -- determined largely by considerations of safeguarding their wealth and perpetuating the social conventions that ratified their sense of superiority. Their houses and their wardrobes were in the "classic" style, which abstained from fashion.
Lately, however, a new market has emerged -- one made up of people who, though they can't afford a house in Paris's 16th arrondissement or an apartment on New York's Park Avenue, have enough disposable income to buy a Vuitton handbag (if not a trunk) or a bottle of Dior perfume. They have a sense of entitlement that transcends social class, a conviction that the finer things are their birthright -- never mind that they were born into a family whose ancestral home is a tract house in the suburbs. These new customers are for the most part younger than clients used to be, and there are far more of them. The competition for their attention is intense. Though they may never have heard of Bernard Arnault, he understands them. 
 The 49-year-old chairman of LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton, Arnault presides with quiet authority over the most extentensive luxury-goods empire in the world at a time when shopping qualifies as a form of self-expression and brand names constitute a universal language -- a consumerist Esperanto spoken by increasing numbers of people in practically every country on every continent. Arnault is revising our notion of luxury and what it looks like through the combined forces of his various trademarks. Among them, amassed in the short space of a decade, are the fashion houses of Christian Dior, Givenchy and Christian Lacroix; the vintners Veuve Clicquot, Hennessy and Chateau d'Yquem; the leather-goods manufacturers Louis Vuitton and Loewe; the perfumer Guerlain; the airport-based retail network Duty Free Shops, and a new cosmetics emporium, Sephora.
If his renown is pretty much confined to business circles, it may be because, despite his youthful demeanor and striking blue eyes, Arnault is conspicuously lacking in charisma. Shy, cerebral, silver-haired, he is not, as the French say, mediatique, or suited to the media. Arnault's charm -- which, as it turns out, is considerable -- is perhaps too subtle for the 10-second sound bite; his story, too complex.
And, indeed, his treatment at the hands of the media in Europe has not been especially kind. He has been sharply criticized for introducing American hardball to the genteel realm of business in France. Early on, the French press nicknamed him Tintin, after the Belgian cartoon character whom he vaguely resembles with his circumflex-shaped eyebrows; the effect, in the end, was more pejorative than affectionate. Attempts to humanize him -- he plays the piano! loves Chopin! -- have for the most part failed in the bitter aftermath of hostile takeovers and forced retirements. Some critics dubbed him the Terminator for his ruthlessness as a corporate raider.
Ill at ease as the center of attention, Arnault readily deflects the spotlight, training it on John Galliano, the flamboyant English designer whom he appointed to head the house of Dior, and Alexander McQueen, another Englishman, angry and outrageous, whom Arnault installed at Givenchy -- Galliano and McQueen being particularly adept at making headlines. Though not mediatique himself, Arnault is frequently blamed for ushering in a new mediatique era in fashion -- one in which designers like Galliano and McQueen have risen to prominence, in which extravagant spectacles have eclipsed ordinary catwalk presentations, preposterous clothing is justified as a loss leader for perfume sales, success is measured in terms of press coverage and designers' reputations are often more in proportion to their oversize personalities than to their talent. Arnault was by no means the first to bring Hollywood-style promotion to the selling of clothes and dry goods, but there is no question that in many people's minds he has come to personify the change from the discreet, elitist approach that prevailed for most of this century.
Nevertheless, things are looking up for Arnault. He has earned the respect of his adversaries, who acknowledge, however reluctantly, that he is in many respects a brilliant, creative businessman. The pitched battle he waged with Robert Miller over the control of Duty Free Shops is over, and Miller, still on the company's board, says that their working relationship has proved to be harmonious. Arnault and his wife, Helene Mercier, a Canadian-born concert pianist, are much in demand, high on the guest list for private dinners, government functions and prestigious cultural events. At shows for Givenchy and Dior, where their presence in the front row is conspicuous, fashion veterans who once regarded them with suspicion now treat them with something approaching awe; members of the press come and pay them court.
Arnault's triumph has to a large extent been based on a simple premise he has acknowledged and acted upon -- that for those looking to set themselves apart from what used to be called the common folk, money is no longer enough. Too many people have it. "When you cannot differentiate yourself from others with money," he says, "then you must differentiate yourself with something that indicates that you know how to recognize the best." In the evolution of the luxury-goods business, the Era of Wealth has given way to the Age of Connoisseurship. The new elitism is predicated on taste, and it holds out an essentially middle-class notion: the promise of a meritocracy in which the hereditary ruling class is supplanted by an aristocracy of style.
Though he rarely grants interviews, Arnault consented to discuss the luxury-goods industry and his role in it in a series of conversations that took place over two weeks in Paris. The salon in which we met, a room expressly designed for receiving visitors -- the outer zone of the inner sanctum that is Arnault's suite of offices at Dior's headquarters -- had been decorated in the high corporate style, tasteful and impersonal: two large white couches facing each other across a large, low table; the walls painted Dior's signature gray; a portrait of Dior.
"When I was for the first time in New York, I bought a Christian Dior bathrobe at Bloomingdale's," Arnault recalls. He was on vacation, taking a break from his responsibilities running the family construction business in Roubaix in northern France, where he was reared. "When you ask a taxi driver in New York, 'What do you know about France -- do you know who is the President?"' Arnault says, "the answer is, 'No.' But he knows Christian Dior. Dior was in his day on the cover of Time magazine. He was already part of French culture, like the Eiffel Tower. To build a name that transcends the individual and becomes a symbol of France -- it's a phenomenon that happens very rarely. That's what got me into the luxury business, when I understood the potential of that name."
Like many French businessmen, Arnault spent the early years of the 80's sitting out the initial phases of Francois Mitterrand's socialism. He had returned to New York, this time to live, and was overseeing a real-estate concern in New Rochelle when, in 1984, he made a bid to take over Boussac Saint Freres, a troubled corporation in government receivership. Among Boussac Saint Freres's diverse holdings was the house of Dior (38 years before, Marcel Boussac, the company's founder, had bankrolled Christian Dior's decision to open a couture house); it was Dior that Arnault wanted. Concetta Lanciaux, now director of human resources at LVMH, remembers her job interview in his office on the Avenue Montaigne. Still negotiating for Boussac, Arnault gestured out the window in the direction of the Dior building. "That is the company that will interest us in the future," he told her.
Madeleine Vionnet, Jean Patou, Elsa Schiaparelli -- other fashion designers had been famous in their time, and when they died, the businesses that bore their names closed their doors. Dior was the first of the great French fashion houses to outlive its founder, who died in 1957 at the age of 52; even then, it was clear that the name was worth too much to be abandoned. Dior's 21-year-old protege, Yves Saint Laurent, was elected to succeed him. The king is dead, long live the king. When, three years later, Saint Laurent was inducted into the French Army, Marc Bohan, the designer who ran Dior's operations in London, took his place. Bohan stayed the course for more than 20 years, producing clothes that were becoming and discreet, if not particularly innovative; he cultivated a loyal clientele. Arnault replaced Bohan with Gianfranco Ferre, the Italian couturier, and later, after Ferre's departure two years ago, he installed Galliano.
Should a designer's name be kept alive when the designer is long gone? That depends on how much of fashion is art and how much of it is commerce -- a distinction that seems increasingly quaint. "If it's a big business, why not?" Karl Lagerfeld says. "The name can be a guarantee of quality." In 1983, Lagerfeld was hired to put the house of Chanel back on the map, which makes him the first in this latest wave of mercenaries. This season alone brought the debuts of no less than seven young high-profile recruits for established houses, of which three -- Marc Jacobs at Louis Vuitton, Michael Kors at Celine and Narciso Rodriguez at Loewe -- were Arnault's appointments (at Lanciaux's recommendation).
Like Arnault, Lanciaux has grafted a business education (in her case, an M.B.A.) onto an artistic sensibility (a background in art and film). And like him, she believes that the time has come for big fashion companies to undergo a transition from the family-run personality cults that they have been since their inception to brand-name public corporations. "This has been one of Bernard Arnault's clear visions," she says, "this passage to a new era when the company's name is no longer identified with the designer and becomes a brand." But for that to happen, Lanciaux says, a company must have a marketing strategy -- an unpopular concept in France, where a designer's creativity is no less miraculous and mysterious than a painter's talent. "I do instinctive marketing," Karl Lagerfeld declares.
Arnault's strategy for Dior and the other fashion houses he has subsequently acquired is not original (Gucci, for one, has followed the same plan): to hire designers capable of attracting attention and forging a brand identity, then to establish a consistent image by gaining control of licensed products and their distribution. These days, Arnault says, "it's very important for a brand to offer the same products in the same setting all around the world, so the customer can recognize your products. Also, people are more educated vis-a-vis the brand. Even in the 80's, even in the U.S., it was very easy to sell products on the strength of the name alone. Today, it's different. Today, people are more interested in a product's quality and its design." Now when Arnault talks about the house of Dior, it is with the pride of a man who has single-handedly rescued a national treasure and restored it to working order.
The thanks he gets are few. Many of Arnault's detractors contend that he is a reckless powermonger, swallowing up fashion houses with little or no regard for their well-being. In an interview with The Daily Telegraph in January, Hubert de Givenchy discussed his reluctant exit from the house he founded and his heartbreak over what had transpired there since. "I used to be very happy to get orders because I knew that the more orders we had, the more work there would be in the atelier and that the heart of the couture house would continue to beat. Now they don't care.. . .They just want their collections to be talked about as mad and extravagant so they can sell perfume and licenses." (In response to a request for an interview for this article, Givenchy declined through his secretary, who explained that he didn't want to concern himself with these matters any longer.)
What is at stake is nothing less than the fragile culture of the haute couture, a centuries-old tradition that sprang up around the mastery of a craft. Ferre talks fondly of the workers at Dior, of their extraordinary skills. The real task for him, he says, was to design something that would "carry them over, to push them forward. These are people who needed someone to encourage and support them. They have been raised in a tradition -- all they know is how to sew. These are not people who participate in the fashion system or live the life of the clients." It is perhaps sad, but hardly surprising, that Arnault does not share Dior's -- and Ferre's -- legendary reverence for the petites mains, the famous "little hands" that could take his ideas and render them to perfection with invisible stitches and intricate beading. "It's a loss, Dior," Ferre says with tears in his eyes.
With so many brands at his disposal, Arnault has turned out to be a kingmaker. His appointments have been sensational and controversial, a subject of great debate even before the designers produced their first collections. Like a Hollywood casting director, Arnault sums up the talents of each of the stars he has hired in a single sentence or less. Galliano, whom he initially placed at Givenchy -- an arrangement that lasted a year before Arnault transferred him to Dior -- is, he contends, "perfect" for Dior because, like Dior himself, Galliano is "a romantic." Whereas Givenchy, he explains, was a designer who built a house based on "structure" -- which makes McQueen, with his background in Savile Row tailoring, ideally qualified to take it over. Jacobs has a talent for "chic sportswear," Arnault says, which is just what Louis Vuitton needs.
On the subject of Michael Kors and Narciso Rodriguez, Arnault sounds a bit vague; in their cases, he says, he was less involved in the selection process. He defines what Kors brings to Celine, a bastion of European bourgeois traditionalism, as "classicism with a touch of modernity." As for Narciso Rodriguez at Loewe, the leather-goods house based in Madrid, "Obviously, it's a Spanish company, and he has Spanish links." (Rodriguez, born and reared in New Jersey, traces his origins to the Canary Islands.) "Anyway," Arnault adds, "I was very impressed yesterday. He was on the front page of Le Monde -- his face was on the cover."
Though previously successful, each in his own right, all five of these designers occupied the fringes of fashion until Arnault placed them smack in the middle of the establishment, throwing the weight of a big corporation behind them: the manufacturing facilities, the distribution network, the marketing expertise, the advertising budget. Skeptics have wondered aloud whether Galliano and McQueen -- at 37 and 29 -- are perhaps too young and inexperienced to take over the leadership of the haute couture. (Both were ready-to-wear designers.) They have been handed their glory without having to earn it, defying the industry's tradition of picking up pins by the side of some acknowledged master and rising through the ranks. Thanks to Arnault, each has gone straight to the head of a large organization, one that took somebody else a lifetime to build.
"When you run a fashion house, you are looking for a future, not a past," Arnault argues. "You have to attract a new clientele and take the risk of bringing in some new ideas. So you take the creativity where you find it, and designers, like painters, are more creative when they're in their 30's."
But to Arnault's mind, talent alone is no longer enough (if ever it was), in fashion or in any other field. "Today's world is a media world," he says without apology. "In order to be successful, you have to be well perceived by the media and have a personality that speaks to the public." Long before being hired by Arnault, Galliano had established himself as one of fashion's more outrageous characters; a fashion chameleon currently in a Roaring Twenties tango-dancer phase, his antics have consistently made good copy. McQueen had already embarked on a career as a provocateur, making fashion history with his "bumster" pants, cut so low as to expose the cleavage of the buttocks. And Jacobs, while never outrageous, had been the fashion editors' darling, his career furthered to a great extent by the attentions of American Vogue.
The fact that neither of the designers on whom Arnault has bestowed a couture house is French has not gone unremarked at a time when French fashion has come under fire for being stuck in a rut, unable to adapt to the changing social climate. "I would have preferred to hire French designers for French names," he admits, "and the only reason I did not is that I thought there was no one who could fit in easily. In a way, it's a pity, because for too much time the design schools of other countries have been more creative than ours."
Lanciaux agrees: "At some point, the capacity of the French brands outstripped the capacity of the French schools to generate designers. There are lots of schools in France that do one thing -- it's an approach that is still artisanal. There is not enough synergy. Each of them is so singular, so limited: they produce designers who are good in one area but disconnected from the conception of the product itself and from the business."
It's not that French fashion isn't powerful, Arnault insists. "Today, French names are very strong -- and I think a talented designer can express the French point of view, even if he's British or German."
According to Pierre Berge, Yves Saint Laurent's business partner, the designers' nationality isn't the issue. "Nobody gives a damn where they come from. The problem is that they're not cut out for haute couture. On the one side, there are two couture houses, called Christian Dior and Givenchy, and on the other there are two designers, John Galliano and Alexander McQueen. Who have a lot of talent, who make fashion, who could legitimately exist for an entire career. But neither has anything to do with what those houses, respectively, stand for. They are completely miscast. If Mr. Arnault loves fashion, which I very much doubt, if he likes young designers, which I very much doubt, why doesn't he set them up in their own houses and open boutiques for them in neighborhoods that correspond to what they do -- in the Marais, for example, or on the Left Bank?"
In fact, Arnault did just that in 1987 with Christian Lacroix. "We are the only brand that he started from scratch," Lacroix says. Now, Lacroix remarks wryly, at 47 he finds himself the oldest designer in the LVMH stable and the only one who is French.
Lacroix came to fame at the height of the 80's as the inventor of the pouf skirt, a style that perfectly captured that decade's excess and exuberance -- a silhouette in the shape of a bubble. And then the economy burst, the Champagne went flat and Lacroix found himself out of step with the times. The arrival and departure of a series of managing directors in quick succession (one, Lacroix recalls, came from carpet manufacturing) illustrated the dangers inherent in running a fashion house according to the principles routinely applied in other kinds of companies. "Impatience," Lacroix says, "has been the group's biggest flaw for years, trying to turn a profit very quickly. On account of which we sometimes made deals that were less than wonderful -- in Japan, for instance. But I'm an optimist. Those days are over and done." Lacroix acknowledges that he and Arnault have had their differences, including one long rift that ended only when a friend interceded. More recently, their relations have been warm and pervaded by mutual respect. Even so, Arnault seems less enthralled with the house Lacroix has built with his backing than with the houses he has acquired. Though he regularly attends the Dior and Givenchy shows, he turns out for Lacroix only on occasion now that the clamor has subsided.
Fashion people -- French fashion people, in particular -- like their businessmen erudite and protective, like Berge, or genteel and deferential, like Jacques Rouet, who founded the house of Dior in conjunction with the designer himself. Right up until his retirement in 1984, Rouet was famous for knowing the name of every employee in Dior's atelier and for giving elegant parties in the spacious apartment where he and his wife lived near the Etoile -- parties attended by many of Dior's couture clients. "Dior was always the boss," Rouet says; he put his own expertise in the service of Dior's talent. And Dior, for his part, put his talent in the service of his workers' skills with a humility that manifested itself whenever he encountered an employee, however lowly, in one of the house's narrow corridors. Invariably, Dior would step aside to let the employee pass.
Arnault reportedly keeps walking, head down. He has not taken the time to get to know the people at Dior -- people like the directrice of the showroom or the vendeuses, with whom he has no direct dealings, or for that matter anyone in the atelier except, of course, the designer. The word that recurs in conversations about his management style is "aloof." One former employee depicts Arnault closeted in his office, logged onto the Internet: "I think he is much more fascinated by the financial aspect of Dior, by its performance on the stock ex-change, than by what goes on inside the house."
Arnault's peers in the French luxury-goods business -- merchant princes like Alain Wertheimer, the magnate whose family owns Chanel, and Jean-Louis Dumas-Hermes, the fifth-generation president and artistic director of Hermes -- are routinely perceived as far more sympathetic. Wertheimer is exceedingly private, with a low-key management style that looks to the long term. "The Wertheimers have a business they inherited," Lagerfeld says pointedly, "so they are used to being rich." Dumas-Hermes, affectionately dubbed Jean-Louis XIV by his employees on account of his grandiose schemes, combines an expert's rigor with a child's enthusiasm. A hands-on executive, involved in every aspect of the business, he got his own start in the company in the 60's. Though his recent hiring of Martin Margiela, the innovative Belgian designer, prompted the inevitable comparisons with Arnault's appointments, Dumas-Hermes is quick to draw distinctions. Margiela is "an accomplice," he says, "not a paid star in my music hall."
Throughout the 80's, while Wall Street was dominated by cutthroat maneuvers that changed the rules once and for all, the French could still pride themselves on the gentlemanly tenor of their business dealings. Then along came Arnault and off came the gloves: he bought companies (Celine, Givenchy) and then sent their founders into exile; he divided families or drove a wedge between business partners in order to acquire their holdings (Chateau d'Yquem, Duty Free Shops). Hubert de Givenchy told a friend that Arnault, having named McQueen to succeed him at the house he had built over the long course of his career, didn't even have the decency to introduce them. Arnault's tactics in these and other instances have earned him the adjective "American." He shrugs. "When you live in a country and do business in it for some time, you try to be influenced by it," he says matter-of-factly, "especially when you do business in the paradise of business, which is America."
Arnault's steep rise has revived the old antagonism between art and commerce, as if his methods had contaminated fashion -- as if fashion had ever been pure. He invokes Dior as an example of a designer who, even 50 years ago, regarded business not as anathema but as an extension of the creative process. "We must make a little Bergdorf Goodman in the Avenue Montaigne," Jacques Rouet recalls Dior saying about the site of his Paris boutique. Soon after, Dior signed the first of the many licensing agreements that would become the foundation of his international empire and embarked on a plan of progressive expansion, opening boutiques in cities all around the world, offering his clients the Dior imprimatur on a wide range of products. (A great gourmand, he briefly considered putting his name on hams.) Rouet believes that with the recent renovation of the Dior store, which now houses departments for linens, china and crystal, cosmetics, jewelry, shoes, handbags and men's wear in addition to women's ready-to-wear, Arnault has fulfilled Dior's dream.
On a Tuesday morning in March at the news conference during which LVMH announces its annual results, Arnault steps up to the podium. It's a tough audience, full of analysts and reporters whose business it is to be skeptical. Prognostications have been dire: LVMH, it is presumed, has been hard hit by the collapse of the economy in Asia, and some 400 people have turned out to hear Arnault reveal the extent of the damage. But in the end, the news is not all bad. "I remain persuaded that our presence in that market is invaluable," Arnault says in conclusion, reading from a prepared statement, "and that the desire to consume our products is absolutely intact."
He is followed by Yves Carcelle, the president of Louis Vuitton, who outlines the company's strategy for reclaiming its lost prestige by cleaning up an image that had fallen victim to a kind of "visual pollution." Patrick Choel, president of the LVMH fragrance and cosmetics division, singles out two Dior products for special praise -- Diorific, a long-lasting lipstick, and Mascara Flash, a hair mascara that he calls "a little revolution." Givenchy, he declares, has had "an excellent year" thanks to its new perfumes, Organza and Amarige. Myron E. Ullman 3d, the chairman of DFS Group, which runs Duty Free Shops, offers a plan for the development of a "galleria" concept -- a collection of stores in a downtown setting bringing "the best brands in the market all together in one location . . . with a profitability well beyond" that of airport stores. Every DFS Galleria, he says, will be "an entertainment destination, stimulating multiple visits."
Bringing up the rear of this solemn parade, a succession of executives in suits, is Daniel Richard, the C.E.O. of Sephora Europe. Tieless, with long hair pulled back in a ponytail, he recounts the company's brief and spectacular history. Nearly five years ago, the first of Sephora's shops opened, stocked with a comprehensive selection of fragrances and cosmetics. The flagship store on the Champs-Elysees -- conceived as "a temple," Richard says -- features books about perfume, quotes from Rilke on the walls and computer terminals from which customers can send E-mail free of charge. This summer, Sephora opens the first of three stores in New York (in SoHo), with plans for 15 more American outposts not far behind.
Arnault fields questions from the floor. For a business that traffics in merchandise whose appeal is ineffable and fleeting, LVMH comes across as remarkably solid. Its performance testifies to Arnault's achievement in extending and diluting luxury's reach to include Midwestern debutantes, noveau-riche Muscovites, Japanese yuppies, Argentine jet-setters and tourists everywhere. The audience punctuates his closing remarks with applause. He has won them over against their better judgment. By the end of the week, the share price has risen 10 percent.
People who have worked with Arnault speculate that his experience as a musician has given him an insight into the creative process that is rare in a businessman. Christian de Portzamparc, the celebrated French architect who designed Louis Vuitton's new headquarters in New York, a 23-story tower going up on East 57th Street, speaks admiringly of Arnault as a collaborator -- of his good eye, of his manner, which was both exacting and supportive. "He took the time to make me improve the design," Portzamparc says with sincere appreciation.
Arnault once aspired to a career as a concert pianist, an ambition he gave up when he was in his teens. "I play not bad, but not well enough," he explains. These days, he practices regularly whenever his schedule permits. He has always leaned toward the romantic repertory -- Chopin, Liszt, Schumann, flashy virtuoso pieces. When in 1991 the French and American Chambers of Commerce elected Arnault Businessman of the Year, he decided to forgo the acceptance speech at the awards banquet and instead played a Gershwin song as a duet with his wife.
Helene Mercier, whom Arnault married in 1991, was born in Montreal and trained as a pianist at the conservatories in Vienna and Paris and at the Juilliard School in New York. Today, she says, she plays some 20 engagements a year and practices five hours a day. If music is a language, it is one that she and Arnault share. They met eight years ago at a dinner in Paris. "I thought he was just a businessman interested in music," she recalls. He invited her for lunch at his office.
The first time he played the piano for her, Mercier says, he was so nervous that he was shaking. "I was very impressed when I heard him play because then I understood that he really loves music and that he had taken it very seriously. When you're young and you spend a lot of time alone with the piano, you get to be a certain kind of person with a certain interiority -- someone for whom communication doesn't go through words necessarily. And that's what seduced me. Because he was so sensitive in his playing, and I thought, Well, there must be something very deep in him." Eight months later they were married (in his case, for the second time). Asked whether that didn't make for a rather speedy courtship, Mercier replies, "He really knows what he wants."
A slim blonde with wide-set eyes and a stunning profile, she is dressed in a cashmere twin set, black leather jodhpurs and crocodile loafers. The room in which she receives a visitor in the house where she and Arnault live with their two young children is outfitted with Louis XV furniture upholstered in crimson damask, Aubusson carpets, crystal chandeliers and paintings by Ensor, Dufy, Monet, Leger, Dubuffet and Braque -- everything in conscientious good taste. The decor reflects a certain cautiousness in Mercier's manner, a painstaking effort to be correct.
When it comes to esthetic decisions concerning lvmh products, Arnault often consults his wife, his daughter, Delphine, now a student at the London School of Economics, and their friends -- a small circle of women who have become his own private focus group. He brings home a perfume or a handbag and asks them what they think. Galliano, McQueen and Jacobs all credit Mercier with enormous influence, and it's easy to imagine that her own casual style has helped to pave the way for Arnault's hiring American designers who specialize in sportswear. Mercier is, she claims, a North American at heart, more straightforward and independent than most of the Frenchwomen she meets. She is also, one imagines, an advocate for the way women actually live. "I'm not going to put on a suit to practice the piano," she says.
It's still too soon to tell whether the changes Arnault has introduced at the luxury-goods houses he acquired will turn out to be financially profitable. To take matters even harder to gauge, the only figures Dior and Givenchy release are their year-end totals, which are skewed by perfume sales. But the speculation has been that neither collection has met with much demand on the part of the customers -- particularly the haute couture, with the exodus of many well-known clients to the houses of Yves Saint Laurent and Balmain. Arnault claims that Givenchy sold twice as many couture dresses this spring as last fall. "Women's Wear Daily announced that they sold four outfits last season," Berge says dryly. "So that makes eight."
But if success is measured in terms of the ruckus they have caused, then Arnault's designers have succeeded brilliantly. The attention of the press may at times seem too important to Arnault, possibly for lack of any firsthand fashion background; he forms his opinions on the basis of other people's. Even so, it would be hard to overestimate the media's role in reinventing the image of a fashion house these days. "The media is what makes things contemporary," Marc Jacobs says. "Seeing a picture of something in a magazine is what makes people want it." Arnault's preoccupation with press coverage, coupled with his apparent unconcern with the clothing's actual sales, seems to corroborate what many people in fashion have long suspected -- that in his big corporate picture clothes are a mere front for the perfume and cosmetics, where the biggest profit margin lies.
At Dior and Givenchy, Arnault has decreed that now, as in the past, the brand's identity begins with the haute couture, in an arrangement that seems curiously anachronistic given the changes that have taken place since Dior's heyday in the 50's. The so-called "laboratory of fashion," the couture then served as fashion's R&D division, responsible for new silhouettes, colors and trends, which were taken up first by a clientele of socialites and movie stars, then copied by women everywhere who aspired to look like them. The news trickled down. But fashion hasn't worked that way in years. With most designers finding their inspiration in the street and everyone, rich and not-so-rich alike, walking around in Nikes, the haute couture has been increasingly relegated to the sidelines as a made-to-measure service for wealthy clients. Arnault's investment in the couture, which as recently as five years ago looked doomed to extinction, has been mistakenly hailed as a revival.
The conditions that have made for the current flurry of excitement can be traced to the rise of cable TV in the 80's. With the sudden hunger for footage of supermodels in tight dresses to help fill all those channels came a new kind of fashion, more highly theatrical and outlandish than anything that had been seen on a runway before, as designers began to play directly to the cameras. "Do they actually expect people to wear that?" was most people's reaction, and, indeed, the answer was no. Unlike the ready-to-wear, which is still obliged to sell clothes, the haute couture is no longer accountable to women's lives. "We are here to sell dreams," Arnault explains. "When you see a couture show on TV around the world, you dream. When you enter a Dior boutique and buy your lipstick, you buy something affordable, but it has the dream in it."
A marketing strategy that favors publicity stunts over what the industry calls "real clothes" and views fashion shows as entertainment, staged for the benefit of other products, threatens to sever the already tenuous connection between fashion and reality. Commendable though they may be as exercises in virtuoso dressmaking, Galliano's odalisques on laudanum and McQueen's Dallas Cowgirl dominatrixes are clearly removed from the realm of most women's experience, existing in a mediatique world of their own devising.
Arnault has borne the brunt of the outrage over these changes, but it would be hard to argue that he is responsible for them personally. Fashion, like every business, mutates in order to go where the money is, and in retrospect much of what has happened so far seems inevitable, with or without Arnault. In Dior's day, the clothes came first; in ours, they appear to be the most precarious aspect of the fashion enterprise, while perfumes and other products conceived as spin-offs have gained the upper hand.
In a photograph from one of Louis Vuitton's recent ad campaigns, a beautiful young woman wearing sunglasses, a scarf and a mink coat is perched on a motorbike, her Vuitton train case and hatbox strapped to the back. The picture is framed and hanging on the wall in Concetta Lanciaux's office, a reminder of the mythological customer that the people at Louis Vuitton have in mind: somebody young and rich with a wanderlust. In March, Marc Jacobs proposed a wardrobe for her, in Vuitton's first ready-to-wear collection since its founding 144 years ago by the royal clothes packer for the Empress Eugenie.
At the show, members of the American press, seated opposite Arnault, kept stealing glances at him, trying to gauge his reaction. The French journalists seemed perplexed. There was a certain reverse snobbery in the extreme at work in items like plain white cotton poplin raincoats (this is luxury?) with no visible indication of their provenance: the logo, as it turned out, was on the button's underside; the signature tape was sewn into the lining. As if to insist that the clothes -- cashmere sweaters, double-face skirts, narrow pants -- be seen on their own terms and not as a backdrop for the house's accessories, there were none: no Vuitton bags or anything else that might enable an onlooker to make the connection.
Intentionally or (more likely) inadvertently, this was a collection that called our motives for buying luxury goods into question by posing a challenge: are you willing to embrace a product that makes recognizing the brand difficult, if not impossible? This absence of all the usual indications -- with the logos hidden, with no design element so distinctive and consistent that it could serve as a signature for the brand (as quilted leather has for Chanel) -- elevated connoisseurship to a secret code. Only someone who was really in the know could trace these clothes to Louis Vuitton. It's a small club.
Over the course of the past few decades, trademarks like Ralph Lauren's polo player, Chanel's back-to-back C's, Gucci's G's and Louis Vuitton's initials have become status symbols that come at a price. But now that even the most inexpensive products are strewn with corporate graffiti and a plain version of practically anything is impossible to find, it's not so hard to imagine a time when we might prize the product that is logo-free as the rarest and most precious of all. And, in an ironic reversal, we might even be obliged to pay more for it. When every product is conceived as an advertisement for its manufacturer, with some blatant trademark as a part of the "design," consumers who refuse to serve as human billboards will have to compensate the company for the attendant loss of publicity.
"Luxury has been wrongly associated with the unattainable," Andree Putman, the French interior designer, has said. Wrongly, but understandably. Among the various utopian notions perpetrated in this century, several have been intent on bringing good design to the masses. This was one of the early modernists' most cherished goals -- this vision of an egalitarian society in which beautiful things could be enjoyed by everyone, not only the rich, and we would all be better people for it. The idealism that informed their landmark efforts has waned, however, and the impulse to spread the material joy around has lately given way to the cynical conviction that the finer things aren't simply one of life's many rewards -- they're the only reward, as each of us makes a grab for the best toys.
To Jean-Louis Dumas-Hermes's way of thinking, the purpose of Hermes is to help people "to become a little more themselves." I shop, therefore I am, and here is who I am: the Manolo Blahnik shoes, the Hermes bag, the Fendi coat, the Michael Kors sweater, the Dolce & Gabbana pants form a constellation of brands that we use to define ourselves -- to ourselves and to other people.
We are witnessing the democratization of luxury: the trophies that once beckoned to us from the highest shelf have been brought dowm to eye level. But, of course, they're worth less for being that much more accessible. Asked what role luxury goods now play in people's lives, Berge replies: "Real luxury doesn't exist anymore. Real luxury was for the 'happy few,' and there is no more 'happy few.' Or, there is 'the few,' but they're not 'happy."' In a world in which so many different brands compete for our attention, the prestige of one seems to cancel out another, and "the best" is the latest, the hottest, the most talked about.
When the young fashion-conscious tourist with a three-hour layover at Heathrow comes upon a Louis Vuitton bag designed by Marc Jacobs, she remembers that she saw it featured in last month's Vogue. The monogram pattern is familiar -- a latticework of L's and V's -- but instead of the standard, stenciled beige on brown, it is embossed, white on white, on patent leather. Between the traditional version and this new monochromatic rendition lies a world of difference, to this young woman's way of thinking: it is the difference between her parents' friends and her own friends, between the commonplace and the rare, between mere wealth and taste. She buys the bag, secure in the knowledge that it positions her a cut above the old Louis Vuitton customers.
The pleasure she takes in it will derive as much from the aura that attaches to it as from the design and the workmanship -- until in time our restless imaginations leave the bag behind and it loses the power it once had, divested of what Arnault calls "the dream." Robert Browning said that a man's reach should exceed his grasp, which for years described most people's relationship to life's biggest prizes. But that was before Arnault brought luxury to the masses. Now, with his help, we grasp at the trappings of happiness and discover that it's a moving target, changing before our eyes.

PUB-DATE: July 12, 1998

SECTION: Section 6; Page 34; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 1547 words

HEADLINE: Socko Finish

BYLINE: By Thomas Lynch; Thomas Lynch is an undertaker in Milford, Mich. A book of his poems, Still Life In Milford, will be published in September.

 BODY:
My son and I were moving caskets -- an oak with Celtic crosses on the corners, a cherry with a finish like that of our dining-room table, a cardboard box with a reinforced bottom, caskets that could be buried, burned, blown into space or set adrift. (The boomers who are buying funerals now do better with a broad selection.) I was talking to him about " protection," about condoms and careful choices and coming of age. He'd been out too late the night before.
But my son has heard this speech already; he and his siblings, all in their 20's, occupy a place where pleasure and risk intersect, so they are experts in cautionary tales. In a display room full of caskets and cremation urns, he would rather talk about his future. 
 He says he wants to be a funeral director. He wonders if I'd ever sell to S.C.I. -- Service Corporation International, the Barnes & Noble of the funeral biz. They're buying up firms like ours across the globe: Frank E. Campbell's in Manhattan; Kenyon's in London, which used to bury the royals. Closer to home, in Michigan, they bought out our nearest competition last year. The talk in the trade is that they raise prices, cut services, put in a fleet of telemarketers to push "preneed" sales and pay their shareholders handsomely. They are aggressively positioning themselves for the baby-boom years, the next 20 or 30, when the number of annual deaths in the United States will grow by a million compared with today. The boomers' presence is already being felt, of course -- some are dying, many more are buying funerals for their parents.
 "The only problem is they buy your name," I tell my son. "It's all you really have." The name on the sign -- ours says Lynch & Sons -- is the one they call in the middle of the night when there's trouble. It's the one that makes you accountable to the community you live in, the one asset we can't replace and dare not sell.
My father taught me about protection. It was the late 1960's, early 70's. We'd go into the casket-selection room at the funeral home. He'd play the undertaker -- no stretch for him. I'd be the bereaved client with a dead mother -- pure theater for me. My mother was going strong back then, full of life. I was floundering between college and career, not quite certain about my "future," interested mostly in Irish poetry and Italian women. I worked at the funeral home to finance my travels and indecision. I caught the phones at night, slept in the apartment on the second floor, kept my passport handy, my bag packed.
"The first one you show them is very important," my father said. "It establishes the mid-range, the average. You know, not the most expensive and not the least." He stopped beside a steel model called Praying Hands, named for the applique in the cap panel. He lifted the velvet overlay to expose the rubber gasket. "The most important difference between one casket and another has to do with its protective qualities," he said earnestly. "Most of the metal caskets in this room are what we call sealed caskets, because of this gum-rubber gasket that runs around the perimeter of the shell."
"Who cares?" I'd say, playing the doubting Thomas. "Isn't she dead?" He showed me the crank used to seal the lid shut, and then he handed me this "key."
"To some families protection is very important." He paused. "To others it means nothing at all." The message was obvious: which kind of family are you from?
Then he displayed the various materials: mahogany, oak, cherry, steel and the top-of-the-line, one that shone like a bright new penny. "This is solid copper, a permanent metal. Unlike steel, which might rust or corrode, copper oxidizes with age. It gets stronger and stronger. These
precious metals are the best value in protective caskets." The room hummed with anticipation as I thought it through.
Stronger, protective . . . Mom?
Protection and permanence were organizing ideas of my parents' generation. Children of economic collapse and a planet constantly at war, they were schooled against waste and letting down their guard. There was general, low-grade anxiety over "exposure" and liabilities. Well-engineered tampons, movie ratings, underarm deodorants -- each offered defense against some contagion, embarrassment or invader.
In the years that have passed since my father taught me caskets, I have sold my share of them. We don't push protection anymore. "Choice" is the buzzword. Everything is customized. The generation now in the market for mortuary wares is redefining death in much the same way that, three decades back, it redefined sex and gender.
If my father sold caskets on protection and permanence, I offer choices, options, New Age alternatives. Where he occupied a world of black and white, custom and tradition, moral certainty, my fellow boomers still see our rights and wrongs as relative; we roll our own orthodoxies.
Always the demographic bullies on the block, boomers are now grieving and dying, so grief and death are all the rage. The market is bullish on ritual and metaphor, for acting out our hurts the way our ancients did. Whether we burn or bury our dead is less important than what we do before we dispose of them. Boomers are hustling to reinvent the rituals that got our parents and their parents through age and sickness and sadness and loss, in case, just in case, it could happen to us. Faced with the deaths of the ones we love, we are stuck between the will to do everything, anything and nothing at all.
Back at the funeral home the hot topics (forgive me) are cremation and designer funerals. Members of my parents' generation, in their 70's now, are behaving as their boomer children once did -- fast and mobile, they're buying motor homes and time shares in casino towns, and they do not want their lives or deaths to be a burden to their kids. They do not want to be "grounded" to the graves they bought when people stayed put and always came home. Their ashes are Fed-Exed around the hemisphere in little packages, roughly the weight of a bowling ball. Not nearly the life-size burden of a casket, not nearly the bother or expense. They get sent back from Florida and Phoenix, to old homes in the cold north and Rust Belt states.
Still, their sons and daughters, in receipt of these tiny reminders, are beginning to wonder: Is that all there is? Is it enough to get out our cell phones and our Gold Cards and have our dead elders disappear with no more pause than it takes to order up sushi to go? Can we distance ourselves entirely from the physical realities of death and still expect to enjoy the physical wonders of life? Is a good bargain on a funeral really such a good deal if it doesn't do the job of properly commemorating death? Even the late Jessica Mitford, that priestess of simplicity, whose "American Way of Death Revisited" is due out from Knopf next month, had a lavish multimedia farewell in London last year.
Hence, more and more, we boomers care for our own dying. More and more we are making up new liturgies to say goodbye. More and more we seem willing to engage fully in the process of leave-taking. We rise early to watch the televised departures of princesses and modern saints. We read the obituaries every day. We eulogize, elegize and memorialize with vigor. The trade is brisk in wakes and funerals that offer a personalized touch. My father's generation did copper and concrete and granite memorials. We do biodegradables, economy models and ecofriendly cyberobsequies. He sold velvet and satin and crepe interiors. We do urns that look like golf bags and go to cemeteries with names like golf courses. You can buy a casket off the Internet, or buy plans for a self-built "coffin table" or one that doubles as a bookshelf until you "need" it. There's a push for "do it yourself" funerals -- as if grief were ever anything but. Cremated remains can be recycled as memorial kitty litter, sprinkled on rosebushes, mixed with our oil paints to add texture to fresh masterpieces.
We have, as the Batesville Casket Company calls its latest marketing approach, Options. And as the demographic aneurysm gets nearer to bursting in two or three decades, the marketplace is readying for another boom. Soon, every off-ramp on the interstate across the continent will have a Burger King, Barnes & Noble and Funerals "R" Us. Telemarketers are busy interrupting our dinners, selling us choices from the ridiculous to the sublime, from bang to whimper, and everywhere between. The fashions change. The feelings seldom do.
The facts of life and death remain the same. We live and die, we love and grieve, we breed and disappear. And between these existential gravities, we search for meaning, save our memories, leave a record for those who will remember us.
I am the age my father was when I was my son's age. Figure that. Halfway between the half a century between those two -- sometimes it seems that we repeat ourselves. I hear my father's caution in the way I caution him about life's changes and dangers, about drugs and drink and being "sexually active." We talk about making responsible choices, safe sex, committed relationships, condoms and consequences: permanence and protection come round again.
One of these days I'll have to teach them caskets.

HEADLINE: On Language;
Ratcheting Up the Periscope

BYLINE: By William Safire 

 BODY:
Anticipating tension among the heirs to Frank Sinatra's estate, Joshua Hammer wrote in Newsweek about Ol' Blue Eyes' will, "It's certain to ratchet up the family feud even higher."
A puzzled Marie Balandis of Houston writes: "My dictionary defines ratchet as a noun meaning 'a pawl, click or detent for holding or propelling a ratchet wheel.' Will be looking for your column on ratchet." 
 Here it is, and you need a newer dictionary.
Every mechanic knows that a ratchet is a toothed wheel or bar used to prevent a gizmo from moving backward. That sawlike catch is what gives us all confidence in elevators and the courage to jack up a car to change a tire. But this word (from the Old German roccho, "spindle") has been reborn with new senses.
The ratchet effect has seized economics, and to ratchet up -- "to move upward in increments" -- is a verb phrase that has thrust aside the previously voguish escalate. (Raise was long ago lowered, and increase has shrunk.)
Prof. James Duesenberry of Harvard launched ratchet effect in a 1948 doctoral thesis that became a seminal macroeconomic book the next year: "Income, Saving and the Theory of Consumer Behavior." He took the ratchet to be a device that enables something to move easily up but prevents it from moving easily all the way down, and applied that metaphor to the way we spend our money. In 1979, Daedalus magazine described the theory as beginning "with the common wisdom that prices go up more freely than they go down."
But that's only the beginning. I asked Prof. William Doyle of the University of Dallas to simplify Duesenberry's theory for me, and it boils down to this: "It's easier for a household to adapt its expenditures to an increase in income than to a decrease in income. When income increases, consumption spending increases; but when income falls, consumers who have come to view their standard of living as 'normal' are very reluctant to decrease consumption spending." That's the ratchet effect: when you've been up there, you tend to spend as if you're still there -- even when you can no longer afford it. Reached in Boston, the emeritus Professor Duesenberry recalls: "I think the ratchet I was familiar with was a car jack. I thought about the ratchet on a car jack and thought of it as an analogy to what was happening. It's an asymmetrical response."
According to Merriam-Webster, the editor of Barron's magazine, Robert Bleiberg, first used the phrasal verb ratchet up on April 10, 1972: "In a striking reversal of policy, the Fed in recent weeks has ratcheted upward the repo a collateralized short-term loan rate to 4 percent." Five years later, Britain's Margaret Thatcher, on her way to becoming Prime Minister, latched on to the image: "Britain is no longer in the politics of the pendulum, but of the ratchet."
Economists still love the saw-toothed image, but came to use it in a broader sense. "If you build in wages and other benefits based upon an exaggerated Consumer Price Index," warned Paul Volcker when he was Fed chairman in 1981, "you ratchet up inflation."
Now it calibrates any rise. "Tension in the border war between Ethiopia and Eritrea," reported Agence France-Presse a few months ago, "ratcheted up a notch."
And Michael Kelly, in his column enlivening the weekly National Journal, dreamed up ways that Democrats would continue to try to embarrass Republicans with anti-tobacco bills, concluding, "The pain level ratchets up, and sooner or later, the theory goes, the G.O.P. caves."
Needed: a phrase meaning "to lower by degrees, to decrease in increments." Ratchet down may be justified mechanically, but it doesn't do it metaphorically.
 
SLOW BOAT TO JAPAN
Never underestimate the ability of dour business executives to come up with colorful word pictures. A system allowing interest rates to rise or fall only within a narrow range was called the snake in the tunnel; a stock rally doomed to be short-lived is a dead-cat bounce.
Japan has the Gososendan-hoshiki. To break it down, Goso means "shipped with protection"; sen is "ship"; dan is "group." Hoshiki is "system." English translation: "the convoy system."
When Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin decided to intervene in the currency markets to support the yen, he had just been assured that Tokyo would take action against the convoys. Last month David Wessel wrote in The Wall Street Journal that Japanese officials promised "that Japan finally will abandon what is called the 'convoy system,' which essentially involves strong companies bailing out weak ones -- often under pressure from regulators -- so that everyone stays afloat."
Vivid metaphor. A convoy is a group, usually of ships, organized to move in a way that best protects the whole group. In World War II "action in the North Atlantic," Allied convoys supplying Britain were assembled to ward off Nazi submarines, and it became a truism that "a convoy moves as slowly as its slowest ship."
In the current Japanese trope, the Gososendan-hoshiki consists of strong and weak banks; the strong banks hold afloat the weak ones. By breaking up the convoy, central bankers around the world hope to allow the Japanese banks weakened by bad loans to sink and the strong to survive.
The hero-villain metaphor has been reversed; in this case, the good guys are the U-boat commanders busting up the self-protective convoys and picking off the laggards. Ratchet up that periscope. Fire Vun!
