HEADLINE: Big Tobacco's Endgame

 BODY:
When I was 13 years old, growing up in the tobacco-growing region of southern Georgia, I cropped tobacco by hand for $5 per day and all I could eat for lunch. In my community, tobacco put shoes on kids' feet, bought the four pairs of blue jeans they needed to get through the school year and eventually sent them off to college to build a new life that didn't involve breaking their backs, in three-digit temperatures, to pay their way.
When I was 29, I stood at my father's hospital bed when his internist told him he had an oat-cell-type cancer growing in his left lung. 
 At 31, I buried him. He had been a lifelong Winston smoker, 43 years -- not counting the two years he quit while undergoing chemotherapy and waiting to die.
At 40, I was feeding and clothing my own kids with commissions I earned from selling magazine advertising space to RJR Nabisco. When I would sit in the company's offices in Winston-Salem and refuse an offer to enjoy a Camel over a business discussion, a little voice kept whispering "hypocrite" in my ear.
No one has to explain to me the conundrum in which this nation and the tobacco companies find themselves. Tobacco's tentacles reach as deep into this country's economy as the cancer it causes does into humans. Its use metastasizes in our society from adults, who should know better, to young people, who think they will never die. But it has fed families and educated children, too.
 
Carlton Alvin Roberts
New York

SECTION: Section 2; Page 27; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk

HEADLINE: CLASSICAL MUSIC;
A Composer's Lament: The Music Goes Soft

BYLINE: By MATTHIAS KRIESBERG; Matthias Kriesberg, an American composer, lives in New York.

 BODY:
ONE morning some 25 years ago, the composer Chou Wen-Chung regaled those of us in his music analysis class with reports of musical life in China. So pervasive was the application of Maoist doctrine, we were told, that music was written by committee. When a piece was completed, it was presented to the farmers' collective for criticism. We all had a good laugh.
Now consider this sentence from an article by a composer formerly in residence at a top American orchestra, describing a response to a commission: "I walked through my community, knocking on doors, and asked people what sort of piece they would like." (Good thinking: this composer went to the farmers before writing the piece.) 
 I have often imagined my response if I had received that knock at my door: "You know, I've always been fond of intricate relationships involving E flat, F sharp and C sharp." Or: "You're the composer. You got the commission. Now go home and write the piece you believe in, and don't worry about what I expect."
But to suggest today that writing music is about more than pleasing an audience is to commit the most horrific cultural crime of the late, late 20th century: "elitism." There is broad agreement across the political spectrum: wisdom resides in the will of the people. Granted, our embrace of the collective philosophy we used to mock has a new twist; yesterday's masses are today's marketplace. And since the power of the market is the flip side of democracy, you can't challenge one without ostensibly opposing the other. So even contemporary classical composition -- not exactly in the mainstream of everyday life -- becomes validated in proportion to the number of people served.
Responsiveness to audience demand has become an obsession. Some months ago, a successful composer described his compositional process in a radio interview: "When I write, I imagine being in the audience and ask myself what it would feel like to hear this passage." Another composer, quoted in The New York Times, stated that his highest ambition was to make new music "accessible."
Partisans of accessibility flaunt their righteous anger. Some weeks ago in these pages, Peter Gelb, the president of Sony Classical, made the perfectly reasonable case that he has a fiduciary obligation to his company to issue recordings that are likely to make a profit, and that he is entitled to advocate the music he believes in. Then he declared, "Serialism will have to start sharing space on concert hall programs with new music of broader appeal." When he delivered the same message to those of us attending the Salzburg Seminar in Austria, last December, he was asked incredulously which composers were supposed to step aside.
After all, the most frequently performed American composers today seem comfortable with the notion that audience response is a legitimate indicator of musical value. Yet for the last 15 years -- at least since the New York Philharmonic's 1983 new-music festival, "A New Romanticism?" -- we have been tirelessly informed that a cabal of composers continues to dominate concert programming and that the public has yet to be liberated by composers daring enough to write music people love. Even now, a generation after the routing of the Gang of Serialists, the battles are recited breathlessly, as if at this very moment we are in mortal danger of succumbing to the forces of elitism. Why keep pumping bullets into the dead?
It is telling that this "liberating" musical style is defined by audience response rather than in musical terms. The old new music, we are told, disdained the audience; the new new music does not. (For the record, the opposite is closer to the truth. The bad-old composers naively believed that audiences would eventually hear what the composer heard; the good-new accessibilists assume that audiences are unimaginative and impatient.)
What no one wants to acknowledge publicly is that the current stylistic evolution in contemporary classical music may have more to do with economic forces than with purely musical considerations. Here is part of a letter I received from someone in a position to know the state of mind of one of our prominent New Romantic composers: "His experience as composer-in-residence was an important matter. Once he found that if the conductor, the orchestra, the critics and the audience liked a piece, it was worth 30 or 40 thousand dollars a crack; he and his wife drove better cars. Isn't the long-term problem of every serious composer how to write music that satisfies oneself while making a living doing so?"
Actually, no. These are separate problems, and they should not be confused. A surgeon has an obligation to perform surgery only when it is appropriate. That he or she may also need to pay off the mortgage on a fine home does not mean that the doctor's "long-term problem" is how to get patients to require expensive surgery. (Such a distinction is especially important if the doctor in question is yours.)
The trouble is, we are in love with two contradictory principles. One is that a composer should write music that flows unimpeded from his or her imagination. The other is that "user-friendly" products are superior. It is no accident that the last 20 years have seen an ever stronger demand that composers make their music more directly useful to the needs of the "community." In America today, authority and wealth are won by the endorsement or purchasing power of vast numbers of people. Our decision makers, even in the arts, increasingly come from the ranks of those who find popular success and intrinsic value indistinguishable, who consider successful marketing synonymous with freedom of expression. Uncomfortable with the uneasy fit of serious music into contemporary culture, they proclaim the need to redefine classical music.
You can't have it both ways. Remember the official in the Reagan Administration who, seeking to cut school lunch subsidies but confronting the requirement that lunches include two vegetables, proposed redefining ketchup as a vegetable? Markets generate great wealth, but that doesn't mean that artistic principles can be rewritten to accommodate them. (Granted, the urge to try can be irresistible. Nowadays a composer practically has to be world-famous just to pay the rent.)
A few years ago, I was in an airplane awaiting takeoff, idly looking at one of those "calm-the-mind" videos. It was a meandering sequence of nature images with a soundtrack of watered-down Minimalism. As it turned out, the flight was held on the ground so long that the film ran right through to the credits, and I learned that the parties responsible were Godfrey Reggio and Philip Glass.
In the early 80's this filmmaker and composer created "Koyanisqaatsi." That memorable and original work inspired Francis Ford Coppola to produce a sequel, "Powaqaatsi." Geared to wider appeal, it lacked the imagination and emotional weight of its predecessor. Now comes "Anima Mundi," commissioned by a company that markets videos to the airline industry.
It is an evolution worth pondering. Because Mr. Glass's Minimalist style imparted cohesion to whatever medium it was attached to, his music became eminently desirable to choreographers, theater directors, filmmakers and producers of television advertising. This statement implies no lack of integrity on the part of the composer. It is simply a characteristic of his music that it is an ideal passenger on other creators' vehicles. Ten minutes of largely redundant gestures in the medium of sound make what you see in another medium appear very convincing.
Mr. Glass's music is now a useful commodity. Its capacity to flatter has brought it to the attention of a much larger audience than would otherwise have encountered it. Since audience size is vital to the media and music industries (both consumed by the task of capturing a market), Mr. Glass is celebrated as a composer who "broke out of the box."
Such a successful career obscures the fact that American composers no longer control the direction of contemporary music with an authority comparable to that exercised by creators in other art forms. True, composition is a relatively dependent art form to begin with. The serious money in music is generated by performance, not composition. Writers produce manuscripts, painters produce canvases, but composers typically respond to commissions. Most of our contemporary music is either neo-conservative or neo-populist. It almost begs for acceptance.
Let's recall what drove a century of glorious achievement in painting and sculpture. A relatively small number of collectors followed their own taste and convictions and bought work they believed in. Painting and sculpture are tangible commodities, but the essential point is that artistic success was not achieved because millions of people purchased reproductions. Individuals with the ability to make a difference exercised creative artistic judgment.
The same could happen with contemporary composition if even a few people of wealth, appreciating what was at stake, dedicated themselves to the future of serious music. The Los Angeles music patron Betty Freeman should serve as an inspiration to those able to wield the powerful combination of conviction and money. The key is engaging actively in the direct support of creative choices: not leaving to others the selection of composers to support. Only direct involvement will empower composers to resume a position of leadership in their profession.
And that's exactly what is going to happen. The triumph of popular judgment over the power of artistic worth cannot be sustained forever. Sooner or later, individuals of financial means will step forward out of profound dissatisfaction with our parade of new music and its split agenda: to be art and to be nice. The market economy that has obliged new music to conform to popular protocols has also generated nearly unimaginable wealth. It's a safe bet that some of that is in the hands of people who don't want all their music soft.

LENGTH: 2381 words

HEADLINE: FILM;
The Fits-and-Starts Education Of a Movie-World Beginner

BYLINE: By BARRY YOURGRAU; Barry Yourgrau's new book of fiction, "Haunted Traveller," will be published next year by Arcade.

 BODY:
IN late 1994 a film was made that centered on me and my dark whimsies about romance and heartbreak: "The Sadness of Sex," from my book of the same name. Here's my sorry tale of how this odd independent movie was brought briefly to the screen -- and then to the shelf, where it now sits, maybe for good. The story is my two cents toward the updating of "Candide" that famously takes place when a neophyte like me gets involved in the mad, bad world of glamour-grabbing and economic hardball that is the film business.
And it even stars Peta Wilson. 
 "Spalding Gray is like Woody Allen; you're like -- Fellini!" cried Rupert Wainwright, a director of big-money television commercials, that night in February 1994. He had just seen my spoken-word act at the Luna Park club in Los Angeles and had been inspired then and there to scratch notes for a performance movie.
Yes, I remember his effusions exactly. As a bicoastal bohemian -- a creature of Paris Review salons and hipster cabarets like Luna Park and New York's Fez, plus a few minutes on "MTV Unplugged" -- here I was finally going to draw my ticket to the commercialization of a career: my own "Swimming to Cambodia." At 45, I made a somewhat hoary Candide.
On the other hand, for Rupert, in his mid-30's, the project was a mad pure-hearted stroke to save his esthetic soul from Ballpark Franks spots, Michael Jackson promos and "Home Alone" knockoffs. Sure, he had a Grammy for his Hammer videos. But big, blond Rupert was also an Oxford English-literature grad.
Looking back, I see that the pathos surrounding both our ambitions wags the tale of "The Sadness of Sex" -- as do our brands of hubris and naivete. Yet credit Rupert for a real miracle, which is the one of getting our unconventionally unconventional movie made at all.
Yes, we began so miraculously, before the farce to come last year in Los Angeles, where the film had a short run, and the shock in New York this spring, when to top everything I got called a "smug lecher" in a review, even though the film ended up not opening at all.
For two glorious, brutal weeks we shot in Toronto's chill fall of '94. A Canadian commercials-production firm had put up half a million dollars -- finally, in what I would come to know well as the film business's puckish, yes-no, yes-no style. Under Rupert's lash I took to the stage and hammed to the camera the stories he and I had shaped into my surreal romantic history.
Then on location for story re-enactments, I did a screen kiss, heart pounding, with a young blond Australian ex-model. A couple of years later, she would be widely known as the star of television's "La Femme Nikita." To my shock -- that word again (the script called for body doubles) -- Peta Wilson and I wound up in a closed-set naked love scene. I had another shock, on another closed set. Outdoors, dressed like Sam Spade, I climbed a shaky fire ladder to fetch a runaway vagina up a tree. I shook, myself, in fear and authorial jubilation.
"This film makes 'Swimming to Cambodia' look like an infomercial," some bumptious soul cackled in post-production.
Oh, indeed. Fully assembled, it was a cross between MTV and "Aida," plus a splash of Hallmark cards. The photography was sumptuous, with Peta blazing in negligee and angels' wings; an editor from "Natural Born Killers" had kaleidoscoped my 90-minute solo with live-action sequences, animation, video footage and photo stills, and Rupert and the big-time music supervisor from "J.F.K." had brought in a marquee-worthy original soundtrack for a pittance.
On screen, "The Sadness of Sex" was a grandiose, double oddity: a quirky little art film cranked to a fare-the-well by loving, Hollywood-savvy hands. It blinded any grainy indie stereotype.
Was I, the author, happy with this extravagant movie version of me and my whimsies? Today, I might hem about sensibilities. At the time, happy wasn't the word. I was thrilled.
The film festivals weren't. All the majors and many minors -- including the hometown event in Toronto -- turned us down.
Because we didn't look cheap enough, snorted one of our distribution agents, trying to steady my distress. These agents had been crucial in attracting financing. They were big in feature-to-television rights ("Robocop" the series); at selling movies like ours, they were new.
Finally the Hamptons festival threw open its arms. Rupert jetted in from the Great Wall of China, where he was filming a commerical. We had buzz, a journalist told me (though he hadn't seen the film). A wisecracking 20-year-old from Brooklyn who showed part of a rough-cut on video got one of the extra jury awards. The glories of "The Sadness of Sex" got no award -- and no distribution offer. Rupert could have taken the boat.
He and I sat our version of an indie post-mortem at a TriBeCa restaurant, with Richard Harris, father of Peta's boyfriend. The Irish film star stroked the tiny dog that was snuggling inside his shirt, gave Rupert thumbs up and burred on about "the great Joe Losey." Misty-eyed, Rupert swore to me that whatever it took, he would find us a distributor.
Such grand moments fortified for a while, until the mixed review in Variety. I barely registered "original and often provocative," "excessive MTV-like style," "commercial prospects skimpy" and "tech credits nothing short of stunning" because I found myself referred to, prominently, as Peta Wilson. First I had given up credit, on screen, as an author (no mention of the underlying book, only "written by Barry Yourgrau and Rupert Wainwright") -- and now, in the industry trade paper, I had vanished as a performer! Who'd God put in charge of movies, Don Rickles?
But what's a few flying pies, when a whole cruel bakery awaits.
Nothing came of Slamdance, the counter-festival to Sundance; nothing of San Jose, where our sumptuous reels showed in wrong order. Rupert perched away gallantly in distributors' offices with a line about "another 'Il Postino.' " No one agreed, for months on end.
I wasn't handling it well. I hadn't the nerves. I couldn't understand: we had people who loved the film whenever we screened it; why wouldn't somebody take a chance on us?
"Because, Barry," blurted David Lancaster, our senior producer, "it's still essentially 90 minutes of one guy talking. Spalding Gray already had a name, from theater!"
I could feel my Big Break slipping away. Frantic, I became someone who showed up at dinner parties with a video clip.
Enter, magically it seemed, Tara Releasing, with the original Dutch thriller "The Vanishing" to its release credit. It was, of course, a so-called "micro-distributor." Its president mainly ran a canoe-rental business.
"The Sadness of Sex" opened in its glory at a reputable Los Angeles art house in the spring of '97, right after April Fools' Day -- appropriately so, given the wincing Hollywood sendup of independent-film ambitions to follow.
Comic highlights: Rupert rushing the two of us, plus cell phone, around Sunset Strip in his new Jag convertible, to Scotchtape our homemade deluxe mini-posters onto mailboxes and lamps, beneath the towering billboard of my "Sadness" lovemate, now far off being Nikita to millions; literary bohemian movie star riding public transport daily to Rupert's grand suite on the Sony lot, to publicity-monger on the phones, which was all the author-performer really did anymore.
More comic highlights: director and movie star roaming supermarket lots and pedestrian malls with Xeroxes of glowing review ("a striking film" -- The Los Angeles Times), getting chased at high speed out of the Directors' Guild parking garage for plastering windshields; anguished studio-lot conference calls to a northern California canoe-rental shop, pleading for posters, ads, promotional help; hangdog bohemian movie star ("ideal for the camera" -- The Los Angeles Times) and resolute linen-suited millionaire director ("expands the boundaries of cinema" -- New Times) trudging side by side, night after night, from windshield to windshield down the winding curbsides, the Hollywood sign looming in the dark behind them.
It was, altogether, a triumph of leafleting. "Thought you guys already had a distributor," someone wondered at the Los Angeles Independent Film Festival, as we worked the lobby.
Tara drifted out of business, slowly and over dim months of nothing, without announcement. "The Sadness of Sex" became ours again. Lucky us. We had a jazzed-up one-man movie with a great Los Angeles Time review, other fine blurbs -- and a feeble couple-of-weeks run featuring a box-office gross to make any distributor laugh and claw his hair.
By now Rupert and I were the only ones with anything really to gain from an opening in New York, instead of going right to video, with Peta on the box cover. But Rupert and I would not give up on the New York prestige, the attention. I was desperately sure we'd find our audience here, where our incorrect blend of high gloss, absurd poetic poignancies and young beauties in lingerie would be treated as, say, a sexy European-style vision (more like Fellini, perhaps, than "Il Postino").
"Not European," a Spanish journalist friend calculated subtly. "Australian."
Rupert finagled a small self-release budget from our television sales to eastern Europe (as part of a package with "The Last Don" mini-series). Screen space in Manhattan art houses is a jungle, ruled by Miramax and other big beasts. But there we were, booked prettily at a venerable showcase for quality unaffiliated eccentricities and sexy European features. Peta agreed to fly in for promotion. I went into hyping overdrive.
On Feb. 13, a Friday (when else?), the polling came back from our first press screening. "Shocking" won't do it. Few major reviewers had attended, and none had tipped their hands, but the viewers who did were united in a hiss of contempt. It was as if our glam literary bauble had committed a cultural outrage of criminal pretentiouness. The second screening was hardly better. We were aghast.
Rupert -- Rupert, who I would boast had switched agents to make this film, who had never given up, who had kissed me at the end of filming for giving him back his life -- Rupert, my champion, had just been green-lighted for a big-budget Hollywood movie. It was his first studio project since Disney's "Blank Check" in '94. I could hear the struggle in his voice. Tortured conference calls revealed his overriding concern: a bad review of "The Sadness of Sex" must not appear in The New York Times on the Friday we opened. He would not risk a review then -- at all.
I heard myself sputtering heroic cliches: he was captain of our ship (I'd just seen "Titanic"); we were proud of what we'd done, should ride it to its end and keep courage. Rupert informed me, tautly, that those metaphors meant nothing to him.
Finally he gave in to having "The Sadness of Sex" open -- on the condition that no reviewer from The Times would see it in time for Friday review. He canceled the remaining screenings (which he had been paying for; he had already called off the premiere party), and schemed a delay in screening cassettes going out to the news media. Our publicity agent informed me that she was in the business of publicizing films, not hiding them.
I had always cleaved to Rupert, out of gratitude and because I felt that he had the most power of us all and that his ambition ultimately served mine. Now I found myself in a nightmare, joining with the producer Lancaster, who was as appalled as I was, in not interfering as screening cassettes went out as normal. I waited in mutinous double-dread for the premiere.
The theater, which knew none of this, trumped all this amateur gore by canceling on us, four days to go. I heard the punch line as I stood with The New Yorker in my hands: "The Sadness of Sex" was featured in its film listings that week with "The Big Lebowski." I was due on radio in an hour.
It was something about us not spending enough on ads and missing a round of them. There was nothing we could do or say. Another film was already in or slot. Imploring got us nowhere.
So, ads had to be pulled frantically; desperate calls had to be made, appealing that reviews be held -- especially to the weeklies, which were already going to press. "If a bad review shows up in a weekly, no one else's going to book us; it's over!" cried Lancaster. What a setup line.
The next day, on cue, The Village Voice finished its review in this way: "Yourgrau hogs the camera, oozing lecherous self-satisfaction." On line, the headline was positively waggish: "15 Short Films About a Smug Lecher." Some epitaph for a movie about a man walking around sighing and being sad a lot.
In the aftermath, the owners of the theater, as distinct from its booker, were chagrined to learn what had happened. They have offered an open, certain date. But our release budget has been pretty much exhausted. I'm informed that Anthology Film Archives seems interested. And a video deal may be forthcoming. I told an indie-filmmaker friend from Los Angeles the whole story, and she laughed and said she would probably have done as Rupert did.
I rang him up just now, to note that I was writing my candid take on our movie-to-screen experience, and wondering what his reflections might be. We hadn't spoken since early March; he had been busy, I gathered, with "Toby's Story,' his religious thriller for MGM.
I must say our talk wasn't pleasant. Rupert insisted vehemently that his New York actions were solely to give "The Sadness of Sex" a chance in the theater, before the critics tore it to bits, as seemed their wont. What's more, after all the toil, all the money he had spent on our film, he felt hurt and outraged at what he saw as the possibility of my stabbing him in the back.
Which shows that a sense of betrayal in the movies is a feeling not exclusive to anyone. That grand Hollywood term "lawsuit" floated over the telephone wire.
Maybe that's the inevitable place to end a film-world tale. But let's try for a happier finis. Me, I've actually had another book optioned -- by a studio. Dennis Hopper tantalized briefly, on something else. Billy Bob Thornton, too. No new Candide-ian miracles yet. But at least I get to change topics from you-know-what.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 1; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 2660 words

HEADLINE: POP/JAZZ;
A Burst of Rock, Bright as the Rising Sun

BYLINE: By NEIL STRAUSS 

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
IT is a decrepit and smoky basement club, but the place is jammed with girls screaming for the Outsiders, a band led by a charismatic long-haired guitarist who shakes his mane as he puts one foot on a stage monitor and lets rip a thunderous solo that shakes the room. Terri MacMillan, a music manager, watches with a banana grin, convinced that she has found a future superstar. She can picture him headlining arenas to mobs of guys playing air guitar and teen-aged girls screaming his name. She is literally jumping up and down in rapture. Only we are not in New York, Seattle or Omaha. We are in Tokyo. And Ms. MacMillan is the only other American in the club.
"I'm convinced that this is happening," she says excitedly, "but the problem is convincing everybody else. It's just like Britain all over again, only everyone is afraid." 
 Ms. MacMillan is referring to the explosion of Japanese pop and rock music. For the past two decades, Japan has been home to the world's second largest music industry behind America's, but only recently, in the face of economic crisis and sweeping social change, has it reached the diversity and originality necessary to find an audience in the West.
"We've been trying to break Japanese bands overseas for 10 years -- 10 long years," says Tom Toeda, Ms. MacMillan's partner in a music management company here, Chibiya. "Now, finally, we feel we're in the right time and at the right place."
Japan today is in some ways like England circa 1960, when Americans thought of British music as just a substandard imitation of American pop. But then came the Beatles, proving that the British weren't just copying American rock and rhythm-and-blues but coming up with their own interpretations, starting a British invasion that has continued, ebbing and surging, to this day. The situation is similar in Japan: pieces of American, British and even French, German and Swedish popular music are being fused into something Japanese.
"With cars and stereos, those things are invented somewhere else," Mr. Toeda says. "Then they come to Japan; we redo it our own way and make it a little better and then put it out. So maybe that's what's happening in the music scene."
Though the Western music audience is too fragmented for another pop juggernaut on the order of the Beatles to emerge, in nearly each splinter of rock and pop there are Japanese bands good enough to rank among the upper echelons. Ms. MacMillan and Mr. Toeda, who have already taken two Japanese bands, Pizzicato Five and Buffalo Daughter, from obscurity to college-rock favorites in America, believe that all it would take is for Japan to export a handful of slightly more successful bands to bring the country closer to ranking alongside America and England as a pop and rock capital -- especially in this time of creative stagnation in popular music in America and increasing openness to Asian pop culture. Their business plan is to find unknown bands in Japan and make them stars in America before anybody has heard of them at home and then bring them back to Japan as conquering heroes. This scenario may be possible within 5 to 10 years. But is the American pop public ready?
Many American music executives are doubtful. "It will never happen," barks one label president, speaking on the condition of anonymity. "They look different than we do. They speak different than we do."
OTHERS, however, have no doubt. Besides Ms. McMillan, there are people like Steve Pross, the obsessive, excitable 42-year-old head of Emperor Norton Records, an independent label based in Los Angeles that is owned by Peter Getty, the grandson of J. Paul Getty. Three days after the Outsiders show, Mr. Pross is at a much larger club in Tokyo, proudly watching the newest addition to his label's roster, the Zoobombs, thrash on stage before a sold-out house. A great garage, punk and blues-rock band, the Zoobombs play funky grooves that explode into guitar-bashing choruses made up of single catch phrases. As the singer and guitarist Don Matsuo -- equal parts Elvis Presley, James Brown and Beck -- spits out lines like "You need to get mo' funky," some 1,000 fans pogo up and down in response.
"I think the next Beck or the next Paul McCartney is going to come from Japan," Mr. Pross says as he observes the scene from the club balcony. "And I want to be the one to find him."
Mr. Pross is in Tokyo preparing to release three albums by Japanese bands -- the Zoobombs, Takako Minekawa and Fantastic Plastic Machine -- in America as well as to find more Japanese bands to license. For Mr. Pross, one of the few American music executives actively looking for Japanese bands, running around to record stores and labels in Tokyo feels like striking oil. And he is rushing to stake a claim on as much as he can before the big corporations move in.
"After talking to you," he tells the head of one Japanese record label during a meeting, "I think my record company is going to do better licensing Japanese bands and selling them in America than licensing American bands and selling them to Japan."
So what does Japanese pop music sound like?
Going to Japan to write about its music scene is not like going to France to write about the electronic music boom there or to China to write about its rebel rockers, because there isn't a scene in Japan; there are hundreds of scenes. For those who like the testosterone-happy American rock bands Rage Against the Machine, 311 and Everclear, there are the Japanese counterparts Mad Capsule Markets, Backdrop Bomb and Thee Michelle Gun Elephant. If your tastes run to Alanis Morissette, Tori Amos and Tracy Chapman, there are Cocco, Bonnie Pink and Ua. And most of them aren't mere knockoffs. Singing in Japanese, English and "Japlish," these acts have come up with a fusion of their own, albeit one influenced by American and European bands. What's surprising is that it's not excellence in recent American music that has inspired this flowering of Japanese bands; rather, many Japanese musicians say it's the staleness of new imported rock that has given them confidence in their own music. In fact, Western music has slipped from a majority market share in Japan to less than 25 percent as Japanese bands have matured.
There are three types of Japanese musicians attracting small audiences in America. One is made up of obscure, uncompromising Japanese avant-garde bands -- psychedelic rockers like Ghost, improvisational guitarists like Keiji Haino and noise bands like Merzbow -- who have been heroes in the American underground for years. The second consists of bands that fit into niche genres -- punk, ska and especially electronic dance music, which doesn't depend on lyrics and language -- in which fans feel part of an international community of music-makers. Some of the top acts in these genres, like the punk band Hi-Standard and the techno musician Ken Ishii, already have American record deals and have sold tens of thousands of albums overseas.
The third type of Japanese band emerging in America is the most interesting because it doesn't fit into an existing style. These bands are evidence of an emerging Japanese sound and esthetic. Like reggae in Jamaica -- an attempt to replicate American rhythm-and-blues that turned into its own genre when the musicians got the beat wrong -- the Japanese sound has roots in a failed imitation. Sometimes referred to as Shibuya kei, after Tokyo's busy youth shopping district and home to foreign record chains, the Japanese style is a pop tsunami swamping everything in its path and washing it ashore in a jumble. Think of the music as an aural equivalent of Japanese commercial slogans like "Calcium loading. Get! In! Hold!" (for the drink Kirin Cadi). Its cultural appropriations bend logic, break rules and inadvertently come up with new and likable turns of phrase.
"Even the artists themselves will admit that so much of the style is built on a misinterpretation of American culture," says Bryan Burton-Lewis, who plays the music as a host on the Osaka radio station FM802 and the cable channel Space Shower TV and who also helps write lyrics for Yoshinori Sunahara, Kahimi Karie, Chara, Bridge and Cornelius. "They'll build an entire world around a few albums, TV programs and movies -- and then they finally get to America and England and find out that it's completely different than they imagined. But in the end they've created something original, a world of their own, which therefore they like better."
In a youth culture in which keeping up with trends insures popularity, coolness is a function of obsession, a trait that has helped make Japanese record stores the most extensive and impressive in the world. Some of the best Japanese bands making inroads in America -- acts like Pizzicato Five and Cornelius on Matador Records in New York, Buffalo Daughter on the Beastie Boys' label, Grand Royal, and Fantastic Plastic Machine on Emperor Norton -- are indefatigable record shoppers who mix and match every genre that interests them in their music. They worship at the altar of classic pop groups like the Beach Boys, soft-pop acts like Burt Bacharach, film composers like Ennio Morricone, rappers like Public Enemy, psychedelic rockers like Pink Floyd and French singers like Serge Gainsbourg. (Mr. Gainsbourg's use of American pop-culture phrases in his songs could be seen as evidence of a very Japanese esthetic, as could the quotation-filled music of Beck and the Jon Spencer Blues Explosion.)
I ALWAYS thought I was just making Western music," says Cornelius. "But now that people all over the world are listening to it and I'm able to get their reactions, they're telling me that they see my music as Japanese sounding. The way the information is overloaded -- even the copycat imagery -- people say is very Tokyo, very Japan. When I was told that, I realized that was true."
But there is more to the current flowering of Japanese pop and rock than simply the sound of one collector collecting. Shingo Sugiyama, an independent producer who is working with a musician whom Ms. McMillan wants to take to America -- a young, raw singer named Kayoko -- believes that Japan may be on the verge of a period analogous to the late 60's in America, when a young generation began to question the wisdom of its elders. As Japan is learning the economic lesson that the summit is the point closest to the precipice, a drop-out culture of people who don't want to join companies after graduation is growing.
"These kids making music now were born in Japan's richest time," Mr. Sugiyama says. "They were spoiled. If they wanted a guitar or a sampler, their parents would buy them one. But as they began to reach the age when it was time for them to enter the workforce, the bubble burst, and they began to feel helpless. The companies their parents worked so hard for were dropping; they started asking questions like: 'What are we working for? Where are we heading?' "
Whether the music will begin to matter in America depends on a number of variables. In the music's favor is the fact that over the last few years American culture has slowly begun opening up to Asian culture. There's the popularity of Hong Kong film stars like Jackie Chan, Michelle Yeoh and Chow Yun-Fat; Hollywood Asian-derived blockbusters like "Mulan" and "Godzilla"; Japanese video games like Parappa the Rapper and Street Fighter and Japanese animation. One American record executive, Karyn Rachtman at Interscope, says she has an 8-year-old son who reads only Japanese comic books and whose ambition is to make a movie in Japanese when he grows up.
Since American popular music was introduced to Japan after World War II, pop has occasionally leaked out of Japan and into the Western consciousness. There were, for example, "Sukiyaki" (the first and only Japanese song to hit No. 1 in America) in the 60's; the pioneering electronic music group Yellow Magic Orchestra; the novelty duo Pink Lady in the 70's, and the heavy-metal group Loudness in the 80's. But these success stories were aberrations.
Perhaps the biggest hurdle that Japanese music has to overcome is one of credibility. Since the 1970's, the music that has dominated the Japanese charts has been made by cheesy, over-produced musicians more talented at personal grooming than singing. These manufactured acts -- pin-ups like B'z, Glay, Speed, Smap and, the most fun of the lot, the classic-rock quoting duo Puffy -- are known as idols. Though the public taste for idols is beginning to wane in Japan, as the music industry is struggling with flat sales and losing touch with its audience, the Japanese bands that have put the most effort into making it in America have been the idols. And yet despite the tons of money that have been poured into marketing campaigns for stars like Seiko Matsuda and Toshi Kubota on Columbia Records, they have failed miserably in America, doing more to tarnish the reputation of Japanese music than to help it. As a result, many record labels in Japan are cynical about breaking acts in America.
"It's no good for business when a band goes to America, because when they come back their Japanese audience is gone," says Osamu Sato, chairman of BMG Records Japan. "So it's nice to have a dream, but a dream and business are not always the same."
What befuddles Japanese record executives the most is that despite their efforts to market popular Japanese artists in America, the Japanese bands that end up building a fan base there are obscure ones like the cutesy female rock trio Shonen Knife. "We all want to know why bands like B'z and Glay don't do good internationally, but bands like Pizzicato Five and Cornelius do," says Tomonori Satoh, the head of artists and repertory at Nippon Columbia's Triad label.
Keith Cahoon, the head of Tower Records Asia, believes that he has the answer. "Foreigners like Japanese bands that smell Japanese," he says. "The reason Toshi Kubota is not interesting to most people in America is because they can see a guy doing covers of black music at a corner bar. Kubota does a good imitation of soul music, but it's still an imitation. But if you see Shonen Knife, they sing about Japanese things like crowded trains, obsessively buying Louis Vuitton luggage and eating ice cream after a bath. Ryuichi Sakamoto and Kitaro use distinctively Japanese melodies. The many Japanese noise bands reflect the intense lives and pent-up anger of Japanese culture."
THOUGH Virgin Records in America is gearing up for a campaign for an English-language record by the Japanese pop band Dreams Come True, most labels are beginning to catch on. Sony recently hired a representative from Japan, Archie Meguro, to figure out how best to bring Japanese bands into the American market. His plan, he says, is to work with small underground acts -- like Ken Ishii, the hip-hop musician DJ Honda, the trip-hop artist DJ Krush and a Japanese equivalent of the Chemical Brothers called the Boom Boom Satellites. What is interesting about DJ Krush and DJ Honda as well as other dance-oriented Japanese acts like Natural Calamity and Silent Poets is that they sidestep language differences by working with American and European singers and rappers.
Perhaps one day the sound of Japanese vocalists singing in English and mispronouncing their r's will begin to sound as cool in America as a British accent, and Japanese-language songs will seem as romantic and beguiling as a French chanson. For this dream to come true, however, it is not Japanese music that will have to change. It is American myopia.
"In England and Japan, people have been listening to American music since the 60s," says Daisuke Kawasaki, who runs an indie-rock magazine, Beikoku-Ongaku, and record label. "But in America they're just starting to catch up to all the Japanese and European music we've been listening to. So maybe it is the American mind that is different now."

PUB-DATE: July 12, 1998

SECTION: Section 2; Page 1; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 1575 words

HEADLINE: Furious Fabricators of a Faust for the Digital Age

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING 

DATELINE: BARCELONA

 BODY:
LA FURA DELS BAUS is as unusual a name in Catalan as it is in English: the Ferret from the Baus. But there was method to the fantasy of the five young street performers who chose the name of their new experimental theater company in Barcelona in 1979. The ferret, which can be trained but not tamed, appealed to their anarchic instincts, while the Baus is the name of a dark ravine near their hometown of Moya, 30 miles north of Barcelona, where the five would hang out before they moved here in their late teens. So it sort of made sense.
The group has offered other, perhaps fanciful, translations in the past. But by now the name has long outgrown deconstruction. Today, at least to its legion of fans across Western Europe, La Fura dels Baus is synonymous with an unorthodox, multidisciplinary form of theater that uses loud music, violent movement, bizarre machinery and almost no words to create a near-apocalyptic atmosphere. It likes to perform before a standing audience in nontheatrical spaces like plazas and warehouses, frequently taking the action into the crowd. It has even spawned a Spanish adjective, furero, to describe its special lenguaje furero, its Furan language. 
 It seemed appropriate, then, that Carlos Padrissa, one of La Fura's founders, felt a need to explain, even justify, the break with tradition represented by its latest work, "F@ust, Version 3.0," which will be performed July 22 through 26 at the New York State Theater as part of this year's Lincoln Center Festival. The company has not surrendered to convention. Yet, for the first time, it is presenting a theatrical work before a seated audience using a written text, in this case inspired by no less than Goethe. Over the past two months, the play has been performed here, mainly in Catalan, at the National Theater of Catalonia. In New York, the show, which lasts 99 minutes without a break, will be in Spanish with English supertitles.
So could it be that success is corrupting the enfants terribles of La Fura into respectability? Or is the lenguaje furero now so persuasive that it is penetrating mainstream theater? The way that "F@ust, Version 3.0" came about suggests the latter. In 1996, the Granada International Dance and Music Festival invited Mr. Padrissa and another company member, Alex Olle, to try their hand at musical theater. Their production of Manuel de Falla's "Atlantida" was seen by Gerard Mortier, the director of the Salzburg Festival, who promptly invited them to direct "The Damnation of Faust" by Berlioz in Salzburg in 1999. It was as a result of this commission that they turned their attention to the legend of Faust, and "F@ust, Version 3.0" came about.
"I had read Goethe's 'Faust' as a kid, but only Part I," recalled Mr. Padrissa, a wiry, balding man of 39. "We began to read it again and saw it would work for our language because Goethe was the first to break with a linear sense of time. If the character of Faust was eternally unhappy, he would be still unhappier at the end of the millennium. So we decided to do a theater version of 'Faust,' but using our own methods. We remain loyal to the spirit of the work, but the form is new."
Having seen "F@ust, Version 3.0" here last month, Mr. Mortier has now asked La Fura to take it to Salzburg along with "The Damnation of Faust" next summer. How German and Austrian audiences respond to this information-age reworking of Goethe's masterpiece, in which the work's very name plays upon the language of software, may be one of the more interesting footnotes of the 1999 festival. "Our Faust is not a post-Renaissance elitist," Mr. Padrissa explained. "Today, with the Internet, anyone can have access to information. Goethe's Faust had wisdom and was unhappy. Today people become dissatisfied through information. That's why there are more Fausts today. Faust can be all of us."
Working with the non-Furans Pablo Ley, who adapted and wrote the text, and Magda Puyo, who directed the eight actors brought in for the play, Mr. Padrissa and Mr. Olle present their "F@ust" as a secular morality play: the combat is not between God and the Devil, but between the good and evil sides of Faust's personality. Mephistopheles appears, but he may also be Faust's imaginary alter ego. Even Faust's ill-fated teen-age mistress, Margarethe, is cast as the universal victim of all violence against the weak.
FAUST, who has cultivated reason all his life, is unhappy and tries to kill himself," Mr. Padrissa said, summarizing the plot. "When he fails, his neglected instinctive side says to him, 'Give me your life and I will give you happiness.' That's the pact. But when his base instincts take over, he kills Margarethe's brother, he leaves her pregnant, she kills her baby and Faust's unhappiness grows until he finally shoots himself. In Part II, while Goethe has him sleeping in a field in the Alps, our Faust lies paralyzed on a hospital bed. With no body and only a mind, he now hallucinates being visited by mythological figures. Finally, when he awakens, he understands that thoughts can be as dark as, well, you know, sex, drugs and rock and roll."
This story is told in lenguaje furero, with Faust's struggle lived out through images taken from the Internet, television, advertising and live video and projected on a giant screen, accompanied by electro-acoustical music (with breaks for Mozart's "Requiem") played by a disk jockey acting the part of conductor. Mr. Padrissa and Mr. Olle cannot resist including a few machines, like one that spins Faust head-over-heels as if in training for a space walk. And, as always, they come up with striking visual effects: Faust hanging in a water-filled plastic bag as an unborn embryo, or Faust and Margarethe courting as they climb a net of thick rope, their shadows magnified on a screen.
"People take time to absorb everything," Mr. Olle, 38, said after a warmly applauded performance here one recent evening. "The hope is that the images stay with them, maybe return to them later."
Like Mr. Padrissa, Mr. Olle is a company veteran, although he was not one of the five original founders from Moya whose theatrical roots were very much in the tradition of village fiestas. By the time he joined in 1981, La Fura was growing rapidly -- at one point it had 30 members -- and was putting on improvised shows at alternative sites across Barcelona. Then in 1984 the company was reduced to just nine young men, because only nine would fit into a small van, and began touring Catalonia.
"The moment was important," Mr. Padrissa said. "Franco died in 1975 and suddenly everything seemed possible. But by 1984, the fight for freedom was over and economic recession had set in. The dream was over for those who thought the world would change. The reality was a lot of unemployment. The fiesta element of our work evaporated. We created apocalyptic scenes to make people react, like electric shock treatment. We'd smash cars, set off explosions, burn sets, whatever. All to music."
With its first formal creation, "Accions," in 1984, La Fura established its theatrical language. And this was developed in five other works that have been described as spectacles of controlled techno-mayhem: "Suz/o/ Suz" (which was part of the New York International Festival of the Arts in 1991), "Tier Mon," "Noun," "MTM" and, most recently, "Manes." All of these have toured widely in Europe, with the company winning a particularly strong following in Germany and France.
From 1992, La Fura began to strike out in new directions. Until then, its members did everything: directing, composing, building machines and performing. However, when they presented a spectacular show to accompany the globally televised opening of the Barcelona Summer Olympics in 1992, they needed a cast of 1,500. And since then, the company members -- there are seven now, all men -- have taken to hiring actors to perform their pieces, leaving themselves time for further diversification. Pera Tantina -- he and Padrissa are the only members of the Moya Five to remain in La Fura -- is involved with "Manes"; Miki Espuma is concentrating on composition; and Hansel Cereza, Jurgen Muller and Pep Gatelli are currently preparing new shows.
Mr. Padrissa and Mr. Olle have evidently taken to musical theater, having already directed Debussy's "Martyrdom of Saint Sebastian" as well as Falla's "Atlantida." After "The Damnation of Faust" in Salzburg next year, they have also been invited to direct a new opera based on Cervantes' "Don Quixote" to be presented in Barcelona's opera house, the Gran Teatre del Liceu, in 2000 (the opera house, which burned down in 1994, is being rebuilt and will reopen for the 1999-2000 season).
"We'd next like to do a movie version of 'Faust,' " Mr. Olle noted. "We'd like to have done 'Faust' in three forms -- opera, theater and cinema."
After New York, though, "F@ust, Version 3.0" should still have a long life ahead of it. Traditionally, La Fura's pieces tour for at least three years, and this production already has dates in a score of Spanish cities through May. What is different about it, though, is that it appears to be drawing a slightly older, perhaps more staid, audience than some of the company's wilder earlier shows.
"Some people were a bit put off by the way we would engage the audience by wandering and performing among them," Mr. Olle said with a laugh. "I think they feel a bit safer now."

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut;
Golf-Course Growth Raises Environmental Issues

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:
THE huge popularity of golf is concerning environmentalists and conservationists in Connecticut. Proposals for new golf courses on environmentally sensitive land, most paired with housing developments, are being prepared around the state.
At the end of last year the state had 183 courses for its 169 towns. Twelve new courses have been proposed, almost 12 more are being planned, and at least seven are being expanded. New proposals are being announced so rapidly here and around the country that the National Golf Foundation in Jupiter, Fla., is scrambling to keep track, a spokeswoman for the group, Judy Thompson, said. 
 One reason for the activity, said Jeffrey R. Dugas, president of Wellspeak, Dugas & Kane, a real estate and golf course consultant in Cheshire, is that "the investment community is seeing that golf is a viable real estate investment."
"The baby boomers are getting older," Mr. Dugas said, "and older people have more time for golf, creating a demand."
Two-thirds of the proposals for new courses are not attached to housing developments, he said. Eight of the 12 proposed in Connecticut, however, have 44 to 264 housing units included in their plans.
"We are playing catch-up to supply the huge demand that began in the late 80's and was damped down by the recession," said Chad Ritterbush, a spokesman for the Chicago-based Society of Golf Course Architects. "The reason golf and housing are such a strong combination is that people like living on golf courses, even if they don't play. You have a beautiful view that you don't have to maintain, and economically these houses hold their value better than most.
"More municipalities want to provide golf courses as amenities," Mr. Ritterbush said, "making use of land that is not much use for anything else. In fact, golf courses have been saluted for preserving green space. Normally they are disputed for environmental reasons. But golf course superintendents are better at dispensing fertilizers and pesticides than homeowners."
That idea was not accepted in two Connecticut towns that have examined plans for courses. Last month a plan for a course and 100 $1 million houses on 730 acres of excess watershed in Easton was aborted when the state, the Aspetuck Land Trust, the Nature Conservancy and the Audubon Society agreed to buy the site for open space. The state will use a $160 million fund for acquiring open space.
In Branford the Representative Town Meeting refused to sell a town parcel to be combined with parcels of unused watershed and private property for a golf course and 44 luxury houses. A grass-roots movement is under way to buy the tracts for open space.
"We intervened in the Branford case," said Carolee Hall, a lawyer at the Connecticut Fund for the Environment in New Haven, "because the golf course was proposed on a site where it would fragment 1,200 acres of undeveloped open space, an unusually large piece for Connecticut. It would have taken about two-thirds of it, displacing all species of birds, animals, amphibians and plants dependent on that habitat."
"The state, Audubon, and open-space groups agree that a golf course is not the same as open space," Ms. Lee said, adding that it was increasingly difficult to find sites for courses in a small state like Connecticut without harming the environment.
Development commissions, town officials and some residents see courses as a way to broaden tax bases without major strain on municipal services, even when accompanied by housing. People who can afford the high prices of golf course houses are rarely first-time buyers with schoolchildren.
"Our economic development commission views a golf course as a life-enhancement issue," said Harry Eberhart, Town Planner in Haddam, which has rejected a course two times and is reviewing the plans again. "You will never be over-golf-coursed in Connecticut. You can't get tee time anywhere."
"I think a golf course is a wonderful amenity for the community" said Mayor Arthur J. Peitler of New Milford, the largest and one of the fastest growing municipalities in the state, covering 64.8 square miles.
The United Water Company is planning a course and 75 houses on 350 acres of excess watershed in New Milford that the utility had planned to develop entirely with housing. But Mr. Peitler, whose town has one course, suggested an additional one, he said, as a way to avoid overdevelopment and preserve open space.
But opposition is mounting over concerns that United Water is withholding 13 acres on which it could build 75 additional housing units, said Roger Moretz, co-chairman of Common Sense, a homeowners' group opposed to the course.
"The town has already approved up to 950 new homes," Mr. Moretz said. "At this rate the new high school under construction will be obsolete before it's finished."
The utility is also decommissioning four reservoirs at the site while planning to increase the population.
ULTIMATELY, the State Department of Public Utility Control determines whether watershed land proposed for development is required for service to customers.
"Many of the companies have sold off large tracts," a spokeswoman for the department, Beryl Lyons, said. "With modern filtration systems they don't need to hold as much land as they used to."
One designation that many people find troublesome in terms of water needs, Class 3, "is up for debate," said Environmental Protection Commissioner Arthur J. Rocque Jr. "The Legislature determined it to be surplus and established the right of first refusal to the state and municipality."
Class 3 lands "have no impact on drinking water," said Dr. Gerald Iwan, Water Supplies Chief in the State Public Health Department. "Water companies can do what they like with them, within local zoning regulations."
Several towns have turned to the Connecticut Environmental Review Team, a quasigovernmental agency in Haddam that gauges environmental effects. The agency is reviewing plans for golf courses in Branford, Haddam, Harwinton, Hebron, Litchfield, Middlefield, Middletown and Milford, among other areas.
"Our reports are nonregulatory," said Elaine Sych, the head of the team, "part of a federally sponsored program in research, conservation and development, with funding coming through the state. Many calls come from concerned citizens seeking assistance.
"A lot of golf courses are going in where people have private wells," she said, "and they are concerned about contamination from pesticides or changes in drainage and irrigation, creation of ponds and the digging of new wells, wondering how much water will be used."
Plans for the Great River Golf Course and 234 houses in Milford and a section of Orange would cover 265 acres next to the Housatonic in an area that requires sewers.
A builder from Middletown, Robert Fusari, wants to erect 80 of the 360 houses in his Riverbend development on a 163-acre golf course proposed by Mark Quattro, another local developer.
Middletown has already approved a 160-acre course on private land at Pistol Creek.
In Wallingford, 158 acres of a former town-owned watershed are in neighboring Durham, which is eager to buy the site because it fears that Wallingford will sell it to a developer for housing, creating a tax burden for Durham. "We would keep it in open space or develop it as a limited golf-training facility for junior golfers," Mayor Raymond Kalinowski of Durham said.
In other situations, a retired wine importer, Frederick S. Wildman, has put his 462-acre dairy farm in Colebrook up for sale, asking $2.9 million. "It can support a golf course and 94 houses under zoning," said Mr. Wildman, who is ailing.
Robert J. Ferrarotti, a developer who wants to build a municipal course on 163 acres in Harwinton, sued the town's inland wetlands commission in April in Superior Court in Litchfield. The commission approved his application, but attached conditions that he said made construction impossible.
In Litchfield an application is to be submitted to the wetlands commission this summer for a course, with no housing, on a former dairy farm. A reconfigured plan for a course and, possibly, housing on 250 acres has been submitted in East Lyme.
East Haddam is one of the few towns to approve a course, with 55 housing units, in an environmentally sensitive area, subject to obtaining a state permit.
"We have an interest in the need for future water supplies," Commissioner Rocque said. "And it's hard for a large-scale development to go forward without somebody calling us who objects to it. From a regulatory standpoint we have pretty good standards. Currently we are less concerned about surface-water supplies than ground water contaminated by gas stations, dry-cleaning establishments and other sources."

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
In a Healthy Economy, a Squeeze in Retail Space

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
THIS year is shaping up to be another good one for New Jersey's retail sector, giving rise to a burst of new and renovated shopping-center projects across the state.
A robust economy continues to increase consumer spending, and financing for development is available. Some retailers are consolidating or closing stores, but others are expanding and new ones are entering the state. This has resulted in an increase in demand for space at a time when the vacancy rate in the 11-county northern and central New Jersey market is low, developers and industry analysts said. 
 Underscoring the activity are four projects, together totaling 1.3 million square feet of new and renovated space, that are moving forward or are soon to begin in Clifton, Bridgewater, Riverdale and North Brunswick.
"What we are seeing now are development deals coming on line after two very strong retail years with the growth spurred by a number of aggressive retail tenants," said Matthew Harding, senior vice president of Levin Management, based in North Plainfield.
His concern, which manages some 4.6 million square feet of retail space in New Jersey, puts the retail vacancy rate in centers in northern and central New Jersey, excluding regional malls, at 5 percent, down from 7 percent last year.
Ted Kraus, who heads TKL/The Dealmakers, a retail consulting firm in Mercerville, puts the vacancy rate even lower, at 3 percent. "Despite the competition Jersey continues to be a great retail state because of the vast amount of shoppers and buying power that exists here," he said. He added, however, that the upshot was that "weak tenants shall perish."
The Rickel Home Center chain, for example, filed for bankruptcy last year and closed its 53 stores, 42 of them in New Jersey. Most, however, have since been leased by Staples, the office-supply retailer. At the same time Lowe's, another home-improvement chain, based in North Wilkesboro, N.C., is making a foray into the state with a store planned as part of a 421,000-square-foot shopping center under way in Piscataway, while Home Depot continues to add new stores. Over the last 18 months Home Depot opened seven stores and plans to open three more by next July for a total of 29 in the state, said Katrina Blauvelt, a spokeswoman for the Atlanta-based chain.
Meanwhile, other "big box" retailers like Wal-Mart and Target, the discount department store chain and a relative newcomer, are also expanding in the state. Their growth, in turn, has pushed up rents; Mr. Harding of Levin said the rents have risen 5 to 8 percent over the last year depending on store size. Large blocks of 100,000 square feet or more average about $15 per square foot a year, up 7 percent from 1997, he said. He added, however, that while he does not see "any abrupt changes in the market in the near future there could be flattening in rent increases."
The amount of retail space in the state has also increased, putting some downward pressure on retailers' sales volume. Data compiled by Grubb & Ellis, the national commercial brokerage, show 144 million square feet of space in 1994 in all shopping centers, excluding regional malls, with retailers averaging $150 a square foot in annual sales. As of Jan. 1, 1998, the latest figures available, there were 158 million square feet and retailers were averaging $139 a square foot in sales.
Despite the fact that retailers are making less money, they continue to open stores, "keeping the market healthy," said Jerry Putterman, senior vice president at the West Orange office of Grubb & Ellis. But, he said, if interest rates rise and money gets tight there "could be a real reversal, spurring more consolidations within the industry."
Until then, construction continues. Brokers said that along with big-box retailers the big space takers are supermarkets and movie theaters. They are being constructed in free-standing locations like the one on West Central Boulevard in Palisades Park where a 65,000-square-foot Shop Rite opened last month or they are moving into key spots within retail centers, often as anchors.
BUT sites for new centers are becoming more difficult to find, prompting the recycling of land once occupied by industrial or office buildings into retail use. In the process "new retail pockets," are being created, said Arthur E. Weiss, senior retail associate at the Teaneck office of CB Richard Ellis, the national commercial brokerage. The creation of such a location, he said, is occurring on 33 acres along Route 3 in Clifton.
There, a 285,000-square-foot retail-entertainment center is rising on 11 acres formerly occupied by Automatic Data Processing offices and 22 acres of the adjacent 62-acre property once used by ITT for its headquarters. Called Clifton Commons, it is the first phase of a larger 73-acre mixed-use project planned by Related Retail Corporation, an affiliate of the Related Companies, a large Manhattan development company.
"The site is the hole in the retail doughnut between Paramus, Secaucus and Wayne," said James M. Jarosik, executive vice president at Related Retail, adding that whatever the market, "having land with frontage along Route 3 is irreplaceable."
Clifton Commons, scheduled for completion next spring, has been nearly fully preleased and will be anchored by an 80,000-square-foot, 16-screen General Cinema complex along with a 65,000-square-foot Edwards supermarket, 130,000 square feet of stores and two restaurants. Eventually, the remaining 40 acres, now home to a 950,000-square-foot building that the avionics division of ITT Industries has leased back from Related Retail until 2002, will also be redeveloped into up to 1 million square feet of hotel, housing and additional retail uses, said Mr. Jarosik.
In Riverdale, construction is under way on a 240,000-square-foot open-air retail strip that replaces a former swim club on 35 acres along Route 23, one-half mile north of Interstate 287.
The center -- where Staples, Home Depot and BJ's Warehouse Club have signed on as tenants -- is being developed by Starwood Heller L.L.C., a joint venture of Heller Enterprises of Edgewater and Starwood Opportunity Fund IV, an affiliate of Starwood Lodging of Greenwich, Conn.
"It is a new retail location in a growing area not yet served by these types of tenants who see it as a way to increase their market share," said Todd A. Heller, vice president of leasing and marketing at Starwood Heller.
The partners also see Edgewater's Hudson River waterfront as another retail growth area and are planning to develop at least 250,000 square feet of stores as well as a 14-screen National Amusement movie theater in three projects along River Road there, said Mr. Heller. A key reason, he said, is that more than 4,000 new residential units are under way or planned at the river's edge in Edgewater as well as nearby West New York.
In Bridgewater, site work began last month on a 625,000-square-foot shopping center on 70 acres at the intersection of Route 28 and I-287 that were once part of the American Cyanamid corporate campus. Bridgewater Promenade, as the center is called, will have a 75,000-square-foot hotel with up to 175 rooms.
"The area is in desperate need of this kind of mixed-used project and the site, in terms of location, access and demographics, can support it," said William G. Krame, president of Krame Development Company of Paramus, which is developing the center in partnership with the Kimco Realty Corporation of New Hyde Park, LI.
Mr. Krame said the project was fully leased to such big-box retailers as Target, Babies 'R' Us and Home Depot as well as to smaller tenants, including a bank, a video store and three restaurants. Completion is expected by the summer of 1999, he said.
OLDER centers are also being redeveloped to remain competitive. An example is the 145,000-square-foot North Village Shopping Center, on 12 acres where Routes 1 and 130 meet in North Brunswick, which Levin Management plans to begin renovating this fall. The center, built in the 60's, is now mostly vacant due to the closing of a 30,000-square-foot A. & P. and an 80,000-square-foot Bradlees.
The work includes reducing the size of the center to 130,000 square feet, dividing the former Bradlees for two or three users and giving the reconfigured center a new facade.
"We're taking outmoded space and renovating it into a 'mini-power center' to attract a few mostly big-box retailers," said Matthew Harding, Levin's senior vice president. He added that deals for that space were being negotiated with such tenants as a bookstore and an office-supply chain.

HEADLINE: Sprint Is Building Huge Headquarters in Kansas

BYLINE: By SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN 

DATELINE: OVERLAND PARK, Kan.

 BODY:
WHILE other telecommunications companies compete to pull off the biggest mergers and acquisitions, the Sprint Corporation can claim bragging rights of its own for the world headquarters campus it is building on 200 acres in this booming, affluent suburb of Kansas City, Mo.
With 3.1 million square feet of space -- at an estimated cost of $700 million over four years of work -- the campus is the largest corporate office construction project in terms of square footage ever undertaken in the Midwest, according to executives of Sprint and the construction firm, and the largest currently under way anywhere in the United States. A possible later phase, not yet approved by Sprint's board, would bring the total to 3.9 million square feet with space for 14,500 employees. 
 The campus will provide what Sprint and its employees say will be the ideal working environment for the new century, and it is highly reminiscent of a model that has been around for a long time: the leafy college campus with low-rise, red-brick buildings.
The work that began last July and is scheduled for completion in late 2001 will create 18 four- and five-story buildings, one of them a training center called the University of Excellence; a 175-foot clock tower; covered walkways; an outdoor amphitheater for 3,000 people; parking garages for 12,500 cars; athletic fields, and hiking and biking trails that connect to public trails outside the campus.
Some other amenities will take this project beyond the traditional collegiate model: a full fitness center, a child-care center, private rooms for nursing mothers next to the women's restrooms, "war" rooms, "solitude nooks" and on-line menus from the three food courts. Sixty percent of the site will be green space, for which there is a $10 million landscaping budget. The campus will have 5,000 trees and will require more than six million bricks.
That is not bad for a corporation descended from a little country telephone exchange that started business a century ago in Abilene, Kan. Today, Sprint has 51,000 employees worldwide and had revenues last year of $14.87 billion. It is the largest private employer in metropolitan Kansas City, with about 10,500 employees.
Though best known as the nation's third-largest long-distance carrier, Sprint also provides local service to 7.4 million customers in 19 states, the heritage of its small-town past, and it is a leader in wireless personal communications systems. It is proud of its all-digital, fiber-optic network and is a major carrier of Internet traffic.
Faye S. Manker, Sprint's vice president for real estate, said that many features of the design and facilities for the corporate campus emerged from employee focus groups and surveys and the more than 300 meetings she and others on the project team held with employees.
"In three surveys, we had them list things they wanted," she said, "in terms of amenities, parking, and technology. We had focus groups on retail, food and wellness facilities. We got great questions and ideas."
A video camera mounted on a pole overlooking the construction site allows Daniel A. Euston, project manager for the J. E. Dunn Construction Company, the general contractor, to observe the site from his office in the temporary building housing the project management team. He can zoom in on any worker or any place. Every hour, a picture is taken from the video and posted on the company intranet, allowing thousands of employees to check construction progress regularly.
A 5,000-square-foot mock-up of interior office space has been built in a warehouse a few miles from the site. Serving as a laboratory for office design, it allows the planners to try out ceiling tiles, lighting, movable furniture and other things.
"This is a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity for someone in the construction business," said Mr. Euston, adding that the real size of the project could be better understood by taking into account that construction costs in this part of the country run 30 to 50 percent below those in the metropolitan areas of the Northeast and California, with cheaper land prices making an even greater difference.
Ms. Manker said this showplace campus will not only bring together employees now in about 60 buildings scattered over many miles of the bistate Kansas City area but "will have a physical presence that represents Sprint to our investors and partners." She predicted that it would aid in recruitment of employees, both locally and nationally. "Recruiting is very difficult today," she said. "It's a buyer's market. With only 2 percent unemployment in this area, we are pleased to see that there's been a lot of attention from potential employees interested in coming to Kansas City to work at the new headquarters."
Before plans were drawn, the project team -- about 25 people representing Sprint, Dunn, Hillier Group, which is the principal architect, and other architects, engineers and consultants -- looked for ideas by visiting 15 corporate headquarters around the country, including those of Microsoft, Monsanto, Ameritech and Sears, Roebuck. Much of the inspiration for the Sprint campus appears to have come from the collegiate-styled Microsoft headquarters, which is slightly larger than what the finished Sprint headquarters will be but was built piecemeal over many more years.
Ms. Manker said that a high-rise headquarters was ruled out "because communication doesn't happen as well when offices are vertical instead of horizontal." She also said the elevators will not be of the high-speed variety because the planners want to encourage employees to use the stairs, which is seen as another way to ease communication.
AS it occupies the new campus, Sprint will vacate 2.5 million square feet of leased space in several steps beginning August 1999 and continuing into 2002.
Many people involved in real estate in Kansas City and the suburbs fear that those vacancies will have an adverse effect on local real estate prices. Ms. Manker argued, however, that any damage will be temporary because the space is widely dispersed, most of it in areas with strong and growing demand for class A office space.
Beyond the question of the vacated space, however, Sprint's move is expected to give a huge boost to the already nonstop commercial and real estate development in the area surrounding the campus for several miles. Mr. Euston said at least five hotels are scheduled for construction or in the planning stages near the campus. Residential realtors said that many homes in nearby subdivisions, where most of the houses are 3,000 square feet and up, are being sold to Sprint employees. The upscale Town Center Plaza shopping area, with 73 shops, restaurants and theaters in 750,000 square feet, opened last year across the street from the eastern boundary of the Sprint site.
Mr. Euston said that 300 to 400 construction workers are now on the site, where three office buildings and four parking garages are under construction. By fall, he said, at least 12 buildings will be under construction, as the work force reaches 1,000. It will remain at that level for more than a year.
Noting the serious shortage of skilled construction workers in Kansas City and many areas of the country, he said it would be a constant juggling act to coordinate Sprint's lease expirations in existing buildings with the availability of craftsmen to complete new buildings.
Even cement, he said, is in short supply nationwide, with contractors in some areas able to pour cement only four days a week. Sprint has dealt with that problem by setting up its own cement plant at the site.
These headaches may help explain why Ms. Manker, even after talking about how exhilarating it was to work on such an ambitious project, said the wall chart that plots the progress of the undertaking had sometimes been referred to as the "wall of pain."
