HEADLINE: Setbacks Challenge The Hudson

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
SO far, 1998 has been a long and dispiriting year for the Hudson River.
The first worrisome news came in February, when the Federal Environmental Protection Agency delayed its long-awaited decision on the cleanup of the river -- putting off until 2001 a decision on whether to order General Electric to remove polychlorinated biphenyls from a 200-mile stretch of the river, which is one of the largest Superfund sites in the United States. 
 Then the corporation -- on the defensive for dumping the industrial contaminant in the river from 1947 to 1977 -- started publicly challenging Government findings that linked the PCB's to an increased risk of cancer. At an April stockholders' meeting, John F. Welch Jr., chairman and chief executive of the Fairfield-based G.E., told the audience that new research indicated that the contaminants, long thought to be carcinogens, had no adverse health effects on humans.
And last month, New York State, bogged down by internal conflicts, failed to approve this year's allotment for the Hudson River Estuary Management Plan, a program that for 13 years has coordinated environmental work along the river. An initial $6 million for the plan in the budget was vetoed by Gov. George E. Pataki, and a separate bill, which followed, failed in the State Assembly.
"The Hudson River has become a victim of politics," John Cronin, executive director of Hudson Riverkeeper, a nonprofit environmental group based in Garrison, observed ruefully last week. "It is a sad state of affairs."
Against this somber backdrop of disappointments, many Hudson River advocates now await President Clinton's announcement, expected later this month, on the 10 waterways to be designated as American Heritage Rivers. A White House advisory committee has recommended that the Hudson be included in the program, which would encourage efforts for environmental protection, economic development and cultural and historic preservation.
"It is a bitter irony that these setbacks have occurred on the eve of the President's declaration," Mr. Cronin said. "We've always assumed that the Hudson would get its due, but the truth is that we have to continue to fight for every inch of the river every inch of the time." Perhaps the blow that struck hardest this spring and hit closest to home for those active on behalf of the river was the loss of state financing for the Hudson River Estuary Management Plan.
"What had not been a partisan issue became one," Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky, a Democrat from Greenburgh and chairman of the Assembly's Environment Committee, said, bristling over the defeat of one of his pet environmental projects. Mr. Brodsky observed that the two separate estuary plan proposals -- in the budget and in a separate bill -- failed even in a year "when the state government is flush with cash."
The Hudson is the last estuary in the North Atlantic to retain strong spawning stocks of its traditional varieties of fish, and it is considered one of the richest estuaries on the planet. But as Mr. Brodsky, sponsor of the estuary plan bill, observed, the river's continued vitality cannot be taken for granted.
Studies, including those by the Federal Fish and Wildlife Service, show that between one and three pounds of PCB's a day leach from the river bottom at Thompson Island Pool, a six-mile section of the Hudson downstream from two General Electric plants in Fort Edward and Hudson Falls, about 45 miles north of Albany. The chemicals in turn contaminate fish and move up the food chain, affecting birds as well.
Among other things, financing for the estuary plan included money for habitat restoration along the river, testing of toxins in fish and provisions for recreational access to the river.
"The program was up and running, and suddenly everything came to a grinding halt," said Gary Sheffer, Assistant Commissioner of the State Department of Environmental Conservation.
While aides to Mr. Pataki and Democratic leaders pointed fingers at one another for the failure to finance the Estuary Management Plan this year, Mr. Brodsky predicted last week that the story was far from over. He said he was optimistic that the Legislature would restore the money.
Meanwhile, General Electric, under pressure for its part in the river's decline, cited a study published last October in The New England Journal of Medicine showing no link between PCB exposure and breast cancer and another Michigan study from 1975 indicating no increased risk of cancer or other health effects in people who had eaten PCB-laden fish from the Great Lakes.
"More than 20 studies, conducted over 20 years mainly by academics, private institutions and government agencies, have shown that PCB's do not cause cancer in humans or other adverse health effects," a recent company publication said.
The publication also said that many of G.E.'s occupationally exposed workers who worked with PCB's on a daily basis for many years have shown little negative effects. "That's very powerful evidence," David C. Warshaw, a spokesman for the company, said.
For three decades, the corporation dumped at least 1.3 million pounds of polychlorinated biphenyls -- used as a coolant in electrical capacitors -- in the river at the two factories in Fort Edward and Hudson Falls. General Electric has spent more than $150 million since then in a continuing effort to seal those sites.
According to the Environmental Protection Agency, General Electric is at least partly responsible for 79 or so Superfund sites in the United States, and PCB's are a substantial part of the contamination at 19 G.E. sites where cleanups are already under way. Most recently, PCB contamination was found in soil around homes near a General Electric factory in Pittsfield, Mass., and residents have since learned that the company had known of the problem as early as the 1980's.
This spring, a group of clergy members from New Jersey, New York and Connecticut that owns General Electric stock began urging other shareholders to press the company to improve its environmental record.
Sister Patricia Daly, a Dominican nun and director of the Tri-State Coalition for Responsible Investment, an association of 35 religious orders, called on the company to publicize the dangers of eating fish from the river and to stop fostering misleading studies.
Government studies have shown strong links between PCB's and malignant melanomas and non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. Some studies have indicated that the contaminants are considered toxic to the developing nervous systems of children and to immune systems. And there is growing evidence that PCB's interfere with the functioning of human endocrine systems.
Sister Pat, as she is known, compared the company's claims that PCB's are harmless with claims made by tobacco industry executives about the harmlessness of smoking.
Although Mr. Welch said that was an outrageous comparison, Mr. Cronin, the Riverkeeper, last week described G.E. as an even worse offender.
"To compare G.E. to tobacco companies is to insult the tobacco companies," Mr. Cronin said. "At least cigarette packs have warnings on them."
Since the early 1990's, the State Health Department and the State Department of Environmental Conservation have advised against eating more than one meal a month of a dozen types of fish caught in the Hudson south of Catskill. Children younger than 15 and women of childbearing age have been advised to eat none.
Nevertheless, favorite fishing sites throughout the county -- like City Pier in Yonkers and Croton Point Park -- remain crowded. And a 1992 study completed by the Hudson River Sloop Clearwater, a nonprofit group in Poughkeepsie, showed that despite regular warnings from the state, most Hudson River fishermen continue to eat PCB-contaminated fish because they are either unaware of the risks or they do not care.
Mr. Cronin said that in light of many of the health concerns, G.E. had undertaken a "brazen and irresponsible campaign" to discount studies implicating PCB's.
He also said that the Environmental Protection Agency, in delaying a decision on the cleanup, "had lost its political nerve" and was, at least for the moment, capitulating to a large corporation.
Cara Lee, the environmental director of Scenic Hudson, a nonprofit environmental group based in Poughkeepsie, said she believed the E.P.A. had "buckled under pressure."
She also observed that the delay -- "a big setback," as she described it -- had effectively pushed the decision on whether to remove the PCB's to the next Administration.
"And if it goes to then, it could be another five, six or even eight years until something is done," she said.
But Carol M. Browner, the Environmental Protection Agency's administrator, denied that General Electric had influenced her decision to study the cleanup issue further. "No large corporation has ever gotten to me," she said.
She said the delay was necessary to prepare an airtight scientific case for PCB removal, because General Electric would most likely challenge a cleanup order in court.
At the invitation of Mr. Brodsky, Ms. Browner was to speak at a hearing of the State Assembly's Environment Committee on Thursday -- "to set the record straight about the misinformation being put forward by G.E.," she said.
Governor Pataki, in two letters this year to Ms. Browner, urged the agency to move speedily ahead on deciding a course of remediation for the river.
"The Hudson River is important to all New Yorkers who enjoy its tremendous beauty and diversity," the Governor wrote. He said that in addition to state efforts to clean up the Hudson, many river communities were undertaking waterfront revitalization efforts now that state grants are available under the state's 1996 Clean Water/Clean Air Bond Act and the Environmental Protection Fund.
Mr. Pataki said that while the state and New York's municipalities continued to move ahead, the Environmental Protection Agency was dragging its feet.
To remove the PCB's, most of which are in scattered spots in the river's sediment, General Electric would most likely have to dredge the river bottom. Costs for that could run as high as $2 billion. But the company has maintained that removing the PCB's might only stir up the contaminants and cause more harm than good.
Despite the latest setbacks, riverfront communities are say they are hopeful that the Hudson will run clean again and that they will be able to profit from tourism and recreation -- luring sightseers to historic sites, orchards, vineyards and picturesque villages along the shoreline.
"It's not all bad news," said Robert W. Elliott, Supervisor of Croton-on-Hudson and chairman of Historic River Towns, an economic effort linking communities from Yonkers to Peekskill.
"We'll lobby hard for the Estuary Management Plan -- it's not sitting on a shelf," said Mr. Elliott, who is also on the advisory board of the estuary plan. "We're also optimistic about the Heritage River designation, and we're moving ahead to restore our waterfronts."
In a related activity, the county's Planning Department sponsored a conference called "Waterfront Planning in the Post-Industrial Age" on June 16 at Marymount College in Tarrytown. The participants looked at current and proposed development along 49 miles of the river in Westchester, long-range planning, boat launches and marinas, ferry routes and development opportunities.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Bruce Ratner;
Meeting the Demand for Stores Outside Manhattan

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
BRUCE RATNER made a big splash when he moved the 7.2-million-pound Empire Theater 170 feet on 42d Street to serve as an anchor for the entertainment and retail complex he is now building.
Cameras recorded the event as balloons resembling the comedians Bud Abbott and Lou Costello, who met at the theater while it was called the Eltinge, appeared to tug the building westward. 
 Mr. Ratner has other high profile Manhattan developments in the works as well. He is seeking approval to build a hotel on 41st Street over the complex and is about to break ground on an 460-room Embassy Suites hotel in Battery Park City.
While such projects have brought the former Commisioner of the city's Department of Consumer Affairs public attention, he has been quietly working at another, perhaps more significant, task -- developing modern retail and entertainment centers in the populous, but underserved, boroughs of the city outside of Manhattan.
Mr. Ratner, whose company, Forest City Ratner, developed the 11-building, 6-million-square-foot Metrotech office building complex in downtown Brooklyn, said he had become interested in retail development when it became clear that the overbuilding of the late 80's and early 90's would preclude more office development for a long time.
"The core of our business was office buildings, but over the last three to four years we have shifted to urban retail," he said.
"We did not think the office market would rebound," said Sandeep Mathrani, a senior vice president of Forest City Ratner and its director of retail development, "and we wanted to continue development in the boroughs. He said the company had conducted a study of stores and neighborhoods and concluded that there was a large market for modern stores.
"Our study found that there is a spending deficit in the boroughs of $10 billion a year," Mr. Mathrani said. "Three billion of that involves automobiles, so we set that aside. Of the remaining $7 billion, $3 billion leaves the city for the suburbs and $4 billion is not spent."
Brokers specializing in retail development agree that many parts of the city could support large, modern stores whose selections are more varied and whose prices are typically lower than the small stores that operate in many neighborhoods.
"Brooklyn and Queens are clearly understored," said Faith H. Consolo, a senior managing director of Garrick-Aug Associates, a retail specialist. "Nobody thought the boroughs were chic and they were not developed for national retail. But now Ratner has done Atlantic Center and it shows the demand is there."
The development is a three-story, L-shaped structure at Atlantic and Flatbush Avenues in Brooklyn that opened in the fall of 1996. Tenants of the 393,000-square-foot center include Pathmark, Caldor, Sports Authority, Old Navy, Office Max and Circuit City.
"Bruce Ratner was the first developer to recognize the strength of the middle class in the city," said Benjamin Fox, a partner in New Spectrum Realty Services, another retail specialist. "For retailers the outer boroughs offer tremendous staying power and stability because there are families with combined incomes of $50,000 to $60,000 a year."
Indeed, Mr. Ratner's own research shows that there are about 130,000 people living within a one-mile radius of the Atlantic Center and that the average household income is almost $53,000 a year. Lengthening the radius to two miles encompasses 437,000 people, but the average household income drops to about $44,000 a year.
Mr. Ratner said the Atlantic Center site had been selected for a replacement for Ebbets Field before the Dodgers defected to the West Coast. "The land was cleared by Robert Moses, but it just sat there for 40 years," he said. He said city officials concluded that office projects would not happen and offered the site for retail development.
The results at Atlantic Center have been favorable enough that the company has recently opened a second center diagonally across the street. Called the Shops at Atlantic Center, its tenants are PC Richard & Son and Sneaker Stadium.
FOREST CITY RATNER, a partnership between publicly owned Forest City Enterprises and Mr. Ratner's company, now has projects under way in all five boroughs and in North Bergen, New Jersey. It has 1.1 million square feet of retail space in operation, 800,000 square feet in development and 725,000 square feet in the planning stages.
In addition to Atlantic Center, some of the projects currently in operation include a 175,000-square-foot Home Depot at Gun Hill Road and Ely Avenue in the Bronx; Maspeth Center at Grand Avenue and 74th Street in Queens, a 100,000-square-foot neighborhood shopping center anchored by an Edward's Supermarket; the Shops at Northern Boulevard on Northern Boulevard and 48th Street in Queens, a 214,000-square-foot center with Edward's Supermarket, Marshall's and Old Navy as major tenants and the Shops at Richmond Avenue at Richmond Avenue and the entrance to the Staten Island Mall, a 76,000-square-foot center with Circuit City and Staples as major tenants.
And if the boroughs outside of Manhattan were considered understored, they are also underscreened, Mr. Ratner concluded. So the company is building a combined bookstore and movie theater called the Heights, at Court and Schermerhorn Streets in Brooklyn, as well as two theaters on Staten Island, Hylan Cinemas, at 101 Quintard Street, and Forest Avenue Cinemas, at Forest Avenue and South Street.
One of the difficulties of building large stores in the city was to translate concepts that were developed in suburban malls to the urban environment. "We had to learn the business, because nobody had ever done it before," Mr. Ratner said. "There were issues regarding parking, security, financing and the micromanagement of goods depending on the neighborhood."
One conclusion was that it was simply not possible to provide as much parking as is available in the suburbs. A typical suburban mall has five parking spaces for every 1,000 square feet of shopping space. In the city that ratio is 1.5 to 3 cars per 1,000 square feet.
Another was that with land scarce and expensive, shopping was going to have to be vertical. Atlantic Center, for example is three stories high, with the Pathmark food store on the first floor and Caldor on the third, with Marshall's and Sports Authority in the middle.
Finding sites in the city is difficult, company officials said. "There are no vacant sites, you have to create them," said Mr. Mathrani. He said the company had videotaped the city by helicopter and identified major street and traffic patterns.
"Then it was a matter of knocking on the doors of people who own large tracts of land and convincing them to sell," Mr. Ratner said. None of the land was being offered for sale when the Forest City Ratner people came calling, he added.
Financing the projects was another obstacle. Since no one had done these types of stores in an urban setting before, there was no track record to demonstrate they could be economically successful. "Four years ago you couldn't gets banks to lend on these projects," said Mr. Ratner, adding that "we went to every one of them."
Finally, he said, Credit Lyonnais agreed to finance Atlantic Center, and the success of that undertaking has made financing less of a problem.
BECAUSE of the density of the population in the city, he said, many of the stores are doing very well compared with their suburban counterparts. He said one Caldor store in the city had $50 million in sales in one year, compared with $25 million to $30 million for a typical suburban Wal-Mart or $20 million to $22 million for a suburban K-mart. He said one of the supermarkets sold $800,000 of groceries a week compared with about $200,000 a week in the suburbs.
One of the advantages of developing in New York, Mr. Ratner said, is that the city has not lost population, like his hometown of Cleveland or Detroit. As people have moved to the suburbs they have been replaced by more recent immigrants eager to partake in the material aspects of the American dream.
"Thirty-seven percent of the city's population is made up of immigrants and it is 50 percent if you count immigrants and their children," Mr. Mathrani said. "Many of them have been deprived of basic necessities like television and a refrigerator, so they have a propensity to spend more than people who have been here for awhile."

HEADLINE: YOUR HOME;
Pitfalls In Luxury Decontrol

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO 

 BODY:
UNDER a law passed in 1993 and amended last year, rent-stabilized tenants who pay $2,000 or more a month for their apartments and whose annual household incomes were more than $175,000 in each of the two preceding years are not entitled to the protection of rent stabilization.
But as a result of strict interpretation of the luxury decontrol law by the New York State Division of Housing and Community Renewal -- and some recent court decisions confirming that interpretation -- even tenants whose incomes are below $175,0000 can suddenly find themselves subject to luxury decontrol and its high free-market rents. 
 "I believe that this is one of the most serious issues facing tenants in the City of New York that I have seen in 30 years of practicing law," said Errol A. Brett, a Manhattan real estate layer.
Mr. Brett said that since luxury decontrol was signed into law in 1993, an increasing number of clients he has been asked to represent have had their rent-stabilized apartments deregulated despite the fact that their incomes were well below the maximum set by the law. And by reducing the limit from $250,000 to $175,000 last year, he said, the State Legislature placed even more tenants at risk of losing their regulated status.
"I've been telling everybody I know that if their rent is more than $2,000 a month they should put a lawyer on retainer and send him every piece of mail they get from their landlord or D.H.C.R.," Mr. Brett said. "And I tell them the advice stands no matter how much money they make."
The problem, he said, results from the complexity of the luxury decontrol law and the inevitable confusion created by the various forms and certifications that criss-cross back and forth among landlords, tenants and the D.H.C.R.
The process starts, Mr. Brett said, with the income-certification form that landlords send to tenants by May 1 of each year in an effort to determine whether any apartments renting for $2,000 a month or more may be eligible for luxury decontrol.
The form, Mr. Brett said, requires tenants to declare whether their total household income in each of the two preceding years exceeded the $175,000 limit. In most cases, he said, tenants complete the form and return it to the landlord within the 30-day time period as required by law. Some tenants, he said, even attach income tax returns to the certification as proof of their income.
The problem, however, is that though the form is sent by the landlord to the tenant and then back to the landlord, it bears the official letterhead of the Division of Housing and Community Renewal -- a factor that could lead a reasonable tenant to believe that the form, and the information it contains, will ultimately end up in the files of D.H.C.R.. As a result, Mr. Brett said, tenants who believe they are safe from decontrol and return the form on time generally forget about luxury decontrol -- at least until the next year's income certification arrives in the mail.
By law, however, landlords can dispute a tenant's income-certification by filing with D.H.C.R. an Owner's Petition for Deregulation. When the division receives the landlord's petition it sends another income-verification form to the tenant along with a request for supporting tax returns. The form also advises the tenant that failure to return the certification within 60 days of receipt will result in automatic deregulation of the apartment.
And that's when things get tricky.
"A lot of tenants ignore the second form," Mr. Brett said. The reason, he explained, is because the income verification form requests essentially the same information as the previous form that had been returned to the landlord. Thus some tenants believe that since they filed the initial form they do not have to bother filing a second time.
Failure to file the second form within 60 days, however, is considered a default on the part of the tenant and nearly always results in an order of deregulation being issued by the division. In some cases it may take several months for D.H.C.R. to issue an order of deregulation. In others, the orders may not reach the tenant until sometime in the following year -- overlapping new income certifications being filed for that year.
"It gets so confusing it can drive you crazy," Mr. Brett said, adding that what is most disturbing is that once a tenant has failed to file a required form on time, there is virtually no way for the tenant to rectify the error and avoid an order of deregulation.
"All you have to do is miss one deadline and you're out of luck," he said, explaining that the D.H.C.R. has consistently interpreted the default provision of the statute in the strictest terms possible.
In a recent ruling that was highly critical of the division's strict interpretation of the procedural requirements of the luxury decontrol law, State Supreme Court Justice Phyllis Gangel-Jacob wrote that the D.H.C.R. policy places a "heavy burden" on tenants.
"Failure to keep a hawk's eye on the mail for year after year into the indefinite future can cost any tenant the valuable protection of the Rent Stabilization Laws, without regard to what their income may be," Justice Gangel-Jacob wrote. "The continuing vigilance that is required to obtain and act on the form is daunting."
There were no responses to telephone messages left at the litigation section of the Division of Housing and Community Renewal seeking comment on the agency's policy. But Jeffrey Turkel, a Manhattan lawyer who represents landlords, said that as harsh as the division's position may seem, it appears to be simply applying the law as it is written.
"There's no question that a lot of tenants don't return their petition within the 60-day time period," Mr. Turkel said. "But what you have here is a statute that says that if a tenant doesn't respond within 60 days, the agency must issue an order of deregulation."
And while some State Supreme Court justices like Justice Gangel-Jacob have found in favor of tenants when it is clear that the tenants' incomes are below the statutory maximum, Mr. Turkel said, those cases that have been appealed have resulted in decisions upholding the D.H.C.R.'s strict interpretation of the law.
As a result, landlord-tenant lawyers say that at present the only way tenants can protect themselves from an inadvertent loss of their regulated status is to exercise the "continuing vigilance" referred to by Justice Gangel-Jacob.
"To me that means that tenants have to read and understand every single document they receive," said William Gribben, a Manhattan lawyer who represents tenants. "You have to become an expert on how the whole process works. You have to clear a space on your desk, get a nice clean legal pad and make a note of every docket number on every form and the dates when the forms were received and returned."
In addition, he said, every form should be copied and every form that is mailed should be sent certified mail, return receipt requested.
"You have to be incredibly diligent," said Mr. Gribben, "because if you make one mistake, it can all go down the drain."

HEADLINE: THEATER REVIEW;
Amid Glitter, a Down-Home Voice

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN 

DATELINE: MILLBURN

 BODY:
IF "The Will Rogers Follies" is not about the endearing old charms of the folkloric entertainer, "Oklahoma philosopher" and "poet lariat," then it must be all about the pizazz and the look of a big-time, old-time, good-time Broadway musical.
A mere seven years ago, the original conceit by Cy Coleman, Betty Comden and Adolph Green, and Peter Stone affirmed both notions, extravagantly so. Fittingly playing the Palace, Broadway's symbol of vaudeville's glory days, "The Will Rogers Follies" revived the glitter of a bygone era, with Keith Carradine as the headliner and Tommy Tune as director and choreographer, emerging the winners in the show's two essential categories. In Mr. Stone's fantasy, more successful in concept than in writing, Will Rogers is conjured up in the here and now. Fate's messenger, Wiley Post, the aviator with whom Rogers died in a plane crash in 1935, watches the show, subtitled in "A Life in Revue") from out front, beckoning its hero to take that fatal flight. 
 One had every right to anticipate a grand first-class show instead of an enervated retread at the Paper Mill Playhouse here. If there is a theater with the resources to perpetuate the musical with a score, a story and a star, without writing it off as a costly artifact, Paper Mill -- New Jersey's major center for the preservation of unstinting musical-theater splendor and potentially the country's -- is the one. And if ever there was an artistic write-off at Paper Mill, "Will Rogers Follies" is it.
When terrific scenery looks tacky, don't blame the designer, and resist all impulses to kill the moving men. Reportedly transported intact, Tony Walton's original sets span the heartlands of the Wild West to celestial heights. (Rogers meets his wife on the moon in the Ziegfeld Follies manner, and his addresses to the audience are, after all, heaven-sent.) Evoking the polarities of down home, up above, and the downs and ups of show business, Mr. Walton's designs, from vaudeville-perfect backdrops to Ziegfeld opulence, desperately need refurbishing and invite recasting. A streamlined Ziegfeld ensemble may be an economic necessity, but the re-creation of Willa Kim's drop-dead costume designs, credited to Gail Baldoni as costume coordinator, is a poor off-the-rack substitute for designer originals.
Will Rogers, who rose from five shows a day in Cedar Rapids to worldwide star of talkies, radio and Broadway, was a bracing advocate of decency, prospering during the Depression, yet denouncing a country's wrong-headed values, stopping just short of radicalism.
But the political barbs and social consciousness of an American icon are here reduced to tired stand-up, coyly and mechanically delivered by John Davidson, who somehow turns the show's far-reaching settings into one state fair in the throes of a cotton candy overdose.
Mr. Davidson's attempts to change his image, in revisions of the failed 1987 Broadway musical "Teddy and Alice" and a one-man play called "Bully," about Theodore Roosevelt, are inoperative here. Mr. Carradine engagingly duped an audience into going with the show's theme song, "Never Met a Man I Didn't Like," even into walking out humming it, and his replacement, Mac Davis, pulled it off, too. Not Mr. Davidson, who makes us wonder just how many men Will Rogers really met.
Here, as on Broadway, the audience is spared Rogers's toughest comments, like his association of Thanksgiving with the Pilgrims, "who would give thanks every time they killed an Indian and took more of his land." (Rogers was one-quarter Cherokee.) It settles for safe flashes of pith, but this edition stoops to washed-out jokes about President Clinton in China and knee-slapping New Jersey slurs. (Don't forget Ken Starr and Monica Lewinsky and Viagra.) The more unsavory and stale, the bigger the laugh. Give Rogers a revelatory moment ("In an American election, nothing can hurt you more than telling the truth") and he gets no laughs. Can it be that the audience has been stunned into silent reflection?
When the real time to startle arrives in "Presents for Mrs. Rogers," the production's coup de theatre wherein bejeweled and bedazzling showgirls are stripped of their adornments and draped in burlap by a cost-cutting stage manager, the moment is clumsily timed. Worse, the house lights are supposed to go up, in startling dismissal of the feel-good aura of an entertainment for the affluent, jolting the audience into shocked awareness of economic reality and summoning unavoidable contemporary associations as Rogers delivers his hard-times radio address to President Hoover. Somehow the director, Mark S. Hoebee, avoids the unavoidable.
Ann Crumb succumbs to the vacuous role of Betty Blake, married to Will Rogers, "the best husband in the world." Given the showiness of Ziegfeld's Favorite, who is meant to propel, narrate and otherwise invigorate the musical, Pamela Jordan's lack of razzle-dazzle is an immense drawback. But Tom and Bonnie Brackney and the Madcap Mutts are really good. At its best, this production truly goes to the dogs, who save it for the moment.
Lowering the impact of a sumptuous spectacle and silencing the sounds of a fanfare for the common man, Paper Mill is serving up leftovers in a commonplace production.

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT: MINDING YOUR BUSINESS;
Should Octogenarians Walk on the Wild Side?

BYLINE: By LAURA PEDERSEN-PIETERSEN 

 BODY:

Q. I am 87 years old and looking for investment advice -- not tax avoidance schemes -- specifically for my age group.
MARTIN FIELD -- Laguna Hills, Calif.
 
A. Hang on while I turn down the gramophone, fill up my fountain pen and grab a grape Nehi out of the icebox. If you think financial planners have passed you by in favor of those 60-something whippersnappers down the block, don't fret. Brokers may soon make cold calls based on black-market lists of videophiles who've rented Walter Matthau movies. 
 And why not? The number of Americans who are 85 or older is rising rapidly: The total jumped 51 percent from 1980 to 1996, and it is expected to climb an additional 32 percent by 2005.
Gerontologists, not to mention marketers, already call this age group the "oldest old" -- an unfortunate moniker that sounds only slightly better than "prime of geezerdom." Likewise, people in the 75-to-84 age group have been classified as the "young old" (though you'll find that many women still prefer "of a certain age," especially if you don't want a hatbox in the face).
Traditionally, many brokers have guided Generation A away from owning stocks -- and toward bonds, fixed-income securities and certificates of deposit. And if we're talking about the money you need to live on, that is probably sound advice.
Take it from Edward N. Polisher, a 96-year-old estate planning lawyer at Cozen & O'Connor in Philadelphia. "I wouldn't invest money in equities at my age," Mr. Polisher said. "First of all, my blood pressure can't take the gyrations of this market and second, if stocks go down, there's no time to make it back."
Mr. Polisher knows about plunging prices -- he was married on Oct. 29, 1929. Nearly 70 years later, he says, he puts his money in Government bonds or tax-free securities and "invests in people" -- in worthy causes like underwriting a lecture series at his alma mater.
A case can also be made, however, for taking some financial risks as you head toward the big double-zero. "The idea of putting money you don't need to live on in bonds and fixed-income securities is ludicrous," declared Venita VanCaspel, a former Houston stockbroker, in a feisty, Ann Richards-sounding, "I love you but cut the cards" Texas drawl.
Ms. VanCaspel, the author of six books on investing, argued that "for one, the bond market, like the stock market, fluctuates, and, two, you'll never keep pace with inflation."
What to do? "If you want access to a certain amount of your cash then use a money market account," she said. For the rest, she advises sticking with stocks. Ms. VanCaspel, herself of a certain age, said: "Pick a mutual fund with a lot of large-cap and blue-chip stocks. Most older people have other interests than the stock market" and thus don't have time to track individual stocks.
She recommended three funds for the older investor: Investment Company of America and Washington Mutual Investors, both part of the American Funds, and Janus Worldwide. If you need monthly income, she suggests setting up a check-a-month withdrawal program.
She approves of buying individual stocks, as long as you have the time, training, temperament and money to diversify. "As we mature emotionally, we tend to clutch our money a little harder," she said, mindful of Jackie Mason's remark: "I've got enough money to last the rest of my life, unless I buy something."
Ms. VanCaspel advised steering clear of options and commodities and anything else with a prospectus that weighs more than the last issue of Modern Maturity magazine. For many people, she says, that means sticking "with companies such as Coca-Cola, G.E. and Wal-Mart -- makers or providers of things that people use all the time."
Owning high-technology stocks can be O.K., too, despite their volatility, she said. But if you want to trade them, she warned, "your timing has to be excellent." She suggests buying through a technology mutual fund like Seligman Communications and Information class A or T. Rowe Price Science and Technology.
Pierre L. Schoenheimer, a New York money manager, has an 89-year-old client who has used a simple, buy-and-hold approach to market success without reaching for his beta blocker pills. The client's portfolio consists of one corporate bond and 13 stocks -- mostly in phone, real estate and banking sectors. All 13 had returns above the market average last year.
James P. O'Shaughnessy, chairman of O'Shaughnessy Funds in Greenwich, Conn., and author of "How to Retire Rich" (Broadway Books, $25) offers a different conservative strategy: Go to the top-ranked stocks in the Value Line Investment Survey and buy the 10 that pay the highest dividends. This will net you mostly utility companies like Ameren, Allegheny Energy, Laclede Gas and New England Electric.
And Ms. VanCaspel is adamant that when it comes to Europe over the next two years, no one -- octogenarian or otherwise -- should sit on the sidelines. "They're doing all the things we did 10 years ago -- downsizing, restructuring, and getting more competitive," she said of the Europeans. "The common currency will be fantastic."
Yale Hirsch, editor of the Stock Trader's Almanac, also thinks it's folly to let dormant dollars gather prune-juice rings. But he suggests pushing the envelope further, into a hedge fund. Such funds can take long and short positions, use leverage and invest in derivatives, thus increasing potential risks and rewards. Mr. Hirsch, who is so coy about his age that I suspect he may know all of Franklin D. Roosevelt's campaign song, "Happy Days Are Here Again," asks, "Why not increase your net worth as much as possible in order to pass it on to your heirs?"
For information, you may want to pick up "Fundamentals of Hedge Fund Investing," by William J. Crerend (McGraw-Hill, $55), or subscribe to MAR-Hedge, a monthly newsletter that ranks and tracks 1,300 hedge funds. (800 638-2525, $495 a year).
But before you set your sundial by all this information, consider a man who has decided to invest in his old age by investing in old age itself -- by trying to abolish it.
"Nine years ago I decided that I felt great and was happy and wanted to live much longer," said Miller Quarles, 83. In the American do-it-yourself tradition, Mr. Quarles, a Houston geophysicist, started the Geron Corporation, a biopharmaceutical company in Menlo Park, Calif., whose mission is to develop products for treating cancer and other age-related diseases.
"There must be a longevity gene in every living thing that determines the time of death for each species," Mr. Quarles said. "Or how else would you have butterflies which last only two days and down in the Galapagos Islands, turtles living for 200 years?"
Mr. Quarles is clearly aligning himself with the turtles. He has founded the Curing Old Age Disease Society (713 654-0194) in addition to offering a $100,000 prize to anyone who finds a cure for aging by 2000.
While the reward waits at Nationsbank, Mr. Quarles receives many letters asking him to first send the prize money and promising the cure later. No dice. "I wasn't born yesterday," he said.
Questions about investing, careers and personal finance can be sent to Minding Your Business, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York 10036. Or they may be sent by E-mail to yourmind@nytimes.com. Questions can be answered only in the column, not by mail, E-mail or telephone.

HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.;
Mom, There Are Two Australians in the Bedroom!

BYLINE: By ERIC HUBLER 

 BODY:
JOHN and Raelea Sharpe of South Caulfield, Australia, wanted an unstructured vacation in the United States, but on one detail they were inflexible: no hotels.
"For the past 35, 40 years, I've been traveling internationally and staying in six-star hotels," said Mr. Sharpe, a retired clothing importer. "I'm all hoteled out. I hate hotels. I'm contemptuous of hotels. All they're interested in is taking your money off you and giving you a room to sleep in." 
 So they responded to an item in an Australian newspaper, and after a few faxes back and forth, agreed to stay in the home of a perfect stranger.
The perfect stranger -- Helayne Soloway Wagner, of Flatbush -- also turned out to be a pretty good hostess, at least in the Australians' eyes. "She's done everything for us, every little thing," Mrs. Sharpe said.
Ms. Wagner, a 42-year-old former curriculum writer for the New York City Board of Education, has always enjoyed being host for out-of-towners. So many Israeli friends of friends found their way to her Jackson Heights apartment when she was single that she called it the Israeli Settlement. Now married with three children, she turned pro in November when she founded Homestay New York. Her company aims to provide foreign tourists with inexpensive accommodations and to promote international friendships. Matches are based on shared interests as described in questionnaires that prospective hosts and guests complete.
"If I've done my job correctly, each guest and host have something in common," Ms. Wagner said.
This approach puts Ms. Wagner's singular operation somewhere between the bed-and-breakfast industry and student-exchange programs. But at the same time, Ms. Wagner said, it is a business and she wants to make money.
Homestay New York will place 40 to 50 traveling parties this summer, Ms. Wagner said. They come in waves, depending on when and where her press releases get picked up. First it was Australians, then Italians, now Germans. Ms. Wagner snared the Sharpes for herself because she was curious to meet Australian Jews.
Religion wasn't all they had in common. The couple arrived on June 6, the day of the Belmont Stakes, and "I found out Helayne's husband likes the ponies, like I do," Mr. Sharpe said. He once owned several racehorses and still has a share in one.
"He was in husband heaven," Ms. Wagner recalled. "I whispered to Raelea, 'They're bonding!' " The Sharpes wound up staying a week longer than planned.
This is Homestay's first summer season, and Ms. Wagner says she doesn't have enough homes to meet demand. Guests pay between $95 and $145 a night, double occupancy, depending on location, whether baths are private or shared, and how much cooking the hosts are willing to do. There is a four-night minimum and the hosts keep $35 to $95 a night, leaving $50 or $60 or so for Ms. Wagner. Hosts cannot have back-to-back guests, to prevent hospitality burnout.
What about Homestay's expenses? "My phone bill is high," said Ms. Wagner, who works alone out of her home. She helps her guests with vacation planning -- she found the location of Rachmaninoff's grave (Valhalla, N.Y.) for one couple arriving in August -- and that means lots of calls and faxes, both overseas and domestic. There are also many calls to foreign publications, to drum up publicity about her business.
Given the singularity of her operation, Ms. Wagner has legal questions to contend with, too. She retains one lawyer to advise her on business requirements, but as the recent increase in New York tourists has given rise to illegal bed-and-breakfasts, she sought the counsel of a real estate lawyer as well. The lawyer said there's nothing illegal about paid home stays, but as a precaution she may start collecting hotel tax.
Thus far, most Homestay-brokered visits have been in single-family houses in Ms. Wagner's neighborhood, Midwood Park, a three-square-block oasis of lawns, shade trees and wraparound porches in Flatbush. Midwood Park homeowners took to the idea immediately, said Peggy Wilkins, a resident, because the houses are larger than most families need. Hers has six bedrooms. Also, there is a local tradition of renting rooms to Brooklyn College students.
Ms. Wilkins and her husband like having foreigners around to teach their children a bit about the world, so they signed on with Homestay and have had two Australian couples, with some Italians on the way.
The Australian guests became instant pals. "I treated them like, well, better than I'd treat relatives," Ms. Wilkins said. One wife was a home economics teacher, and Ms. Wilkins sews draperies and slipcovers for architects, so they had the needle trade to talk about.
And their husbands?
"Well, they drank beer out on the porch," Ms. Wilkins said.
Paula and Gail Monroe said on their host questionnaire that they were interested in religions, so Ms. Wagner sent them an Australian pastor and his wife. "We're Russian Orthodox, which is kind of esoteric, and it's interesting to exchange ideas with another religious person," Mrs. Monroe said. One of the Australians' goals for their vacation was to attend an African-American church service, so the Monroes sent them to St. Jerome's, a nearby Roman Catholic church with many black and Hispanic parishioners.
The guests stayed in the upstairs suite the Monroes had renovated for visits from their son and daughter-in-law, both Marine captains. ("Now I have to make an appointment?" her son asked.) The visitors ate well. Mrs. Monroe, a caterer, is writing a cookbook, and needs subjects to try her recipes on. Chicken is expensive in Australia, so she had a couple of happy Aussies on her hands when she made them chicken in yogurt-and-lime sauce.
Ms. Wagner hopes to have a Homestay Web site designed by her husband, Leslie, up and running soon (www.homestayny.com). She has visions of hiring workers, expanding her business to domestic tourists and those from more non-English-speaking countries and even franchising her idea in other American cities.
If your place is no more than 30 minutes from Manhattan by public transit and you are interested in being a host, you can call Ms. Wagner at (718) 434-4433 and she'll visit. Clean before she gets there. Offering her a glass of orange juice wouldn't hurt. But whatever the condition of your house, she has probably seen worse.
At one home Ms. Wagner visited, several walls had collapsed, and an old woman wandered around aimlessly; the would-be host never introduced or acknowledged her. Ms. Wagner took the application anyway. "What was I going to say, 'I think you're a little psychotic and I don't think I can make a match'? Maybe if someone said they were traveling with an imaginary friend. . . ."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 4; Column 4; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1254 words

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
When the News Is Bad, Analysts Feel the Heat

BYLINE: By RICK GLADSTONE 

 BODY:
ALL STREET securities analysts occasionally deliver bad news on a stock. But it's unusual when they unequivocally call their past advice to buy it a blunder.
That is what David Snyder, an analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, did with regard to the shares of the Agco Corporation, a leading maker of farm equipment, whose stock has fallen by a third since March and is languishing in the $19 to $20 range. Mr. Snyder removed Agco from the firm's "recommended list" on May 30, saying the company had often fallen short of earnings expectations since 1996, when it began an enormous expansion overseas. Given that history, he wrote in a summary of Donaldson, Lufkin's stock picks, "investors are not likely to be very patient with any disappointments." 
 But Mr. Snyder went further. He wrote that Agco's stock valuation would likely remain depressed, and that "we have been terribly wrong on Agco's stock over the past two years."
Mr. Snyder subsequently left Donaldson, Lufkin, co-manager of the underwriting of Agco securities in 1996 and 1997, for Dawson Samberg Capital Management, a money management firm. Leslie Thompson, a spokeswoman for Donaldson, Lufkin, called Mr. Snyder's departure and the Agco downgrade coincidental. "A good analyst is an honest analyst," she said. "Mr. Snyder is a very well respected person. We have the highest regard for him."
Mr. Snyder did not return several telephone calls for comment.
Judith Czelusniak, vice president of corporate relations at Agco, said the company, based in Duluth, Ga., had only recently learned that Mr. Snyder had moved on, but she declined to comment on his departure.
Still, Mr. Snyder's downgrade of Agco to "market performance" -- considered a euphemism for "sell" -- was conspicuous because of its blunt, self-critical assessment of a perceived mistake. Against the backdrop of the voracious appetite for stocks in a seven-year-old bull market, a sell signal like that tends to stand out.
"He committed the unforgivable," said Marvin Roffman, a securities analyst at Roffman Miller Associates in Philadelphia. In the "sell side" world of stocks, Mr. Roffman said, "even using the word 'sell' is anathema."
 MR. SNYDER was not the first to lower his opinion of Agco. Eric Hunter, an analyst at S.& P. Equity Group, said he downgraded the stock from "accumulate" to "hold" in January, largely because the company was trying to maintain prices in Latin America, one of its most promising markets, while rivals were cutting theirs. "How long can you maintain that strategy until you lose customers?" he asked.
Others say the stock remains attractive. John Mackin, who follows Agco for Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, said the decline in the share price reflected economic pressures in developing countries that have affected all companies trying to sell costly machinery abroad. His rating on the stock has been a "strong buy" for two years.
Downgrades of stocks have become unusual in the last several years, in part because of a marked change in the role analysts play in a stock's prospects.
These researchers once worked in relative obscurity to help determine which stocks clients should buy and sell. Now, firms compete more aggressively for the lucrative investment banking business of publicly traded companies, so it is in their interest to promote the stocks of those companies.
As a result, critics say, many stock analysts who work for Wall Street firms have grown too cozy with the companies they cover and have lost credibility -- effectively becoming cheerleaders instead.
That may help explain why recommendations to buy stocks vastly outnumber recommendations to hold or sell. The First Call Corporation, a Boston research firm that tracks analysts' opinions on 6,000 stocks, says more than a third are rated "strong buys," slightly less than a third are "buys," and most of the rest are "holds." Only 1 percent are "sells."
Chuck Hill, research director for First Call and a former securities analyst himself, said there was more fear now among analysts that they would offend their firm's investment banking departments or the companies they cover.
"There is some reluctance to put a sell on a stock," Mr. Hill said. "It's tougher now to be independent."
Others are far more indignant about what they regard as a high level of excessively optimistic analysis, which they say hurts investors' ability to gauge a stock's prospects.
"Unequivocally, what you'll see is that today, analysts are like the front guys," said Mr. Roffman, a former analyst at Janney Montgomery Scott, a Philadelphia investment firm. "They can't tell it like it really is."
Mr. Roffman speaks from experience: He was dismissed by Janney Montgomery in 1990 after he refused to retract a negative report about the financial stability of Donald J. Trump's Taj Mahal casino after Mr. Trump had complained and pushed for Mr. Roffman's dismissal. Mr. Roffman then started his own research firm, unfettered by possible conflicts that might arise if he were also trying to generate investment banking fees. Mr. Roffman also sued Mr. Trump, contending defamation, settled the case for an undisclosed sum and was awarded $750,000 from Janney Montgomery in a New York Stock Exchange arbitration claim.
Mr. Roffman's case was well known in the industry, but there have been other, less publicized examples. Wall Street firms sometimes lose a client company's investment banking business because of a downgrade, and analysts have been ostracized by a company in retaliation for a downgrade. Sometimes, a company sharply curtails analyst access to management if it deems that a rating on its stock is too low.
In April, Michael L. Mayo, a banking analyst at Credit Suisse First Boston, was excluded from a Mellon Bank analysts meeting. When he asked why, he said Mellon executives told him it was "because of your rating on the stock." Mr. Mayo rates Mellon as a "hold." Mellon declined to comment.
Even analysts who do not work for Wall Street firms can find it difficult to appraise a company's stock critically. Like others, they try to maintain cordial relations with a company's management to gain access to information that will help them evaluate growth potential.
"We have a lot more leeway than these guys on the Street. There's not much a company can do if we downgrade its stock," said Mr. Hunter of S.& P. Equity Group. Still, he said, issuing a downgrade "is never a comfortable situation."
Sometimes, however, a sell signal can make an analyst a hero. Andrew Shore, an analyst at Paine Webber, downgraded the shares of the Sunbeam Corporation in early April before the appliance company -- formerly a Wall Street darling -- began a plunge from the mid-$40's to the $10 level last month. Mr. Shore was also the first analyst to publicly question the capability of Albert J. Dunlap, Sunbeam's chief executive, who was dismissed on June 13 amid growing questions about the company's accounting practices.
"I don't think I had made a major sell call like this in my whole life," Mr. Shore recalled.
Immediately after he downgraded the stock, Mr. Shore said, he received some "extremely nasty phone messages." Weeks later, he said, some of those same callers phoned to apologize and to thank him.
Mr. Shore said that he felt vindicated but that any analyst who issued a sell recommendation had better be right.
"There's a lot more pressure when you say sell," he said. "Everyone who owns it at least listens when you say sell."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: TRIBECA -- UPDATE;
That On-Again, Off-Again Street Plan Is On Again

BYLINE: By BERNARD STAMLER 

 BODY:
After more than a decade of stops and starts and unmet promises to begin work, it looks this month as if the on-again, off-again greening of Greenwich Street project is finally and irrevocably on. Again.
This time the word comes directly from Charles Millard, the president of the city's Economic Development Corporation, who called plan proponents right before the July 4 holiday weekend to give them the news. "He told me that they were going to go forward," said City Councilwoman Kathryn Freed, "and that work would begin right away" on the street-narrowing and tree-planting project that has been in the works, in one form or another, since 1987. 
 Officials of Community Board 1 and members of the Friends of Greenwich Street report receiving the same message, although no one knows the reason for the sudden announcement. The plan had been in administrative limbo ever since a round of winter meetings between its advocates and its detractors, notably Drew Nieporent, the restaurateur, and his brother Tracy.
The brothers, who operate the TriBeCa Grill on Greenwich Street and nearby high-profile restaurants like Nobu and Montrachet, were accused by some of "holding the neighborhood hostage," as Ms. Freed put it, to their desire for double and triple parking of their customers' limousines on the street.
This winter, however, plan proponents secured letters of support from, among others, Representative Jerrold L. Nadler and Sanford I. Weill, the chairman of the Travelers Group, whose headquarters are diagonally across from the TriBeCa Grill.
Mr. Millard declined to talk about the reasons behind the restart, although a spokeswoman for his office confirmed that bids would be taken this fall for construction next spring. In a prepared statement, he said only that he had been glad to help opposing parties come to a compromise. (Other E.D.C. officials, however, said the plan remains unchanged.)
The go-ahead was news to Tracy Nieporent, who said he has yet to hear officially of the city's decision. Still, he struck a conciliatory note. "We still think this is bad urban planning," he said. "But we hope now that we're proven wrong." BERNARD STAMLER

Ms. Robbins And Mr. Dowling

 BODY:
Jacqueline Sara Robbins, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart M. Robbins of Old Greenwich, Conn., was married on Monday to James Joseph Dowling, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James J. Dowling of Doylestown, Pa. Leonard Levy, a justice of the peace in New Haven, officiated in his office there.
The couple graduated from Yale University, from which the bridegroom also received a master's degree in molecular biochemistry and biophysics.
Ms. Robbins, 26, is keeping her name. She teaches the first and second grades at the Ancona School in Chicago. Her father is the managing director of the equities division at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, the New York investment bank.

Dowling, is the chairwoman of the arts department at Newtown (Pa.) Junior High School, where she teaches home economics. His father is the Eastern regional manager of sales and marketing at Ethan Allen, the furniture store chain in Danbury, Conn.

HEADLINE: In SoHo, as Galleries Depart, Temples of Beauty Are the Show

BYLINE: By JUDITH NEWMAN 

 BODY:
A PALE woman in black stands on the corner of Mercer and Prince Streets, twirling like a weather vane. "Lip liner?" she mutters, stepping forward, then abruptly swings around 90 degrees. "Or polish?" A young visitor from Denmark, she's in hot pursuit of beauty, but she's not sure where to start.
If she walks due west, she can nab a favorite lip liner at Shu Uemura. Then again, a silvery nail polish she likes -- called, she thinks, Obscenity -- is one block south at Face Stockholm. Later, she might have her skin exfoliated to the strains of Enya at Haven, a New Age day spa on Mercer Street. Her tattooed and branded boyfriend stares coolly into the distance, contemplating a nonexistent horizon. This was probably not how he planned to spend his day. 
 Something strange is happening in SoHo. The skin trade has moved in. Not the one Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani fumes about, but rather the kind that plies toners, moisturizers and other forms of hope in a bottle.
"The meatpackers have their district, the financial guys, the garmentos, the flower people -- they all have theirs," said Marcia Kilgore, owner of Bliss Spa on Broadway. "So why shouldn't we have our lipstick district?"
Within the rectangle bordered by Broadway, the Avenue of the Americas and Houston and Spring Streets, there are at least six day spas and nine beauty-product retailers, many of which sprang up in the last nine months.
With the flight of art galleries to Chelsea, beauty has become SoHo's new art -- or at least, that's how cosmetics retailers want consumers to think of it.
The stores are even designed like galleries, with soaring spaces and high-tech installations. And they want to offer a form of artistic satisfaction, which means visual excitement, spiritual enrichment and lots and lots of people-watching.
Why the onslaught? "The whole idea is to get individual brands out of the clutter of department stores," said John Ledes, editor and publisher of Cosmetic World, a trade magazine.
The biggest news along Skin Row, as the new cosmetics district has been dubbed by the beauty industry, is next week's opening of Sephora, France's largest perfume and cosmetics retailer. The first of 14 planned American outlets, the Sephora at 555 Broadway is a 9,000-square-foot behemoth selling strictly up-market brands.
The store's design is, to say the least, arresting: the womblike circularity of the displays; the black, white and red color scheme; the laptop computers (for finding product information on the Internet), and the cavernous space make the store seem like a cosmetics mother ship built by the engineers of the Starship Enterprise.
Sephora is only the latest and most ambitious of beauty retailers to head to the area better known for canvases by Eric Fischl than for facials. Outlets for Mac Cosmetics, Aveda and Origins -- all owned by the Estee Lauder company -- have been around for years, but since last fall, the competition has gone into overdrive. L'Occitane, a skin- and hair-care company from Provence, opened a branch on Spring Street in October.
Shu Uemura, a Japanese makeup artist, opened his high temple of beauty on Greene Street in November. And in May, Shiseido politely muscled in with 5S (that stands for "Five Senses") on Prince Street.
Elaine Good, a makeup artist who has worked in cosmetics retailing and teaches at the Fashion Institute of Technology, says that the SoHo beauty outlets are setting themselves apart from department-store beauty counters by offering nonaggressive service. "In a department store, you're assaulted by women spraying you with perfume and almost forcing you into a makeover in an effort to sell, sell, sell," she said. "People are sick of it."
Allan G. Mottus, editor of The Informationist, a cosmetics industry trade publication, confirms the disaffection. "Since the early 90's, department-store traffic has continually slowed," he said.
The SoHo stores are going to great lengths to distinguish themselves in the eyes of consumers, even though almost every one, echoing the industry's marketing catch phrases, says it is "about color," "about choice" and "about creativity."
Makeup Forever, for instance, lures strollers inside with a woman whose indigo toenail polish matches the jeweled bindi on her brow. She sits in the window painting henna designs on skin.
It seems it's no longer enough for makeup to make a woman simply look better. "We're for the soul, as well as the body," Beth Ofier, Face Stockholm's store manager, insisted, echoing the sentiments of many others who hawk blusher.
Perhaps more than any other place, Shu Uemura takes this philosophy to heart. "Notice that everything in this store is circular," said Kim Ryan, the store manager, who sports a circular tatoo around her bicep that reads, "That which doesn't kill makes us stronger."
With black-lacquer packaging for everything from $20 lip glosses to inexpensive blotting papers, all displayed in calming, bone-color cases, Shu Uemura is perhaps the most starkly beautiful of the stores, if the most intimidating.
One shopper, a fresh-scrubbed 30-something woman, stepped tentatively into the store, eyeballed the modelesque sales personnel and fled.
But the creepy Zen calm is perhaps the appropriate ambiance for Mr. Uemura, a man given to pronouncements like, "Listen to the voice of your skin" and "There is a circle to beauty."
Every store has its gimmick. Shu Uemura has a set of recessed light simulation boxes in the wall where the shopper can see how makeup colors, tested on the hand, look in outdoor, fluorescent and other light conditions. L'Occitane uses Braille on most of its packages. "An effort to bring the benefits of natural beauty to blind and partially sighted people," the store's catalogue explains.
Origins is so environmentally friendly that one willowy blond shopper wondered aloud why the green-and-khaki-clad staff members were impersonating forest rangers.
Sephora promises a wall of more than 400 lipsticks, a skin treatment library, organized by problems and solutions, and a fragrance organ, a display where shoppers can dab and spritz at will. "And I promise you, men will feel comfortable shopping here," said Sherry Baker, vice president for international marketing.
Sephora's salesclerks, known as product consultants, are to be outfitted in unisex black tunics, and each will wear one black glove to "showcase the product, like a jewel at Cartier's," Ms. Baker explained.
All the SoHo stores maintain that they are places where a shopper can experiment and play, although the play is supposed to be serious.
At Shiseido's 2,700-square-foot 5S, a mid-price cosmetics line geared toward women in their 20's and 30's, there is the muted sound of running water coming from somewhere. Photographs of ethnically diverse models line the walls. There are magazines to read, and there is icy lotus tea to sip, as a "beauty partner" -- please, not a salesclerk -- materializes from seemingly nowhere to explain the 5S philosophy.
Perhaps someone will one day write a dissertation about this philosophy, but suffice it to say that it has to do with how you want to feel and knowing which products will help you feel that way.
For example, "energizing sense" products are for a woman who wants extra power and firmer-looking skin; "nurturing sense" products are for one who craves comfort and nourishment. If she might want a little of each -- comfort and firm skin -- presumably, she's on her own.
Jacalyn Lee, a woman with delicate dreadlocks gathered in a ponytail, hunched over one of the store's many computers the other day, her brow furrowed in concentration. The computer suggested words for how she was feeling, or wanted to feel.
Ms. Lee hesitantly clicked on phrases like "revive your spirit," "need willpower" and "empowering." Finally, "peace" and "smooth complexion" drifted by in little word bubbles. Ms. Lee eagerly clicked on both.
"That's what the whole world wants, really," she murmured. "Peace and a smooth complexion."
At this point, a confusing array of 5S products popped onto the screen. Ms. Lee ignored them, opting instead for the $10 bottle of Charm glitter powder she was going to buy to begin with. But she was pleased, and rubbing the powder on her arms, she returned sparkling to the streets of SoHo.
Whether beauty becomes as integral to SoHo as fish is to Fulton Market is an open question. "I don't think the single-brand stores can succeed economically," Mr. Ledes of Cosmetic World said, adding that Sephora seems to have the best chance in SoHo for long-term success.
"The American woman has one quote, unquote, failing, which is a love of selection and variety," he said. "The one-brand stores will have a great difficulty in surmounting that historic habit."
In the meantime, the great migration of single-brand stores to SoHo continues. By the end of the year, Helena Rubenstein plans to open a space on Spring Street, which will be both store and day spa. As Mr. Ledes put it, "SoHo is going to be so overburdened with beauty, you'll be lucky if you can find a grocery store."

HEADLINE: EARNING IT;
Minding the Children While on the Road

BYLINE: By JULIA LAWLOR 

 BODY:
THE last time Rebecca Teiken left town on a four-day business trip, her 5-year-old son, Spencer, was cared for by a sitter. Ms. Teiken made sure Spencer had his favorite blanket and stuffed animals, called him every night to chat and counted the hours until she would see him again.
But one thing that didn't trouble her was the cost of Spencer's overnight care. Her employer, Amoco, reimburses workers for dependent care -- to a maximum of $1,500 a year -- when they travel overnight on business and there is no other family member at home to care for a child or, in some cases, an elderly relative. As a single parent who travels often, Ms. Teiken says the policy allows her to pursue a career she loves without sacrificing peace of mind. 
 "When I travel, this is one less thing I have to worry about," said Ms. Teiken, 40, a project manager for Amoco in Des Moines. In her area of the country, the going rate for overnight care is about $50 a day. "I know I can pay the caregiver well," she said, "and that reduces the stress on me so I can focus on the work."
Amoco is one of a relatively small number of companies offering such benefits to employees who must travel as part of their jobs. The Families and Work Institute, a research firm in New York, has found that 6 percent of companies with 100 or more employees reimburse child care expenses when workers travel on business.
In a global economy, travel has become a fact of life for more and more workers. In 1996, the most recent data show, 42.9 million Americans traveled on business, a 21 percent increase from 1991, according to the Travel Industry Association of America. One in five employees regularly takes overnight business trips, according to a 1997 study by the Families and Work Institute. What's more, the workplace is increasingly populated by single parents -- almost one of every five employed parents is single, the study indicated.
Even so, many companies that offer such a child care benefit say that relatively few workers take advantage of it.
"I don't use it that often," said Bonnie Anderson, vice president of employee relations for American Express Financial Advisors in Minneapolis. Ms. Anderson, 49, a single mother who travels once or twice a month for her job, usually arranges for her parents or close friends to care for her daughter, Sashi, 10, when she cannot be there.
But occasionally a backup plan can fall through, and she must pay for overnight care. About a year and a half ago, just before a trip to California, Ms. Anderson wound up hiring her daughter's regular day-care provider to care for her for two nights, and the $50 extra cost was reimbursed.
"This is not a huge economic benefit for me, but what I like about it is that the company wants to do the right thing," said Ms. Anderson, who lives in Robbinsdale, Minn.
Amoco, based in Chicago, began its program in 1993 as it started to see an increase in employee travel. Roughly 160 people used the benefit last year, out of a total of 28,000 employees in the United States, the company said.
"We want to help employees meet the balance between work and their personal lives," said Patricia Massucci, Amoco's director of corporate policies and work-life strategies.
Some employees, however, may question whether such a policy helps employees lead a more satisfying personal life, or simply keeps them on the job and away from home longer.
Employers should consider ways to structure their work so that travel is not always necessary, said Karol L. Rose, leader of the work-life effectiveness practice for Global Human Resource Solutions, a benefits consulting unit of Pricewaterhouse Coopers L.L.P., the accounting giant. A sales call might be made just as easily through a video conference, for instance, as through a face-to-face meeting.
"This benefit is fine as far as it goes," Ms. Rose said. "But there should be lots of options. Having the company pay for your dependent care when you're traveling is not the solution, but it may come in handy."
One business rethinking its expectations for employee travel is Pricewaterhouse Coopers. "We're looking at ways of doing for travel what has been done for child care," said Iris Goldfein, head of Global Human Resource Solutions. "We can't take travel out of our business, but we can make it easier."
The firm is testing a program in its Philadelphia office to reimburse workers for dependent care costs incurred while traveling. For the last year, a new policy in its management consulting division dictates that employees do not travel on Sundays. The firm is also considering whether to limit travel on Fridays.
"Plain and simple, we are trying to get people more time with their families," Ms. Goldfein said. Reimbursing workers for child care costs, she said, is one way of recognizing "that travel is an additional burden."
Some companies, like John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance in Boston and HBO, the premium cable division of Time Warner, reimburse child care expenses when employees are out of town only if their jobs do not normally require travel.
"This is not appropriate for a salesperson whose job is to travel three days a week," said Shelley Fischel, vice president of human resources and administration at HBO. "If you have to go to a conference once a year, you'd qualify."
Some employers also reimburse child care costs if a worker's business travel creates a need for additional child care during evenings or on weekends. Mark Majors, 34, a Chevron engineer in Pascagoula, Miss., was reimbursed a total of $500 last year for evening child care when he had to travel overnight and his wife, Kim, a pharmacist, worked late hours.
Peter Carter, 35, a lawyer for Dorsey & Whitney in Minneapolis, is reimbursed between $500 and $700 a year when he travels to cover the times he and his wife must hire a baby sitter, at $9 an hour, to watch their four children, all under age 7. Though Carter's wife, Dede, is a stay-at-home mom, she has volunteer commitments that keep her away from home on nights and weekends; her husband is often called out of town at the last minute.
 IN two of her last three jobs, Cynthia Ahart, 41, now a marketing executive for a computer trade publication, has been reimbursed for all or part of the child care expenses incurred because of her travel. A single mother of a 13-year-old daughter, Alexandra, Ms. Ahart says she travels 30 percent of the time and has spent as much as $150 a night for child care. One week-long trip to a conference cost her $1,200, with less than half of it reimbursed.
"Being able to travel and being visible is critical," said Ms. Ahart, a resident of Newton, Mass., who will soon be transferring to her hometown of San Francisco. "I hate leaving her alone, but I've been able to triple my income in five years. Much of what I do is sales-related. You have to be face to face with people. Management has to have the impression you're willing to go the extra mile for the client."
Before accepting one job, Ms. Ahart negotiated partial payment of her child care bills while on the road despite the fact that the company did not have such a policy. Still, the strain of traveling has made her want to cut back. After she moves to San Francisco, Ms. Ahart plans to leave her daughter with her parents or ex-husband when she has to travel -- and to be at home more.
"Now that she's a teen-ager, it's important for me to be there," Ms. Ahart said. "My next demand, instead of asking for more money, will be to ask for less travel."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: GOWANUS;
Dredging Up A Revived Waterway

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
The muck-ridden Gowanus Canal, which dates to the 19th century and runs through Cobble Hill, Park Slope and Carroll Gardens, has been so smelly that for decades it's been compared to the River Styx, the mythological river of the dead. Many people who live nearby have all but given up hope of seeing something done about the odor. But now the city is set to take a step toward addressing the problem.
The New York City Department of Environmental Protection says dredging at the mouth of the Gowanus Canal, near DeGraw and Bond Streets, is set to begin this week and will last as long as five weeks. 
 The work is part of a $10 million city project to partly dredge the canal and flush cleaner water through it. That will involve putting an underground brick flushing tunnel, which dates to 1911, back into operation. The tunnel, which runs 6,300 feet from the Gowanus Canal to Buttermilk Channel, would bring water from New York Harbor into the canal.
But the tunnel hasn't been used since 1963, when the flushing device, which resembles a propeller, broke down and wasn't repaired. The muck in the canal -- mostly a combination of human waste, street refuse, oil and harbor silt -- got thicker and thicker until it resembled a giant clogged drain.
The propeller was finally fixed this year. But until the dredging is done, the city won't flip the switch to flush out the mess.
The dredging was supposed to be done in June. Why the delay? A D.E.P. spokeswoman, Cathy DelliCarpini, said the sediment had to be assessed for toxic chemicals (trace amounts were found) and an appropriate disposal site had to be located (it will be shipped to Delaware).
"There's been delay after delay, so we're worried," said Salvatore Scotto, the chairman of the Gowanus Canal Community Development Corporation and an advocate for more than 20 years of cleaning up the canal. "If it stretches past August, we'll just have to start picketing."
But John C. Muir, executive director of the Brooklyn Center for the Urban Environment, said, "This delay is merely a ripple."
Mr. Scotto's group wants the cleanup of the canal to be the first step in transforming it into a revived waterfront with elegant canal-side cafes and apartments. Mr. Muir's group and others favor bicycle paths and more park space.
Both groups hope to persuade government officials to dredge the entire canal of sediment -- perhaps 30,000 cubic yards, at least 15 truckloads -- instead of the 2,000 cubic yards at the mouth. More dredging, they say, would insure that the canal would stay clean.
Meanwhile, Place in History, a Manhattan arts group, is going forward with plans to raise about $7,000 for a series of viewing boxes to be set up along the canal in August. The viewing boxes would have historical photographs dating back to the 1860's, when the canal was built, to the early 20th century when the canal was an active waterway for barges. ANTHONY RAMIREZ
