HEADLINE: The World: Bolivia Falls Short;
When Even an Economic Miracle Isn't Enough

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

DATELINE: LA PAZ, Bolivia

 BODY:
ALL around Latin America, book stores are well stocked with new texts about free markets and global free trade. Such books brim with hope for the future, and they are beginning to appear even in this backwater capital high in the Andes. But here, they still have to share shelf space with a rather depressing best-seller that carries a very different message.
The book, first published in 1937, is Alcides Arguedas' "A Sick People," and it seems at times that every literate Bolivian has read it. It indicts Bolivia's history and national character as a blight of corruption, provincialism and racial hatred, a synthesis of "laziness, poverty, barbarism." That conclusion, and the book's abiding popularity, highlight the challenges that the global free-market revolution faces here. 
 As that revolution is increasingly accepted around the world as the wave of the future, Bolivia's experience also can serve as a lesson for other countries -- Cambodia and Congo, for example -- that are also plagued by intractable geographical disadvantages, caste structures and unstable political histories. The lesson is the limits of the miracles promised by global free enterprise.
 
Not Enough Growth
 Carlos F. Toranzo Roca, a prominent Bolivian economist, sums up the lesson this way: "You don't eradicate centuries of structural social inequalities with 4 percent growth rates."
That, however, is exactly what a series of Bolivian Governments has tried to do since 1985, with the help of American economic advisors including Jeffrey D. Sachs, the director of Harvard University's Institute for International Development.
In a number of ways, the results have been spectacular. First, the Government tackled a 24,000 percent annual inflation rate by slashing its budget and subsidies, and instituting property and value-added taxes. The inflation rate was reduced to single digits virtually overnight.
Per capita income, which had fallen by 30 percent between 1985 and 1990, began to climb an average of between 4 and 5 percent a year, and with economic stability came political stability. The nearly ritualistic annual coups that Bolivia had suffered through for more than a century were replaced by a series of clean, peaceful elections.
The last Bolivian Government ceded a controlling share of the Government oil, railroad, electricity, telephone and airline monopolies to foreign corporations and overhauled the country's tax and pension systems, diversifying the economy and boosting savings rates in the process. Hoping to soften political opposition to the privatization, the Government put large minority holdings in the firms into a private pension trust fund that is beginning to pay all Bolivians older than 65 a modest annuity. Foreign investment is blossoming, and a new pipeline will soon deliver natural gas to Brazil.
Signs of globalization are popping up in the most unlikely places. Indian trinket stands in La Paz are beginning to accept American Express cards. Peasant union leaders now wear cellular telephones on their belts. A fading mural depicting a defiant Che Guevara on the campus of the national university now pales alongside a bright new Coca Cola advertisement. Bolivia, where most people still drink coca tea and a high-octane maize liquor called chicha, is even beginning to export wine.
Still, the results remain mixed for the great majority of poor Bolivians.
The average Bolivian still earns $900 a year, less than one-fifth what the average Argentine or Chilean earns, and few of the poor can expect to live long enough to see the benefits of economic growth trickle down to transform their existence into anything like a middle class lifestyle.
 
Too Little Schooling

While the cities of La Paz, Cochabamba and Santa Cruz are booming with new condominiums, banks and McDonald's franchises, the rural Indian highlands continue to fall behind. Foreign investors can't be enticed to build factories in mountain areas where shipping costs are prohibitive, where even a third-grade education is unusual and where only 1 percent of the people have finished high school. More than half of all Bolivians speak Indian dialects as their first language and many speak no Spanish at all. Forty percent of the children in La Paz are chronically undernourished.
That is not to say the lower classes have made no progress. While life expectancy at birth remains a miserably low 60 years, that is a major improvement over the 42 years that an infant born in 1960 was expected to live. Only 55 percent of the population currently has access to potable water, but in 1975 only 34 percent did.
Still, this amount of progress is not enough to stem the widening of the income gap between rich and poor, and particularly between city dwellers and rural Indians -- although it apparently has helped lend Bolivia a semblance of stability.
"The key to sustained economic growth is education, and you can't educate a country overnight," conceded Vice President Jorge Fernando Quiroga Ramirez.
The new Government of President Hugo Banzer Suarez is planning a rural literacy campaign, and has proposed steps to help poor people acquire loans. But with the region's economies beginning to slow in the wake of the Asian financial crisis, no new economic boom is anywhere in sight.
Another intractable problem is Bolivia's virtual inability to ship by sea, given the fact that its access to the Pacific Ocean was lost in a war with Chile over 100 years ago, and the two countries have not forgiven each other. Bolivia and Chile still do not have diplomatic relations, leaving Bolivia dependent on unreliable mountain roads and expensive air traffic to export its goods.
"There are probably not any more economic policy dials that can be easily turned in Bolivia," Mr. Sachs acknowledged. "You can do marvelous reforms, but still have very significant problems in achieving a rapid improvement of living standards."
 
Too Much History
 One thing economic reform can't change is history.
Bolivia's Andean remoteness protected its Indians from the European smallpox and plague that decimated most of Latin America's indigenous populations. So a large Indian population remained to be exploited by the Spanish colonizers as miners and tenant farmers, and what emerged was a highly stratified society wracked by class strife.
Bolivia was so unruly with caste and Indian wars that its namesake, Simon Bolivar, fled it in disgust after he wrote a constitution inspired by the most enlightened European ideals. The constitution survived on paper, but the society went through more than 250 rebellions and military coups over the next 150 years.
A longstanding joke among neighboring Argentines compared Bolivia to a long-playing record: "33 revolutions a minute."
The quip now seems as dated as the phonograph itself, but many vestiges of class conflict survive.
According to the United States Government's 1997 human rights report on Bolivia, "some rural indigenous workers are kept in a state of virtual slavery by employers who charge them more for room and board than they earn." A system of child servitude known as criadito survives in which Indian parents indenture their pre-adolescent children to middle- and upper-income families to perform household chores. Many of the children are badly abused.
"Bolivia has made tremendous progress," said Herbert Klein, a Columbia University historian who specializes in Bolivia, "but it starts from an incredibly backward base compared to everyone else in Latin America." And with virtually every other country in Latin America following the same successful economic policies, there is no reason to believe Bolivia will catch up with its neighbors any time soon.

HEADLINE: How a Swiss Bank Gold Deal Eluded a U.S. Mediator

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 11

 BODY:
Late on a Friday night two weeks ago, just before months of bitter negotiations between Switzerland's three major commercial banks and Holocaust survivors collapsed, one of the Clinton Administration's most senior diplomats placed an urgent call to the President of Switzerland, Flavio Cotti.
The diplomat, Stuart E. Eizenstat, the Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, told the Swiss President that the two sides were narrowing their differences. But after rounds and rounds of talks in New York and Washington, neither side was willing to move further. 
 The Swiss Government, Mr. Eizenstat said, had the power both to speed a settlement and to end a 50-year-long chapter of its history that tarnished Switzerland's reputation around the globe. He urged Mr. Cotti to reverse a long-held position and have the Swiss Government contribute to a "global settlement" with Jewish groups and with Holocaust victims and their heirs.
He even suggested a figure: more than $300 million, a large sum but only a fraction of the $2.8 billion in Nazi gold, measured in today's values, that a Swiss historical commission recently concluded was received on behalf of Nazi Germany by the Swiss central bank.
Mr. Cotti refused.
While Mr. Eizenstat declines to discuss details of the discussion, he said "no common understanding was reached" in the conversation. "It is our impression that the cycle of accusation and counteraccusations had substantially hardened opinion in Switzerland," said Mr. Eizenstat, who has led the State Department's efforts to settle the contentious issue.
Thomas G. Borer, the Swiss ambassador for Holocaust issues, was even more direct.
"The mood in Switzerland has changed in the past year, and Mr. Cotti explained this," Mr. Borer said in a telephone interview. "Most Swiss don't even want to talk about a global settlement. They know that whatever we do, no one gets credit."
Several participants in the negotiations now say that Switzerland's hard-line position -- a refusal even to consider joining the private banks in settling the legal claims -- helped scuttle an agreement in late June. And while a settlement is not dead, it is clear that announcements this past spring that a settlement was in the offing were premature. There are indications that talks could resume in a few months, as New York and California begin to carry out sanctions against Swiss businesses operating in the United States.
But Mr. Eizenstat's unusual, direct appeal to Mr. Cotti, and lower-level talks between American and Swiss diplomats, had echoes of an earlier time. Nearly two generations ago, in 1946, the State Department tried to get Switzerland to disgorge the huge profits it accumulated when it served as banker to Nazi Germany, taking in stolen gold, jewelry, art and other property.
The result was an agreement called the Washington Accord, now regarded as a diplomatic fiasco, in which Switzerland agreed to turn over a small part of its holdings to repay countries invaded by Germany and to aid refugees. But it never fulfilled major parts of the accord, and it has resisted several efforts in the years since to settle the accounts. The Swiss central bank did make a contribution of more than $70 million to a humanitarian fund, but it has said that was a one-time act of compassion -- not something that will be repeated under legal pressure.
Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York, who has led the investigations into the Nazi gold questions, has scheduled hearings for later this month on the question of whether the United States should try to reopen the Washington agreement, a step the Clinton Administration has been loath to take, saying that it would irreparably breach the American relationship with the Swiss.
Mr. Eizenstat has been scurrying for more than a year now to avoid that. This spring he turned out a detailed study of how other neutral nations dealt extensively with the Nazis during World War II, a study that seemed intended to make the Swiss seemed less of a lone target.
All spring, he acted as a go-between in the negotiations between the three big private Swiss banks -- Union Bank of Switzerland, Swiss Bank Corporation and Credit Suisse -- and the fractious group of plaintiffs who are suing them. In early June, just before the New York State Banking Commission was supposed to consider an application for the merger of Union Bank of Switzerland and the Swiss Bank Corporation, the banks began to offer larger settlements.
But they had a condition: before Mr. Eizenstat could convey their offer of several hundred million dollars, the banking commission had to approve the merger. The commission had suggested earlier in the year that it might hold up the American approval -- critical to operating on Wall Street -- because the banks had not been diligent enough in tracking down Holocaust-era accounts.
"We believe that there was no legitimate regulatory objection to the merger," said Roger Witten, the lead lawyer for the banks, "and we wanted to make sure that we were free from efforts to use that process to extort a result on another front."
Mr. Eizenstat called the World Jewish Congress to say a major offer was on the way, and sent a letter confirming that he was in possession of "a firm and concrete offer from the banks for settlement of the class action litigation" that would be conveyed after the merger was approved. With that assurance, the Jewish groups said they would drop their past objections to the merger.
The banks, pushed further by Mr. Eizenstat, ultimately offered $530 million for a "rough justice fund" that would pay the plaintiffs and be used to help indigent survivors of the Holocaust.
"We came up with a reasonable estimate, based on the very limited dealings the commercial banks had with German gold," Mr. Witten said, and then multiplied the figure several times, he said, explaining how the banks came to that number.
The Jewish groups, however, were looking for something closer to $1.5 billion, and dismissed the banks' offer as insulting. (In addition to the $530 million, the banks have previously pledged to pay any amounts mandated by an independent commission headed by Paul Volcker, the former Federal Reserve chairman, which is reviewing long-dormant wartime accounts in Swiss banks.)
Bitter charges were exchanged. Some of the plaintiffs charged that the banks, having received the merger approval, were no longer motivated to increase their offers significantly. The banks, in turn, charged that the Holocaust survivors and Jewish groups, which have fought among themselves over strategy, were trying to obtain more money with threats of bad publicity and possible economic sanctions against the banks.
In fact, a meeting to impose sanctions -- headed by Alan Hevesi, the New York City Comptroller -- loomed in late June, prompting Mr. Eizenstat to call President Cotti. He offered a rationale: the Swiss National Bank, which is Government-owned, received more than 85 percent of the gold deposited by Nazi Germany. Commercial banks got just a fraction.
But Mr. Cotti refused even to bring the issue in front of the legislature, saying it would only further inflame public opinion.

HEADLINE: For Las Vegas Locals, Heavy Action Is at the Buffet

BYLINE: By FRANK BRUNI 

DATELINE: LAS VEGAS, Nev., July 11

 BODY:
Any outsider would have mistaken Ty Seedig for a waiter, so nimbly did he balance three full-size dinner plates in one hand, so fleetly did he hurtle toward a table in the rear of a restaurant at the Main Street Station hotel and casino here.
But any local resident would have caught the longing in Mr. Seedig's eyes and the delight on his lips and known exactly what he was: a buffet hound, practiced at the trick of maximizing each trip down the trough. 
 On his latest foray, he had netted what looked like an entire bed of clams, a wedge of ahi tuna, a slab of trout and, of course, a huge steak, this being T-bone night, which jacked up the price all the way to $10.99. Normally, it was $9.99, already a tad steep by Las Vegas standards.
"I do about six buffets a week," Mr. Seedig, 38, said Tuesday night as he rotated the plates before him to get a better angle at the T-bone, which was obstructed by several red potatoes and an ear of corn. His trimness suggested a metabolism worthy of scientific research.
"For being fast and cheap," he mumbled between forkfuls, "you can't beat a buffet."
That could be the motto for this desert city, the nation's capital of gorging as well as gambling.
Overstuffed, underpriced smorgasbords have long been a staple of Las Vegas's tourist trade, an enticement and reward for spending money in casinos. But a lure for heavy rollers is becoming a life style for heavy eaters as the city's resident population swells.
Most of the people who line up at the buffets in casinos away from "the Strip" live in Las Vegas, and the buffets they patronize are growing more absurdly, insanely bountiful.
The one at Main Street Station takes so many twists and turns along its odyssey from iceberg lettuce to carrot cake that a person would be wise to leave a trail of multicolored cheese cubes to find the way back.
But Marvin Faleck and Anthony Ippolito had no trouble with their bearings. Since moving to Las Vegas from Long Island two years ago, they have been on something of a buffet safari.
It has taken them to more than a dozen buffets both off and on the Strip, including an Oktoberfest event at the Nevada Palace that featured vats of sauerkraut and a polka band, all for $6.99.
"But I don't think we've done the MGM buffet," Mr. Faleck, 40, said on Tuesday night as he munched on some of Main Street's undeniably tasty fried chicken.
"The Oz buffet?" Mr. Ippolito, 38, responded, nibbling pizza. "Yes, we have."
"Luxor and Excalibur -- feh!" Mr. Faleck said, dismissing two buffets with one syllable. "It's $5.99 at Excalibur; you figure, how can you go wrong? Feh!"
"Monte Carlo wasn't feh," he added, "it was eh."
One of their friends, Danny Schaeffer, 28, swallowed part of a burrito and chimed in that an unfortunate episode several months ago left him wary of how long the food is maintained at safe temperatures.
"After that experience," he said, "I never say a buffet is good until I've gone home, slept through the night and gotten up in the morning without anything going wrong."
Perhaps the most ardent pilgrims to the buffets are retirees, who get coupons, discounts and other breaks that often put the price of a limitless meal for two below $10. That includes non-alcoholic beverages and as much pie, cake and pastry as a body can manage.
The buffet mavens of Las Vegas manage a lot. And they know exactly when and where to go.
"The Gold Coast only charges something like $5.30 for its lunch buffet," said Ted Morgenbesser, 61, who took an early retirement from his insurance job in Manhattan last year and moved here with his wife, Vicki.
"But it serves until 3," Mr. Morgenbesser said. "So if you get there at 2:30 and have your big meal for the day, it's basically $5 a person. The price goes up at least a dollar for dinner."
Like the bigger houses and lower taxes that help lure thousands of transplants to Las Vegas every month, the buffets feed newcomers' faith in greater bounty and possibility here. That expectation is grounded partly in reality, and partly in myth.
While most of the buffets do essentially give away much of the food each patron consumes, losing money in the process, they easily make up the difference in the coins that patrons cannot resist dropping in the thicket of slot machines they must penetrate to get to the make-your-own-taco bar.
Mr. Ippolito and Mr. Faleck blew $17 on slots as they left Main Street Station. But Mr. Faleck explained that the appeal of buffets transcended mere economics.
"What they are is a goof," he said.
There are Chinese buffets and Japanese buffets, breakfast buffets and lunch buffets, buffets that operate 24 hours a day and buffets that span half the distance of a football field.
The Carnival World Buffet at the Rio Suites Hotel and Casino is at least that long, and it has more than seven ethnic sub-buffets. Even at 9:30 P.M. Tuesday, hundreds of people were zipping -- or, it must be said, waddling -- from Italy to Mexico and back again.
Some old-timers scoff at such clutter, preferring to stick with what they know and like best. For Erne D. Vining, 64, that's fish, and he nightly heads to whichever buffet is having its weekly seafood special.
"On Monday I go to Orleans," said Mr. Vining, who has lived in Las Vegas for more than three decades. "On Tuesday, Boulder Station. On Wednesday, Fiesta. On Thursday, Sunset. On Friday, Fremont. Sundays is Silverton."
And what of Saturday? Does he fast?
"Sometimes," Mr. Vining conceded in an almost apologetic voice, "I cook."

HEADLINE: Common Ground Is Missing In Battling Plains Farm Ills

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 11

 BODY:
With the national economy booming, lawmakers have begun to focus on one of the few places in the country where times are bad: the Northern Plains, where wheat and livestock prices have plunged and many farmers are desperate.
"This is an especially bad year in terms of wheat prices," said Senator Richard G. Lugar, the Indiana Republican who is chairman of the Agriculture Committee and who helped rush through the Senate on Thursday a bill to allow farmers to sell wheat to Pakistan. 
 Senator Tom Daschle, the Democratic leader, said the situation on the farms in his state, South Dakota, was the direst in 15 years and was becoming worse. "We've got to take action now," he said. "It must be done this summer."
But while Republicans and Democrats have weighed in with proposals to meet what both sides describe as a crisis involving an important election-year constituency, they are addressing the situation from entirely different angles.
Republicans like Senator Lugar favor a free-market agriculture policy and believe the Government can best help farmers by staying out of their hair and promoting export markets for their products.
That was the basis of the legislation approved by the Senate on Thursday to exempt food exports from the sanctions the United States imposed on India and Pakistan after those countries conducted nuclear tests in May. The House Republican leadership has promised to follow suit in time for American farmers to bid on Wednesday on a large Pakistani order for wheat.
Democrats like Senator Daschle believe that it is more important for the Government to restore some Government farm subsidies that were developed in the New Deal and repealed by the Republican Congress in the 1996 farm bill. Democratic lawmakers promised this week to press for more Government assistance for farmers.
President Clinton plans to meet on the situation early next week with Democratic senators. Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman said in an interview that the Administration would announce its response to the farm problem in the next week or two.
The matter could come to a head next week, if the Senate takes up the agriculture appropriations bill. The outcome could affect the Congressional elections this fall.
Few other issues so vividly illustrate the fundamental split between the parties on the proper role of Government in the society.
Generally, politicians from the same state but different parties vote alike on questions that are of primarily local concern. In New York, for instance, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, a Republican, and Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, a Democrat, walk in tandem on such issues as mass transit and acid rain.
But in Iowa, Minnesota, Montana, Nebraska and Washington -- states with mounting trouble on the farms and with one Republican and one Democratic senator each -- the senators are walking the party lines and taking opposing positions on farm policy.
Senator Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa, described the division this way: "They have great confidence in Washington bureaucrats. We have confidence in Iowa farmers to manage their own destiny."
But Iowa's Democratic Senator, Tom Harkin, has a completely different view.
"For Republicans, the 1996 farm bill is like holy scripture, and any change would show they were wrong," he said. "I simply do not believe you can trade your way out of a farm disaster. I think the Government has got to step in."
Nationwide, the farm picture is not entirely bleak. Corn farmers in Indiana, Ohio and Illinois are anticipating a good year when their crop comes in this fall. Cotton producers in Arkansas and Mississippi are doing well. Rice growers in the South are prospering.
But so many farmers lost money in North Dakota last year that net farm income was down 98 percent from 1996, and the situation has deteriorated this year. Senator Byron L. Dorgan, Democrat of North Dakota, said that in his state, auctioneers had to be called out of retirement to handle all the farmers who were selling out.
The problem is also severe in South Dakota, western Minnesota and the other states along the Canadian border to the Pacific.
Senator Patty Murray, Democrat of Washington, said her constituents were facing "the worst crisis ever seen in the Pacific Northwest."
The farmers' troubles stem from several unrelated events: farm exports are way down, mainly because of the staggering economies in Asia; wheat production is strong because of warm weather worldwide, driving down prices; many farmers in the Northern Plains have not recovered from last year's floods; a disease called scab has affected much of the wheat in the Middle West.
"Prices today for wheat and corn and soybeans and barley are at a level equal to what they were when I was born, 50 years ago," said Senator Daschle. Farmers, he continued, are expected "to live on salaries and income that was generated right after World War II, and you can't do that."
Democrats hold that the plight of farmers has been worsened by the Republican legislation Congress approved two years ago called the Freedom to Farm Act. The law reduces crop subsidies in increments until they no longer exist, after 2002, and gives farmers freedom to switch crops in response to market demand. Most Democrats voted against the measure. President Clinton signed it with serious reservations, he said at the time, because he feared the bill would not "provide an adequate safety net for family farmers."
Now, Democrats want to roll back that legislation by raising the ceiling on Government-guaranteed loans to farmers and by introducing a new emergency-relief program that would help farmers affected by floods, drought and other natural disasters.
Their prospects for success do not appear to be strong. Senator Lugar said he and his fellow Republicans would fight hard to preserve the 1996 law. Farmers, he said, "should rely on a market approach, not a political fix."
In the House, Speaker Newt Gingrich promised last month that he would promote legislation to stimulate farm exports. He said he would press to renew the President's fast-track authority to negotiate trade agreements, an authority that Congress failed to re-enact last year. He said he would also seek financing for the International Monetary Fund and continuation of normal trade relations with China, both of which would presumably help farm exports.
The Democrats are sure to turn this conflict into an election issue in a year when they need a swing of only 11 seats to regain control of the House. In Montana, for instance, Robert Deschamps, the Democrat challenging the state's only Congressman, Rick Hill, a Republican in his first term, is making changes in the 1996 farm law a major part of his platform.
According to the Congressional Quarterly, Republicans hold nearly two-thirds of the 57 Congressional seats representing districts in which at least 60 percent of the population lives outside metropolitan areas. A clear majority of these districts favored President Clinton in 1996.
But John Morgan, a Republican political consultant, said he did not think his party needed to worry on this score. "There aren't that many seats left that turn on farm issues," he said.
Russell Ross, professor emeritus of political science at the University of Iowa and a specialist in rural politics, agreed with Mr. Morgan's assessment that farm issues would not cause many Congressional seats to change hands. "The cities and the small towns," he said, "that's where the votes are."

HEADLINE: Sides Are Squaring Off on Raising Retirement Age

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 11

 BODY:
Given that people are living longer, many politicians and economists think that gradually raising the retirement age to 70 or even higher is a fair means of reducing the financial strain that threatens the Social Security system.
Given that her bones ache after decades of hard work, Beth Hamilton of Exeter, R.I., thinks otherwise. 
 At the age of 62, Ms. Hamilton works full time in a group home for mentally and physically disabled adults, lifting, bathing, dressing and cleaning up after them. It is difficult and dirty work that takes its toll; earlier this year she contracted pneumonia from one of the people she looks after.
Even if it was implemented so slowly as to not affect her, Ms. Hamilton said, raising the retirement age would be unfair to her younger colleagues and to future generations of people who do not have the luxury of working behind a desk.
"We've had all sorts of injuries," she said. "Our backs are hurting. We've been bitten and had hepatitis shots. The idea of doing this until 70 is too much."
As they begin examining details of various plans for restoring Social Security's long-term financial health, Clinton Administration officials, members of Congress and interest groups say few issues will be more passionately debated -- or subject to demagoguery -- than proposals to raise the age at which retirees can claim full benefits.
"It's a very visceral issue for a lot of people," said Warren B. Rudman, the former Republican Senator from New Hampshire who is co-chairman of the Concord Coalition, a fiscal watchdog group that favors a gradual increase. "A lot of people can't conceive of the notion that they will have to spend more time in their jobs than they planned."
Although the impact of any change could be substantial -- on individuals, employers and the economy -- the issue has gotten relatively little attention so far in Washington.
Many people appear unaware that, under changes adopted in 1983, the age at which retirees can claim full Social Security benefits is already scheduled to increase. From 2003 through 2008 it will gradually rise to 66 from 65. Then, from 2021 through 2027, it will rise gradually to 67. (The early retirement age would remain 62, but the benefits available at that age would decline as the full retirement age increases.)
Some of the plans being considered in Washington would accelerate the existing timetable. Others would push the retirement age even higher. A comprehensive plan developed by a bipartisan commission working with the Center for Strategic and International Studies, a research group, recommended in May that the retirement age be raised to 70 by 2029, and be raised as needed after that to account for further increases in life expectancy.
Given that tough tradeoffs are going to have to be made to insure Social Security's long-term survival, increased life expectancy alone makes raising the qualifying age for full benefits fair game, said Senator Judd Gregg, a New Hampshire Republican who was a member of the bipartisan commission. Life expectancy for males, which was about 60 at the time Social Security was created in 1935, is almost 73, meaning that people are spending many more years in retirement.
But Senator Gregg said the commission's plan offsets the increased retirement age in other ways, including removing the cap on how much money retirees can earn before the age of 70 without reducing their Social Security payments. That change might lead some people to choose early retirement at reduced benefits in the expectation that they would keep working part time.
Moreover, he said, the centerpiece of the commission's plan -- private accounts that allow workers to invest a portion of their payroll taxes in the stock market -- will provide a pool of wealth beyond Social Security benefits that retirees will be able to tap starting at age 60. Advocates of such accounts say they will more than offset any reductions in benefits.
And since the change would not take place for decades or affect anyone near retirement age now, those who are affected will have plenty of time to prepare, Mr. Gregg said.
The proposal "is tied to a system that gives you many more options so that you can have a quality life style if you retire early," Mr. Gregg said.
"On substance," he said, "this is a heck of a good approach. On the demagoguing aspect, Social Security has always been demagogued by people who are absolutely irresponsible and only look to the next election."
Labor unions, as well as some Democrats in Congress, said it is not a matter of demagoguery at all, just of understanding how strongly working people feel about the issue.
"We've done focus groups in which people reject resoundingly some of the ideas that are taken for granted around here, like raising the retirement age," said Gerry Shea, assistant to the president for government affairs at the A.F.L.-C.I.O. "People don't realize it's already going to 67, and when you tell them about proposals to move it up to 70, their reactions range from incredulity to, 'Who came up with that idea'?"
Democrats in the House see the issue as a potent one as they draw distinctions between how they and the Republicans would deal with Social Security. They are drafting a comprehensive Social Security proposal that would not call for any further changes in the retirement age.
But for many people the issue is complicated, involving the kind of work they do, changing cultural assumptions about when old age begins, the value put on youth in the work place and their own goals for financial security, career accomplishment and leisure time.
Rosemarie Cola, a 65-year-old retired employee assistance worker from New York City, said she thought raising the retirement age might be a reasonable way to help insure that Social Security will be around in the future. But she wants to hear more about the tradeoffs, and she said she wondered whether employers would be in step with a movement toward having people work until they are 68 or 70.
"Older people are being pushed out of their jobs," she said. "They have the biggest health benefits, the most vacation, the biggest salaries. Employers want you out."
The group that has the most at stake in the debate -- generally those who are 40 or under and would be most likely to feel the full impact of any further changes -- appears most ambivalent.
"How can I know where I'll be when I'm 65 or 67?" said Mary Ann Mroz, a 35-year-old college administrator from Somerville, Mass. "I don't think it's been fully thought through."
Mr. Rudman said that as the population ages, employers will face a shortage of workers, and will increasingly seek to lure retirees back into full- or part-time work. Moreover, he said, many people realize when they reach age 65 or 67 that they are not ready yet to stop working entirely.
Yet although there are signs of more retirees from white-collar jobs looking for full or part-time employment, a trend toward longer working lives would reverse decades in which there has been a pronounced trend toward early retirement. In 1965, 30.2 percent of the men who applied for Social Security retirement benefits were under age 65. Since 1985, the figure has been around 66 percent, and is much higher for women.
Ms. Hamilton, who attended a recent conference on Social Security as part of a contingent of union members brought in by the A.F.L.-C.I.O., said she had been working since she was 14, and had been eager to cut back to part time this month when she turned 62.
But when she went to her local Social Security office, she found that her benefit would be $550 a month if she retired now, instead of $730 if she retires at 65. Feeling that she could not afford to live on the reduced benefit, she decided to keep working full time, but is already counting the days until July 2001.
"If I had a job like Andy Rooney, I'd work until I'm 75," she said. "But right now I'm disappointed."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Beth Hamilton, 62, of Exeter, R.I., is not happy about the discussions of raising the age to qualify for full retirement benefits to beyond 65. (Joanne Ciccarello for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Alabama Resort Fears Potential Ban on Red Snapper Catch

BYLINE: New York Times Regional Newspaper Group 

DATELINE: ORANGE BEACH, Ala.

 BODY:
Accustomed to weathering the occasional hurricane that barrels out of the Gulf of Mexico, this bustling resort is now bracing for a potential catastrophe of a different sort.
Federal officials, saying the Gulf's signature red snapper is as overfished as it is delicious, are threatening to close down recreational angling for snapper as early as Sept. 1. It is a decision that could have a devastating economic impact on this community that bills itself as "the red snapper capital of the world." 
 "That would put me out of business," said Neal Grube, a veteran charter captain who earns $750 a day and more from sports anglers on his his 38-foot boat, the Catch-it.
He is not the only one. About 100 charter boats run out of the marinas dotting the waterways of this fishing center on the eastern end of the 32-mile island reaching from the Florida border to Mobile Bay, informally called Pleasure Island.
World-class fishing and sugar-white sand have helped Orange Beach and the adjacent Gulf Shores blossom into a full-fledged tourist destination. But fishing drives the economy, and tourism officials are busy estimating the potential losses in an effort to persuade officials of the National Marine Fisheries Service to keep the season open even if the agency determines that too many red snapper are being killed in the nets of commercial shrimpers.
A 1994 study put the direct financial impact of charter fishing on the local economy at $35 million annually with $10 million to $15 million more attributed to the ripple effect.
Once abundant, the snapper supported a thriving commercial fishing industry as far back as 100 years. But in the 1980's, the take of red snappers reached historical lows and worried Federal fishery managers began searching for solutions.
The National Marine Fisheries Service imposed quotas on commercial and recreational fishing. This spring, after a decade of deliberations and $10 million in research, the service went after what it believed to be a major cause of the declining snapper stock: the trawls of commercial shrimpers that ensnare and kill inch-long snappers.
To eliminate what it estimates is the loss of 35 million juvenile snappers a year in shrimp nets, the fisheries service in May began requiring shrimpers plying most Gulf waters to use a special device that is supposed to let trapped fin fish escape. If agency officials determine it is not sufficiently effective, they could reduce or shut down recreational snapper fishing. Commercial snapper fishing -- already suspended -- would not be allowed to resume this year.
"The stock is seriously overfished and I think you have to put the emphasis on the word seriously," said Andrew Kemmerer, southeast region director for the National Marine Fisheries Service.
But the charter boat captains say their experience suggests otherwise. They say passengers on their boats easily catch their daily four-fish limit of snappers. On this day, Captain Grube's party included a trio of young Mississippians who brought in an impressive catch, running as large as eight pounds each.
Mr. Kemmerer and conservation advocates concede the snapper stock appears to be recovering. But they say continued limits are necessary to give the new fish the chance to reach their prime reproductive years.
"Four snapper a person to me is fair," said Ben Fairey, captain of the Necessity. "But when you are talking about a closed season in the middle of our tourist season, that is economic disaster for us."

HEADLINE: Low-Key Bidding for State-Sponsored Credit Card Raises Questions

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

 BODY:
In late 1995, the Pataki administration, looking for innovative ways for the state to promote and profit from its image, decided to sponsor an "I Love New York" credit card. The idea was to sell the rights to the slogan to a bank, which would emblazon it on a standard Visa card or Mastercard along with pictures of scenic New York.
The contract went to the MBNA Corporation of Delaware, a large credit card issuer that in the last four years has been one of the biggest political contributors to the New York Republican State Committee and to Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato. 
 It is perhaps no surprise that MBNA received the contract, since it was the only bidder. While the administration went through a formal process to solicit bids, an examination of the way it was handled shows that officials did not aggressively pursue other credit card issuers, raising questions about whether they got the best deal possible.
The Department of Economic Development said it solicited bids from only nine banks. Two of them are so small that they do not issue credit cards. Those two, as well as three others, said they had no record of having received a bid request. While the department said that it had hoped to give the contract to a bank based in New York, it did not solicit bids from several obvious candidates, like Chase Manhattan and Citibank.
MBNA received the three-year contract on March 15, 1996. The following month, just as the credit card program began, it donated $50,000 to the Republican State Committee, according to disclosure records.
Since that time, MBNA has distributed 109,000 of the "I Love New York" credit cards, officials said, making it a successful line for the company's so-called affinity card business.
Banks typically produce affinity cards in partnership with a range of groups, from alumni associations to sports teams to government agencies. The number of "I Love New York" cards ranks it as a medium-size affinity issue, marketing experts said.
The Pataki administration, MBNA and the Republican State Committee said there was no link between political contributions and the contract.
The Department of Economic Development defended the method that it used to find a card issuer, saying that it was fair and impartial. The department said it had to award the contract to MBNA because no one else had bid.
The department's Commissioner, Charles A. Gargano, used to be Gov. George E. Pataki's chief fund-raiser, but he said he stopped raising money for the Governor and the state party after Mr. Pataki took office in 1995.
A spokeswoman for the department, Caroline Quartararo, noted that the state had collected $388,000 in fees from MBNA. The company pays the state $1 for each new card, $1.50 for each card that is renewed and 25 cents for each charge.
The department said it sent applications to eight banks in New York and to MBNA. Among them was Olympian Bank of Brooklyn, which has only two branches.
"I don't recall ever seeing such an application," said Joseph A. Baldasare, senior vice president of Olympian Bank. "We don't offer credit cards ourselves. We are a very small, little bank in Bay Ridge."
The department did not request bids from a number of out-of-state banks that, like MBNA, issue affinity cards.
Several big banks in the state and elsewhere said they did not know whether they would have bid on the contract had they been notified about it, and some pointed out that affinity cards were not their focus.
But they all said they would have considered it.
"There are a lot of programs that we look at, and there are probably very, very few that we would reject out of hand," said George McCane, a senior vice president for corporate affairs at First USA, which is based in Delaware and is the biggest rival of MBNA in the affinity market.
Asked to explain how it chose the banks that received the applications, Ms. Quartararo said at first that the eight banks in New York were all the banks that were chartered in the state. She said MBNA was asked for a bid because it was a major issuer of affinity cards.
"We wanted the business to stay in New York if possible," she said.
When told in a subsequent conversation that more than 150 banks are chartered in the state, Ms. Quartararo said she had been mistaken, explaining that the department had sent out applications to the largest banks chartered in the state.
It was then pointed out to her that some of the banks that received the applications are very small or have their headquarters in New York but are not chartered in the state. "What can I tell you?" she responded. "There is this bureaucrat who works in our finance office who just did it like that. It sounds ridiculous, but that's what happened."
Ms. Quartararo declined to identify the employee in the department's finance office.
She added that the department had announced the bidding in a newsletter published by the state that lists available state contracts. Any bank that had seen the listing and asked for an application could have bid, she said.
In addition to the $50,000 contribution, the Republican State Committee has received two others from MBNA: one for $20,000 on Oct. 22, 1996, and another for $100,000 on March 5, 1997. MBNA and its executives have also given more than $300,000 to political committees controlled by Mr. D'Amato. The Senator is chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, giving him great influence over any banking legislation that MBNA supports.
In response to questions about the card contract, Terry O'Brien, a spokesman for the Republican State Committee, said in statement, "The State Committee does not involve itself in governmental or policy decisions, nor will it."
David Spartin, an MBNA vice chairman, said there was "absolutely no connection" between the contract and contributions.
"The fact that we were selected is not that unusual," he said. "We have 5,000 organizations that endorse us." But he acknowledged that the "affinity market is very competitive."
While Ms. Quartararo said the search for an issuer was done properly, some credit card consultants disagreed. Michael Auriemma, president of Auriemma Consulting Group in Westbury, N.Y., said it was likely that other issuers would have sought the account.
"If they did it right, they would have gotten a lot more than one response," Mr. Auriemma said. "In order to guarantee that you get the best deals, you want to talk to different players."
Other credit card issuers said they would not discuss the fees they paid for affinity cards, or comment on those in the "I Love New York" deal.
But when South Orange, N.J., began sponsoring an affinity card a few years ago, it received $5 for each new card in the first year or so of the deal with Valley National Bank, said the village president, William Calabrese. New York receives $1 per new card.
After the first year, South Orange's fee has been 1 percent of sales on the card.
In 1995, the Giuliani administration considered sponsoring a New York City affinity credit card, though it eventually decided not to because it was concerned that people might think that the city was the actual issuer of the card or was responsible for debt on it.
But before the plan was canceled, several issuers had said they would consider bidding for the card, said John S. Dyson, a senior adviser to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.
"There was a healthy interest in it," Mr. Dyson said.

HEADLINE: In a Post-Nuclear Town, Some Adjustments Hurt

BYLINE: By CAREY GOLDBERG 

DATELINE: WISCASSET, Me., July 9

 BODY:
Things change when a place goes post-nuclear.
Almost a year ago, Maine Yankee, the state's only nuclear plant and once New England's biggest electricity producer, stopped generating power here for good, to the joy of nuclear opponents, the regret of the townfolk who depended on its taxes and jobs, and the pain of its hundreds of workers.
The 25-year-old plant had long been one of the most divisive issues in Maine and had survived three referendums on closing it over the years. But ultimately, it was stopped not by politics but by economics: plagued by safety concerns and with electricity deregulation coming on, it could no longer operate competitively, its owners decided. 
 That ending was also the beginning of a new phase, one that is becoming ever more common in host towns around the country as aging nuclear plants shut down and the nuclear industry withers.
Tensions dissipate, these towns find, but new problems arise, from economic woes to worry over nuclear waste.
The closing of Maine Yankee brought heartfelt relief to those residents who had worried that the warning sirens would break the coastal calm here with a nuclear alert.
But the towns that are home to the country's remaining 107 nuclear plants might do well to note what Wiscasset and more than 20 other spots where plants have been closed are finding out: all is not resolved with the flick of a switch.
Some of the adjustment is economic. In Wiscasset, the uncomfortable pinch of belt-tightening comes across even through Maine stoicism.
"No one is jumping out of windows," said Robert Blagden, Wiscasset's First Selectman, the closest thing the town has to a mayor. "It's not like a stock market crash."
But Maine Yankee used to pay something like 96 percent of the taxes for Wiscasset, a town of 3,500 on Route 1 that bills itself as "The Prettiest Little Village in Maine" and may not be too far off, with its fine old sea captains' houses and seaweed-podded old pilings. This year, Mr. Blagden said, the plant will go from paying Wiscasset nearly $13 million to about $6 million, and townspeople's taxes will rise to make up much of the gap. Property taxes are expected to double if not triple.
So great was the town's dependence on Maine Yankee's jobs, purchases and taxes that Raymond Shadis, the plant's nemesis and spokesman for the anti-nuclear "Friends of the Coast-Opposing Nuclear Pollution," bitingly calls Wiscasset a "cargo cult," willing to worship the nuclear plant in exchange for its bounty.
The bounty was plentiful. Wiscasset schools spent a luxurious $12,000 per pupil, the town has a new multimillion-dollar community center, it had free ambulance service and its roads have been thoroughly rebuilt.
"It was like living in fairyland," said John Chester, a local freelance writer who serves on a community panel advising Maine Yankee on its shutdown. "Everything you wanted, you got."
Not anymore. The most direct losses have fallen to the plant employees themselves. Maine Yankee had 480 full-timers when it closed. Their numbers have been reduced to 166 employees who are maintaining the plant and preparing it for decommissioning, said Maureen Brown, the plant's spokeswoman. About 100 of those who left retired, she said over lunch at "Fission Chips," the plant's little restaurant. In general, she said, about 60 percent of those who found new jobs have moved away.
In what used to be Maine Yankee's information center -- and was rapidly converted into its career center last August -- paper balloons tacked to the wall list the names of former workers who have had to go on to new lives, and most of them carry destinations linked with other plants far away: Point Beach in Wisconsin, Millstone in Connecticut, Vermont Yankee.
The plant held 78 job fairs and hundreds of counseling sessions, Ms. Brown said, and in general is determined to make its decommissioning a model for other plants, both technically and in human terms.
But there are still workers like Jim Weast, a 27-year veteran of the plant, an engineer, licensing expert and its former assistant operations manager, who says he has found, "No one wants to hire a 50-year-old." He has had a chance to work at the Millstone plant in Connecticut, which was recently permitted to reopen after safety concerns shut it for two years, but "that would be out of the frying pan into the fire," he said.
"Nuclear power is dead, has been dead for a long time, and the public doesn't realize it," Mr. Weast said, sounding more sad than bitter.
For Wiscasset and the surrounding area, the economic losses include not only jobs but the money that employees would have spent locally, along with the occasional influx of hundreds of contractors when the plant was preparing to re-start, and its purchases of incidentals like office supplies.
"There's a huge ripple effect," said State Senator Marge Kilkelly, who heads the community panel on the shutdown.
Though life styles must change, she said, that ripple will fade eventually, and Wiscasset's nuclear era will pass quietly into history just as its shipping heyday and railroad heyday passed: "So be it," she said.
But the biggest Maine Yankee concern now is a problem that will not pass so easily: the high-level radioactive waste that the plant produced. It does not seem as if the Federal Government is going to find a repository for it any time soon. At this point, plant officials say, the Government has promised to begin picking up Maine Yankee's high-level waste a decade or two into the 21st century, but many do not count on it.
Until then, despite the Federal obligation to dispose of the 1,432 spent-fuel assemblies weighing more than 1,500 tons, it stays here, where it is Maine Yankee's, and Wiscasset's, problem. Maine Yankee is suing the Government over the waste, but the many here expect the plant to become one of more than 100 unexpected waste dumps around the country, wherever plants are.
W. Donald Hudson Jr., a member of the community panel and president of the Chewonki Foundation, a major environmental education center that with 150 workers may soon employ more people than nearby Maine Yankee, predicts the waste will be here long, long after 2050. If that is the case, he said, it is up to the plant and Wiscasset to figure out how to store it safely for hundreds of years.
"The drum I keep beating is, how are we going to come up with a system of managing something for a minimum of 500 human generations?" Dr. Hudson asked. "The pyramids are only 150 human generations old, and we've got to make something to last at least 500."
Waste storage, however, is only one of the issues to arise in the complex process of decommissioning. Mr. Shadis, a sculptor who is probably Maine's best-known and most unrelenting opponent of nuclear power, has raised handfuls of other concerns. They range from the possibility that "hot" waste had been trucked to the town dump (none has been found) to questions about whether the plant's eventual demolition would involve blowing up concrete structures that could contain radioactivity "and you wouldn't know until you had a cloud of concrete dust sailing across the river."
But, Mr. Shadis said, some of the fire has gone out of the fight, and Maine Yankee has become more open than ever before, even allowing him to read its file of "Radiological Incident Reports" of spills over the years. His side has lost ardor, as well, he said: When the plant was closed and he sent out invitations to a celebration, out of a mailing list of 7,000, only 200 or 250 responded.
And recently, he said, as he pressed a point at a community panel meeting, a top Maine Yankee official told him to let go, adding, "Ray, you've won."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Joseph Darman, top, a decommissioning specialist, is part of the dwindling work force at Maine Yankee, above, the nuclear plant that stopped generating power a year ago. Fewer and fewer employees hang their hats on the wall, creating new tensions even as old ones ease. (Photographs by David McLain for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Engines Roaring, Pagers Beeping;
Middle Class Leads a Renewed Romance With Biker Culture

SERIES: RITES OF SUMMER: Urban Riders

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY 

 BODY:
It was not exactly the biker image Hunter S. Thompson described in "Hell's Angels": gangs of burly guys flashing earrings, armpits and chain whips, barreling through traffic "like a burst of dirty thunder."
The dozen riders who roared through the West Village one night last week included a surgeon whose leather jacket has a special pocket for his hospital beeper; an engineer from Pennsylvania with two small children, and a former New Jersey police officer turned computer analyst wearing a "Ride Nude" T-shirt. Vicki Rossetti, 36, who works for an insurance company, was along and not on the back of her boyfriend's bike -- she commands her own black Harley-Davidson Sportster. 
 Weaving through taxis, Jeffrey Hicken, an advertising art director, turned to the rider on the back of his Harley and yelled, "To tell you the truth, I don't even know who a lot of these guys are."
The Hooligans, a loose collection of middle-class motorcycle fanatics, had picked up a crowd. And it was not the first time since the weather turned warm. It happens nearly every time they roam these days around New York, a city in the middle of a renewed romance with biker culture.
Steve Manes, a Web site developer who sometimes rides with the group, calls it "the summer of the motorcycle in New York," and there is ample evidence to support the claim.
Consider: More than 100 bikers from around New York descended on the Guggenheim Museum one night last month for the opening of "The Art of the Motorcycle," an exhibit of motorcycle design from the 1860's to the present that runs through Sept. 20. The museum's well-heeled neighbors on the Upper East Side complained that the patrons were racing their motors.
In many neighborhoods, garage space reserved for motorcycles is full, because more people are buying motorcycles and because the city has begun to crack down on an increasing number of motorcycles illegally parked between cars and on traffic islands.
Classes for the city's best-known motorcycle safety course are booked through the summer, and the school's director, Gasper Trama, who has trained the likes of Liam Neeson, Matthew Broderick and Alan Alda, said the demand is the highest he has seen in several years.
Manhattan's motorcycle-friendly bars -- Hogs and Heifers in the meatpacking district, the Ear Inn in SoHo, Red Rock West in Chelsea, American Trash on the Upper East Side and Barcode in the East Village -- are all seeing larger crowds of bikers.
And, in perhaps the quintessential confirmation of a New York City trend, people are angry. Those who live within earshot of the biker bars have begun to complain about the noise, particularly the screams emitted by motorcycles with illegally altered mufflers called drag pipes, which are loud enough to trigger car alarms.
Hundreds of Chelsea residents along 10th Avenue signed a petition to the police complaining about the noise. Arthur W. Strickler, the district manager of the community board that represents SoHo and the West Village, said the board is considering asking the City Council to ban motorcycles from the neighborhood altogether, though it admits such a ban would probably never work. Short of that, he said, the board is pushing for fines even steeper and stricter than those enacted by the City Council last year for excessive noise.
Mr. Strickler calls drag pipes, which he concedes are used by only a loud minority of bikers, "one of these macho, sicko ways of saying, 'Here I am, look at me!' "
But why, so many years after "Easy Rider," does motorcycling suddenly seem to be cool again in the city?
Veteran riders, for whom it has never been uncool, say interest has actually been building in New York for the past four or five years, driven by some of the same factors that have pushed motorcycle sales up 43 percent around the country since 1991.
The hellbent-for-leather image of biking has softened, and the pastime is now attracting a new segment of older, more affluent riders eager to motorcycle through the midlife crisis or see the country. The healthy economy also means more money is available to consumers for such expensive toys. (Brand-new motorcycles can cost anywhere from $5,000 to $50,000.)
But in New York, riders say, the popularity has also grown as parking and maintaining a car in the city have become more expensive and traffic has become more nightmarish. Motorcyclists cannot only squeeze -- sometimes illegally -- right through midtown gridlock, but they can roll into the country on weekends while cars are still crammed in the tunnels. And they can do it at 46 miles to the gallon or better.
"Basically, we're just ordinary taxpaying citizens trying to save a little on gas and get where we're going," said Susan Buck, the East Coast editor of Thunder Press, a monthly Harley-Davidson enthusiast magazine.
Then, of course, there's the fact that it is just undeniably cool to be riding a motorcycle on the streets of Manhattan. Mark Novitz, a 30-year-old computer analyst who bought his first BMW motorcycle three years ago, vowed never to use it to get around the city because he considered it too dangerous, "but that fell apart in a couple of weeks," he said.
"Going through the Helmsley Building tunnel on Park Avenue or up Riverside Drive to Grant's Tomb -- on a bike it's just a completely different thing," he said.
Kyrie Collins, an aspiring entrepreneur who waits tables at Moomba, the West Village restaurant, said simply and only somewhat facetiously: "I know I look good on my bike."
Ms. Collins, 35, has been riding for 11 years and despite being seriously injured four years ago while touring California, she said she never really considered not climbing back on her sleek gray Moto Guzzi. "People ride in New York because it makes them unique," she said recently, her bike lined up with about 40 others during a regular Tuesday night conclave at the Ear Inn. "It makes me run solo in a city of eight million."
She added: "It's also deeply erogenous. It's always been a male bike to me. So I guess what I'm saying basically is -- it's all about sex."
Diane Howells, who took up motorcycles two years ago and loved them so much that she recently made a documentary film about women riders, said motorcycling, at the very least, makes the city friendlier. "People come over and talk to you about your bike," she said. And suddenly, "you're part of a clique."
Of course, the cliques don't always see eye to eye. The rivalries are much gentler than those between, say, warring Hell's Angels. But longtime riders are often disdainful of new riders with a tendency to show off. Riders who spend their weekends on road trips through Pennsylvania or upstate New York disparage those who buy bikes to cruise slowly around Manhattan bars.
Riders who buy lightning-fast, colorful sport bikes -- such as Italian Ducatis and British Triumphs -- sometimes depict Harley-Davidson owners as passe. Middle-class riders tend to refer to younger, inner-city riders -- who are usually on smaller street bikes, dressed in T-shirts and shorts, and prone to popping wheelies -- as "squids."
And, while no one will admit to being one, everyone seems to disparage riders they call RUB's -- rich urban bikers -- who buy $40,000 custom-made specialty bikes like Titans or Californias simply because they can afford them.
"English Don" Cornwallis, a well-known New York motorcycle builder, blames RUB's for the growing sentiment against motorcycles in many neighborhoods. "In recent years the motorcycle has become the new gotta-have toy for the urban classless rich," he wrote in a city biker newspaper. "These idiots are the perpetrators of the loud pipes and ridiculous showboating around these bars."

Rites of Summer
This is the first article in a series about summer in and around New York.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Bikers hung out last week in front of the Ear Inn in SoHo before a Tuesday night ride. The Ear Inn and other motorcycle-friendly bars are seeing larger crowds of bikers. (pg. 23)
 
Chart: "LINGUA BIKER: Talking the Talk Over the Rumble"
 
BEATER -- A second motorcycle that owners of expensive cycles use for commuting and errands.
 
BILLET BARGES -- Expensive, customized motorcycles covered with shiny parts machined from a solid block, or billet, of aluminum.
 
BURNOUT -- A show-off maneuver in which a rider holds the front brake while racing the throttle, causing the back wheel to spin and billow smoke.
 
PILLION -- A Britishism that means the seat or saddle for the second passenger on a motorcycle. Often used in the United States to refer generally to a woman who rides behind a man on a motorcycle.
 
ROLEX RIDER -- See RUB.
 
RUB -- Rich urban biker, a derisive term coined by Harley-Davidson enthusiasts to refer to executives, lawyers and other professionals who buy expensive motorcycles primarily as status symbols.
 
SQUID -- First used in the Navy to refer to new sailors, the term also refers to rookie riders who drive recklessly or buy motorcycles they cannot handle.
 
STRAIGHT PIPES, DRAG PIPES -- Mufflers with noise-curbing bafflers removed. The pipes, illegal in New York State, create a deafening roar. (pg. 23)

HEADLINE: Few in Van, If Any, Wore Seat Belts

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN 

 BODY:
A van that crashed Friday evening on a Pennsylvania highway, killing two Brooklyn girls on their way home from a day-camp outing, was overcrowded and none of its occupants were wearing seat belts, camp counselors who were in the van and state troopers said yesterday.
The accident, on Interstate 80 in Jackson Township, Pa., about 80 miles northwest of New York City, killed two girls, age 6 and 7, who had been crowded with 18 other children and 4 adults into a van designed to carry only 15 people, the Pennsylvania State Police said. Most of the occupants were asleep and many were thrown from the van when the driver fell asleep and lost control of the vehicle about 5:25 P.M., witnesses said. Only one person in the van, Najier Matthews, a 6-year-old girl, was uninjured. 
 As the state police continued their investigation, parents, including the father of one of the dead girls, questioned whether proper safety precautions had been taken. "Grieving is going to take a long time," said the father, Michael Channell, describing the loss of his daughter Michael Marie Channell. "But after we are done grieving, we are going to address whether there was overcrowding on the van and if there was a lack of seat belts."
The other girl who died was Janine Ocean, 7, the Pennsylvania State Police said.
The state police identified the driver of the van as Gary R. Huggins, 24. He was not injured. Officials at the Bedford-Stuyvesant Restoration Corporation in Brooklyn, which operates the day camp that the children attended, described him as an employee on the corporation's security and transportation staff. He has a valid chauffeur's license and a clean driving record, according to records at the Department of Motor Vehicles. Mr. Huggins returned home to Brooklyn and, distressed by the accident, was placed under sedation, the officials said.
Seven children and two counselors remained hospitalized in Pennsylvania yesterday, said Roderick Mitchell, the president of the restoration corporation, a community development group. All nine were expected to recover, he said. Hospital officials said one child remained in critical condition while the others who remained under care were in stable or satisfactory condition. The other passengers were treated and released and they returned to Brooklyn yesterday afternoon.
Among them was Nickida Amsterdam, 7, whose left arm was broken in the crash and was put in a cast. Her mother, Fiona, traveled to Pennsylvania on Friday night with other parents to be with their injured children. "I went out last night and after seeing what happened, I believe my daughter is lucky to be alive," Ms. Amsterdam said. "Right now she is in shock. She hardly says anything."
One camp counselor, Patricia D. Parrish, 22, said that the adult supervisors had given little consideration to the number of children in the van and that it had not appeared to be overcrowded. The van held the youngest campers, most between the ages of 5 and 8, she said, while older campers had ridden in a school bus that was not involved in the crash.
"They were small children -- they all fit," Ms. Parrish said in an interview at Community Medical Center in Scranton, Pa., where she was waiting to have surgery on her left hand, which was broken in two places.
"Now I think there should have been less kids," she said, holding her daughter, Shaquasha Chambers, who was slightly injured in the crash. "But it wasn't uncomfortable."
The campers had spent the day at Knoebels Amusement Park in Elysburg, Pa., and many were still wet from the park's water rides when they climbed aboard the blue Ford Econoline van for the drive home. Witnesses said that most of them were asleep when the driver also nodded off, ramming the rear of a Saturn sedan.
The van spun wildly out of control, slammed into an embankment and flipped onto its side.
Mr. Mitchell and other officials with the Bedford-Stuyvesant development group declined to comment on reports that the van had been overcrowded and that the children had not worn seat belts, saying they first wished to read a complete accident report by the Pennsylvania State Police. Mr. Mitchell also expressed gratitude to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's Office of Emergency Management, which helped transport parents to Pennsylvania.
Donald S. Sutton, a spokesman for the corporation, said the driver of the van, Mr. Huggins, had a long affiliation with the group and had attended the same camp as a child.
"As best we can see, he is an experienced driver," he said. "He is under sedation. He is obviously very, very distressed about what has happened." The driver, he said, had not been charged "with any infraction in Pennsylvania."
A state police dispatcher said no more information would not be released until the investigation into the accident was completed.
Mr. Channell said he had identified his daughter's body at Lehigh Valley Hospital, where he had first seen a pastor. He said he had asked the priest, "Do I need to prepare for the worst?" When the priest nodded, Mr. Channell said, "I knew then that I had lost my little girl." Mr. Channell said his older daughter, Danielle, had also been on the trip but was riding in the bus, not the van.
Describing his daughter Michael, who would have turned 7 on Tuesday, Mr. Channell said: "She is a very sweet, very special little girl, so full of love. She looked forward to everything. She would say, 'I love you, Papa Bear,' and I would call her my baby bear. She and her sister were always making friends, always outside playing. Michael was just so full of love."
"Michael knew she was always supposed to belt herself in," he said. "We always belted our kids in. We didn't want to lose either of them. We want to start finding out what happened and why."

HEADLINE: YIELDING TO WEST, I.M.F. WILL DOUBLE RUSSIA LOAN OFFER

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, July 11

 BODY:
The international effort to calm Russia's shaky financial markets began to fall into place today, as negotiators sought to complete talks on more than $12 billion in new loans.
The International Monetary Fund has informed Russian officials that it is now prepared to lend about $11 billion, Russian officials said. About half the sum would be provided up front and the rest would be disbursed by the end of this year. 
 I.M.F. officials initially discussed $5.6 billion in new loans. But the fund increased its financing package under pressure from the United States Treasury Department and Western investors. Russian and I.M.F. officials said they hoped to complete their talks before the financial markets open on Monday.
In parallel talks, the World Bank and Russian officials hammered out an agreement today on a new loan that will range between $1 billion and $1.5 billion, Russian and Western officials said.
The World Bank accord requires the Russians to introduce more competition in their gas and electrical sectors, which have been dominated by powerful monopolies. It also lays the groundwork for the reform of Russia's railways and encourages further privatization of state-owned enterprises, among other measures.
Reflecting the urgency of Russia's financial crisis, Michael Carter, the head of the World Bank office here, finished talks with his Russian counterparts at 1 A.M. The accord was then E-mailed to Washington at 4 A.M. for formal approval by the World Bank's management. The intensive round-the-clock negotiations have taken place against a background of deep concern over Russia's financial crisis.
Anxiety over rising interest rates, the backlog of unpaid wages and shrinking Central Bank reserves has become so great that it has begun to rattle the Kremlin. President Boris N. Yeltsin has gone so far as to issue public warnings against coup attempts, asserting that he commands enough loyalty from the military to put down any "extremist" challenges to his power.
Concerned about the deteriorating Russian economy, the Clinton Administration has prodded the I.M.F. to increase the size of its loan, to keep its demands on the Russians realistic and to bring the negotiations to a close. Washington's main fear is that a devaluation of the ruble would unleash a fresh round of inflation, undercut Prime Minister Sergei Kiriyenko and his team of reformers and destabilize Russia.
But to negotiate agreements with international financial institutions is just part of the problem the Kremlin has been facing. The Yeltsin Government must still win approval of its deficit-cutting and tax-reform measures from the Communist-dominated Parliament. It is also trying to negotiate $10 billion in loans from Western commercial banks, in hopes of bringing the total financial package to more than $20 billion.
President Yeltsin met today with top aides to discuss strategy. The aides included Prime Minister Kiriyenko; Sergei Dubinin, the chairman of the Central Bank; Finance Minister Mikhail Zadornov; and Anatoly Chubais, the lead negotiator with the I.M.F. and the World Bank.
"The President on the whole approved the progress of the talks and instructed a completion of the talks in a compressed period," a statement from the Kremlin said.
The main focus today was on the talks with the I.M.F. The lead fund negotiator, John Odling-Smee, arrived in Moscow on Friday evening, and appears to have been locked in intensive negotiations ever since.
Russian and I.M.F. officials are near to settling a paramount question of how much and how quickly to cut the federal deficit. They have been trying to resolve differences over amendments that the fund insists be attached to the tax code submitted to Parliament.
When Russia's financial crisis began to deepen in May, Mr. Odling-Smee was openly skeptical of the need for more assistance. And he was described by one person in the talks as negotiating "efficiently but without much pleasure."
The World Bank accord concluded today seeks to advance market reforms in several respects. But it would not require the breakup of Gazprom, the natural gas monopoly and one of the last symbols of Soviet power. Suggestions that Gazprom be broken up to foster competition have been denounced by the Communists as a Western plot to destroy what remains of Russian industry.
The World Bank accord would, however, change the tax system to make it easier for other gas producers to enter the market.
To make the company's finances more transparent, financial accounting of Gazprom's gas production operation are to be separated from the accounting for its pipeline operations. The World Bank accord also aims to open Russia's electrical sector to private investment.
To encourage more privatization, the accord would reduce the number of so-called strategic state enterprises that cannot be sold off.
Many of these reforms will take months, if not years, to carry out. Achieving them will be the litmus test for the young Kiriyenko team."The Government has been given a chance," one Western specialist said. "But now it has to make a sustained effort. The key thing is to make this work."
