HEADLINE: Kennelly Talks Openly About Her Campaign's Problems

BYLINE: By MIKE ALLEN 

DATELINE: WILTON, Conn., July 10

 BODY:
United States Representative Barbara B. Kennelly, the Democratic candidate for governor of Connecticut, has startled supporters and opponents alike by breaking a cardinal rule for surviving poor poll showings. Instead of dismissing them, she has acknowledged bluntly that they spell trouble, and has agonized publicly about how to fix them.
"It's going to be a long summer," she told a group of supporters recently. "Has it been rough? It's been rough and tough." Later, when a caller to a statewide radio program told her it was time to get moving on her campaign, she asked: "What would you suggest I do?" 
 Mrs. Kennelly, 62, is challenging the one-term incumbent, John G. Rowland, a Republican, who at 41 is the nation's youngest Governor. The governor's race will officially begin Monday, when Mr. Rowland leads a caravan on a four-stop tour to formally announce his candidacy. Saturday, Mrs. Kennelly is to be nominated at the Democratic State Convention. But Mrs. Kennelly is already quick to acknowledge problems.
Last Thursday, financial reports revealed that Mr. Rowland had broken the state record for fund-raising for a gubernatorial campaign, collecting $4.3 million, more than twice as much as Mrs. Kennelly. During the last three months, normally a time to hoard money for television commercials in the fall, Mrs. Kennelly's campaign just broke even.
Mrs. Kennelly, the fourth-ranking Democrat in the House, started her race in a dead heat with Mr. Rowland. But recent polls showed Mr. Rowland with a huge lead in a state where registered Democrats substantially outnumber Republicans. A University of Connecticut poll taken June 23 to July 1 showed Mr. Rowland leading Mrs. Kennelly 55 percent to 27 percent and a Quinnipiac College poll taken June 16 to 22 put Mr. Rowland at 56 percent and Mrs. Kennelly at 32 percent.
Munching calamari during a break in 14 hours of campaigning on Tuesday, Mrs. Kennelly (pronounced (ken-NELL-ee) said that polls are more significant to candidates than most let on. "Everything runs off the polls," she said. "They drive media coverage, and they drive fund-raising. The cliche is that the election isn't held until November. But that isn't modern politics."
Dennis W. Johnson, the associate dean of the Graduate School of Political Management at George Washington University in Washington, said it was very unusual for a major candidate to offer such a pessimistic public face. "Voters don't want to hear a candidate whine," he said. "Voters like a leader who's tough and breaks through the barriers," he said. "You're not going to catch fire if you make it sound like it's over."
Mrs. Kennelly, a lifelong Hartford resident, is no political novice. Her father, John M. Bailey, was the national Democratic chairman under President Kennedy. Her husband, James J. Kennelly, who died in 1995, was Speaker of the Connecticut House of Representatives, and her brother, John M. Bailey, is the Chief State's Attorney. After raising four children, she was elected to the Hartford City Council in 1975 and as the Connecticut Secretary of the State in 1978. She won her seat in Congress in 1982. She was so happy working behind the scenes in the House that she did not have a press secretary for the first 13 of her 16 years on Capitol Hill.
On Tuesday, Mrs. Kennelly announced that Joseph D. Courtney, a former state representative, had agreed to run as her choice for lieutenant governor, after a string of better-known Democrats had taken themselves out of the running during her long public search. The announcement should have generated political excitement. Instead, Mrs. Kennelly faced a grilling on Tuesday night at the monthly meeting of the Democratic committee in Wilton.
Bruce Redman Becker, an architect and developer in Wilton, began the question-and-answer session by saying, "What I'm eager to hear is what magic strategy you have to shake things up." Mrs. Kennelly replied that she and Mr. Courtney "both love substance; we love policy."
"It's very difficult with the press to get attention in that direction," she said. "We're trying very, very hard. I wish I could buy $1 million on New York City television right now."
Michael A. Slutsky, a Wilton lawyer, said he appreciated her support for education and the environment, but he added, "I'm looking for a defining issue." Mrs. Kennelly responded by talking for the first time that night about transportation problems.
Mrs. Kennelly's supporters complain that she has not aggressively worked the state's 169 Democratic town committees. Mrs. Kennelly blames her straits on what she sees as Mr. Rowland's recent attention to issues she has been pushing all along, including health care for poor children, the preservation of open space and ways to rein in the cost of attending state colleges. "He's done a 180 on everything," she often tells audiences. And she says, "He has the bully pulpit."
In an interview, Mrs. Kennelly said her candor was deliberate. "I am not a politician's candidate," she said. "What your political pundits would say is my problem is I don't spin. What you see is what you get. What you hear is what it's about. I'm probably brutally honest, with myself and with others."
Political analysts, however, said that few candidates can survive the combination of a vague message and poor delivery. Terry P. Michael, the executive director of the Washington Center for Politics and Journalism, a nonpartisan group, said Mrs. Kennelly's candor could be effective. "You can be unslick," he said. "Voters relate to that -- that's a good message. But you have to communicate that as a strategic message."
State Democratic leaders had spent months persuading her to run, believing that her connections, her record in Congress on health and children's issues and her wide margins of victory in her Congressional district would enable her to unify their party.
These party leaders had believed that she could give Mr. Rowland a tough battle by publicizing assertions that he has used state resources to benefit his supporters. Even some strategists for Mr. Rowland at first had feared Mrs. Kennelly's entry, worrying he might be vulnerable to a candidate who is a woman.
But Mrs. Kennelly had been warned otherwise by none other than President Clinton, who revealed at a fund-raiser last month that he had tried to dissuade her.
"You've virtually got to have a lobotomy, and you can get re-elected if the economy is good if you're governor," Mr. Clinton said in his remarks after a lunch at Martha Stewart's studio in Westport. (He did hasten to add that he meant no offense to Mr. Rowland.) "I told her the truth. I said, 'This is like rolling a rock up a hill if the economy is good.' "
It has not been an easy campaign. For all her experience, Mrs. Kennelly's speaking ability has never been tested in a campaign because she has not faced serious opposition in the First Congressional District, which is centered in Hartford. Mrs. Kennelly has now become known for her convoluted and sometimes puzzling sentences. "I've been everywhere in Connecticut, and everywhere is wonderful," Mrs. Kennelly said at one point. Another time, she observed, "Now we have to figure out if we have to get beyond what we have to get beyond."
She often speaks so rapidly that she can be hard to understand, and she frequently employs the stuffy vocabulary of the bureaucracy.
Mr. Rowland, on the other hand, is a voluble pol who plays up his pizza-and-beer image. But Mr. Rowland said he did not think voters would base their decision on personality. "People are going to see that this race is about the past versus the future," he said on Thursday.
Mr. Rowland was calling from Block Island, R.I., where he was vacationing at his family's summer home. He had just caught a 38-pound striped bass, and called himself "happy as a clam at high tide."
And he has plenty of reason. The state's economy has rebounded, although not as smartly as the nation's, and most state taxpayers are getting rebate checks this summer. In his announcement speech on Monday, Mr. Rowland plans to tout a record of "tax cuts, balanced budgets, job growth and prosperity."
Mrs. Kennelly's aides settled this week on a media strategy that they consider risky but necessary. While Mr. Rowland blitzes the state with television advertising about "building a better Connecticut," she plans to buy little advertising time until September. Throughout the summer, she hopes to attract news coverage of her challenges to Mr. Rowland on the issues of education, ethics and the environment.
Taking a break from fund-raising calls this week, Mrs. Kennelly said she is "obviously not what the press wants, but I think when I get out on Main Street, I'm very much what they want."
"I really thought the state could do better, and I think we're not preparing for the future as we should," she said, sounding wistful. "I thought I could come home and discuss the issues and say what I thought was not going well and what could go better. And that's what I'm doing."

HEADLINE: July 5-11;
H.M.O.'s Pull Out of Medicaid And Medicare in Some States

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN

 BODY:
Employers give health maintenance organizations the credit for stopping inflation in the cost of their workers' health benefits, and Congress and the Clinton Administration want them to do the same for their big benefit programs -- Medicaid, for the poor, and Medicare, for the elderly. 
 But blaming inadequate reimbursements for their services, leading H.M.O.'s have been pulling out of at least 12 states. Aetna U.S. Healthcare has dropped Medicaid programs in Connecticut and New York, leaving only New Jersey with one. Medicare beneficiaries are losing programs in 10 California counties and 22 in Ohio.
The move is more a trickle than a flood, with most of the managed care organizations still operating their programs. But President Clinton called the trend "disturbing."
The abandoned elderly have no choice but to return to more costly fee-for-service medicine, and the poor to "Medicaid mills" that provide inferior care. PETER T. KILBORN

HEADLINE: July 5-11;
A U.S. Bond That's Pegged To Inflation

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration rolled out a new type savings bond that it billed as inflation insurance for small investors -- or just folks searching for the right birthday/wedding/new baby gift.
The bonds' returns will rise and fall with consumer prices, eliminating the risk that inflation will wipe out the value of a 30-year security. 
 The new securities, which have all the tax benefits of traditional savings bonds, are to be sold in eight denominations from $50 to $10,000. Most of them, bearing the likenesses of such people as Helen Keller ($50) and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King ($100), go on sale this September. JAMES BENNET

HEADLINE: The Goodwill Games: Here Comes the Crowd

BYLINE: By STEWART AIN

 BODY:
AT the Empress Diner in East Meadow, Mike Panagatos has canceled his staff's vacations and put on extra help as he braces for what he calls "organized bedlam."
"It's going to be like a Super Bowl type of thing," Mr. Panagatos said. "I've been to four Super Bowls. It's hard to get reservations and at every place you have to wait. We're expecting something like that. We have no convention center on Long Island, so we have never had anything like this before." 
 "This" is the Goodwill Games, which are coming to Long Island July 19 through Aug. 2. A total of 1,500 athletes from 60 countries will compete in the 15-day invitational event. Three Nassau County sites -- the Nassau Coliseum in Uniondale, the Mitchel Athletic Field in Uniondale and the new Goodwill Games Swimming and Diving Center at Eisenhower Park in East Meadow -- will be used for 9 of the competition's 15 events. The 6 other events will be at sites in Manhattan and Staten Island.
"We're going to be a very busy place for two weeks," said Michael Hollander, president of the Long Island Convention and Visitors Bureau. "This will be perhaps the biggest international event on Long Island, and the largest event the bureau has been involved with in our 18 years."
County and state officials have been planning for the onslaught, and several officials took pains to reassure county residents that they would experience little or no inconvenience from the games.
"I don't think Long Islanders are going to be inconvenienced," said John Kiernan, commissioner of Nassau County's Department of Recreation and Parks. "Traffic should not be a problem because of the plans that have been developed."
He added that more people have attended concerts in Eisenhower Park than are expected to attend the games at any one time.
Neil S. Yellin, president of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's Long Island Bus, was more circumspect. "We want to reduce the headache for everyone and make the games as convenient as possible," he said. But he did suggest that for Long Islanders not wishing to attend the games, it might be a good time to "go to the Hamptons."
The Goodwill Games, which have been held every four years since 1986, are the creation of Ted Turner, who wanted to repair some of the damage done by the tit-for-tat cold-war boycotts that marred the Summer Olympics in Moscow in 1980 and Los Angeles in 1984.
He also wanted to fill air time on his Turner Broadcasting System, which will offer daily prime-time coverage in the United States and provide feeds to more than 130 countries. In addition, CBS and HBO will carry some events.
Such extensive coverage will affect Nassau County's attempts to woo other major sporting events and the big bucks they bring to the local economy. So it would help the organizers if the pool doesn't spring a leak and the athletes and fans aren't stuck in horrific traffic jams on the Meadowbrook Parkway.
The pool, which has been open since May, seems a safe bet. The traffic situation is a little dicier. Mr. Yellin said that fans are expected to file through Long Island turnstiles as many as 250,000 times during the games.
"The first five days will be the busiest because all three venues will be in use those days at about the same time," Mr. Yellin said. "Some start and finish close to each other. The challenge is moving spectators to and from the events during a short period of time. We have little flexibility because these events are on television and they have to start and conclude on time. I'm sure the big-name athletes will compete during prime time."
He was referring to such track stars as Michael Johnson and Jackie Joyner-Kersee and the figure skater Michelle Kwan.
Because most of the weekday events are scheduled to be held in prime time, Mr. Hollander said that he believed games-related traffic would not overlap with the evening rush-hour and that Long Island commuters would feel little impact.
Mr. Yellin said he had been working with the Nassau County Police Department to develop traffic mitigation programs. It includes deploying 18 to 20 message signs to direct people to the proper location, having a strong police presence to direct traffic and keeping tow trucks standing by to assist motorists in need.
Mr. Yellin said that because all of the venues can be reached from major roadways, the events should not disrupt local road traffic. But he suggested using the Southern State Parkway instead of the Long Island Expressway or Northern State Parkway to avoid traffic headed to or from the games.
Mr. Yellin said a key concern was parking. The venues themselves have a large amount of parking spaces, he said, and additional parking areas are being made available from which free shuttle buses will operate.
The organizers are estimating that only 12 percent of those attending the games will take public transportation. To encourage spectators to use public transportation, the Long Island Rail Road is to provide free passes to the Hempstead and Westbury stations; free buses would then take passengers to the events.
A spokeswoman for the L.I.R.R., Susan McGowan, said free passes are distributed with the purchase of any event ticket costing more than $10. But she cautioned that the rail pass must be requested at the time the sports ticket is purchased and that it must be exchanged for a regular ticket at staffed Long Island Rail Road ticket offices. The passes themselves will not be honored by conductors, she stressed.
Ms. McGowan said that there are currently no plans to add extra trains for the games, but that such service might be added if it is warranted by ticket sales.
Regardless of how smoothly they are handled, the crowds will mean some Nassau County merchants will make a bundle.
Mr. Panagatos hopes to be one of them. His 215-seat diner at 2490 Hempstead Turnpike is close to all three venues.
"We expect an influx of people from the local area and from out of town," Mr. Panagatos said, adding that a lot of money will be pumped into the Island's economy during the 15-day event "and we hope to get a piece of it."
Hoteliers seem assured of a good two weeks. "Every hotel room in Nassau County is booked for a three-week period," Mr. Kiernan said. There are 8,000 hotel rooms in the county. An additional 4,000 to 5,000 hotel rooms in western Suffolk County are also booked, Mr. Hollander said.
Frank D'Andrea, director of group sales at the Long Island Marriott in Uniondale, says the games brought the hotel its single largest group sales contract since it opened in 1982. The $1.3 million contract is to feed 25,000 individual meals to 1,700 athletes and staff, about half of whom will be staying at the hotel, over 18 days.
Joseph P. Cilia, general manager of the Roosevelt Field mall, said sales have been good this summer "and we hope the additional traffic from the games will add to it."
He said a directory listing the location and phone numbers of all 270 stores at Roosevelt Field would be distributed to area hotels, and that additional personnel have been assigned to information booths at the mall. He noted that hotels in the area already provide free shuttle buses to Roosevelt Field.
The mall, he said, can handle the added volume. "We're one of the largest malls in the country," he said. "We average 40,000 visitors a day."
Just how much money the Goodwill Games will generate for the Long Island economy is uncertain, according to Mitchell Pally, vice president of the Long Island Association, the Island's largest business organization. He said that when Nassau County and New York City jointly bid for the games in 1991, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey did a study that estimated the event would bring $250 million to the region.
"At the time, we weren't sure how many events would be on Long Island, and since then no other study has been done," Mr. Pally said. "But we see two impacts: it will put Long Island on the sports map for future events, and it will bring money to Long Island from visiting tourist-spectators and the Turner people."
To help make a good impression, visiting officials from national and international sporting organizations will be feted with a cocktail party and luncheon and each will get one of the 1,500 gift packages to be distributed to VIP's attending the games, according to Hilary Hartung, director of marketing for the Coliseum and hospitality co-chairwoman of the games. The packages will include pens, hats and shirts bearing the words, "Long Island 98, Good for You and the World."
The idea is "to get to the decision-makers who will decide to bring their athletes here in the future," Ms. Hartung said.
The new Swimming and Diving Center appears to be a prime candidate for repeat business from the purveyors of athletic extravaganzas. The heated pool, which is 68 meters long and holds 1.6 million gallons of water, is the second largest in the world, according to Nicholas A. Dellisanti, deputy commissioner of Nassau County Department of Recreation and Parks. By rearranging some moveable bulkheads in the pool, a diving competition could be staged at the same time two 25-meter swim meets are held, he said. There are 1,800 permanent seats at the pool and room for another 1,200 portables. The $30 million facility cost New York State $24 million; Nassau County paid the rest.
Indeed, the Swimming and Diving Center has already begun snaring other events, including the Girls High School State Swim Championships next fall, the Philips 66 Senior Swim Championships next March for those who will compete in the Olympics in the year 2000 and the Synchronized Swim Championships next spring, Mr. Kiernan said.
"We're building a sports infrastructure that will be part of the economic base of the county in the future," Mr. Kiernan said.
The athletic complex, newly refurbished at a cost of $22 million, has also started to pay off for the county. Mr. Pally said it helped snare the Empire State Games to be held next July. A total of 6,000 high school and college athletes will participate in the event.
"We never hosted them in their 20 years of existence," said Mr. Pally. "But they decided to come because they see what we can do."
Situated just one block west of the Coliseum, the athletic complex has a seating capacity of 12,000, half of which are permanent seats. It was used for the International Games for the Disabled, which attracted 3,500 athletes from 57 nations in 1984. But Mr. Dellisanti said the track, which was obsolete for this year's competition, was replaced with a nine-lane, 400-meter track. "We are going to be a sports mecca," he predicted.
Of the three venues, the Coliseum is the largest but perhaps the least inviting. Its main tenant, the Islanders hockey team, has been pushing for construction of a replacement for the old arena, which manages to be cavernous and too small at the same time. Nassau County has begun negotiations with the owners of the Islanders to develop a plan for a new arena-convention center.
"It's true that we could use a new facility," said Mr. Hollander of the Convention and Visitors Bureau. But, he insisted, "that does not get in the way of us being a sports mecca, because of all the other things we have."

HEADLINE: The Art of Crafts

BYLINE: By DIANE NOTTLE 

 BODY:
THERE are crafts fairs, and then there are crafts fairs. At many, all it takes to set up shop is a booth and some handiwork to sell. Then there are the juried shows, where exhibitors must convince judges that they do quality work before they're allowed to put the work on display (and up for sale.)
At these fairs, there are no bread-dough ornaments, no floppy-eared bunnies in old-fashioned dresses (well, relatively few). Instead, you may find handsome soft-sculpture mermaids, or wooden coat hooks carved and painted in the form of ballerinas in arabesque or Folies-Bergeres girls doing high kicks. 
 "The line has been erased as to what is art and what is craft," said Hortense Green of Westfield, who was the crafts coordinator of the State Council on the Arts for 15 years before leaving to work with the American Craft Council. "I hate labels, and there are many, many craftspeople who work in fiber or glass who are true artists."
Asked to estimate how many might be working in the state, Ms. Green said, "I honestly couldn't." With a laugh, she added: "I say we're going to sink from either potholes or crafts. New Jersey has been extremely active, and it's a marvelous area for crafts. We also have a very receptive and sophisticated audience."
The arts council last did a study of craftspeople in the 1980's, when Ms. Green identified 5,000 working in the state, said Carol Coren, director of communications for the arts council. Since then, the council has "focused our energies on a broader assessment of people who characterize themselves as working artists," Ms. Coren said, and today 47,000 New Jerseyans say they derive their primary income from the arts, including crafts.
At the turn of the century, the Arts and Crafts movement promoted the values of beauty and functionalism in fine handiwork. Now, as the 20th century comes to a close, some crafts artists see a revival.
"Little did I know I was on the edge of that," said Jim Fiola, a woodworker based in Branchville. When he started his business more than two decades ago, "there was nothing out there to show that other people were doing this," he said. "Then, starting in the mid-70's, these shows began to develop. They gave a market to thousands of people in all different types of media."
Today, "it's a very competitive business," said Mr. Fiola, who now exhibits only at juried crafts fairs. "Some shows have only 200 spots for 2,000 applicants, and they all do good work. You put up your slides, the judges sit there and sometimes they have less than five minutes to look at a piece and judge it. You have to make an impact in a very short time."
Crafts have found their way into galleries and museums. Mrs. Green helped develop the New Jersey Arts Annual exhibitions, involving six museums and equally divided between fine arts and crafts. New Jersey Designer Craftsmen, a nonprofit group founded in 1950 to promote fine craft work, has its own gallery in the New Brunswick Cultural Center and participates in other exhibitions statewide. Among them is "Handmade at the Shore," the current show of home furnishings and pottery at the Asbury Park gallery Cleopatra Steps Out.
Within the Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area in Layton, Sussex County, the Peters Valley Craft Education Center has seven working artists in residence, a full program of classes, and an annual juried festival, scheduled for Sept. 26 and 27 this year. On Tuesday, Governor Whitman visited the Peters Valley school as part of her efforts to promote tourism.
Despite its growth, the state's crafts industry remains essentially a collection of cottage industries. Artists by nature tend to work alone or in small groups. And most have traveled distinctly individual paths to their metiers.
 
CERAMICS
Out of the Military And Into Flowers
Back in the 1970's, while the crafts movement was burgeoning, Debra Betancourt was sitting at a computer panel where she "ran the war" for the Strategic Air Command during her eight years in the United States Air Force. These days, she sits behind a potter's wheel, shaping clay into lilies, orchids, peonies and especially irises, of which she recently finished No. 1100.
Last year, Ms. Betancourt won the best-in-show award in the ceramics category of the Lincoln Center Crafts Festival from the Montclair-based American Concern for Artistry and Craftsmanship. Her "Summer Vine" and "Marchioness" were displayed last spring as part of "Flora '98," a juried exhibition at Macculloch Hall Historical Museum in Morristown.
Her vases, candles and mugs are done in a style she considers "strictly sculptural and not strictly functional." Many of her vases, for example, are not closed containers. "Some of my customers are not ready to make the big leap, so some hold a little water," she said.
Her delicate-looking art actually grew out of her military life. "Because I had such a high-stress job, I was told to find a relaxing hobby," she said. "They did a profile on me, and I had always been good at art in school, so I was sent in that direction." After leaving the Air Force, she found that she could combine her career, her family life and her hobby into a workable package. By the time she was laid off from her job in 1991, she was ready to go into ceramics full time.
Recently she moved from a tiny 300-square-foot work space in Manville into a 1,400-square-foot storefront in Bound Brook, where she can be seen working in the window. She sells to 60 or 70 retail stores and galleries and now appears at major wholesalers' shows as well as 12 to 15 crafts fairs a year. Her prices range from $10 for mugs to $49 to $250 for irises to more than $1,000 for peonies and special pieces.
And she goes on inventing. "Pottery has been done to death," she said. "I like to think my work is right on the cusp."
 Avatar Pottery, 231 East Main Street, Bound Brook; (732) 271-2767.
 
METALWORK
Entomologist Manque With Wings of Silver
You might almost expect to see one of Ricky Boscarino's creations alighting on one of Ms. Betancourt's. Mr. Boscarino, of Luna Parc in Sandyston, Sussex County, makes bugs -- that is, finely wrought insects, mostly of sterling silver and bronze, to be worn as jewelry. And why not? He always wanted to be an entomologist.
"When I was a kid, I was really into biology," said Mr. Boscarino, 37, who was born in Paterson and grew up in Piscataway. "I always had a fascination with insects. I was going into it as a vocation, but I guess the right side of my brain took over, and years later, this is how it came out."
When he was about 14, he said, he became an apprentice to a jeweler in Summit, and by the time he entered Rhode Island School of Design, he was ready to major in metals.
The traditional metal smith's techniques he learned there were so time-consuming that "unfortunately, there's just no way of making a living," he said. Now he uses an ancient process called repousse, working with the metal on a bed of heated pitch, "like a gooey black tar."
"You can hammer into it and it gives," heo said. "It holds and forms the metal."
He estimates that only 1 percent of the metalworkers at crafts shows work in repousse. "It's so mysterious no one uses it," said Mr. Boscarino, who considers himself more of a sculptor than a jeweler. "That's why my work stand out. It's so voluptuous."
Besides insects, he also does a shoe line: "I happen to have a shoe fetish myself." His best, he said, is a saddle shoe in mixed metals. The shoes sell for $40 to $100, the insects from about $150 to $500.
A personal project right now is a garden of illuminated sculptures at his home, which he started about seven or eight years ago. "Some are quite tall, maybe 10 feet, and each one lights up in some way," he said. Who knows? Perhaps his illuminated sculptures will attract moths.
Luna Parc, Sandyston, (973) 948-2160.
 
WOOD
A Career Devoted To Making Better Boxes
Saws can be heard buzzing in the background when someone answers the phone at Designer Craftsmen in Branchville, Warren County, where Jim Fiola and his two full-time assistants created the "Empress" chest seen all over Manhattan on posters for the Lincoln Center crafts festival in June. Despite the high visibility, Mr. Fiola describes his work in simple terms: "We make boxes."
Jewelry boxes make up 70 to 80 percent of the business; the rest consists of items like humidors, floppy disk holders, CD-ROM boxes and pen chests.
The "Empress" looks imposing on the poster, but in fact it measures only 20 by 14 by 9 inches. It sells for a hefty $650. Prices range for $36 for small boxes to $1,200 and up for what Mr. Fiola describes as "borderline pieces of furniture." Although more than 60 galleries throughout the country handle his work, he estimates that 70 percent of his sales are direct. "What makes it so interesting is not only the design and making of it, but putting it into the customer's hand," he said.
Like many craftspeople, Mr. Fiola is essentially self-taught. He wasn't sure what to do with his 1970 bachelor's degree in history, so like so many other young people in the 70's, he entered "the graduate school of life," traveling around the country. That led him to homesteading, which led to woodworking.
The early years were a struggle, Mr. Fiola admits, and "after 24 years, I feel I'm just getting the hang of it." "I still get a kick out of it. It's a labor of love."
Designer Craftsmen, 2 East Trail, Branchville; (908) 362-5727.
 
GLASS
Little Pieces, Big Pieces: How They Fit Together
Rosemarie E. Mazzei makes glass. Michael Grant Solomon sometimes likes to break it.
Ms. Mazzei, who runs Distinguished Art Glass Studios in Great Meadows, works in fused glass. That means she takes layers of window glass; paints on them with ground glass and pigment, which turn to liquid at more than 1,500 degrees Fahrenheit, and shapes them over terra-cotta molds. The glass pieces form a single piece when they cool, resulting in bowls, plates and lamps of clear glass with flowers and other designs apparently captured inside.
"I've painted all my life," said Ms. Mazzei, formerly an office manager for her husband's construction company. She has had no formal training beyond high school art classes. In 1990, on vacation in Maine, she walked into a fused-glass artist's studio and walked out with a calling.
She bought a kiln and spent a year experimenting. "I learned, 'This is not acceptable; this blows bubbles; this cracks,' " she said. "It took years before I had anything to take out of the house." When she did, she started going to crafts shows. Now she has five kilns, sells wholesale to galleries and is represented in the Museum of American Glass at Wheaton Village in Millville and other museums.
"Plates are what a lot of people buy, but what attracts me are the larger pieces," she said. Among her favorites are a large vase, about 13 inches high, with a variety of flowers, and her lamps.
Mr. Solomon calls his business Reflective Art, and he means it literally. The centerpiece of his work is usually one or more mirrors, framed by stained-glass mosaics or window frames with patinated finishes. Recently he showed two examples of the latter: "For the Roses," a window frame covered with three mirrored panes and three containing dried roses ($300) and "Winner Longest Drive," with six mirrored panels, one of which has been shattered by the golf ball still embedded in it ($250).
"They give those out as prizes for losers at tournaments," Mr. Solomon said. "The people who appreciate that that don't necessarily appreciate what I'm doing now with glass, but they smile."
Working with glass was "a hobby that just evolved," said Mr. Solomon, who taught himself the craft while working as a salesman for a printing company.
Feedback at crafts shows has been instrumental to the evolution of his work. "You're there and you're naked and you're in their world and their environment," he said. "And that pushes you to try and please them. It presses the evolution."
Distinguished Art Glass Studios, 206 Free Union Road, Great Meadows; (908) 637-4305. Reflective Art, Post Office Box 854, Millburn; (973) -762-6334.
 
TEXTILES
Like Making Potholders, But What a Difference
"I'm on the road so much I don't know my neighbors," says Barbara Bass, a fiber artist who drops by her homes in Ocean, and Arizona between the juried crafts shows to which she travels every weekend. But even in hotel rooms, she works, carrying with her the frame on which she makes her Creations by "B."
"I do all types of fiber work, not just weaving or crocheting or knitting," she said. "I like to use very unusual yarns -- wools, mohairs, silks, linen, metallics." From them, she makes jackets, shawls, hats, scarves, collar hoods and fringe necklaces.
"It's very unique because I do everything on the frame, not a harness loom," she said. "It's like making potholders. I think the texture is very sensual. It's also very feminine."
Ms. Bass used to teach second and third grades but has been in the fiber business for 21 years now. She started with wall hangings, but "when the economy got bad, I found women would put things on their backs before their walls," she said.
Anyone who doubts that a little booth at a craft fair can turn into a big business might ask the proprietors of Blue Fish Clothing. In 1985, 17-year-old Jennifer Paige Barclay founded Blue Fish in her parents' garage "with $100 and a T-shirt and a block print," said Susan Flynn, the company's public affairs director. Now Blue Fish is the largest employer in Frenchtown, with 200 workers nationwide and five retail stores.
Ms. Barclay started at crafts fairs and she still goes to about a dozen selected fairs a year, including the local shad festival.
"We have customers who look forward to seeing us every year," Ms. Flynn said. "It's a way to bring a little of our retail operation to their backyard."
Creations by B, (888) 566-7774. Blue Fish Clothing, 62 Trenton Avenue, Frenchtown; (908) 996-3844.
 
To Look, Perchance to Buy

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;
Bright Arrival At Kennedy

BYLINE: By BETSY WADE 

 BODY:
THE all-new Terminal 1 at Kennedy International Airport has already garnered critics' praise for its architecture. The people who built this international terminal for the owner airlines, Air France, Japan Airlines, Lufthansa and Korean Air, and those who work in it, seem in love with it. They stop frequently to point to views through certain windows, particular pieces of design, giant new gadgets.
The departure area is dazzling in its light and loftiness. The interior balcony offers good people-watching. But how will the terminal work for passengers at the airport where, as the signs all over Kennedy say, "America Greets the World"? 
 It is usually true that departing passengers see the best of an international airport, according to William N. Bodouva, the principal architect. Arrivals enter on the lower level -- the equivalent of steerage.
Since the departure level is dictated by the height of the airplane door, Mr. Bodouva said, getting people aboard without climbing is possible only from an upper level. The baggage removed from the plane is handled at ground level and so, then, are its owners.
At Terminal 1 passengers still arrive downstairs in the so-called sterile security-sealed lower corridor. But they do not set foot on United States soil in a windowless wooden-walled corridor with no light at the end, as has been the case at the old International Arrivals Building.
The inbound concourse leading to the Immigration and Customs area at Terminal 1 has a moving sidewalk along one wall, and windows along the other with a view over runways and the aircraft parking area. The ceiling is undeniably low -- "the sterile corridor is always a squeeze, but we softened it a little," Mr. Bodouva said, referring to electric-light coves cut into the ceiling. Then, when passengers turn left toward Immigration control, the overhead opens into a vast skylight.
The Immigration area has 34 booths leading to four luggage carousels and space for a fifth. This area and the Customs staff at five channels are designed to handle 2,200 passengers an hour.
 
Expanded Customer Service
Coincidental with the opening of Terminal 1 came a new amenity for all three New York area airports: On June 15, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey hired a staff of 235 customer service agents, suited them up in red jackets or vests and sent them to the airports, turning a formerly seasonal program into a year-round project. Five of Kennedy's 82 permanent multilingual greeters are assigned to Terminal 1 seven days a week on two shifts.
Andrew E. Kreek Jr., Kennedy's manager of landside services, said these helpers had instructions to approach people in difficulty and to be sure they found what they needed. They can direct people to taxi lines and provide guidance on fares. Seventy percent of the customer service people speak a second language, commanding among them at least 30 languages, including French, German, Japanese and Korean.
 
Numbers Instead of Names
All terminals at Kennedy but Tower Air's are being redesignated by numbers. Terminal 1, built on 36 acres formerly used by Eastern Airlines, is the first major terminal an arriving driver meets coming off the Van Wyck Expressway; the last ones on the outbound swing, used by American, are now identified as Terminals 8 and 9.
Terminal 1 cost $445 million, according to Dieter Bergt, the chief operating officer. Ground was broken in September 1995, although the old Eastern terminal was not yet completely demolished. Terminal 4, formerly International Arrivals, has lost some of its tenants and is also being renovated.
Terminal 1 has 96 check-in positions and 32 ticketing positions on four islands on the departure level. Each island bears the logo of one of the four tenant-owner lines. But Mr. Bergt said the computer systems allowed any airline to use any counter in case passenger lines backed up. Air Afrique, Olympic Airways, Royal Air Maroc, Singapore Airlines and Turkish Airlines are moving into the new terminal, too, and others may follow.
Debra Shore, the project manager for the Terminal 1 Group Association, particularly admires the features that give the new terminal the ability to serve several functions in tight quarters. She pointed to the design of 6 of the 11 plane-entrance ramps, called lofting bridges. Departing travelers and arriving international passengers may not be mixed, and this usually requires using separate gates, or walled-off walkways in the interior. The adjustable end of the lofting bridges is on the terminal side: the plane can stay in the same place during its turnaround, and at the terminal end the gate is lowered to disembark passengers at the lower level or raised for embarkation at the upper level.
 
Cash Machines Scarce
On a humbler scale, the A.T.M. situation at Terminal 1 is not optimal. There are to be only two cash machines, according to Kevin Corrigan, a spokesman for Airport Aviation Professionals. This organization served as adviser on concessions to the Terminal 1 Group Association. Both machines are provided by American Express. The one that was working June 22 charges users $1.50 a pop to get at their bank accounts. It is inside the security barrier, near the American Express money exchange counters and, naturally, the stores. The other is on the ground floor, outside the security barrier, where arriving passengers are met.
The terminal has lots of phones, including a good number on pedestals in the meet-and-greet area, where they are so often needed. The wall installations on the departure level, oddly, are all at wheelchair height, which makes the keypads hard to read for those who dial standing up.
The 6,000-square-foot duty-free shop, where one may not enter without a boarding pass, is run by International Shoppes. Because Terminal 1 is used only by international passengers, this store is able to hand the merchandise, including cigarettes and liquor, to the buyers right in the store. The shop emphasizes California wines, and has a good selection of American whiskies.
Also beyond the barrier are two small bars and snack bars, Brooklyn Brewery Pub and Napa Valley Wine Bar, and some stores. One that has just opened is an H. Stern jeweler.
First- and business-class passengers can use spiffy private lounges run by the individual airlines. The walls facing out are almost entirely glass, with varying views, some distant, some of waiting planes. There are plenty of easy chairs, tables with phones and modem outlets, phone booths or communications carrels, meeting rooms, and a couple of windowless rooms with recliners for naps. The host airlines, which serve countries where smoking is apparently unabated, have encapsulated smoking rooms within their lounges. V.I.P. rooms, useful for those who crave privacy (rock stars perhaps), are available on request.
Three lounges have showers: Air France, Lufthansa and Korean Air. Attendants will fetch towels from well-stocked linen closets. Japan Airlines has no shower, but provides high-tech bidets with adjustable water temperature. In addition to the usual coffee, snacks and alcoholic drinks, Lufthansa and Air France will serve dinner at tables in the lounge to first-class passengers taking late-evening flights who want to go straight to sleep once on board.
Air France has transferred its children's playroom, with a wooden plane suitable for small children to climb aboard, a fabric tunnel for floor crawling and other games, from its former terminal to the corridor near its lounge. To reach the lounge or the playroom, passengers must go through security. The children's area may be used by Air France economy passengers, too.
There will also be a play area for children of all departing passengers out in the open on the departure level. It was still being put together on June 22.
The food court area on the balcony outside the security barrier is also still being finished, although a self-service counter was open, selling coffee and small sandwiches and cakes. It's hard to discern what it will be like when the Greenwich Village Bistro and the like are up and running, but in spacious unfinished condition, the balcony revived two vivid memories. One was the Golden Door at Newark Airport in the 1950's, a restaurant whose name reminded visitors that America was the place of opportunity, and whose splendid food endowed the portal itself with romance. Another feeling, from an even earlier era, overcame me as I stood at the balcony edge looking over the concourse: the sense one got in the old Pennsylvania Station -- of purposeful people under a high, high roof going someplace exciting.

CORRECTION-DATE: July 26, 1998, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
The Practical Traveler column on July 12, about Terminal 1 at Kennedy Airport, misstated the name of the 1950's restaurant at Newark Airport. It was the Newarker, not the Golden Door.

HEADLINE: A BOMBERS TALE: Taking Aim at Castro;
Key Cuba Foe Claims Exiles' Backing

BYLINE: By ANN LOUISE BARDACH and LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: MIAMI

 BODY:
A Cuban exile who has waged a campaign of bombings and assassination attempts aimed at toppling Fidel Castro says that his efforts were supported financially for more than a decade by the Cuban-American leaders of one of America's most influential lobbying groups.
The exile, Luis Posada Carriles, said he organized a wave of bombings in Cuba last year at hotels, restaurants and discotheques, killing an Italian tourist and alarming the Cuban Government. Mr. Posada was schooled in demolition and guerrilla warfare by the Central Intelligence Agency in the 1960's. 
 In a series of tape-recorded interviews at a walled Caribbean compound, Mr. Posada said the hotel bombings and other operations had been supported by leaders of the Cuban-American National Foundation. Its founder and head, Jorge Mas Canosa, who died last year, was embraced at the White House by Presidents Reagan, Bush and Clinton.
A powerful force in both Florida and national elections, and a prodigious campaign donor, Mr. Mas played a decisive role in persuading Mr. Clinton to change his mind and follow a course of sanctions and isolation against Mr. Castro's Cuba.
Although the tax-exempt foundation has declared that it seeks to bring down Cuba's Communist Government solely through peaceful means, Mr. Posada said leaders of the foundation discreetly financed his operations. Mr. Mas personally supervised the flow of money and logistical support, he said.
"Jorge controlled everything," Mr. Posada said. "Whenever I needed money, he said to give me $5,000, give me $10,000, give me $15,000, and they sent it to me."
Over the years, Mr. Posada estimated, Mr. Mas sent him more than $200,000. "He never said, 'This is from the foundation,' " Mr. Posada recalled. Rather, he said with a chuckle, the money arrived with the message, "This is for the church."
Foundation leaders did not respond to repeated telephone calls and letters requesting an interview to discuss their relationship with Mr. Posada. But in a brief statement faxed to The New York Times, the group denied a role in his operations, saying "any allegation, implication, or suggestion that members of the Cuban American National Foundation have financed any alleged 'acts of violence' against the Castro regime are totally and patently false."
 
The Recluse
Talking on His Terms, After Years of Silence
Mr. Posada, 70, has long refused to talk to journalists; his autobiography, published in 1994, provided only a sketchy account of his dealings with the foundation's leaders.
But in two days of interviews, he talked openly for the first time about those relationships and how they figured in a fight to which he has devoted his life, a fight that has left him far from his declared goal of toppling the hemisphere's last Communist state.
His motives for agreeing to the interviews are not easy to pin down. Mr. Posada, who has survived several attempts on his life, told a friend recently that he was afraid he would not live long enough to tell his story.
For the first time, Mr. Posada also described his role in some of the great cold war events in which Cuban exiles were key players. He was trained for the Bay of Pigs at a camp in Guatemala, but did not participate in the landing on Cuban beaches after the Kennedy Administration withheld air support from the first wave of rebels, whose attack quickly foundered.
It was Cuban exiles like Mr. Posada who were recruited by the C.I.A. for the subsequent attempts on Mr. Castro's life.
Jailed for one of the most infamous anti-Cuban attacks, the 1976 bombing of a civilian Cubana airliner, he eventually escaped from a Venezuelan prison to join the centerpiece of the Reagan White House's anti-Communist crusade in the Western Hemisphere: Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North's clandestine effort to supply arms to Nicaraguan contras.
Mr. Posada denied any role in the Cubana bombing, which killed 73 people, many of them teen-age members of Cuba's national fencing team.
He agreed through an intermediary to meet with The New York Times, provided his current residence and alias, and the location of the interviews, were not divulged.
Some of what he said about his past can be verified through recently declassified Government documents, as well as interviews with former foundation members and American officials.
But he made several claims that rest solely on his word, including an assertion that he has agents inside the Cuban military and that American law enforcement authorities maintained an attitude of benign neglect toward him for most of his career, allowing him to remain free and active.
Mr. Posada said all payments from the exile leaders to him were made in cash, and he said he did not know whether the money came from personal, business or foundation accounts. He said that the money was used for his living expenses and for operations and that Mr. Mas told him he did not want to know the details of his activities.
In the interviews he was generally expansive on broad questions of philosophy but evasive on specifics. He spoke in Spanish and English, with difficulty, his speech distorted by the severe damage done to the nerves of his tongue in a 1990 attempt on his life.
Mr. Posada said he was angered by recent newspaper accounts of his activities and eager near the end of his life to put his version of events on record, perhaps reinvigorating a movement he sees as lacking energy and direction since Mr. Mas's death.
The exiles' foundation, created in 1981, has sought to portray itself as the responsible voice of the Cuban exile community, dedicated to weakening the Castro regime through politics rather than force. Thanks to that approach and millions in campaign donations, the foundation became one of Washington's most effective lobbying organizations and a principal architect of American policy toward Cuba.
Any evidence that the foundation or its leaders were dispensing money to Republicans and Democrats while underwriting bombings could weaken the group's claim to legitimacy. That kind of activity could also violate the Logan Act, which makes illegal any "conspiracy to kill, kidnap, maim or injure persons or damage property in a foreign country."
Mr. Posada's remarks hinted that the foundation's public advocacy of purely nonviolent opposition to Mr. Castro was a carefully crafted fiction. Asked if he functioned as the military wing to the foundation's political wing, much as the Irish Republican Army does for Sinn Fein, he replied, "It looks like that," and laughed.
 
The Money
Assertions and Denials On Sources of Support
In the interviews and in his autobiography, "The Roads of the Warrior," Mr. Posada said he had received financial support from Mr. Mas and Feliciano Foyo, treasurer of the group, as well as Alberto Hernandez, who succeeded Mr. Mas as chairman.
Dr. Hernandez and Mr. Foyo did not respond to repeated requests for comment, and it was unclear whether they were aware of how Mr. Posada might have used any money they provided. In his autobiography, Mr. Posada said foundation leaders helped pay his medical and living expenses and paid for his transportation from Venezuela to Central America after his 1985 jailbreak.
At times, Mr. Posada said, cash was delivered from Miami by fellow exiles, including Gaspar Jimenez, who was jailed in Mexico in the 1976 killing of a Cuban diplomat there. Mr. Jimenez is now an employee of the medical clinic that Dr. Hernandez operates in Miami, according to employees at the office.
Mr. Jimenez did not respond to requests for comment.
When the bombs began exploding last year at Cuban hotels, the Government there asserted that the attacks had been organized and paid for by exiles operating out of Miami, a claim it bolstered with the videotape of an operative confessing to carrying out some of the bombings.
More recently, reports in The Miami Herald and the state-controlled Cuban press tied the operation to Mr. Posada. However, he told The New York Times that American authorities had made no effort to question him about the case. He attributed that lack of action in part to his longstanding relationship with American law enforcement and intelligence agencies.
"As you can see," he said, "the F.B.I. and the C.I.A. don't bother me, and I am neutral with them. Whenever I can help them, I do."
Mr. Posada gave conflicting accounts of his contacts with American authorities. Initially he spoke of enduring ties with United States intelligence agencies and of close friendship with at least two current F.B.I. officials, including, he said, an important official in the Washington office.
"I know a very high-up person there," he said.
Later he asked that those comments be omitted from any article and said it had been years since he had had these close dealings.
An American Government official said the C.I.A. has not had a relationship with Mr. Posada "in decades," and the F.B.I. also denied his assertions. "The F.B.I. does not now have nor have we ever had a longstanding relationship with Posada," said John F. Lewis, Jr. who as assistant director in charge of the national security division supervises all counterintelligence and counterterrorism work for the agency.
Declassified documents unearthed in Washington by the National Security Archives support Mr. Posada's suggestion that the F.B.I. and the C.I.A. had detailed knowledge of his operations against Cuba from the early 1960's to the mid-1970's.
G. Robert Blakey, chief counsel to the 1978 House Select Committee on Assassinations, said he had reviewed many of the F.B.I.'s classified files about anti-Castro Cubans from 1978 and had noted many instances in which the bureau turned a blind eye to possible violations of the law. As he put it, "When I read some of those things, and I'm an old Federal prosecutor, I thought, 'Why isn't someone being indicted for this?' "
On one point Mr. Posada was direct and unrepentant: he still intends to try to kill Mr. Castro, and he believes violence is the best method for ending Communism in Cuba.
"It is the only way to create an uprising there," Mr. Posada said. "Castro will never change, never. There are several ways to make a revolution, and I have been working on some."
Within militant Cuban exile circles, Mr. Posada is a legendary figure, celebrated for his tenacity and dedication to the anti-Castro cause. He has at various times also worked for Venezuelan, Salvadoran and Guatemalan intelligence or security agencies because, he explained, he wanted "to fight against the Communists, the people who helped Cuba."
But the Cuban Government regards him as a terrorist and a "monstrous criminal" responsible for numerous acts of violence against official installations and personnel, on the island and off, and has called on the United States to curb his activities.
Mr. Posada proudly admitted authorship of the hotel bomb attacks last year. He described them as acts of war intended to cripple a totalitarian regime by depriving it of foreign tourism and investment.
"We didn't want to hurt anybody," he said. "We just wanted to make a big scandal so that the tourists don't come anymore. We don't want any more foreign investment."
The bombs were also intended, Mr. Posada said, to sow doubts abroad about the stability of the regime, to make Cuba think he had operatives in the military and to encourage internal opposition. "People are not afraid anymore," he said. "They talk openly in the street. But they need something to start the fire, and that's my goal."
 
The Bombings
A Mastermind Reveals Some Key Secrets
 For several months the attacks did indeed discourage tourism. With a rueful chuckle, Mr. Posada described the Italian tourist's death as a freak accident, but he declared that he had a clear conscience, saying, "I sleep like a baby."
"It is sad that someone is dead, but we can't stop," he added. "That Italian was sitting in the wrong place at the wrong time."
In Havana last September, authorities arrested a 25-year-old Salvadoran, Raul Ernesto Cruz Leon, and accused him of carrying out a half-dozen of the hotel attacks. Mr. Posada said Mr. Cruz Leon, whom he described as a mercenary, had been working for him, but said "maybe a dozen" others reporting to him remained at large.
The hotel bombings were organized from El Salvador and Guatemala, Mr. Posada said. Explosives were obtained through his contacts there, and subordinates in turn recruited couriers like Mr. Cruz Leon to take the explosives into Cuba and detonate them in carefully selected targets.
"Everything is compartmentalized," Mr. Posada said. "I know everybody, but they don't know me."
"This was an inside operation in Cuba," he added, explaining that he was now trying to think of another way to disrupt the Cuban economy and demonstrate to the Cuban people that Mr. Castro's security apparatus is not all-powerful and all-knowing. "Very soon there will be exciting news," he predicted.
Mr. Posada said he had several ongoing operations, including one that resulted in Cuba's capture of three of his colleagues in early June. "Castro is keeping this a secret," he said. "I don't understand why."
In response to several questions about operational details that he clearly did not want to answer, he jokingly said, "I take the Fifth Amendment."
While agreeing to allow the interviews to be taped, he declined to be photographed, saying he did not want to provide Cuban agents with any information that would help them hunt him down. "The reason that I last so long is that nobody knows how I am," he explained. "Not having pictures of my pretty face has kept me alive a long time."
In Guatemala in 1990, he was attacked and gravely wounded in what he describes as an assassination attempt mounted by his enemies at Cuban intelligence. He was hit with a dozen bullets, one of which shattered his jaw and nearly severed his tongue, requiring several rounds of reconstructive surgery.
He said that during his long recuperation in El Salvador, some of his expenses were paid by Dr. Hernandez, the current chairman of the Cuban-American foundation, whom he described as "a great Cuban patriot and a dear friend." Just last year, he said, a Houston surgeon whom he also described as a friend flew to El Salvador and performed further surgery on him.
Mr. Posada detailed instances of support from foundation leaders throughout his career. Mr. Mas, he said, helped organize his escape from a Venezuelan prison in 1985, and then helped settle him in El Salvador, where he joined the White House-directed operation that led to the Iran-contra scandal.
"All the money that I received when I escaped from the jail," he said, "it was not that much, but it was through Jorge."
Mr. Posada said Mr. Mas was also very much aware that he was behind the hotel bombing campaign last year. But the two men had a longstanding agreement, he said, never to discuss the details of any operation that Mr. Posada was involved in.
"He never met operators, never," Mr. Posada said. "You ask for money from him, and he said, 'I don't want to know anything.' " Any discussion was "not specific, because he was intelligent enough to know who knows how to do the things and who doesn't know."
Mr. Mas, he added, "was afraid of the telephone."
"You don't talk like that on the telephone."
Asked when he had last visited the United States, he answered with a laugh and a question of his own: "Officially or unofficially?" A State Department official said Mr. Posada was reported to have visited Miami in the summer of 1996.
Mr. Posada acknowledged that he has at least four passports, all in different names. He regards himself as a Venezuelan citizen, but he has a Salvadoran passport bearing the name Ramon Medina Rodriguez, the nom de guerre he assumed during the Iran-contra affair, and a Guatemalan passport issued in the name of Juan Jose Rivas Lopez.
He also reluctantly admitted to having an American passport. But he would not discuss how he had obtained it or disclose the name in it, saying only that he occasionally uses it to visit the United States "unofficially," and had once used it to gain refuge in the American Embassy when he was caught in the middle of a revolution in the West African country of Sierra Leone.
"I have a lot of passports," he said with a laugh. "No problem."
He added, "If I want to go to Miami, I have different ways to go. But I don't go. You can't control Customs people. They can do anything."
"Then," he said, "Your friends can't help you."

CORRECTION-DATE: August 16, 1998, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
A front-page article on July 12 reported a series of interviews with Luis Posada Carriles, a Cuban exile who told of having waged a campaign of violence aimed at toppling Fidel Castro. Mr. Posada was quoted as saying his operations had been financed for years by Jorge Mas Canosa and other leaders of an influential American lobbying group, the Cuban-American National Foundation.
Because of an editing oversight, one sentence reported that Mr. Posada said the Cuban-American leaders had "supported" a series of hotel bombings in Cuba. The wording was not intended to mean that Mr. Posada said the foundation leaders had paid specifically for the hotel bombings.
In the interviews, Mr. Posada acknowledged having organized the bombing campaign. He also noted that leaders of the foundation had publicly expressed support for the bombings, which they characterized as an act of internal rebellion. But, as was made clear elsewhere in the article, Mr. Posada said Mr. Mas and other leaders of the foundation did not earmark money for specific operations, and asked not to be told how he used their funds.

HEADLINE: Tool Orders Rose 16% During May

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 12

 BODY:
Domestic orders for machine tools jumped in May, with orders increasing in all regions except the Northeast, an industry survey showed today.
Orders from American companies for domestic and foreign-produced machine tools rose 16 percent to an estimated $795 million in May, compared with April, according to a joint report from the Association for Manufacturing Technology and the American Machine Tool Distributors' Association. 
 Estimated orders for machine tools for the first five months of 1998 totaled about $3.7 billion, up 3 percent from the corresponding period a year earlier. Some tool makers, though, expect to come under pressure because of weakening demand from Asia. Also, the effects of the strikes against the General Motors Corporation are likely to hurt demand further.

HEADLINE: THE ARTS IN: DES MOINES -- Ripples in the Cultural Mainstream;
Arts Play a Curious Role In a Business Minded City

BYLINE: By BRUCE WEBER 

DATELINE: DES MOINES

 BODY:
It was a bit of Americana, stirring and sincere. Sockless, in baggy shorts and a tennis shirt as though fresh from a holiday barbecue, the Governor himself, Terry Branstad, stood on the Capitol's steps and introduced the Des Moines Symphony to some 20,000 Iowans gathered on the lawn and in the parking lot. This was the night before Independence Day, the occasion of an annual concert here. Rain clouds sprinkled a few drops on the crowd, but didn't dare spoil the party, dispersing as the evening darkened.
In the fading light, the gold dome of the Capitol glinted, even under its scaffolding. And by the time the orchestra rendered a George M. Cohan medley; a tone poem by its guest artist, Mark O'Connor, a country fiddler, and reached the climax of the "1812 Overture," many in the audience were cheering the musicians and waving tiny flags. Des Moines takes ardent pride in both its cultural institutions and its mainstream values. 
 Of course, therein lies a conflict. Although audiences in Des Moines, a city of 400,000 people with a healthy corporate base, have supported their symphony, their well-regarded opera company, their world-class art museum and their community theater for more than a quarter-century (and dozens of others for not quite so long), no one is claiming the city as a hotbed of experimentation or even as terribly tolerant of art that leans to the subversive. It was only a decade or so ago that a patron stood up at a performance of "A Chorus Line" at the Civic Center of Greater Des Moines, demanded that the profanity be halted immediately and had to be escorted from the theater.
" 'Angels in America' would not play well here," said Jeff Chelesvig, the general manager of the Civic Center, which is the city's only site for professional theater. "I'd love to do it, but I couldn't."
Indeed, the role of the arts in Des Moines is a curious one, characterized by cultural officials as both a strength and a weakness of a community that is generally enthusiastic if narrowly focused.
"I do think there's a general perception here that the arts are supposed to be entertainment," said Kenneth W. Hopper, the executive director of the symphony, who, like other cultural officials in town, sees himself as an educator of a sort. The symphony featured seven world premieres last season, well received, Mr. Hopper said, though he added that it thrills him when people applaud between movements of a Beethoven symphony, because it means the audience is full of new members.
"Opera is not indigenous to Iowa, but I've felt proud of our audiences," said Jerilee Mace, director of the 26-year-old Des Moines Metro Opera in Indianola, a dozen miles to the south, which has 1,500 subscribers. "They're growing into an appreciation of an unusual repertoire."
That would apply to a current production, Lee Hoiby's adaptation of "Summer and Smoke." After each performance, delighted patrons swarm the lobby to meet the performers, still in costume, a company tradition.
Most people acknowledge that, unlike the two major university towns nearby -- Ames, home of Iowa State, to the north, and Iowa City to the east, where the University of Iowa (and the renowned Iowa Writers Workshop) is located -- Des Moines is more a center of capitalism than intellectual ferment, an indistinct place that struggles with the image of blandness.
"I come from Des Moines," Bill Bryson wrote at the beginning of his dyspeptic travel book, "The Lost Continent" (HarperCollins). "Somebody had to." And though Mr. Bryson may not be held in particularly grand repute in his hometown, he isn't disputed much.
"We're just like the rest of the country," said Louise R. Noun, an art collector who specializes in work by women. "Same crime, same culture, just in smaller quantities."
Ms. Noun, it must be said, however, is pretty distinctive herself, having turned 90 in March, just after serving as curator for a show of an early 20th-century Iowa painter, Agnes Weinrich, at the Des Moines Art Center. (It travels to the Provincetown Art Museum in Massachusetts next month.)
 
Preferring Poetry To Auto Racing
There are, of course, other local residents who defy the mainstream cultural stereotype. One is James Autry, a former president of the Meredith magazine group here (the Meredith Corporation publishes Better Homes and Gardens and other magazines), and the author of several management books and a book of poetry.
Nine years ago, irritated that a group of businessmen had sponsored a Grand Prix auto race in town, Mr. Autry helped found the Des Moines National Poetry Festival, which has brought poets like Galway Kinnell, Carolyn Forche and Czeslaw Milosz for weekends of readings and workshops. More than 800 people took part in the eighth annual event in May.
"And I'm pleased to say, as a postscript, that the Grand Prix is out of business," Mr. Autry said.
Another offbeat arts entrepreneur is John Gaps 3d, an Associated Press photographer and the author of "God Left Us Alone Here" (Lone Oak Press), a collection of his photos from war zones with accompanying poems.
"I don't know what Des Moines is," Mr. Gaps said. "It doesn't have enough of any one influence to be any one thing. There's not a preponderance of pain here, but there is a preponderance of introspection."
Mr. Gaps is plumbing that introspective vein; he has started both a small publishing house and a literary magazine, Stand Alone, devoted primarily to Iowa writers. "The most prestigious literary publication in Iowa is The Iowa Review," he said, "and there's no one from Iowa in it."
The main influence on the culture of Des Moines, however, is commerce. A center of insurance and agribusiness, the city has a downtown where 65,000 people go to work every day, more than in Kansas City, Detroit or Phoenix. Companies like Meredith, the Principal Financial Group (which commissioned a sculpture by Maya Lin for its corporate headquarters) and Pioneer Hi-Bred International are the primary benefactors of the city's cultural institutions.
 
Cultural Groups As a Selling Point
Pioneer, for example, the world's largest seed-corn producer, endows a string quartet, the only four salaried players in the Des Moines Symphony. Part of this is enlightened self-interest, perhaps. Recruiting executives and technically trained workers has become difficult in Des Moines, where unemployment is less than 2 percent, so many companies are reaching out nationally. A local study showing that Des Moines has more cultural organizations per capita than cities like Austin, Tex., and Portland, Ore., is regarded as a selling point.
The arts scene, said Eric Fogg, the program manager for community development at Pioneer, "comes up in most interviews, and if it doesn't come up, we'll bring it up, because we're pleased with the quality and quantity of the arts in Des Moines."
Still, as in many other cities that have expanded away from the center, downtown more or less clears out after dark. And though situated prettily at the junction of the Des Moines and Raccoon Rivers, the city has acres of riverfront that have gone unexploited.
As it happens, the city has only just begun to address the lifelessness at its heart at night, with proposals pending before the local government to create a downtown arts district, establish incentives for converting abandoned warehouses to residential lofts and build an entertainment center that would include a 24-screen movie complex, restaurants, shops and nightclubs.
"The resources are here to invest in culture and entertainment," said David M. Feehan, president of the Downtown Partnership, an organization of businesses. "The likelihood is that we'll build $750 million worth of stuff downtown in the coming years."
This is encouraging talk, given the relative noninvolvement of the government; frustrated by the lack of support, the city's cultural institutions have recently formed an alliance to begin seeking funds from the suburbs. On the state level, Iowa ranks 42d among 56 states and territories in arts dollars spent per capita.
"Government support is terrible, pathetic," said David Kruidenier, 77, the former chairman of the Cowles Media Company, which owned The Des Moines Register before it was sold to Gannett in 1985. "Iowa is kind of an odd place. It's been so agriculturally oriented that I think the arts have been viewed as frivolous. But there has been a change among business leaders, a recognition that we haven't paid enough attention to esthetics."
Mr. Kruidenier was among those who selected I. M. Pei, in the 1960's, and Richard Meier, in the 80's, to create new wings for the Des Moines Art Center, whose main building was designed by Eliel Saarinen in 1948. The first museum built in the United States after World War II, it stands on a rolling, city-owned greensward west of downtown. Most residents consider it the city's cultural jewel, though it seems to be appreciated by a remarkably insular group; of its 110,000 visitors a year, 90 percent are Iowans, said Jessica Rowe, the acting director.
What others are missing is a collection that holds, among dozens of works by 20th-century masters, the Edward Hopper painting "Automat," which is featured on a 32-cent stamp; a white square by Robert Ryman much like the bone of contention in the Tony Award-winning play "Art," and "Amazing Juggler," by Kuniyoshi Yasuo, which Nikita Khrushchev once stood before in Moscow as he denounced modern art.
 
Vegetable Art With Dash of Humor
The Pei wing, a contemporary sculpture court, is particularly lively, with arresting pieces by Donald Judd and Claes Oldenburg (whose giant umbrella in front of the Civic Center downtown makes him well represented in Des Moines).
An installation by Red Grooms, depicting a booth at the Iowa State Fair, includes busts done in vegetables of native Iowans like John Wayne and Herbert Hoover, and indicates that, if anything, Iowans will tolerate a little humor about themselves.
A current exhibition of Iowa artists is an eclectic group of works, including paintings, kinetic sculptures and photographs. But at least one artist featured in the show, Sarah Grant-Hutchison, seemed a quintessential representative of Des Moines. An abstract painter who has had exhibitions in many regional museums, she was asked 12 years ago by a Meredith publication, Weekend Woodworker, to design a wooden nativity scene. She balked at first, but agreed when she was told her fee would be $500.
In addition to her painting, she now runs Sticks, a company that makes original furniture with wood-burned and painted designs, employing 55 people and represented by 125 galleries around the country. Sales last year were $2.5 million, and the company, having outgrown its studio, is putting up a new building.
"I've come to love the business end of things," Ms. Grant-Hutchison said, as mainstream an American artist as perhaps there is. "It's as creative and challenging for me as my painting."

HEADLINE: Applied Materials Offers Warning on Profit

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, July 12

 BODY:
Applied Materials Inc., the world's largest maker of semiconductor-manufacturing equipment, said late Friday that its fiscal third-quarter results would fall below analyst forecasts, hurt by delayed orders and cutbacks in capital spending by chip makers.
The company said it expected to report an operating profit of 15 cents to 18 cents a diluted share in the quarter ending July 26. Analysts had forecast earnings of 21 cents a diluted share, according to First Call. 
 Applied is the last major chip equipment company to warn that the Asian economic crisis and slowing orders from chip makers will hurt profits.
Applied, which is based in Santa Clara, Calif., said it expected new orders of $600 million to $675 million, and revenue of $850 million to $885 million.
The company made the announcement after the stock market closed. Applied's shares had been up 50 cents, at $29.50, before Nasdaq trading was halted pending the report.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Deutsche Bank Is Shopping For Acquisition or Alliance
Deutsche Bank, reeling from the recent defection of several top investment bankers to Credit Suisse First Boston, is looking to buy an American investment firm or to establish a significant alliance with one.
The chairman of Germany's biggest bank said he did not yet have a specific target. Industry executives have mentioned J. P. Morgan, Paine Webber and Hambrecht & Quist as possible partners. Page D2. 

BET Plans to Start a Film Venture
Robert L. Johnson, the chairman and founder of Black Entertainment Television, plans to start a venture to make low-budget films with black stars -- the first black-owned company to completely own films. The plan would start gradually and would be based on films with production costs of $3 million and advertising budgets of $2 million. D4.
 
2 Exchanges Discussing a Merger
The Chicago Board Options Exchange, the world's largest options exchange, and the Pacific Stock Exchange, a fast-growing regional stock exchange in San Francisco that controls the third-largest market in stock options, are discussing a merger. D2.

Patent Aims to Calm Crying Babies
A patent has been approved for a voice-activated sound-and-light box that attaches to a crib. It is intended to play a soothing message from the baby's mother or father when activated, show a picture of the parent talking and calm the wailing baby. D8.
 
Gemstar Approves Rights Program
Gemstar International Group has approved a shareholder rights program that is aimed at making a $2.8 billion hostile takeover bid by United Video Satellite Group more difficult to complete. D4.
 
Orders for Machine Tools Rose
Orders from American companies for domestic and foreign-produced machine tools rose 16 percent to an estimated $795 million in May, with orders increasing in all regions except the Northeast. D2.
