Chart: "An Exile's Life"
 
FEB. 15, 1928 -- Luis Posada Carriles is born in Cienfuegos, Cuba.
 
1947 TO 1952 -- Mr. Posada attends Havana University. One of his class 2/3mates, who is three years ahead of him, is a young law student named Fidel Castro.
 
JAN. 1, 1959 -- Mr. Castro marches into Havana, ousting the corrupt regime of Fulgencio Batista, the longtime dictator. Mr. Posada quickly sours on Mr. Castro.
 
APRIL 1961 -- After fleeing Cuba, Mr. Posada trains for an American- sponsored invasion. A band of Mr. Castro's opponents goes ashore at the Bay of Pigs, hoping to spark an uprising that will oust Mr. Castro. The operation is supported by the Central Intelligence Agency, but the United States reneges at the last moment on its promise to provide air cover. The invasion fails.
 
MARCH 1963 -- Mr. Posada enlists in U.S. Army and receives training in intelligence operations and demolitions at Fort Benning, Ga. There he meets a young exile named Jorge Mas Canosa.
 
1964-67 -- In March 1964, Mr. Posada quits the Army. He then takes on a string of jobs in Miami. He forges close ties with the Central Intelligence Agency. Mr. Mas joins the anti-Castro paramilitary organization RECE (Cuban Representation in Exile).
 
1967 -- Mr. Posada moves to Venezuela and, with C.I.A. help, takes a job as chief of operations of the country's security police.
 
OCT. 6, 1976 -- A bomb destroys a Cubana Airlines flight shortly after takeoff from Barbados, killing all 73 aboard. Among the dead are teen-age members of Cuba's national fencing team.
 
NOV. 1976 -- Authorities in Venezuela charge Mr. Posada, Orlando Bosch and two Venezuelans in connection with the bombing. All four are immediately jailed.
 
JULY 6, 1981 -- Mr. Mas formally incorporates the Cuban-American National Foundation.
 
AUG. 18, 1985 -- Mr. Posada escapes from a Venezuelan prison. The warden later acknowledges that he was bribed. Mr. Posada goes to the Ilopango air base in El Salvador, where he begins working on the contra resupply operation directed by Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North.
 
OCT. 7, 1986 -- A contra resupplyplane is shot down and the operation exposed. It is quickly disclosed that the Cuban carrying the passport Ramon Medina is actually Mr. Posada.
 
FEB. 28, 1990 -- Mr. Posada, working as a private security consultant in Guatemala, is shot 12 times by three gunmen. He attributes the attack to Cuban intelligence. No arrests are made.
 
APRIL 1997 -- Bombs begin to explode at Havana's better hotels, an operation Mr. Posada says he directed. (pg. A6)

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Desperado Democracies

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

 BODY:
Three weeks ago I visited Tirana, Albania, and on my way out of the airport to board my plane, I was stopped by an Albanian customs "official." She looked me up and down and asked: "How much money are you carrying?" There was a certain Jesse James tone in her voice. I told her I had $3,500. "$3,500," she repeated, her eyes lighting up. "He has $3,500," she said to her fellow customs agent. "Where are you from?" he asked, apparently trying to determine if I was a diplomat and therefore immune from this bureaucratic stickup. "I'm from The New York Times," I answered. "Let him go," the man said, apparently concluding it wouldn't be good publicity to separate me from my money.
These two Albanian customs agents had a lot more in common with Bonnie & Clyde than Coopers & Lybrand. They were a reminder, though, of a basic truth -- that in many formerly Communist countries, the successor to Communism is more often kleptocracy than democracy. That fact is too often forgotten in today's debates about China, Russia and other once-Communist states. 
 For instance, the Kosovo Liberation Army is now talking about uniting all the Albanian communities in the Balkans into a "Greater Albania." That is a frightening thought -- not because Albanians aren't entitled to unification, but because they haven't proved they can properly run one Albania, let alone five put together. The whole debate in Washington about China is when it will become a democracy. The much more important question -- for them and us -- is how it will become a democracy. How will it make the leap from where it is now -- with antiquated institutions and a police-state apparatus increasingly unsuited to its rapidly modernizing economy -- to a more open, rule-based system, without chaos in the transition?
It is one thing for Albania to collapse; it would be quite another for China to start spewing refugees, weapons and financial scams. "China had 70,000 traffic deaths last year -- roughly 630 deaths per 100,000 cars. America had 21 deaths per 100,000 cars," notes the Stanford University China scholar Mike Oksenberg. "It's because China has all these new highways with inadequate passing signs, or warnings about oncoming hills, or even traffic lights in some places, and no free press to report on it all. Their growth is simply outrunning their existing systems of governance and education."
That's why the ultimate test of U.S. China policy is not whether President Clinton shook his fist hard enough at President Jiang Zemin. The ultimate test is how well the U.S. uses its influence to promote a more rule-of-law system in China -- one that first constrains the Chinese state, and then gradually lays an institutional foundation that can carry Chinese society forward after the inevitable collapse of the Communist Party or its evolution into an electoral body.
If Congress wants to do something useful on China, it should spare us the chest-thumping and instead appropriate the funds sought by Mr. Clinton to train lawyers, judges and law professors in China. When Communist states collapse, before the new institutions have evolved you are much more likely to get Russia -- where they have a free press and the Mafia guns down inquisitive journalists -- than you are the best case, Poland, which had a Catholic Church and trade unions to fall back on.
But preventing Albania in China takes a lot of engagement, on a lot of levels. Those who argue that America should simply isolate China and hasten the collapse of its system now are just begging for a big Albania.
Fatos Lubonja, editor of the Albanian literary journal Endeavor, talked to me in Tirana about post-Communist Albania: "After Communism we had total equality in Albania. We were all at zero. There was no real infrastructure, no one really had property or contacts. Politics became just another business, because being a politician meant you could or could not give stamps of approval. The free market here was considered freedom to do anything. One of the West's great errors was that during the collapse of Communism, sometimes we changed the people in charge , but we did not really change the system. Instead of building a free economy, based on initiative and risk, we created a criminal economy. No one understood that without the software of real governing institutions , Albania is just a jungle."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Nasdaq Sets a Record on Gains From Technology Issues

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
A brighter earnings outlook for several leading technology companies propelled the technology-laden Nasdaq composite index to its fourth consecutive new high yesterday.
Aside from the gains among technology issues, stocks were mixed, as investors pondered how the unexpected resignation of Japan's Prime Minister would affect American companies. 
 The Nasdaq composite rose 22.49 points, to 1,965.53, led by gains among some of its bellwether issues like Microsoft, Intel and Dell Computer.
The surge in the index reflected renewed enthusiasm by investors for computer-related issues, which have largely been the torchbearers of this year's bull market. Many investors are now betting that earnings and sales of these companies -- which have taken a hit this year, in part because of slowing demand -- will rebound in the second half of 1998, as a worldwide glut of personal computers abates. Once that happens, makers of personal computers like Dell and Compaq will increase production and purchases of computer chips, improving the lot of chip makers like Intel.
Shares of Intel rose 2 5/8, to 82 3/8, on expectations that sales for the world's largest semiconductor maker will soon improve. While Intel is expected to report weak second-quarter earnings later this week, investors are optimistic the company will signal a sales improvement in the second half of the year.
Microsoft gained 4 3/8, to 117 9/16, on optimism that it would report better-than-expected fiscal fourth-quarter earnings Thursday.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 9.53 points, to 9,096.21. General Motors, Exxon, Sears, Roebuck and Procter & Gamble were among the blue chip decliners.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index inched up 0.86 points, to 1,165.19, just 1.18 points shy of the record close set last Wednesday.
In Asia, Japan's benchmark Nikkei index rose 1.68 percent, but most equity markets were lower. The Prime Minister of Japan, Ryutaro Hashimoto resigned, accepting responsibility for the ruling Liberal Democratic Party's dismal showing in weekend elections.
Reacting to the news, the dollar fell against the Japanese yen yesterday and Treasury bond prices dropped, suffering their largest declines in more than a month. The retreat indicated a possible end to the recent strong gains by the dollar and bonds, much of which was attributed to safe-haven buying by foreign investors.
Analysts offered mixed views of how domestic stock markets will fare as a result of the latest Japanese development.
"I'm just breathing a sigh of relief that they got off the ground," said Peter J. Canelo, a United States investment strategist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. "I wasn't expecting a resignation, but that's even better. It's an even stronger signal that they're going to do something right."
But other analysts remain skeptical that the resignation signals that the Japanese Government is ready to take quick action and carry out major economic changes to pull the economy out of recession.
"Investors around the world are looking for concrete steps," said Douglas Cliggott, United States equity strategist at J. P. Morgan Securities in New York. "There've been a lot of false starts."
"There's change," Mr. Cliggott added. "I think people are hoping there will be change in the right direction, but I don't know if there's anything to support" that conclusion.
While technology shares led the market higher yesterday, declines among issues like Applied Materials indicated that aside from global economic news, quarterly corporate earnings reports are still a focus.
Applied Materials closed at 28 9/16, down 15/16. Shares declined after the computer chip equipment manufacturer warned that fiscal third-quarter earnings would fall below analysts' forecasts, weakened by order delays and spending cutbacks.
But "the stock really didn't cascade" the way other shares have done after forecasting earnings disappointments, said Anthony Conroy, a managing director for Bankers Trust Global Investment Management. He attributed the stock's limited slide to investors' belief that "we're close to a bottom" and the sector is ready to rebound.

HEADLINE: Japan's Voter Revolt

 BODY:
Japanese governments do not normally resign after election losses for Parliament's less important upper house. But so emphatic was the defeat voters inflicted on the ruling Liberal Democratic Party on Sunday that Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto decided to quit. The L.D.P. had expected to take about 60 of the 126 seats being contested. It won only 44.
The rebuke was richly deserved, and Mr. Hashimoto was right to resign. For most of its two and a half years in power, his Government made no serious effort to revive the world's second-largest economy, and indeed made matters worse by introducing a national sales tax. When the Prime Minister finally did cut taxes earlier this year, it was too little and too late. Japan, once the main engine of Asian prosperity, now threatens to drag its neighbors and itself into prolonged recession. 
 Despite Washington's repeated urgings to reform, reflate and clean up billions in bad bank debt, Mr. Hashimoto spent most of his term dithering instead of leading. Like most of his predecessors, he deferred to powerful Finance Ministry officials, who preferred inaction to reforms that might erode their bureaucratic grip.
Only this month, eight years after Japan's banks began weakening, did Mr. Hashimoto announce a credible plan for weeding out failing institutions and reinforcing the rest. Now that belated but important initiative could be lost in the extended transition rituals of Japanese politics.
The L.D.P., still the majority party in the lower house, will pick the next prime minister, spending the next week choosing among four uninspiring candidates. The front-runner, Keizo Obuchi, is even more colorless than Mr. Hashimoto. Two others, Kiichi Miyazawa and Yohei Kono, have already failed in leadership roles. The remaining contender, Seiroku Kajiyama, is a veteran insider who at least has called for more vigorous economic action. But there is little realistic hope of reform policies emerging from an L.D.P. system designed to keep things as they are.
The brightest aspect of this election may be the emergence of the Democratic Party, led by Naoto Kan, Japan's most popular politician, as a potential competitor to the L.D.P. Mr. Kan earned his popularity two years ago when, as Health Minister, he stood up to bureaucratic resistance to resolve a scandal over H.I.V. contamination of the blood supply.
The L.D.P. has recovered from past election setbacks and has always come back. But with Japan now facing its worst economic crisis of the postwar era, muddling through an additional two years to the next election is no longer an acceptable option. World financial markets will not accept it, and Asia's other economies cannot afford it. Now, it appears, Japan's voters have lost patience with it as well.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasury Prices Fall on Hints Of Japan and Russia Recovery

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury securities suffered their worst one-day losses in more than a month yesterday on suggestions that Japan and Russia would overcome their economic crises, which diminished the allure of United States bonds as a safe-haven investment.
The benchmark 30-year bond's price fell 31/32, or nearly $10 for each $1,000 in the face amount, to 106 7/32. Its yield, which rises when the price falls, increased to 5.69 percent from 5.62 percent on Friday. 
 The main force behind the bond selloff was the resignation of Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto of Japan, after weekend elections that reduced his party's power and showed widespread dissatisfaction with his Cabinet's handling of the country's deepening economic problems. The drop in United States bond prices came on speculation that the new Japanese prime minister, as yet to be designated, might speed up tax cuts and other measures to stimulate the economy.
The financial turmoil in Asia has been a major reason United States bonds have rallied in recent months, sending the yield on the long bond as low as 5.56 percent last week, the lowest level since the Treasury began regular sales of these securities in 1977. Buyers have been acting on the belief that Asia's problems will hurt the American economy, keeping inflation and interest rates down.
Bonds also weakened yesterday on news of an agreement on new international aid to Russia to help it avoid default. Russia's worsening economic problems had also been an important force driving up United States Treasury prices.
Today, bond traders should get more data on the possibility of American inflation when the Consumer Price Index for June is released along with the report on June retail sales. Most economists are expecting a gain of two-tenths of a percentage point, both in the overall inflation index and in so-called core inflation, which excludes food and energy prices.
Despite yesterday's bond market weakness, the weekly Treasury auction of new three- and six-month bills met with strong demand. Three-month bills were priced to yield an average rate of 4.98 percent, up from 4.96 percent a week ago, while the six-month bill was priced to yield an average rate of 5.025 percent, up from 5.010 percent last week.

HEADLINE: The Murky Life of an International Gun Dealer

SERIES: A WORLD OF ARMS: Weapons in the Sky

BYLINE: By RAYMOND BONNER 

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
An athletic-looking Dane, with blond hair, blue eyes and an arrest warrant for armed robbery, hires a British arms dealer with a Walter Mitty complex. In Latvia, they buy a Russian cargo plane and have it flown to Bulgaria where it is loaded with 77 cases of weapons, including 300 assault rifles, ammunition, pistols, hand grenades and rocket launchers.
The lumbering plane then heads east to India. When it gets over the village of Purulia, near Calcutta, the weapons are shoved out, drifting down under parachute rigging purchased in South Africa. The deal is financed out of Hong Kong. The intended recipient is a violent religious sect. 
 However fictional it might sound, this was a real-life arms shipment, one that reveals the circuitous measures terrorists and rebel groups employ to get weapons, and how relatively easy it is for them to do so. It also illustrates the almost complete lack of international controls on the small-arms trade. In Oslo on Monday, the United States and 20 other governments opened a meeting to discuss measures to deal with the spread of assault rifles, pistols, grenades and other so-called small arms.
Generally it is not a crime for a weapons dealer to get around the arms-control laws of his country by having the weapons shipped from another country.
"It's a huge loophole," said Geraldine O'Callaghan, an analyst at the British American Security Information Council, an independent group that lobbies on small-arms issues. "It needs to be addressed urgently."
In the United States, the Clinton Administration closed this loophole two years ago by giving the State Department greater authority to monitor and regulate arms brokers. As a result, American arms dealers are now subject to the same laws whether they are shipping weapons directly from the United States or brokering deals abroad.
The Administration is pushing other countries to adopt similar controls.
Britain plans to address this, but only in part, by preventing arms dealers from selling weapons to countries on which the United Nations has arms embargoes.
While weapons falling from the sky is downright bizarre, the other elements of this tale typify a black-market small-arms transaction.
"You have deals like this being brokered on all continents of the world every day," said Donald Manross, an American who is the director of the firearms and explosives division at Interpol, the international police group that is still investigating the Purulia deal, which occurred in late 1995.
It is easier for the black-market trade to flourish because even legal transactions are highly secret. To protect the commercial interests of businesses, most governments, including the United States, do not disclose information about licenses issued to arms exporters.
Also, the document that governments rely on to control the destination of weapons, the so-called end-user certificate, can be easily forged, and a dealer has no legal responsibility to check on the validity of this certificate before shipping the weapons.
Rebel groups and terrorists use phony end-user certificates in order to disguise where the weapons will wind up.
Britain has tough export controls, but in this sale to the Indian religious sect, none of the arms touched British soil and no British documents were involved. Thus, while the British arms broker, Peter von Kalkstein-Bleach, languishes in a Calcutta jail on charges of waging war against India -- his plane was grounded by Indian authorities in Bombay when the deal went sour -- he does not appear to have violated any laws in Britain where he was based.
Nor is the other British arms-trading company, Border Technology and Innovations Ltd., which arranged for the weapons to be bought and shipped from Bulgaria, accused of any crime.
Mr. Bleach has pleaded not guilty in India to 12 counts, all of which carry the death sentence.
The deal began in the summer of 1995 when Mr. Bleach heard from a German commodities trader that a Danish businessman wanted to buy weapons.
Like many arms traders, Mr. Bleach, now 47, has a military background and colorful resume. After serving in the British Army, he was a prison guard in what was then white-ruled Rhodesia. He returned to Britain as a private investigator and later took up commodities trading, including arms deals. His company, Aeroserve, has a license from the British Defense Ministry.
"He's a Walter Mitty character, and a bit of a lady's man," said Christopher Hudson, who met Mr. Bleach 15 years ago in the course of their political activities in the Tory Party.
Mr. Hudson, who is engaged in a campaign to save Mr. Bleach from hanging, likes to call Mr. Bleach "the Milk Tray man." It is a reference to an advertisement popular in Britain in the 1970's, where a dashing man in a black polo shirt jumps out of planes and helicopters and braves shark-infested waters or other dangers to deliver a lady her Cadbury's chocolates.
For the Purulia deal, Mr. Bleach showed up in Amsterdam to meet a short man with a big Adam's apple, contact lenses and sunken cheeks, who introduced himself as Kim Davy. Mr. Bleach also met with Mr. Davy, and his lawyer, at the business center of the Intercontinental Hotel in central London.
Mr. Davy's real name is Niels Christian Nielsen. He was born in Denmark in December 1961, according to a confidential Interpol report. He took the name Kim Davy from a New Zealand infant who died at the age of 5 weeks. He has also engaged in gold and drug smuggling, money laundering and counterfeiting $100 bills, according to the report Interpol refers to as a "red notice."
A teetotaler and vegetarian, Mr. Nielsen is a member of the Ananda Marga, a Hindu fundamentalist group founded in 1955 in India, according to Interpol. The police agency says that the sect has been responsible for "many acts and threats of violence against Indian Government buildings and personnel," and was the intended recipient of the weapons. Mr. Davy eluded the Indian police when Mr. Bleach was seized and is still at large. Several European countries also want him for crimes ranging from armed robbery to counterfeiting.
A series of faxes from Mr. Bleach to Mr. Davy and his partners provides rare glimpses inside the world of small-arms trading.
"I stressed from the very beginning that in order to be successful, it is most important that this resembles a perfectly normal transaction in every possible way," Mr. Bleach wrote in one five-page fax.
"No single contractor should be aware of the entire route," Mr. Bleach scolded. Only the pilot should be aware of the ultimate destination of the weapons, he said.
For reasons that are not completely clear, at the time he was meeting with Mr. Davy, Mr. Bleach decided to go to the British authorities.
In a letter to the British Defense Ministry, one that is again highly revealing, Mr. Bleach said that if he backed out of the deal, Mr. Davy "will simply go elsewhere, and somebody else will provide the goods."
In the end, he took $30,000 from Mr. Davy and bought the Russian aircraft, Mr. Hudson said. After the operation, Mr. Bleach planned to sell the plane and keep the money as part of his profit, Mr. Hudson said.
To get the arms, Mr. Bleach turned to Border Technology, an arms-trading company in Hexham, in northeast England, because it had experience in getting weapons, said Peter Scott, one of the company's two directors; both men are former British military officers.
Border Technology would not discuss the details of the transaction but Mr. Bleach told Mr. Hudson that the company was paid $165,000 for the first shipment of weapons, the one that was parachuted, netting the company a "minimum profit" of $100,000.
Besides the 300 Kalashnikov assault rifles there were 20,000 rounds of ammunition; 15 9-millimeter pistols and 4,000 rounds of ammunition; two sniper rifles, with night vision sights; 10 rocket launchers and 200 rocket grenades, and 100 hand grenades.
If they had been shipped from Britain, Border Technology would have needed an export license, which the British Government might have been reluctant to issue.
So Border Technology turned to a leading Bulgarian arms maker, the Arsenal Company, for the high-quality Kalashnikov rifles and pistols. On the shipping documents Arsenal declared the weapons "technical equipment" and omitted the code of letters and numbers that would have identified the cargo as weapons, a senior Bulgarian defense official said.
Arsenal did not respond to telephone and fax requests for comment.
In a letter from prison to Mr. Hudson last August, Mr. Bleach said that when he became suspicious about the deal, he told one of Border Technology's directors "the facts, and suggested that it would be a damned good idea to call the authorities."
"He did not want to know," Mr. Bleach wrote. Mr. Bleach had already made his initial contact with the authorities, and continued to talk with them after his warning to Border Technology, Mr. Hudson said.
Mr. Scott, the Border Technology director, said his company had acted on the basis of what it considered to be a "genuine" certificate that identified the final customer as the Bangladesh Defense Ministry, and in any event had done nothing improper.
The certificate was fraudulent, Mr. Hudson said.
If significant curbs are going to be made on the shadowy arms trade, said Mr. Manross of Interpol, end-user certificates need to be standardized so that it is more difficult for them to be forged and easier for a company to check their validity.
Mr. Manross noted that in the last year there has been considerable discussion among independent groups that study the small-arms trade, and a few governments, about the need to crack down on the illicit trade in small weapons. "Now, we have to move to concrete action," he said.
 
Later articles will report on other aspects of the spread of arms around the world.

In most countries, it is not a crime for a broker sitting in an office in one country to arrange for a load of arms made in a second country to be shipped to a customer in a third. Here is one such case.
 
1. A British arms dealer, Peter von Kalkstein-Bleach, agrees to purchase weapons for a Danish client, Kim Davy.
 
2. Mr. Bleach arranges for the purchase of a Russian cargo plane, an Antonov 26, in Latvia.
 
3. The plane is flown to Bulgaria where it is loaded with 77 cases of Bulgarian-made weapons including assault rifles, ammunition, pistols, hand grenades and rocket launchers.
Mr. Bleach and Mr. Davy board the plane.
 
4. The plane continues on to India. The weapons are dropped by parachute into Purulia, near Calcutta, for delivery to a militant religious sect.
 
5. In Bombay the plane is grounded by Indian authorities and Mr. Bleach is arrested. Mr. Davy, the mastermind of the plan, escapes and is still at large.

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: Second Time Around, and Around;
Remanufacturing Is Gaining Ground in Corporate America

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
Dig inside the Xerox Corporation's newest stand-alone digital copier and the nuts and bolts of a big shift in manufacturing swing into view.
Parts that were welded are now fastened, and easy to take apart. Components that were scattered throughout the machine are arranged on subassemblies that can easily be lifted out. The fuser roll, which fixes the toner to the paper, is no longer made of an aluminum core that is tossed out when its rubberized coating wears off; the core is now a combination of aluminum and steel that can be recoated again and again. 
 Why all the changes -- particularly since some of the new parts are more expensive to make? Because they add a re-use option to the "recycle or dump it" choice for disposing of used or obsolete products.
"In the long run, it is cheaper to re-use a part than to recycle it," said Jack C. Azar, Xerox's director of environment, health and safety.
Once the purview of myriad small companies that eked out a living refurbishing carburetors, printer cartridges and other used parts, remanufacturing -- a method of re-using old parts in new machines -- has hit corporate America in a big way.
From Xerox to Saturn, from Lucent to DuPont, from Kodak to Steelcase, companies of all types and technologies are looking to remanufacturing as a premier way to hold costs down and keep products out of landfills. No longer happy to let their small-company forebears breathe new life into their discarded machines, many are stepping up their collection methods and re-use technologies to bring older products home.
But they are not content just to salvage parts from old products. Now, they are beginning to design products with eventual remanufacturing in mind.
"We're finally convincing designers that it doesn't matter if a part is twice as expensive, if you can use it again and again," said Cavan Kelsey, manager of design for health, safety and environment at the Eastman Kodak Company, which recently replaced some plastic parts in its high-speed copiers with more expensive, but reusable, stainless steel.
Designers are not the only converts. The Federal Trade Commission, the Environmental Protection Agency, and even Congress have recently embraced remanufacturing, with money, technological support and new rules. And numerous universities are studying it and teaching it.
In fact, interest is running so high that some manufacturers are using design changes and sometimes lawsuits to keep the independent remanufacturers at bay. Some are fearful that the remanufactured versions of their products will eat too deeply into sales of new ones. Others just want to do the remanufacturing themselves.
Although they have similar environmental goals, recycling and remanufacturing are not at all alike. Recycling generally involves destroying something so that its materials can be re-used. remanufacturers remove parts, test them, refurbish them and re-use them.
Recycling methods -- melting down steel or dissolving paper -- can be energy intensive and polluting, and often yield lower-grade materials. And they do not recapture the value that was added through processing or assembling.
By contrast, "remanufacturing is an affordable way to get the highest value out of parts," said Nabil Nasr, director of the Rochester Institute of Technology's National Center for remanufacturing and Resource Recovery. That realization, said Stuart L. Hart, professor of strategic management at the Kenan-Flagler Business School of the University of North Carolina, is yielding "tremendous corporate interest in, and sophistication about, remanufacturing."
Universities are fanning the embers. Kenan-Flagler just hired a professor of reverse logistics -- getting products back and remanufacturing them. The Rochester Institute sponsored a conference on remanufacturing in June. Gary A. Davis, director of the Center for Clean Products and Clean Technology at the University of Tennessee, said his group was about to study remanufacturing for the automobile industry "because it is infinitely superior to any type of recycling."
And numerous schools now preach remanufacturing in industrial design courses. "We are teaching students that it is silly to think one-time use when they design products," said Steven Derby, associate professor of mechanical engineering at the Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute.
remanufacturing is no panacea. The logistics of getting products back can be daunting. So can putting in tracking systems to insure that a part with a 10-use life is not on its 11th go-round. And some customers eschew remanufactured products, no matter how rigorously tested and warrantied.
"Some people will always believe that if something isn't brand new, it isn't high quality," said Michael J. Best, a product manager for Steelcase Inc., which makes new and remanufactured furniture.
Still, a growing number of manufacturers think the pluses outweigh the drawbacks. Computer companies, including the International Business Machines Corporation, are retrieving chips from old machines. Telecommunications equipment companies, including Lucent Technologies, are remanufacturing switching equipment. Lexmark International, which remanufactures its own printer cartridges, is looking "on a test basis" at whether it should use remanufactured parts in printers, a spokesman said.
The General Motors Corporation's Saturn division is working with the University of Tennessee to develop a software program that tracks the energy and environmental impact of every part of a car, from manufacture to disposal. One major use for the program: letting designers run "what if" scenarios to see whether tinkering with certain parts will make them easier to recycle or remanufacture. "We want designers to look at the environmental component of all their decisions," said William R. Miller 3d, Saturn's manager of environmental affairs.
Even chemical companies, which deal with vats of materials rather than discrete parts, are learning to remanufacture. Instead of melting down old polyester film -- which degrades the fiber -- or burning it for fuel, DuPont now "unzips" the polyester molecule down to its atoms, and remanufactures the polyester. DuPont is "scouting around for a similar chemistry for nylon," said John B. Carberry, director of environmental technology. "Billions of pounds of nylon carpeting is going into landfill that we should be able to re-use."
Collins & Aikman Floor Coverings Inc. has noticed that, too. It has a new technology, which falls between recycling and remanufacturing, for grinding up old carpets and, without any chemical processing, using them as backing for new ones. "You can do this forever, without the fiber degrading in any way," said Lee H. Schilling, senior vice president.
Remanufacturing as a separate industry has been around for more than 50 years. Remanufactured parts dominate the aftermarket for cars and trucks. Remanufactured office furniture and printer cartridges have also been available for years.
The United States military, the largest remanufacturer in the world, routinely uses remanufactured parts in vehicles and weapons. And "disposable" cameras are a misnomer: since the early 1990's, Fuji and Kodak have retrieved them from photofinishers and re-used the flash and other parts in new cameras.
"It didn't take long to realize how much value was left in those so-called throwaways," said Stephen C. Rumsey, Kodak's manufacturing manager for single-use cameras.
Indeed, remanufacturing is a good-sized industry in its own right. Robert T. Lund, a professor of manufacturing engineering at Boston University, said that in 1996, the last year for which he gathered figures, companies that rebuild parts comprised a $53 billion business employing 480,000 people.
But until recently, manufacturers and regulators barely acknowledged them. "This industry has grown and grown, yet it's been completely overlooked," Professor Lund said.
Now, remanufacturing is being promoted by its proponents -- including several state legislators in New York, which is home to many cartridge remanufacturers -- as the answer to everything from global warming (it requires less energy, and thus reduces greenhouse gases) to welfare reform (it provides jobs for low-skilled workers). Congress just granted the Rochester Institute's remanufacturing center $10 million over five years to develop new technologies.
The F.T.C., whose Green Guide to products with recycled content is widely followed by corporate and government procurement departments, amended its guidelines in May to embrace remanufactured products. The E.P.A. is financing some studies on remanufacturing. "It's an environmentally friendly solution for businesses looking to hold down costs," said Jane Bare, a chemical engineer in the E.P.A.'s office of research and development.
Remanufacturing companies are trying to capitalize on their new fame. Last year they formed the Remanufacturing Industries Council International, which is lobbying Congress to make remanufacturing equipment eligible for a 25 percent capital investment tax credit.
"As George Burns used to say, 'Hang around long enough, and you'll get discovered,' " said William Gager, chairman of both the Automotive Parts Rebuilders Association and the new council.
But what may be old hat for Mr. Gager is brand new for primary manufacturers. Many are under pressure from shareholders to meet environmental goals, and from customers who, facing their own environmental pressures and leery of rising landfill charges, want them to take back used items.
The pace of technology and the robust economy together encourage companies to upgrade old equipment, creating a steady flow of products to be remanufactured. And the pressure to keep costs down, combined with the growing number of start-up businesses that cannot afford all-new products, has created a growing market for remanufactured goods like office furniture or cartridges, which, unlike remanufactured copiers or cameras, are generally sold at a discount.
The battle lines between primary manufacturers and the independent remanufacturers are being drawn. Several printer companies have redesigned their cartridges to make them harder to refill. And they have aggressively sued remanufacturers -- and sometimes each other -- for trademark infringements when the packaging on the remanufactured cartridges looks too much like that on their new ones.
Furniture manufacturers may be playing hardball, too. Bill Davies, owner of Davies Office Refurbishing in Albany, says it used to be simple to remove fabric from the frames of office panels; now, he says, Steelcase and other manufacturers are laminating the fabrics "solely to make them hard to remanufacture."
Mr. Best of Steelcase says that is nonsense -- particularly since his company has a thriving remanufacturing business of its own. "The new design makes it easier to route cable through the panels," he said.
Maybe so. But it also brings more of the panels home to Steelcase itself for remanufacturing.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Steven R. Perez, left, and Jack Azar examine some remanufactured components at a Xerox plant in Webster, N.Y. (Phil Matt for The New York Times)
 
Chart: "Re-Use It or Lose It"
A new Xerox copier is a prime example of a movement among companies to design and build new products in a way that allows key parts to be re-used over and over again. The idea is to hold down costs and avoid unnecessary waste.
 
ORIGINAL MANUFACTURING
At its Utica, N.Y., factory, Xerox builds and remanufactures the fuser cartridge - the heart of the image reproduction system - for its new digital copy machine.
 
RE-USE
Instead of throwing out the cartridge, as it did in previous models, the company rebuilds the part after 275,000 copies.
 
INSPECTION
The fuser cartridge is disassembled, cleaned and examined.
 
SEPARATION
Individual parts that can be refurbished are sent to the factory where the machine is built.
 
REMANUFACTURING
At a separate site, the roll inside the fuser cartridge is stripped of its coating and a new skin is put on. The cartridge is remanufactured to meet specifications.
 
RECYCLING
Anything that cannot be re-used is recycled.
 
DELIVERY
The rebuilt part is installed in a copier.

(Source: Xerox)

LENGTH: 749 words

HEADLINE: George Dunne, 92, Priest and Ecumenist, Dies

BYLINE: By ERIC PACE 

 BODY:
The Rev. George H. Dunne, a Jesuit priest who was an impassioned critic of racial segregation and prominent in ecumenical efforts to combat poverty and foster peace, died on June 30 in a hospital in Los Gatos, Calif., outside San Jose, near the Jesuit retirement community where he had been living. He was 92.
Father Dunne was also a student of Chinese theology and language, a playwright and an author. But he was best known for his criticism in the 1940's of racial segregation, particularly in Roman Catholic institutions. 
 "He was basically a prophetic voice for social justice long before his time," said the Rev. Paul Locatelli, president of Santa Clara University, a Jesuit institution in Santa Clara, Calif. "He talked about racism back in the 1940's. He predicted in 1933 that if we did not develop democratic leaders in China, it would fall to the Communists within 30 years."
Father Dunne made that prediction after spending a year as a missionary in China.
Later, after receiving a doctorate in international relations in 1944 from the University of Chicago, he went to work at the Institute of Social Order, a new program at St. Louis University, another Jesuit institution, that was meant to respond to social problems and increase Jesuits' awareness of them.
But as things turned out, he was transferred to California after strongly expressing his opposition to racial discrimination at the university. In 1946, in an article published in the influential Catholic lay magazine Commonweal, he branded segregation a sin. (He was later called one of the first prominent Roman Catholics to have done so.) In that article, he contended, among other things, that segregation constituted a breach of justice.
A year earlier he had written a play, "Trial by Fire," that described the bombing of a black family that had moved into a Los Angeles neighborhood restricted to whites. The play was performed in 1947 and 1948 in Los Angeles and Chicago and at the Blackfriars Theater in New York.
Father Dunne spent much time and energy combating prejudice: writing articles, making speeches and taking part in numerous civil rights demonstrations, including several led by the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.
In 1968, Pope Paul VI and the Rev. Eugene Carson Blake, the general secretary of the World Council of Churches, named him the first director of the Committee on Society, Development and Peace, an ecumenical group based in Geneva.
Father Dunne wrote later in "The King's Pawn: The Memoirs of George Dunne, S.J." (Loyola Press, 1990) that the committee's "stated purpose was to focus attention upon the problems of poverty, especially in the third world, and upon the imperatives of peace."
"Through the churches," he added, "it proposed to quicken the consciences first of Christians, and then of all men and women, to their moral responsibility to concern themselves with the issues."
He and other members of the committee traveled widely and held conferences in Lebanon, Japan, South Korea and elsewhere. At a conference in 1968 in the mountains above Beirut, participants blamed a lack of political will, among rich and poor nations alike, for inadequate economic growth in most emerging nations.
Pope Paul VI sent a special blessing to that gathering, and messages from him and leaders of the World Council of Churches emphasized the importance of joint Christian action in the sphere of international cooperation.
After four years as director of the committee, Father Dunne retired from the post. The panel expired not long afterward.
Father Dunne's chief literary work was "Generation of Giants" (1962), about Matteo Ricci and other Jesuit missionaries who worked in China during the Ming and Manchu dynasties. His view was that those missionaries' lives had provided a lesson for the present day by adapting Christianity and humanism to the culture of China and not imposing Western ways on the Chinese.
A relative of the American humorist and journalist Finley Peter Dunne and the author Dominick Dunne, Father Dunne was born in St. Louis, grew up in Los Angeles and studied at various institutions, receiving a bachelor's degree from Loyola College in Los Angeles and a master's from Gonzaga University in Spokane, Wash.
In later years, his activities included teaching at Loyola and at Santa Clara and serving as the president's assistant for international programs at Geogetown University.
Father Dunne is survived by six nieces and two nephews.

HEADLINE: TURNOVER IN JAPAN: WASHINGTON;
White House Hopes Japan Can Restore Confidence

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 13

 BODY:
The White House today urged Japan's next Government to move quickly to "restore confidence in Japan's financial system," even while Administration officials said they feared that political paralysis in Tokyo greatly complicated efforts to ignite a recovery in Asia and ease pressure on other countries, including Russia.
White House officials today spent little time mourning the departure of Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto, whose slowness to act on economic reforms had been a continuing source of frustration here. 
 But several Administration officials wondered aloud whether any of Mr. Hashimoto's likely successors would be able to piece together a coalition strong enough to bail out the Japanese banking system and provide a sharp stimulus to the economy -- and to do so before the deterioration in the Japanese currency does greater damage to the world economy.
Charlene Barshefsky, the United States trade representative, said in an interview, "One can hope that this vote will be seen by the new administration in Japan as a definitive wake-up call."
But colleagues of hers in the Administration said it was too early to determine whether Mr. Hashimoto's party would interpret its electoral loss on Sunday as a signal to accelerate reforms or a sign that it should be cautious about causing economic pain.
Some experts on Japan say the election could stimulate action. "Up to now the main pressure to get the house in order was from the U.S. and from the markets," said Michael Mochizuki, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution. "That was big pressure. But still, what you read from Japan was that no one wanted to make any hard choices.
"Now there is domestic political pressure. The question is whether that translates into action."
How the markets interpret the politics will reverberate beyond Japan. Just a few weeks ago, for example, a Treasury Department study found a "surprisingly strong correlation" between the fall of the yen and the flight of investors from Russia.
Like the other financial contagions that have swept through Asia and beyond in the last year, no one can entirely explain this phenomenon, beyond citing the psychology of increasingly wary investors who are nervous about emerging markets of all kinds, including Russia's.
But the link was one more factor in the race to put together the loan package for Russia that was announced today by the International Monetary Fund.
It was this same concern about Russia, and the growing pressure on China to devalue its own currency, that led President Clinton and Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin to order an intervention in the currency markets a month ago to strengthen the yen.
But Sunday's election could unwind that effort. If the political turmoil in Japan is prolonged, one result could be another panicky sell-off of the yen.
"This is going to soak up time that Japan doesn't have, and that the rest of Asia doesn't have," one Administration official said today.
The size of the Liberal Democrats' drubbing clearly took the Administration by surprise. At White House meetings last week, the consensus was that the party would garner at least 54 or 55 seats in the upper house of Parliament. It won only 44.
But in public today, Administration and Japanese officials aimed their public comments at forestalling a sharp reaction in the financial markets.
"Whoever the new Prime Minister is, he will try to implement the economic plans formulated by the Hashimoto Government," Japan's Ambassador to the United States, Kunihiko Saito, said as he sipped green tea in his office along Embassy Row.
Mr. Saito is a veteran of managing relations with Washington during times of upheaval: he was the country's top career diplomat, running the day-to-day operations of the Foreign Ministry, when the Liberal Democrats were thrown out of power in 1993. Then, it was because of corruption, not ineptitude in handling the economy.
But while Sunday's defeat was less dramatic, in some ways it is more complicated.
There was little international cost to the political chaos that followed the 1993 upset; the issues of political reform were entirely domestic. This time they ripple daily through the international markets.
So now, though the party retains the prime ministership, it must convince Washington, the markets and Asia that a weaker governing party will push through painful reforms that a stronger Government, under Mr. Hashimoto, shied away from.

HEADLINE: Hillary Clinton Inaugurates Preservation Campaign

BYLINE: By PATRICIA LEIGH BROWN 

DATELINE: BALTIMORE, July 13

 BODY:
The heroic bronze figures on the Francis Scott Key Monument are corroded, and an oar that was once in the statue's supple-looking stone waters is long gone. But standing in front of this beleaguered 1911 monument to the national anthem in a quiet, green square this afternoon, Hillary Rodham Clinton spoke of renewal.
Her visit kicked off "Save America's Treasures," Mrs. Clinton's four-day history tour and preservation pledge drive that ends on Thursday in Seneca Falls, N.Y., at a celebration of the 150th anniversary of the first American women's rights convention. 
 In many ways, the tour reflects the current diversity of the historic preservation movement, once associated with battlefields, Presidents' birthplaces and blue-haired lady restorers in sneakers. Although Mrs. Clinton is in fact visiting one site where George Washington really slept -- his headquarters in Newburgh, N.Y. -- her stops also include a dilapidated theater, an Indian archaeological site, Thomas Alva Edison's laboratory and landmarks devoted to women's rights and African-American history.
The tour, a traditional First Lady-like endeavor, is designed to raise public awareness that if history is America's future, the bridge to the 21st century is in precarious shape.
Earlier today, the President appeared with his wife at the National Museum of American History in Washington. They were dwarfed by the original "Star-Spangled Banner." The 15-stripe, 15-star flag, which looms nearly three stories high, survived the attack on Fort McHenry in 1813-14 and inspired Francis Scott Key but is now a fragile, muted textile in dire need of restoration.
The President and First Lady shared the stage with Ralph Lauren, the designer who launched thousands of Polo sweaters with the American flag on them. Mrs. Clinton's campaign began with the announcement that Mr. Lauren had agreed to contribute $10 million toward the flag's conservation, including a state-of-the art laboratory that will be visible to museum-goers.
"We've been assured that this is a philanthropic gift and not a marketing gift," said I. Michael Heyman, secretary of the Smithsonian Institution.
The sites on Mrs. Clinton's tour include Federal, state and privately financed landmarks, all with expensive wish lists. One of the not-so-subtle purposes of the tour is to encourage public-private partnerships like Mr. Lauren's donation, the single largest corporate contribution in the Smithsonian's history.
The Park Service alone has a $1 billion backlog in historic structure repair, said Randall J. Biallas, the chief historical architect. The President's budget request of $50 million for the preservation program has yet to be approved by Congress.
"We are not talking about just generous gifts, but also encouraging kindergartners to collect pennies to clean up the monument in the town square," Mrs. Clinton said in an interview at the White House.
Speaking later at the National Museum of American History, she encouraged Americans to be "good ancestors," preserving landmark buildings as well as artifacts like "historic photographs yellowing in a county clerk's cabinet."
An example is the contents of the Thomas Alva Edison National Historic Site in West Orange, N.J. It was there, in his Invention Laboratory, that the master inventor developed, among other things, the motion picture camera, the nickel-iron-alkaline battery and the disk photograph.
Now a little-known outpost of the National Park Service, the site consists not only of historic structures, including the first building designed for motion-picture filming, but also 400,000 artifacts and 5 million pieces of paper, including original letters and lab notes, many of which are decomposing.
Mrs. Clinton is the latest of several First Ladies to adopt American history and the environment as their cause: Lady Bird Johnson campaigned for the beautification of the nation's highways, and Jacqueline Kennedy took on the renovation and preservation of the White House.
In her new endeavor, Mrs. Clinton has surrounded herself with preservation gurus, most notably Richard Moe, president of the National Trust for Historic Preservation, which is sponsoring the "Save America's Treasures" program with the White House Millennium Council. "She's really into it," Mr. Moe said. "We've never had a First Lady this deeply involved."
Mrs. Clinton acknowledged that historic preservation is an easier cause than, say, health care. "The politics are less controversial," she said. "No one is going to stand up against 'The Star-Spangled Banner' and its need for preservation."
In embracing preservation, Mrs. Clinton is attaching her star to a populist design movement that has sprung from the ground up from its inception, often against the wishes of politicians. In 1859, for example, Anne Pamela Cunningham established the Mount Vernon Ladies Association as a last resort after failing to persuade either Congress or the State of Virginia to save the mansion from developers.
"Historic preservation is the most important singular popular mass movement to affect architecture and planning in the modern era," said Vincent Scully, the Sterling Professor Emeritus of art history at Yale University, who recently gave an architectural lecture at the White House that reportedly had the Clintons spellbound.
Mr. Scully continued: "Architects hate it. It's the people taking back the way they want to live and what they want their cities to be, instead of being at the mercy of architects, planners and politicians."
Among the people Mrs. Clinton will encounter is Stephen Miller in Pittsfield, Mass., whose art supply and wallpaper store is housed in the 1903 Colonial Theater, imbuing the neo-Baroque haunt of Douglas Fairbanks, Ethel and John Barrymore and Sarah Bernhardt with the scent of linseed oil and vinyl. This week the marquee reads, Miller Supply Co. Inc. Welcomes Hillary Rodham Clinton.
Mr. Miller's father, George, bought the place in 1952, dreaming that one day he would restore it as a theater, drawing on both the local community and the Berkshire-bound culture tourists. The Colonial Theater has been waiting in the wings, mothballed and hidden, ever since, its now abandoned rotund balconies resplendent with dusty, peeling putty.
Like the theater, Pittsfield has had its economic hardships. Robert Boland, the head of the Friends of the Colonial Theater, a private group, said that about $10 million was needed to restore the building. The state has committed $2.5 million, he said.
There is no Ralph Lauren in Pittsfield, and the unglamorous nitty-gritty work of preserving landmarks falls to people like Mr. Miller.
"We'd love to see it renovated; that has always been the intent," Mr. Miller said recently, leading a visitor up a hidden staircase to the theater, its silk and linen damask curtains still sweeping the balcony but no longer Nile green. "There's plenty of sweat maintaining a building like this. My hope is that Hillary Clinton's presence will serve as a catalyst to get this off the ground."

HEADLINE: SOCCER;
Reprise: France Salutes Its Champions Again in Daylight

BYLINE: By CRAIG WHITNEY 

DATELINE: PARIS, July 13

 BODY:
For the second time in 24 hours, hundreds of thousands of ecstatic and patriotic French soccer fans thronged the most famous avenue in Paris today, this time to thank their national team for bringing France its first World Cup soccer championship.
"On est champions, on est champions, on est, on est, on est champions," supporters with the tricolor painted on their faces chanted victoriously on the Champs-Elysees this afternoon as members of the national team, bearing the gold cup to thunderous cheering, slowly worked their way up the avenue toward the Arc de Triomphe on an open-air double-decker bus. 
 French flags waved in the fresh breeze under a day that made people happy to be alive. Some flew the tricolor alongside the flag of Algeria, a salute to Zinedine Zidane, the team's playmaker. Zidane, the son of Algerian parents, scored two of France's three goals in Sunday night's 3-0 victory over Brazil. Marseilles, where Zidane grew up, celebrated far into the night after the game.
"Merci Zizou!," his nickname, became a chant in itself on the Champs-Elysees this afternoon. People were hanging from sycamore trees, street lights, traffic signals, and jumping up and down on top of steel-and-plastic bus shelters.
And there in the middle of the packed milelong avenue stood Martel Chatelain, wearing a New York Yankees windbreaker. "I watched the game at home last night on television," he said. "The guys played so well I just had to come down this afternoon to tell them how grateful we were."
So grateful, in fact, that the country's politicians let this be the team's day, since Tuesday is the Bastille Day national holiday, when the Champs-Elysees will fill again with tanks and marching soldiers to mark the 209th anniversary of the storming of the Bastille.
Defense Minister Alain Richard paid tribute today to the 8,500 soldiers and gendarmes who had worked throughout the monthlong tournament to assure public safety, recalling that one of them, a policeman in Lens, still lay in a coma after being attacked by German hooligans there on June 21.
On Tuesday, President Jacques Chirac, the French team's honorary No. 23, plans to talk in a nationally televised interview about "the France that wins," his aides said. The President, a Gaullist conservative, has been trying to get his compatriots to cheer up and be happy for the past three unemployment-ridden years, and the national team's victory on Sunday finally did it just as the French prepared to set off on their annual five-week summer vacations.
The President also invited team members as guests of honor to the sprawling gardens of Elysee Palace, the French equivalent of the White House, for the Bastille Day garden party Tuesday afternoon.
A million and a half Parisians surged through the city Sunday night after the game ended shortly after 11 P.M., most of them on the Champs-Elysees.
There, after a moonlight night turned to clouds and rain shortly after 3 A.M., a black Volkswagen driven by a woman whom the police said was under psychiatric treatment plowed into the crowd and hurt 80 people, 11 of them seriously, according to hospital officials. None of the injured was in critical condition, they said today.
The driver, a 44-year-old teacher, fled the scene of the accident but surrendered to the police in Yvelines, the western Parisian suburb where she lives, this morning. The police said she was still in their custody this evening.

HEADLINE: I.M.F. Says It Will Borrow From Members

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 13

 BODY:
With its financial strength depleted by the Asian crisis, the International Monetary Fund said today that it would have to borrow from its richest members to pay for the bailout of Russia.
The $11.2 billion in new loans being provided by the fund to Russia this year, plus the possibility of an additional $2.6 billion next year, would just about wipe out the money available from the fund's main financing pool, I.M.F. officials said. 
 As a result, said the managing director of the fund, Michel Camdessus, the loan package to Russia will largely tap a backup credit line from 11 of the largest industrial countries, including the United States. The American share is expected to be $2.1 billion.
The fund has not had to use the credit line -- described by a senior American official today as a "spare fuel tank" -- since 1978. With Japan in political and economic flux and other economies throughout Asia moving downward, analysts and American officials said the I.M.F. and the other multilateral lending institutions faced a real possibility of being caught short should another major crisis erupt.
"This puts them pretty close to the bottom of the barrel," said Morris Goldstein, a former I.M.F. official who is now with the Institute for International Economics in Washington. "If a big case comes in, or maybe a couple of medium-size cases, then you're stuck. Your alternative then is to go around hat in hand and try to put it together bilaterally."
Clinton Administration officials said the situation added urgency to their request that Congress provide new money for the I.M.F. The Senate has approved a White House request for $18 billion for the fund.
But the House has balked at providing the money without conditions that the White House has considered unacceptable, including limits on family planning.
Any Congressional approval would not have direct effects on the Russia bailout. But it could help the fund if it needed additional money to deal with a further spreading of the Asian crisis.
"With each of these developments, it becomes ever more important that Congress act quickly to approve I.M.F. funding," a senior American official said today.
A House Appropriations subcommittee is scheduled to take up the issue on Wednesday. But Republican aides said today that the party leadership has not decided whether to seek the full $18 billion or to limit the bill to one part of the financing, $3.5 billion that would go to an expanded version of the backup credit line.
That would leave open the question of the other $14.5 billion. That money would be the American contribution to an increase in the monetary fund's main financing pool, which is financed by quotas -- or membership dues -- levied on each of the 182 member countries.
Democrats in Congress said they would push the Republicans to act quickly to approve the new appropriation.
"We no longer have the luxury of simply waiting for something to happen," said Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Democratic leader, said after meeting President Clinton at the White House today. "It's happened. We've got to act soon."
Fund officials said they plan to raise $8.4 billion for the Russia bailout from the credit line, known as the General Arrangements to Borrow. The United States, which provides 25 percent of the money under the credit line, expects the fund's request to be approved quickly by the big industrial countries, the senior American official said. American participation would not require Congressional approval.
Under the credit line, the United States and its major allies can provide the fund with up to $23 billion, which has to be repaid at market interest rates.
The quotas paid into the fund by its members total $195 billion. But of that the fund has $30 billion available. Half of that has to kept in reserve in case any member countries decide to withdraw part of their quotas, which they are free to do, much like a depositor at a bank.
The bottom line is that without tapping the backup credit line, the fund has no more than $15 billion available. By the end of the year, fund officials said, its available funds will have declined to worrisomely low levels, even including the backup credit line.
Some Republicans in Congress said the fund was exaggerating the crisis it faces. They said the fund has $30 billion in gold reserves, plus the ability to borrow on the financial markets.
But Administration officials said the fund badly needed the flexibility that would accompany the pending quota increase and the increased backup credit line. The increases were proposed by the fund after the financial crisis in Mexico in 1995. That crisis showed international lending institutions how quickly global financial markets could overwhelm entire economies.

HEADLINE: Clinton Seeks Power to Lift India-Pakistan Sanctions

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 13

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration asked Congress today for more flexibility in its dealings with India and Pakistan, saying that current sanctions against the two countries for their nuclear weapons programs are too rigid and limit Washington's ability to halt a South Asian nuclear arms race.
The Administration is not calling for an immediate lifting of the sanctions, but only the power to lift them. That power, many officials believe, would enable them to induce India and Pakistan to stop testing or deploying nuclear weapons. 
 After the two countries tested nuclear weapons in May, the Administration was forced under a 1994 law to impose harsh sanctions against them. The law contains no provision that would allow the President to lift sanctions, either in whole or in part. Any changes in sanctions require a new law, passed by both the House and the Senate.
"Our purpose is not to punish for punishment's sake, but to influence the behavior of both Governments," Karl F. Inderfurth, Assistant Secretary of State for South Asian affairs, said at a hearing of the Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee on Near Eastern and South Asian affairs. "We do not wish for unnecessary harm to fall on the civilian populations of either country," he said, "or on U.S. businesses."
Last Thursday the Senate voted, 98-0, to exempt wheat and other agricultural exports from the sanctions because farm state legislators said the sales ban hurt only American farmers and would not prevent foreign farmers from profiting instead.
A provision attached to that law would have given President Clinton the authority, through March 1999, to waive the other sanctions imposed on India and Pakistan. But it was dropped after protests from Senator John Glenn, an Ohio Democrat, who wrote the original 1994 bill.
Other sanctions include a cutoff of trade credits, private bank loans and American support for loans not based on relief needs from the World Bank and International Monetary Fund.
Recently the United States voted for a World Bank loan to India meant for child education and health care.
Arms sales and military aid to Pakistan were cut off under separate legislation in 1990, when it was determined that Pakistan had nuclear weapons. "Right now there's no system to give the executive branch any flexibility," said James P. Rubin, the State Department spokesman. "We'd like it to come in the form of Congressionally mandated authority for the executive branch to respond to, or to induce, changes of behavior on the part of India and Pakistan."
What is new, Mr. Rubin said, is the Administration's request for such authority now in order to induce policy changes in India and Pakistan, rather than simply gaining it in time to respond to changes.
Together with other countries, the United States is asking India and Pakistan to stop testing, sign the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty without conditions, stop producing any more fissile material, quit deploying nuclear weapons, and stop testing or deploying missiles capable of delivering nuclear weapons.
"The intent is not to waive sanctions now," a White House official said. "But we'd like to have the authority to do so later once India and Pakistan have taken enough steps to warrant a waiver."
Senator Sam Brownback, a Kansas Republican who is chairman of the subcommittee and just returned from a trip to the region, said the sanctions were imposing significant economic harm on both countries in the midst of the Asian economic crisis.
"The economic situation there was not very good before we imposed sanctions, particularly in Pakistan," he said, "and now it is even worse."
Senator Brownback has sponsored another bill that may come up later this week. It would waive all the current sanctions for nine months, and follow that with a graduated waiver based on a Presidential certification that India and Pakistan were making progress in reducing nuclear tensions.

HEADLINE: Rowland Opens Re-election Effort With a Pledge to Cities

BYLINE: By MIKE ALLEN 

DATELINE: NORWICH, Conn., July 13

 BODY:
Formally starting a re-election campaign that has been under way for a year, Gov. John G. Rowland of Connecticut declared today that his top priority in a second term would be helping to rebuild the decaying cores of the state's largest cities.
That choice as a campaign centerpiece is part of a continuing effort by Mr. Rowland, a Republican, to chart a course that he calls "fiscally conservative and socially inclusive." It also reflects the evolution of the ever-more-moderate Mr. Rowland, 41, who went to Congress in 1985 as a brash right-winger and won the gubernatorial race in 1994, a year of big Republican gains. 
 On Nov. 3, Mr. Rowland will face a former colleague on Capitol Hill, Representative Barbara B. Kennelly, 62, a Democrat who has championed women's and children's issues during her 16 years in Washington. Mr. Rowland has built a wide lead in polls and has set a state record for a governor's race by raising $4.3 million, or more than twice as much as Mrs. Kennelly.
Basking in the state's rebounding economy and showing a deep tan after nine days at the beach, Mr. Rowland cut a confident and casual figure as he led a caravan across the state for four rallies featuring Boy Scouts, Dixieland bands and all the other patriotic trimmings.
"We've looked the bad times in the eye and we've turned things around," Mr. Rowland said, sporting a gold elephant in his lapel. "More jobs, higher wages, health care for children, better schools, safer streets." Pausing for applause, he said, "I promise you that we are just getting started."
Mr. Rowland began running television ads nine months ago, so today's rallies were hardly a surprise. But his campaign tried to pump up supporters by sending star-spangled postcards urging: "Don't miss out. It's the tour that makes it official."
He began the day under a white tent on a wharf in this mill town in eastern Connecticut, drove 100 miles west to the office towers in the New York suburb of Stamford, then doubled back to West Hartford and finished the night at an amusement park near his hometown of Waterbury, where he once worked in his family's insurance business.
In his speeches, Mr. Rowland said that he would continue to try to cut taxes, and he hailed the state's efforts to move welfare recipients into jobs as "tough love."
But he said he was making the cities his top priority because the state as a whole is in such good economic shape. "All of our cities are on the way back to an economic renaissance that we've never seen before, because of our hard work," he said. "But we can do so much more."
After his address in Stamford, Mr. Rowland said he wanted to follow through on economic development plans that had been announced for the downtown areas of Hartford, New Haven, Bridgeport and Waterbury.
Mr. Rowland said that he wanted to promote similar projects in other cities and urban towns, but would like them to rely on local and private money rather than on state financing.
"It's going to be a combination of universities, colleges, private investment, Federal dollars in some cases, city dollars in some cases, waterfront development," he said. "So I want to kind of stick around for a few more years to see that come to fruition."
Responding later to Mr. Rowland's plans, the chairman of the state Democratic Party, Edward L. Marcus, pointed to Mr. Rowland's long-abandoned promise of the last campaign, to repeal the state income tax, and asserted that today's pledges were no different.
"He takes positions as they become convenient," Mr. Marcus said. "He ignored the cities and education and the environment for three years. Now in an election year, he's for all of the above."
Mr. Rowland brushed off questions about whether he would commit to serve out a second term before seeking a higher office, or whether he might seek a third term. (Connecticut has no term limits for governors.)
In his speeches, Mr. Rowland made only the vaguest reference to Mrs. Kennelly or the Democratic Party. But he said he would stand by his challenge to debate Mrs. Kennelly six to eight times before Election Day.
A spokeswoman for Mrs. Kennelly said that the Congresswoman wanted to participate in debates, but said it was too soon to discuss how many.
This afternoon, Mrs. Kennelly held a news conference outside a recycling plant in New Haven to accuse Mr. Rowland of "putting polluters before people," a charge that she planned to make repeatedly through the fall.
Mrs. Kennelly had expressed frustration and even defeatism at several recent appearances, but aides said today that she was upbeat.
"The state of Connecticut will be better for this race, and I intend to win this race," Mrs. Kennelly said. "I'm going to work so hard, you won't believe it."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gov. John G. Rowland of Connecticut formally began his re-election campaign yesterday. Mr. Rowland and his wife, Patty, greeted supporters in Stamford, at one of four campaign rallies held across the state. (Janet Durrans for The New York Times)

Accord Reached on Loans
To Help Russian Economy
The Russian Government and international lenders concluded an agreement aimed at easing Russia's financial crisis and restoring confidence in its economy. The agreement would provide $17.1 billion in additional loans over the next two years. Combined with existing international assistance, the new pact would bring total lending to Russia to $22.6 billion this year and next. A1 

The I.M.F. said it would have to borrow from its richest members to pay for the Russian bailout because its financial strength had been depleted by the Asian crisis. The Clinton Administration said the situation gave urgency to a request that Congress provide new money for the I.M.F. A9

Politicians began jockeying for the chance to play chief surgeon to the Japanese economy after Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto resigned, saying he was responsible for his party's disastrous finish in parliamentary elections on Sunday. Mr. Hashimoto's resignation left a political vacuum at the economic heart of Asia, sending stocks and currencies reeling across the continent. A1
