HEADLINE: The Face-Off at G.M.

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: FLINT, Mich., July 13

 BODY:
It began 39 days ago as a simple strike at a single General Motors factory over how modern-day workers should build fenders and hoods. But like two neighborhood toughs daring each other with escalating taunts, G.M. and the United Automobile Workers union have fallen into a dispute so big, complicated and destructive that a solution now seems more elusive than ever.
The strike has forced G.M. to lay off 165,000 workers across North America and close 26 of 29 assembly plants. Any hope of resolving it soon was dealt a big setback this weekend when both sides threw up their hands in frustration. 
 It has also laid bare some emotional issues for the auto workers about job security and a steely resolve by the world's largest auto maker to fracture, once and for all, the union's insistence on a relationship that G.M. says threatens its competitiveness. Both sides have invested too much in the strike to accept defeat.
"Looking at it in actual dollar terms, it's hard to justify, but our long-term viability is on the line," Donald Hackworth, G.M.'s group vice president for North American car operations, said tonight in a recorded strike-update telephone message in which he also suggested a settlement would not come soon.
Mr. Hackworth said that G.M. had to improve productivity to maintain its market share. "We continue to lag behind our competitors -- as they continue to get better, our volumes continue to shrink," he warned.
Each side has repeatedly tried to force the other to back down by escalating the struggle, introducing new issues in the process that were not even part of the original dispute. G.M. and the union have been willing to escalate because of a combustible combination of huge cash reserves, which have given them the confidence that they can stand a fairly long strike, and a desire by G.M. executives to stand fast.
The U.A.W. has a strike fund of $725 million and is only spending about $3 million a week for strike benefits and health insurance for the 9,200 striking workers and a few laid-off workers who appear ineligible for unemployment compensation.
G.M. had $13.6 billion in cash at the end of the first quarter, and Wall Street analysts estimate the company has probably not spent more than half of it so far.
G.M. has been fighting for years to reduce its costs. But its struggle has grown more intense because of steady cost reductions at Ford Motor and Chrysler .
Record profits at cross-town Detroit rivals, combined with Chrysler's pending merger with Daimler-Benz of Germany, have put pressure on G.M. to eliminate a succession of factory-level agreements concluded over the years that have allowed some employees to collect a full day's pay for a few hours work and have left G.M. with the highest labor costs in the industry.
G.M.'s biggest productivity problem rests with its parts plants, which have the least-flexible work rules. The plants were starved of investment in the 1980's, when G.M. was pouring billions of dollars into assembly-plant robots, and have antiquated machinery as a result.
Harbour & Associates, a manufacturing consulting firm in Troy, Mich., has calculated that G.M.'s average labor cost for the auto parts in each vehicle is $2,765, compared with $2,322 for Ford and $2,167 for Chrysler. Ford and Chrysler buy a slightly higher proportion of their parts from outside suppliers that pay lower wages and also require fewer workers because they have invested in more modern equipment.
Because a strike at a crucial parts factory can shut down the company, G.M. has until now been leery of taking on the U.A.W. But under steady pressure from Wall Street, G.M. has become more willing to challenge the union.
Mr. Hackworth said G.M. was still pursuing a legal complaint accusing the U.A.W. of using the strikes at the two factories here to wage, in effect, a national strike in violation of a national labor contract that runs through next year. The union has denied this, but if G.M. wins an arbitration ruling, it could not only seek damages from the union but could also stop it from pursuing similar strikes. Legal experts give G.M. little chance of success.
The diminished hope for an end to the strike was reflected today in G.M.'s share price, which fell $2.3125, or 3.2 percent, to $68.875, after remaining fairly steady last week when optimism about a settlement had been growing.
Each side's sheer losses are now making it harder to compromise. The strike has cost U.A.W. workers about $300 million in lost pay, though many workers are eligible for unemployment benefits equal to about a quarter of their usual compensation.
G.M.'s losses have been heavier: 227,000 cars and light trucks not produced, with further production losses now rising at a rate of 21,000 a day, and an after-tax loss of $1.18 billion in after-tax losses, also rising now at a rate of $75 million a day.
G.M. and the workers will recover half or more of their losses through extra production and overtime pay after the strike. But G.M. dealers are complaining that they are running out of popular models and may permanently lose customers who try other auto makers' cars and light trucks and never come back.
Soon after the strike started, both sides began alternating serious negotiations with moves to escalate the dispute.
G.M. and the U.A.W. made a strenuous effort to find a solution after just six days of the strike at an auto body parts factory in Flint that makes hoods, fenders and engine mounts. G.M. even made the important concession on June 11 of promising to return parts-making equipment removed from the factory before the strike. But when those talks broke down, the U.A.W. ordered a walkout at a nearby spark plug and speedometer factory that is losing jobs to Mexico and East Asia, where wages are lower.
The second walkout raised the difficult question of G.M.'s steady push to build factories overseas while slowing investment in its low-profit American operations.
Unlike the auto body parts factory, the spark plug and speedometer factory is part of G.M.'s inefficient Delphi Automotive Systems subsidiary, which makes mostly small, low-technology auto parts. G.M. wants to sell part or all of Delphi, and the U.A.W. does not want it sold; so the second walkout dragged in this long-festering issue.
A few days after the second walkout, G.M. began threatening to close assembly plants and terminate the production of some slow-selling car models if the U.A.W. did not compromise. The threats angered the U.A.W., and raised the contentious question of how many workers G.M. would employ in the long term.
In response, the U.A.W. threatened further walkouts later this year at other parts factories here and in Indianapolis and Dayton, Ohio. G.M. responded last week by insisting that long-simmering disputes at those factories be resolved before any agreement is reached here.
The entire morass has left bargainers saying that while G.M. and the U.A.W. have labored through more than a dozen local strikes the last five years, none of those disputes have approached the complexity of the current mess. "It's complex enough that we've been out here a lot longer than we should have," Richard Shoemaker, the U.A.W.'s vice president for G.M. issues, said at a news conference this afternoon.
Yet both sides say the broader questions are unlikely to be settled by any deal here. Gerald Knechtel, G.M.'s vice president for North American personnel, said on Sunday that the main issue remained the union's insistence that G.M. invest more in the auto body parts factory here despite its low productivity. Improving that productivity will require changes in union work rules and a company investment in new equipment -- the local issues here 39 days ago when the first strike began.

HEADLINE: Lobbyist Is Indicted Over Campaign Donations

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 13

 BODY:
A Federal grand jury today indicted a Thai businesswoman who worked as a Washington lobbyist on charges that she and her family funneled hundreds of thousands of dollars in foreign money to the Democratic Party to gain access for her clients to President Clinton and members of the Administration.
In a 24-count indictment, a grand jury here said the businesswoman, Pauline Kanchanalak, and her family made unlawful donations of at least $679,000 to the Democratic National Committee and other state and local political committees from 1992 to 1996. The contributions were typically reimbursed from money sent through companies incorporated in the Cayman Islands and in Hong Kong. The contributions enabled Ms. Kanchanalak to attend a White House coffee and a birthday celebration for President Clinton, a fund-raiser with Vice President Al Gore, and events with other Democratic lawmakers. 
 The indictment was the third criminal case filed by the Justice Department's Campaign Financing Task Force in two weeks. Earlier this month, Howard Glicken, a Miami business executive, was charged with soliciting a political contribution from a foreign national and causing it to be made in someone else's name. On July 7, a grand jury indicted Maria Hsia, a California Democratic fund-raiser, on four tax counts. Ms. Hsia has also been charged with disguising illegal campaign contributions to President Clinton's re-election campaign.
With today's indictment, prosecutors in the special task force have now charged most of the main contributors who gave money to the Democratic National Committee through John Huang, the former senior Democratic finance official who has long been a central focus of the inquiry.
Erik L. Kitchen, one of Ms. Kanchanalak's Washington lawyers, issued a brief statement today saying that she "will ultimately be vindicated in this matter."
"Ms. Kanchanalak has been caught up in a political controversy relating to D.N.C. fund-raising practices," the statement said. "The filing of a 24-count indictment against her continues a pattern of the Government inflating alleged Federal Election Commission violations into massive felony charges."
The indictment said little about Ms. Kanchanalak's clients. One, Dhanin Chearvanont, is one of the richest men in Asia, controlling a business conglomerate, the Charoen Pokaphand Group, that involves more than 250 companies that sell products as diverse as chickens, shrimp, petrochemicals, motorcycles and telecommunications. The company is also the largest foreign investor in China.
Ms. Kanchanalak helped arrange for Mr. Dhanin to meet with President Clinton, Mr. Huang and Donald Fowler, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, at a White House coffee on June 18, 1996. According to the indictment, Mr. Dhanin discussed "primarily economic and political issues relating to the relationship between the United States and the People's Republic of China."
Around the same time, Ms. Kanchanalak gave the Democratic National Committee $135,000, and her sister-in-law, Duagnet G. Kronenberg, who listed the same home address in Virginia as Ms. Kanchanalak, contributed $50,000.
In addition to the charges against Ms. Kanchanalak, 47, today's indictment also accused Ms. Kronenberg, 41, of conspiracy and other violations. Ms. Kanchanalak's husband, Chupong, and her mother-in-law, Praitun Kanchanalak, were not indicted but were identified as co-conspirators.
As she fell under investigation in late 1996, Ms. Kanchanalak fled to Thailand, where Justice Department officials believe she remains. A Federal magistrate-judge today issued a bench warrant for her arrest.
The indictment describes numerous efforts by Ms. Kanchanalak to cover her tracks. Shortly after articles began to appear in late 1996 about her, she took steps to destroy and hide possible evidence, according to the indictment. She hired a computer expert to erase the hard drives of her office and home computers. She also removed boxes of records from her office, some of which she shipped to Thailand.

HEADLINE: TURNOVER IN JAPAN: THE OVERVIEW;
JOCKEYING BEGINS FOR POST IN JAPAN

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: TOKYO, July 13

 BODY:
Politicians began jockeying today for the chance to play chief surgeon to the world's second-largest economy after Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto resigned, saying he was responsible for his party's disastrous finish in parliamentary elections on Sunday.
Mr. Hashimoto's resignation left a political vacuum at the economic heart of Asia, sending stocks and currencies reeling across the continent today and touching off fears that another chapter could be beginning in the Asian financial crisis. At midday on Tuesday, the yen was up slightly against the dollar and stock prices were mixed. 
 The sudden and unexpected nature of the political upheaval here was underscored when Prime Minister Sergei V. Kiriyenko of Russia arrived in Tokyo this morning for a visit with Mr. Hashimoto. It was the first such visit ever by a Russian Prime Minister, and it seemed sensible enough when Mr. Kiriyenko left Moscow, but by the time he stepped off the plane in Tokyo, Mr. Hashimoto was history.
Mr. Hashimoto formally resigned shortly afterward and also had to cancel plans for a state visit to the United States later this month.
A new Prime Minister is expected to be chosen in the next week and installed on about July 30, after intensive horse-trading in the governing Liberal Democratic Party.
But the election has left some wondering whether Japan is on a transition toward a two-party system that will change the character not just of the party but also of the nation. That is subject to debate, but there seems little doubt that the election has already left the party with a reduced ability to govern and with a handful of prime ministerial candidates who represent precisely the old school of politics that the voters decisively rejected on Sunday.
"Hashimoto is one of the best that the L.D.P. can produce," said Takashi Inoguchi, a political scientist at Tokyo University. "Unless someone terribly fresh and surprising comes along, it's hard to see how the next Prime Minister can handle the issues head on and fast.
"To handle the problems efficiently, you need a fresh, strong and decisive leader, but they are very hard to find. So we'll have to muddle through with less than competent political leadership."
The selection of a new prime minister for Japan is of intense interest around Asia, for Japan is seen as the key to overcoming the region's crisis. Its economy is eight times as big as China's and twice as big as all the rest of Asia's put together, and it has contributed far more to bail-out packages than the United States or any other country.
Handicapping the race is a bit difficult, however, for the last thing candidates do is express interest in the job. Instead, if one is asked if one is interested, it is deemed polite to assume a pained expression and rush away without answering -- which is precisely what the front-runner, Foreign Minister Keizo Obuchi, did today when reporters raised the issue outside his home.
While in the United States the metaphor for becoming a candidate is to toss one's hat into the ring, in Japanese it is to be an omikoshi, a portable shrine. Just as throngs of revelers together carry an omikoshi on their shoulders in exuberant street festivals, so the candidate is supposed to be carried by supporters into the fray.
In reality, of course, the candidates are a bit different from other omikoshi: they desperately scramble for shoulders to carry them, and in some cases they even pay party officials huge sums for support.
Mr. Obuchi, 61, is the leading candidate largely because he heads the largest faction in the party and is respected for his affability. But critics say that while he may not have enemies, he also has no policies or initiatives, and it would be difficult to find someone less charismatic.
Another contender is Seiroku Kajiyama, 72, a much more outspoken and controversial party elder. He has some support, because he has consistently urged a more aggressive posture in tackling Japan's economic problems, but he has also made missteps over the years.
A possible compromise is Kiichi Miyazawa, 78, a former Prime Minister who is respected for his command of financial affairs.
Mr. Hashimoto, in announcing his resignation, declined to endorse a successor. His face grim and his eyes moist, he urged his successors to continue his policies of rectifying Japan's finances and restructuring government.
"I have proposed a number of reforms that are painful to people," Mr. Hashimoto said, apparently referring to such measures as his increase of the national sales tax. "I realize that there are various objections to this. But I did my best on these matters."
Asked what the biggest reason was for his defeat, Mr. Hashimoto scarcely paused.
"It was totally my fault," he said. "I lacked ability."
Mr. Hashimoto will remain a caretaker Prime Minister until his successor is chosen.
One of the new leader's central tasks will be to shore up not only the country but also his party. The elections Sunday for the upper house of Parliament were a major blow to the party, as it won only 44 seats out of the 126 contested.
Perhaps most worrying for the Liberal Democrats were the hints that Japan might be moving toward a Western-style system in which two political parties alternately hold power. For decades Japan has been a multiparty democracy in form, but the reality has been something closer to a one-party state.
"It is surely changing," Takao Toshikawa, publisher of a political newsletter in Tokyo. "We're moving toward a two-party party system."
Commentators have been saying that for a number of years, and it never came true in the past, even in similar circumstances. In the 1989 elections for the upper house, for instance, the Liberal Democrats suffered an even worse defeat, which was widely seen as a sign of fundamental change. Then tides quickly shifted again.
Yet the latest result also indicated that a two-party system may be emerging. The main opposition group, the Democratic Party, consolidated its status by winning big in the election, gaining respectability and legitimacy.
Moreover, in the proportional representation part of the ballot, the Democrats won 22 percent of the vote, just behind the Liberal Democrats, who got 25 percent. The balance was divided among a profusion of small opposition parties, and if some of them join forces with the Democrats -- as the Democrats hope -- then the opposition would be theoretically able to outvote the Liberal Democrats.
The Democratic Party is poorly organized. Its greatest asset is Naoto Kan, a dynamic former Cabinet minister who is by far the most popular politician in the country. The Liberal Democrats are fretting that they have no one with close to the appeal of Mr. Kan.
Another key factor is that disaffected citizens once simply did not bother to vote. But this time, exit polls indicate, the disaffected turned up at the polls -- and voted against the Liberal Democrats. Voter turnout surged from 44 percent in the last election for the upper house to 59 percent this time.
"This time is extremely different from past elections, both upper house and lower house elections," Mr. Toshikawa said. "This time, people were motivated to vote because of the economic circumstances."
More broadly, the election suggests that the Liberal Democrats are relying on a dwindling power base. They won their seats primarily in the rural areas that are losing population and influence, and they were demolished in the urban areas, failing to win a single district in Tokyo, Osaka, Kobe or Nagoya. In urban areas, even the Communists did better than the Liberal Democrats.
Kazuyuki Hamada, a political commentator in Tokyo, said that the challenge will be for the Democratic Party to unite the fragmented opposition, but that if this happens, the impact on Japan will be historic.
"They have to put aside their differences and work together," Mr. Hamada said of the opposition parties. "It's a life-or-death moment for Japan. If they fail, in the 21st century Japan will drift along and we will have no hope."
Japanese and Western analysts, even those in the Liberal Democratic Party, often emphasize the importance of a nurturing a two-party system as the best way to create a responsive political structure to lead the nation. For now, Japan in some respects resembles a one-party state, with a familiar pattern of political corruption and stagnation.
Moreover, many say that it would be difficult to restructure the Liberal Democratic Party and make it more forward-looking unless it is evicted and kept from power for some time. Just as the best thing that happened to the British Labor Party was the introspection and change during its years in the political wilderness, the thinking goes, the only way to refocus the Liberal Democratic Party may be to exile it from power.

HEADLINE: Russia and Lenders Seal Accord On $17 Billion in New Support

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, July 13

 BODY:
The Russian Government and international lenders concluded an agreement today aimed at easing Russia's financial crisis and restoring confidence in its economy.
The agreement would provide $17.1 billion in additional loans over the next two years. About $12.6 billion would be delivered this year and another $4.5 billion would be available in 1999. Combined with existing international assistance, the new pact would bring total lending to Russia to $22.6 billion over this year and next. 
 Most of the new money is to be lent by the International Monetary Fund, which came under pressure from the Clinton Administration to increase the amount of money it was willing to lend to Russia and to quickly wrap up negotiations that had dragged on for weeks.
To finance the Russian bailout, the United States agreed to lend the fund $2.1 billion. Other countries making loans include Japan, Germany, France and Saudi Arabia.
Anatoly B. Chubais, the lead Russian negotiator, described the round-the-clock talks as the most difficult ever held between the Yeltsin Government and the I.M.F. "The decisions taken today signify a restoration of faith in Russia's ability to overcome its difficulties," Mr. Chubais said.
In fact, the process -- and the endless drama here -- is far from over. Russia still has to take a number of important steps before any of the money will be distributed. On Wednesday and Thursday the Russian Government will attempt a crucial hurdle when the lower house of Parliament is expected to vote in extraordinary session on the Kremlin's plan for ending the financial crisis.
The plan calls for lower tax rates and laws to stimulate investment as well as a new law on budgeting procedures, all considered vital by the I.M.F.
John Odling-Smee, the chief negotiator for the fund, said the fund would decide on July 20 whether to start distributing its new loan to Russia and the actions of the Parliament would heavily influence the I.M.F.'s decision.
The Parliament has already balked at measures to reform the personal income tax and to change procedures for determining value added taxes. If the legislature also rejects additional proposals, Mr. Yeltsin can impose some of his measures by decree. But that could plunge the nation into a legal and political quagmire.
Still, today's announcement provided badly needed fuel for Russia's financial markets, which have been waiting for the I.M.F. to throw its support behind the Russians. Russia's stock market rose 10 percent today.
Mr. Odling-Smee described the agreement as "a major strengthening of Russia's economic program" that will enable the Yeltsin Government to avoid devaluing the ruble.
To a large extent, Russia suffered from Western investors' general unease over emerging markets following the economic turmoil in Asia. But Russia has also been vulnerable to a global currency crisis because it depends on foreign investors to finance so much of its deficit.
Initially, the I.M.F. said new loans were not needed. It wanted to husband its limited resources and insisted that the Kremlin could weather the financial storm by taking its own corrective measures.
But as interest rates on Russian Treasury bills soared, recently reaching 120 percent, and Russia's bond markets weakened, investors began to worry about the ruble and whether the Government would be able to avoid a devaluation of the currency as a means to lower interest rates.
With Central Bank reserves of dollars and other foreign currencies at about $15 billion, and foreign investors owning about $20 billion in treasury bills, there was a widespread concern among investors that a investor panic might drain Russia's slender cash reserves. Of the $15 billion, $5 billion of that is in gold, which cannot readily be spent.
The worry was that a foreign panic might set off a stampede in the treasury bill market in which investors would convert their ruble proceeds into dollars. Without adequate reserves the Central Bank would be unable support the value of the ruble by purchasing it in the currency markets, and a devaluation might soon follow.
The concern was that a devaluation of the ruble would not only lead to a round of inflation but might also shake the nation's political establishment. Mr. Yeltsin has even gone so far as suggest that "extremists" might attempt to launch a coup.
As Russia's financial markets shuddered in May and June, the I.M.F. began to consider additional financing. I.M.F. officials initially proposed only $5.6 billion in new loans. But after President Clinton returned from his trip to China, the United States began to focus on Russia's economy with new intensity.
The Clinton Administration considers Sergei Kiriyenko, the new Russian Prime Minister, and his team of aides to be the most reform-minded Government Russia has had in years.
American officials argued that assistance had to be large enough to impress the world's financial markets and give Mr. Kiriyenko the breathing space he needed to try to turn the country's economy around.
The American pressure bore fruit last weekend when the I.M.F. doubled its financial package and sought to wrap up the negotiations.
To come up with the additional funds, the fund was forced to use the General Arrangements to Borrow, a little-used loan fund established in 1962 to stabilize the world monetary system.
Still, even with the lure of additional funds, the monetary fund and Russia had to work hard to overcome their differences.
A major issue in the talks, for example, was been the pace at which Russia should cut its budget deficit. The two sides now agree that the deficit should be reduced to 2.8 percent of Russia's domestic production in 1999 from more than 5 percent currently, a huge step that will require raising billions of dollars in new revenue.
To reassure investors, Mr. Chubais emphasized that Russia will receive $22.6 billion in loans during the last half of 1998 and in 1999. That figure, however, combined old loans that were worked out before the financial crisis and the new rescue package.
The actual amount of new financing is somewhat less, though still substantial.
Russia will receive $12.6 in additional financing during the rest of 1998. Those loans include $11.2 billion from the I.M.F., $800 million from the World Bank and $600 million lent from Japan.
Some $2.2 billion in previously agreed I.M.F. and World Bank loans is also to be disbursed, bringing the total for this year to $14.8 billion.
Next year, Russia will receive $7.8 billion in new aid, including $4.5 billion in new loans and $3.3 billion in previously agreed financing.
There may be even more loans in the future, as the fund indicated that it is willing to negotiate a further three year loan if the Government stays on the reform track. That would provide an additional $2.6 billion a year in new financing.
Besides the loan package, Russia said it would stop issuing short-term treasury bills, which have been sold at high interest rates in auctions that have occurred every week or 10 days. Instead, it will now offer investors an opportunity to convert their ruble denominated treasury bills into longer-term dollar denominated bonds.
Russia has been negotiating to receive $10 billion from western commercial banks. But today, Mr. Chubais suggested that the commercial loans would not be needed. "We are not seeking to increase debts, but on the contrary to diminish debts."
Not everyone applauded the new financial package.
Gazprom, the huge natural gas monopoly, complained about provisions that would require it to make its transport pipeline system available to other gas producers. The World Bank insisted that the pipeline be opened to limit Gazprom's dominance and introduce more competition.
Though the Russian Government was breathing a sigh of relief, the toughest part lies ahead. The Yeltsin Government has to win parliamentary approval of its package to end the crisis. Then it has to try to stay the course.
One Yeltsin aide said he had no time to celebrate today's agreement. "It is going to be a difficult week," he said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Chrysler Profits Double, Topping Analysts' Forecast
Chrysler reported second-quarter earnings of $1.51 a share, surpassing Wall Street's projections by about 10 cents a share.
The auto maker, whose profits were more than double those of the strike-ridden second quarter of last year, attributed the sound performance to strong sales, cost- cutting and the growing popularity of high-margin products like the Dodge Durango sport utility vehicle. Page D2. 

Turmoil in Japan Causes New Fears
The resignation of Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto of Japan left a political vacuum at the economic heart of Asia, sending stocks and currencies reeling across the continent and touching off fears that another chapter could be beginning in the Asian financial crisis. A1.
 
Russian Loans Package Approved
The Russian Government and international lenders concluded an agreement to ease Russia's financial crisis. The deal provides $17.1 billion in additional loans in the next two years, with most of the money provided by the International Monetary Fund. A1.
 
The I.M.F. said it would have to borrow from its richest members to pay for the bailout of Russia. The American share is expected to be $2.1 billion. A9.
 
Intel Responds to Antitrust Suit
Intel said it acted lawfully in withholding some technology from three computer companies and in seeking to retrieve other technology from them. It was Intel's first formal response to a Federal Trade Commission antitrust lawsuit against the top computer-chip maker. D19.
 
Nasdaq Sets a Record; Dow Falls
A brighter earnings outlook for several leading technology companies propelled the technology-laden Nasdaq composite index to its fourth consecutive high. Other stock gauges were mixed. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 9.53 points, to 9,096.21. D8.
 
Higher Earnings at Two Big Banks
Nationsbank's quarterly earnings rose 53 percent on stronger loan growth and improved investment banking and brokerage revenue. First Chicago NBD earnings rose 8 percent on higher income from bank fees that offset declines in loan income. The results at both banks exceeded expectations. D2.
 
Tenneco Was Near Deal for ITT Unit
Tenneco halted talks to buy the European brakes division of ITT Industries, but two other bidders, the German tire maker Continental A.G. and Ford Motor's Visteon Automotive Systems, are said to be interested in the concern. D6.

Earnings Rise 39% at Paine Webber
Paine Webber Group said second-quarter earnings jumped 39 percent, to $129.5 million, or 82 cents a diluted share, from $93 million, or 58 cents, beating Wall Street forecasts of 78 cents. Sales rose to $1.2 billion from $976 million. The record earnings and revenues were attributed to strong asset management and investment banking fees. D6.
 
Milan Jury Convicts Media Tycoon
Silvio Berlusconi, the flamboyant media tycoon and former Prime Minister of Italy, was convicted by a Milan jury of making illegal political donations and was given a sentence of two years and four months as well as a $5.6 million fine. Mr. Berlusconi, 61, was convicted last week of bribing tax inspectors and sentenced to a term of two years and nine months. He was also convicted of accounting fraud in a trial in December. A4.

CORRECTION-DATE: July 15, 1998, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
A headline in Business Day yesterday about the Intel Corporation's response to an antitrust lawsuit by the Federal Trade Commission misstated the company's position. As the article noted, Intel contends that it was within its rights; it does not deny having withheld technology from three computer companies.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Wondering How the World Will End? Some Mordant Thoughts from Physics

BYLINE: By MALCOLM W. BROWNE 

 BODY:
IN contrast with the malevolent scientists of horror movies, most physicists are well-adjusted, friendly, attractive people whose conspicuous brain power is generally mixed with the milk of human kindness.
It might therefore seem a little uncharacteristic that some physicists are eagerly hoping to see some tiny blue flashes streak through a cathedral-size water tank buried under a mountain: a signal that an inexorable process of annihilation is gnawing away at the universe. The universal rot, if it is real, will take untold eons to complete, but it will be thorough, leaving no stars, no people, no monuments, no cinders, no sonnets, no atoms, no memories. 
 Except for a faint and ever fading glow, the corpse of our universe would cease to exist.
And yet, a harbinger of this dismal future would be welcomed by many theorists.
For much of the 20th century, physicists have tried to construct a theory that would mathematically bring three of the four known forces of nature -- the electromagnetic force and the weak and strong nuclear forces -- into consonance. (A theoretical assimilation of the fourth force, gravity, poses many more formidable problems for theorists.)
There are various candidates for the title Grand Unified Theory, but none has been validated by experiment or observation, and all of them seem to embody a disquieting requirement: the eventual death of every proton in the universe.
So far, in nearly two decades of searching, no experiment has produced convincing evidence of the decay of even one proton, much less an appreciable fraction of the 10 to the 79th power protons the universe is estimated to contain. (That number is mathematical notation for the numeral one followed by 79 zeros.)
This hasn't stopped scientists from continuing the search; in fact, there are hopes that the mighty Super-Kamiokande detector under a mountain near Kamioka, Japan, which contains 50,000 tons of water, will soon see the telltale flash signaling the death of a proton. This minuscule event, the theorists predict, would yield some decay products. In one possible decay route, the products would be an antielectron and a pi meson, which would almost instantly decay into two gamma-ray photons. In another proton decay mode, the debris would include a K meson with a specific energy associated with proton decay, and a virtually undetectable neutrino.
The demise of a proton (or better, of several protons) would make it easier for theorists to build a Grand Unified Theory that would actually work. Frustrated scientists therefore feel a certain urgency in the quest for deceased protons. During a physics conference in Japan last month, Dr. Frank Wilczek of the Institute of Advanced Studies in Princeton, N.J., told an audience that "if we don't see proton decay pretty soon, we'll be in serious trouble."
Of course, if scientists do detect a proton decay, the whole universe, not just theorists, will be in serious trouble. The death of just one proton would herald the eventual end of everything; if one proton can decay, all protons will decay, and without protons there can be no atoms, molecules, DNA, mountains, roses or concertos.
Fortunately, even if a protonic funeral should occur in the coming months, the demise of the universe would not be imminent. In exquisitely sensitive experiments in Japan and elsewhere, physicists have determined that if protons decay at all, it must take them more than 2.5 times 10 to the 32d power years to die, on average. That's about 10 quintillion times the present age of the universe, which is believed to be about 14 billion years. (Although the average lifespan of a proton must be phenomenally long, a handful of them could be expected to have short lifetimes, some ending now rather than in the remote future. This is why the current search for proton decay is practical.)
Of course, inhabitants of the surface of our terrestrial ball of iron and stone have many more immediate worries than proton decay, astrophysicists tell us. The devastating impact of a large comet or asteroid, for example, has furnished profitable grist for movie makers, and there are lots of other celestial catastrophes the entertainment industry has yet to mine.
The nearby explosion of a supernova is one. There is no telling when or where a supernova will explode, but a few known candidates are uncomfortably close. The red supergiant star Betelgeuse, a mere 430 light years from the Earth, might be about ready to pop. Betelgeuse, a bright star at the shoulder of the constellation Orion, is close enough to us that its explosion could conceivably shower the Earth with potentially harmful radiation and disrupt the protective ozone layer.
Another nasty possibility came to light during the past year -- roasting by a nearby gamma-ray burster.
Since the advent of orbiting gamma ray telescopes in recent years, astrophysicists have been puzzled by gamma ray bursters -- spots in the sky that emit intense gamma-ray radiation for a few seconds or hours and then fade away without a trace, never to recur.
But observations by a new gamma-ray satellite named BeppoSAX, built by Italy and the Netherlands, are so fast and so accurate that they can be used by optical, infrared and X-ray observatories to hunt for faint objects created by or left over from the fleeting gamma-ray bursts.
Such objects have been found, and their distances from the Earth measured. This led to a sensational surprise last year: some gamma ray bursters appear to be vastly farther away than had been believed. To produce gamma rays of the intensity recorded from the vicinity of the Earth, these mysterious objects must be almost inconceivably powerful. One of them seems to have produced more energy in a few seconds than an entire galaxy generates during a year.
Theorists surmise that such "hypernovas" may result from the violent merger of pairs of black holes or black holes with neutron stars. But no one knows how these great bombs are distributed throughout the universe; if one happened to go off relatively near the Earth, there could be dire consequences.
Among the outlandish doomsday scenarios dreamed up by some scientists is the possibility that the energy density of "empty" space in our part of the universe represents a "false vacuum"-- an emptiness pervaded by a certain amount of hidden energy. The menace is that there might be another vacuum with a lower energy level into which our part of the universe might tumble, losing all its protons and thereby obliterating our neck of the universal woods, ourselves included.
It has been suggested by some non-physicists, led by Paul Dixon, a psychologist at the University of Hawaii, that the powerful Tevatron particle accelerator at Fermilab in Illinois (which collides particles together at a combined energy of two trillion electronvolts) might pack so much punch it could start a tear in our friendly space-time along with its false vacuum. Such a catastrophe, it is surmised, would propagate at the speed of light, plunging Batavia, Ill., the site of Fermilab, and the rest of the universe into non-existence.
Physicists scoff at this notion, saying that the Earth is continuously peppered by cosmic rays that have energies up to 10 to the 19th power electronvolts -- about 10 million times more energy than the most potent accelerator collisions -- and yet our universe survives.
Nevertheless, Fermilab is pestered often enough by doom-saying demonstrators that the editors of the laboratory's news letter devoted two pages last month to debunking the torn space-time threat.
This seems to be the season for contemplating decay and doom, not only in movies but in such serious publications as Sky & Telescope magazine. The August issue features an article entitled "Future of the Universe," which paints a somber process of universal aging and decay, with the last stars winking out about 100 trillion years from now, and even the most massive black holes evaporating in around 10 to the hundredth power years.
But although the long-term prognosis for our "region" of the universe is grim, physics offers some possibilities that could save us from the awful all-becoming nothing, to borrow a phrase from Asian philosophy.
Dr. Alan Guth of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, whose revolutionary conjectures have strongly influenced cosmological thinking during the last two decades, envisions an eternal process, in which our stable region of the universe must run down to cold, dark death, but other unstable regions of the universe might undergo the same instantaneous process of "inflation" that our own region supposedly once underwent long ago. Inflation, in the cosmological sense, means not only instantaneous expansion of space-time, but the spontaneous creation of energy to fill the new space-time, providing the raw stuff of a new universe.
A new generation of observatories and experiments now on the drawing board may provide some answers to human's most deep-seated questions about the texture and fate of universal existence. In any case, the quest will continue.
The authors of the Sky & Telescope article, Dr. Fred Adams of the University of Michigan and Dr. Gregory Laughlin of the University of California at Berkeley, put it this way:
"Whether life can exist indefinitely, or whether the universe is structured to guarantee the final annihilation of all consciousness, purpose and meaning -- including any record that such things ever existed -- holds an inordinate fascination."

CORRECTION-DATE: July 16, 1998, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Science Times on Tuesday about theories on the end of the universe misstated the name of the institute in Princeton, N.J., with which Dr. Frank Wilczek, a physicist, is affiliated. It is the Institute for Advanced Study, not the Institute of Advanced Studies.

SECTION: Section A; Page 10; Column 5; National Desk

HEADLINE: Taking His Own Path, He Follows His Father

BYLINE: By PAM BELLUCK 

DATELINE: INDIANAPOLIS, July 8

 BODY:
When Birch Evans Bayh Jr., the notable Democratic United States Senator of the 1960's and 70's, first learned that his son wanted to run for public office, the elder Bayh was wary.
"I guess my first thought was, was that something he really wanted to do or is that something he wanted to do just because his father wanted to do it?," Mr. Bayh recalled recently. 
 And during the son's first campaign -- for Indiana Secretary of State in 1986 -- the father said he wanted his son to make his own way. "If he said, 'Dad can you call so-and-so?' I would say, 'Yes, I can call so-and-so, but are you sure that's what you want to have happen?' "
The son, Birch Evans Bayh 3d, who prefers to be called Evan Bayh, won that race and went on to be Governor of Indiana. And now, Mr. Bayh, 42, is running for the Senate seat that his father lost in 1980.
He is favored to win back his father's seat for the Democrats. But Evan Bayh is not a carbon copy.
While his father, now 70, spent 18 years in office as a prominent Great Society liberal, Evan Bayh is a fiscal conservative who takes credit for balancing his state's budget, implementing welfare reform and cutting taxes. While his father wrote constitutional amendments, including the one lowering the voting age to 18, and helped block two of President Richard M. Nixon's Supreme Court nominees, Evan Bayh has practiced what he describes as a politics of "pragmatic," incremental change, an approach that supporters praise as savvy and critics consider overly cautious.
"Sometimes making progress a step at a time is better than no progress at all," Mr. Bayh said in an interview at the Democratic Party's campaign headquarters across from the state Capitol. "If by demanding revolutionary change, I run the risk of accomplishing nothing on behalf of the public, then I'm not sure that's a responsible course of action."
Mr. Bayh is enormously popular in Indiana, with his famous name, his earnest manner, his good looks and his risk-averse governing style in a state dominated by Republicans.
He has also been mentioned as a prospect for higher office. Held up as the embodiment of President Clinton's "New Democrat" policies, Mr. Bayh gave the keynote speech at the 1996 Democratic National Convention. While he was edged out of prime-time airplay by other speakers, and pundits said his performance lacked excitement, Mr. Bayh came across as a good sport, appearing on stage with his wife, Susan, a lawyer, and their twins, Nicholas and Beau, then 9 months old.
"He's the kind of boy the people in Indiana would like their daughters to bring home," said Brian S. Vargus, a political science professor at Indiana University-Purdue University at Indianapolis. "Mr. Clean, crisp, Boy Wonder, young, attractive, articulate, nice."
Mr. Bayh gets chided by more liberal Democrats, who, Professor Vargus said, privately "refer to him as a Republicrat."
While Republican leaders consider the race for this seat, vacated by Senator Dan Coats, to be their toughest senatorial election this year, they are running a well-credentialed candidate, Paul Helmke, 49, the three-term Mayor of Fort Wayne, Indiana's second-largest city.
"Evan still comes across a little the empty suit," said Mr. Helmke, a moderate Republican who won a three-way primary and has achieved some national prominence of his own, as a former president of the U.S. Conference of Mayors. "He looks good. He sounds good. But there's a sense that he's trying to be all things to all people."
Born on Dec. 26, 1955, in Terre Haute, Ind., Evan Bayh was swaddled in politics. His mother, Marvella Bayh, was the daughter of an Indiana Governor, Matthew E. Welsh. His father ran twice for the Democratic nomination for President, dropping out in 1972 because his wife was stricken with cancer, which took her life in 1979.
When Evan Bayh was 6, he accompanied his parents to the home of former President Harry S. Truman, where his father was seeking advice about his first Senate race. He remembers that Truman gave him a silver dollar and that sometime in the political discussion he blurted out, "I have to go to the bathroom." Truman rescued him from his mother's mortified looks by saying, "You know, son, I have to go the bathroom, too," and taking him there.
At a White House dinner with his mother and father, Evan saw President Lyndon B. Johnson put his feet up on the table and was escorted by Lady Bird Johnson into the Lincoln Bedroom to watch television.
"Evan grew up in a very public home," said his father, now practicing law in Washington. Mr. Bayh said Evan was aware that his father was controversial because of the judicial appointments and other liberal stances, and once heard a phone caller threaten to kill the Senator.
Evan Bayh helped run his father's unsuccessful last Senate campaign, against Dan Quayle in 1980, and the loss "probably hurt him more than it hurt me," the elder Mr. Bayh said.
Eight years later, at age 32, the son was elected the nation's youngest governor and served the maximum two terms. Mr. Bayh, who contended with Republican-dominated Legislatures during his tenure but benefited from a robust economy, said his accomplishments included creation of 350,000 jobs and doubling the state surplus, to $1.6 billion, the largest in state history. He trimmed a deficit in state pension plans and sliced Medicaid spending to restore the state's fiscal health.
There were no tax increases. He did try to raise taxes on hospitals and cigarettes, but was blocked by Republican legislators.
Political experts say Mr. Bayh, who has been practicing corporate law since 1996, made few major advances on issues like education.
"Most of his governorship time was devoted to dollars-and-cents kinds of issues," said Jay McCann, associate professor of political science at Purdue University.
Although a polished spinner of phrases, Mr. Bayh said he resisted "generalizations" and "buzzwords," believing that most issues were complex.
He gets ideas from reading history and biographies that he orders from a history book club. He just started Theodore H. White's "Thunder Out of China," because he is "trying to learn more about foreign policy and defense policy."
Mr. Bayh said that as Senator he would work to raise educational standards and support "a flatter, fairer tax." While government should help the disadvantaged, he said, "personal responsibility has to go hand in hand."
"I'm trying to find the sensible center," he said.

An article on Tuesday about Gov. Evan Bayh of Indiana and his candidacy for the Senate misidentified Mr. Bayh's maternal grandfather. He was Delbert Hern, not Matthew E. Welsh, a former Indiana Governor.

SECTION: Section F; Page 3; Column 2; Dining In, Dining Out/Style Desk 

LENGTH: 1280 words

HEADLINE: EATING WELL;
Saving Rare Breeds, the Tasty Sort

BYLINE: By Marian Burros 

 BODY:
KA-BOSS, ka-BOSS, ka-BOSS."
On a sunny morning last week, Annie Farrell was using her all-purpose animal call to round up her Large Black pigs. The three sows and a boar came readily, thinking there might be food; the six piglets were having too much fun foraging. 
 When they finally trotted over from a nearby field, Ms. Farrell couldn't help gushing over the Large Blacks, one of the highly endangered domesticated breeds she is trying to save on a farm less than an hour from New York. "They are wonderful pigs, good natured, great mothers, very protective," she said, then stopped herself before adding, "I don't want to get mushy about them because they are the best eating."
Good eating. That's Ms. Farrell's mantra.
If there is one thing she has learned in her efforts to save historic breeds of farm animals from extinction, it is the need to get people excited about eating the food these animals produce. It's all well and good to talk about preserving parts of the gene pool, but the only thing that will make the idea economically viable is meat tasty enough that people will want to buy it.
Just think of a Noah's Ark for epicures.
The pig-calling might have been a scene out of "Babe," but Ms. Farrell and her patrons, Nancy and Jerome Kohlberg, are deadly serious about their purpose at Cabbage Hill Farm, 200 bucolic acres in the backwoods of Westchester County.
The broods at the farm include 29 Large Black pigs, a rare Gloucestershire Old Spots sow, 32 Scottish Highland cattle, 72 Shetland sheep, 16 Shetland geese, 40 Shetland ducks and very rare Bronze turkeys.
These are the breeds that factory farming forgot, once popular but now disappearing in favor of fast-growing animals that yield the highest profits.
The Scottish cattle are accustomed to being outside in cold weather, and they have adapted to it by growing a heavy hairy coat rather than an extra layer of fat.
"We've had the meat tested at two different labs -- the first report was so surprising we couldn't believe it," Ms. Farrell said. "The meat has the same cholesterol count as white-meat chicken."
The Scottish Highland cattle are not actually listed as endangered by Britain's Rare Breeds Survival Trust, the pioneer conservation organization, now a quarter-century old. But they are classified as a "minor" breed, meaning they are definitely outside mainstream agribusiness. "We are watching them to make sure they don't head toward our priority lists," said Richard Lutwyche, the publicity officer of the group.
Now, Ms. Farrell is looking for butchers who are willing to hang the Scottish Highland beef she and the Kohlbergs are raising (hint: the farm's number is 914-241-2658). Fed exclusively on grass, the beef is filled with the flavor anyone over 40 may remember. Without grain, the beef is much leaner -- but it is also less tender until it is hung.
"People don't know how good rare breed meat is because they are used to fatty meat," she said. The Large Black pigs are far rarer: "There are only 300 Large Black breeding sows on the planet," Ms. Farrell explained as she continued rounding them up to meet a visiting veterinarian. The three sows and the boar were imported from Southwest England. Today they are doing well enough at the farm that some of the offspring will be sold for meat.
Ms. Farrell looked perturbed for a moment: There was still one pig missing, a sow that answers to the name of Abigail (when it deigns to answer at all). She is a Gloucestershire Old Spots, also "extremely flavorful," Ms. Farrell added. Like the Large Blacks, which forage and are happy to root around for themselves, these pigs are more flavorful than pigs from factory farms that are fattened on corn.
Abigail may be a good breeding sow, but her hearing is none too sharp: she either had not heard the calls or chose to ignore them. Then Ms. Farrell noticed a barely visible snout wiggling inside the enclosure where the pigs go to farrow.
"Come on, sweetie -- come on Abby sweetie," she said, coaxing her out. Abigail, who preferred snoozing, came out quite grumpily and was even grumpier when she and the other pigs were vaccinated.
Mr. Lutwyche, in England, points to the Gloucestershire Old Spots with cautious optimism. "It was the most popular breed in England in the 1920's," he said. "There were four or five thousand, but in the 1960's it had got down to 200 or so, almost all in one herd. Now we're back up to five or six hundred." But it is still on the trust's "endangered" list, its second most critical rating.
What's so special about the Gloucestershire Old Spots? The fact that they happily live outdoors makes them ideal "free-range" pigs. And their foraging skills are another thing in their favor, saving on feed costs. Their high fat content gives them added succulence and flavor.
"All biological systems need to have genetic diversity to make way for environmental change," said Dr. Donald E. Bixby, the executive director of the American Livestock Breeds Conservancy in Pittsboro, N.C. In other words, you can't respond to shifting tastes and conditions if the gene pool is gone.
Playing Noah is only one of Ms. Farrell's goals at Cabbage Hill Farm. She also produces salad greens, herbs and broccoli sprouts, and farm-raised fish.
Amid the snorts of indignation from just-vaccinated pigs, the tour moved on to Ms. Farrell's aquaponics department, housed in a greenhouse. It is a closed recirculating system: the water from the fish tanks circulates through gravel beds, from which the plants pick up nutrition. The water feeds the greens and is then cleaned and returned to the fish tank. There are plenty of delicate, sweet talapia for sale. (More good eating.)
While the system at the farm is still too small to make a profit, it is used as a model to teach people how aquaponics works. The entire farm, in fact, is a teaching laboratory. Visitors have come from as far away as Israel and Kenya.
Ms. Farrell, who sold baskets of mesclun at the Union Square Greenmarket before most people knew what mesclun was, has been involved in sustainable agriculture for all of her adult life, though she has no formal training. She was known around New York as the Veg Lady in the early 80's, when she grew speciality crops, like white strawberries, for some of the city's best chefs.
Building a showcase for rare breeds and sustainable agriculture costs money, and Ms. Farrell is fortunate to have patrons like the Kohlbergs, who share her passions and have the means to further them through their Cabbage Hill Farm Foundation. (Mr. Kohlberg was a founding partner of the investment firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company.)
She and the Kohlbergs met about five years ago through friends and discovered their common interest.
"Mr. Kohlberg said to me, 'What would you do if you could do anything you wanted?' " Ms. Farrell recalled. Four months later she was at Cabbage Hill Farm.
Everyone at the farm does chores, even the cattle. They gladly do the initial "mowing" of the fields and are moved from one to another as their task is completed. They are followed by the Shetland sheep, who graze more intensively.
Two imperious looking llamas, Felix and Eleanor, zealously guard the sheep from coyotes, seen in the neighborhood. Coyotes tangle with llamas at their own risk. "The llamas either crush them to death or they kick them," Ms. Farrell explained. So much for the llamas' gentle looks.
Just then there was a cry of "Help, help!" Or something like it. "That's either a peacock or a woman being attacked," Ms. Farrell said. "Peacocks are great watchdogs." In some places, peacocks are also considered good eating.

GRAPHIC: Photos: OUTDOORS TYPES -- A rare Gloucestershire Old Spots sow, a free-range pig, above, at Cabbage Hill Farm in Westchester County. At right, llamas protect the Shetland sheep. Scottish Highland cattle, below right, eat only grass, not grain. (Photographs by Susan Farley for The New York Times)

LENGTH: 1113 words

HEADLINE: Wine Talk;
Pioneers of the North Fork, Farewell

BYLINE: By Frank J. Prial 

DATELINE: CUTCHOGUE, N.Y., July 11

 BODY:
"Twenty-five years is a long time for a career in any sport," Alex Hargrave said. "And winemaking is an Olympic sport."
This was Mr. Hargrave's deceptively casual way of explaining why he and his wife, Louisa, are ending their remarkable career as Long Island's pioneer winemakers. In 1973, the couple -- he was 28, she 25 -- set out their first vines in a former potato field on the North Fork. They were bravely -- and in the opinion of just about everyone else, foolishly -- determined to produce wines to rival the best that California and Europe could offer. 
 "It's good that we were so young," Mrs. Hargrave said, curled up on a sofa in the family home here. "When you're young, you don't want to take advice."
Youthful enthusiasm paid off, as it often does. Starting from scratch, the Hargraves created an industry that was ecologically and culturally in tune with the times.
And by demonstrating that vineyards and winemaking were economically viable, they showed that it was possible for Eastern Long Island to remain at least partly rural and agricultural.
The Hargraves, who were wine drinkers when most Americans did not know much about the stuff, particularly loved the grape varieties found in the great wines of Bordeaux and Burgundy: cabernet sauvignon, merlot, chardonnay, pinot noir.
"We resolved to go ahead only if we could make those kinds of wine," Mrs. Hargrave said.
They did, in the face of the conventional wisdom, much of it from state agricultural officials, who warned: don't even think about growing European grapes on Long Island.
But the Hargraves had visited other potential sites for their business that were as close as the Finger Lakes and as distant as British Columbia. Nothing they saw offered the climate and the soil of the North Fork.
They bought their first plot of land and in 1973 planted their first grapes and installed their press and fermenters in an old potato cellar. They produced their first wine, a cabernet sauvignon, in 1974.
Within just a few years, those who had doubted them were giving them respect instead, and many would-be winemakers followed in their footsteps.
Today, there are 21 wineries on Long Island, most of them within 10 miles of Hargrave Vineyards on Route 48. The wineries draw on some 1,500 acres of wine grapes, none of which existed 25 years ago.
A half-dozen more wineries are planned, and each week more and more people, both farmers and wine hobbyists, inquire about getting into the business, which now produces about 200,000 cases a year in the region.
That figure should double in the next few years, Mr. Hargrave said. "Every bottle we make these days is spoken for," he said. "Every good bottle has a home." Hargrave Vineyard produces 6,000 to 7,000 cases a year, he said.
Equally important, he continued, "the North Fork has become a wine destination." He added, "All year long, people flock to the wineries to taste, to learn and to buy."
The Hargraves have had dozens of inquiries about their 84-acre property, which includes the winery, the aging cellar, some 20 acres of vines, their home, a pool, tennis court and farm buildings. They are asking about $3 million and said they may close a deal sometime in the fall.
So why are they selling? The end to their wine story has its roots in its beginning. After graduating from Princeton University in 1968, Mr. Hargrave, whose grandfather was chairman of the Eastman Kodak Company in Rochester, did graduate work at Harvard University in Asian studies. By 1969 he had married Louisa, a graduate of Smith College, whose grandfather was Norman Thomas, the Socialist leader.
While Mr. Hargrave was recuperating from back surgery, the couple decided to leave academia and take on something they could do together. They chose wine.
In searching for a site, they visited John Wickham, a North Fork farmer who had grown vinifera table grapes successfully for more than a decade. Seeing his red Malagas convinced the Hargraves that they could grow vinifera wine grapes.
"Long Island has always had the potential to be an important wine region," Mr. Hargrave said, pointing out that wine grapes were grown in what is now Queens in the 1830's. But most of the farmers who were drawn to the region were teetotalers, he said. So potatoes, not grapes, became the agricultural stars. Until the Hargraves showed up, that is.
But starting about seven years ago, Mr. Hargrave was drawn back to Asian studies; particularly Chinese culture and specifically the origins of Chinese languages.
"It's called paleolinguistics," he said. Working at night and during winter breaks from the vineyards, he has been reconstructing what he calls a hypothetical language from which Chinese and other languages must have come.
"I find time to do the research, but not the writing," he said.
"We thought that eventually we'd have time to do other things," he added. "But a winery is like a sailboat -- someone's always got to be at the helm."
The Hargraves do not anticipate a complete break with the North Fork and wine; they may serve as consultants. But they do foresee a change in their life style, which may include his return to academia.
"An apartment in Boston and a cottage here on Peconic Bay sound pretty good to me," Mr. Hargrave said.
More immediately, the Hargraves, who have a son, 21, and a daughter, 23, must get the 1998 harvest in, bottle the 1997 vintage and prepare themselves for a new way of living.
"I guess it has something to do with choices, with making sense of a life," Mr. Hargrave said. "Do I want people saying, 'He's a vintner and his field is historical linguistics'?"
They hired a manager, to try and get more free time. "But we were still involved because it was the hands-on part that we loved -- the esthetics of making wine," he said. "It's so beautiful. That will be the hard part to give up."
 
Tastings
Orvieto's Pride
Salviano Orvieto Classico 1996, Umbria, Italy. About $12.
 
ITALY leads the world in the production of top quality wines at moderate prices, as this exceptional Orvieto readily attests. Orvieto, an hour's drive north of Rome, is a delightful small city, which gives its name to one of Italy's best-known white wines.
The prescribed formula for Orvieto permits a wide choice of grapes in the blend, but the base wine is invariably the dull trebbiano. The Tenuta di Salviano estate rescues this wine, of which about 40 percent is trebbiano, by adding verdello, grechetto, chardonnay, sauvignon blanc, malvasia and drupeggio -- a new one to me. The result is a golden, fragrant, surprisingly complex wine to go with Italian cheese and seafood.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Visiting South Africa, Rubin Sides With the Free-Marketers

BYLINE: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr. 

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG, July 14

 BODY:
Stepping into a sharp South African debate without acknowledging it, Secretary of the Treasury Robert E. Rubin repeatedly endorsed South African economic policies today even as these policies faced attack by the Government's closest allies.
Mr. Rubin, who is on a five-nation Africa trip, said in Soweto that the country's economic policies were "strong and stable" and that the Government's controversial Growth, Employment and Redistribution Policy "sets forth a medium-term plan to keep them that way." 
 Besides South Africa, the American Treasury Secretary is visiting the Ivory Coast, Namibia, Mozambique and Kenya to encourage policies that Washington and international lending agencies endorse: austere budgets, open markets, vigorous business competition and the sale of state-owned companies.
He also called here for expanding loans to small businesses, more education for the poor and greater flexibility from labor unions.
He deflected questions about the value of the South African currency, the rand, which has fallen sharply, other than to repeat that good economic and fiscal policies made for resilient currencies. The rand rose 2.6 percent today to a rate of 5.985 to the dollar. But it remains 19 percent below its value at the end of 1997, when it took 4.86 rand to buy a dollar.
Although Mr. Rubin did not mention the political criticism faced by the ruling African National Congress, he made it clear that the United States supported the Government's economic policies.
In an evening session with reporters, Mr. Rubin said he had "no ulterior motive" in praising these policies and was not conveying an American position on next year's South African national elections.
The A.N.C.'s two closest political allies, the South African Communist Party and the Congress of South African Trade Unions, an umbrella organization of mostly black labor unions, strongly oppose Government economic policies, which favor cutting public payrolls, keeping Government debt low, accepting high interest rates to control inflation and selling the airlines, railroads, ports, phone and electric utilities, diamond mines and dozens of other companies owned by the state.
The Government's opponents also oppose its request for "labor flexibility," considered a euphemism for union agreement to end wildcat strikes and accept changes such as around-the-clock mining operations.
Such policies represent a sharp reversal for the A.N.C. -- which, until it came to power in 1994, took a socialist approach that favored nationalization of the gold mines and full employment through state projects. The unions and the Communists, who hold many seats in Parliament in return for years of loyal support of the A.N.C., have criticized these current policies because the economy grew less than 2 percent last year, with a net loss by some estimates of 130,000 jobs.
But last month, President Nelson Mandela and his heir apparent, Deputy President Thabo Mbeki, warned the unions and the Communists that these policies would be A.N.C. positions for the 1999 election campaign.
Today, Mr. Rubin pressed here for stimulating the economy through "micro-enterprise lending" -- loans of as little as $50 given to the poor to start businesses. To push the point, he visited a Soweto day care center run by Francina Mbense, who has stocked it with books, toys and furniture bought with a 15,000 rand loan -- about $2,500 -- which she received under a program financed by the United States Agency for International Development. Although she pays 23.25 percent interest, Mrs. Mbense said she was grateful because South African banks would not make loans of less than 50,000 rand and Soweto loan sharks charged as much as 50 percent a month.
At an hourlong discussion afterward with South African bankers and small-business executives, Mr. Rubin heard bankers explain why they did not make loans in impoverished areas. The cost of administering the loans was too great, they said; they cannot offer the business advice small borrowers need, and they are criticized when they build cut-rate branch offices because they build fancy ones in white suburbs.
Mr. Rubin suggested that they look at American business models such as pooling their money to be lent, and he noted that American bankers had been pushed through legislation into making small loans to customers in rundown areas.

HEADLINE: Business Travel;
For the summer, Northwest is offering weekly nonstop flight between Anchorage and Tokyo.

BYLINE: By Edwin McDowell 

 BODY:
ALMOST a decade after Alaska lost its nonstop passenger service to Japan, Northwest Airlines is currently making weekly nonstop flights between Anchorage and Tokyo.
In 1996, Gov. Tony Knowles of Alaska proposed $1 million in incentives to any airline that provided direct service to Tokyo. However, Northwest does not qualify for the incentive because it plans to suspend service Sept. 24, at least until next summer. But its 15 summer round-trip flights are expected to bring in more than 4,200 Japanese business and leisure travelers, and Governor Knowles said the flights would add more than $12 million to the Alaskan economy. 
 "Prior to 1989, most international traffic stopped here to refuel," said Morton V. Plumb, Jr., director of Anchorage International Airport. But Anchorage was no longer needed after the fall of Communism opened the shorter polar routes to international air traffic, and more fuel-efficient jet planes made refueling unnecessary.
While Anchorage does a big business in cargo flights, ranking 12th in the nation, its international traffic dwindled to 396,000 passengers in 1994, the fewest number in years, from 1.5 million in 1989. This year, including the expected 4,200 Northwest passengers and those who connect from Hawaii and cities in the continental United States, the foreign passenger tally in Anchorage will rise to about 720,000, Mr. Plumb said, while domestic passengers will total 4.3 million.
Meanwhile, gross sales at Anchorage's duty-free shops have struggled back to about $16 million, double that of four years ago but still only a fraction of the $118 million in gross sales in 1989. The main reason for the drop in revenue is obviously the result of the big drop in international passengers. But Mr. Plumb observed that many of the current Chinese and South Korean visitors are less free spending than were the Japanese passengers of a decade ago, and today's Japanese visitors are themselves less free spending, no doubt because of their nation's economic woes.
 
Millennium Cruises
The jointly owned Royal Caribbean International and Celebrity Cruises have announced millennium plans for their 17 ships. Royal Caribbean's Legend of the Seas, for example, will be among the first and last cruise ships to celebrate the event by positioning itself west of the international date line on Dec. 31, 1999, and east of the dateline Jan. 1, 2000. Its Vision of the Seas will be the first to enter the Panama Canal from the Caribbean in 2000, followed by Celebrity's Zenith.
 
A Gift in Time
By commissioning a line of gifts from some of Japan's leading artists and craftsmen, the Park Hyatt Tokyo Hotel has made it easy for its guests in that gift-giving country to pick up a little something for customers, business associates, family or friends -- remembrances ranging from paper coasters with artistic designs to tea sets and sake bottles.
Items, most of them hand crafted, can be ordered from hotel rooms and are wrapped by the hotel staff in traditional Japanese paper and cord.
 
Matter of Commissions
Rumors abound in the travel agent community that at least three airlines plan to lower commission caps further or eliminate commissions altogether. While the carriers have neither confirmed nor denied the rumors, John Hawks, president of the Association of Retail Travel Agents, appears guardedly optimistic that they are just that -- rumors. "It seems unlikely that the major carriers would take action now," he said, "given the very unfriendly atmosphere in Congress on issues like airline alliances."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Dow Surges 1.6% to Join Other Stock Gauges at Record Levels

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
The stock market rallied sharply yesterday as several companies reported good or better-than-expected earnings for the second quarter, easing concerns about the drag from Asia's economic turmoil.
The surge was enough to push the Dow Jones industrial average up 1.6 percent to a new high -- making it the last of the big three indexes to climb back into record territory. 
 Whether the rally will hold will depend a lot on how the the rest of the second-quarter earnings season plays out. Only a small proportion of the 500 companies in the Standard & Poor's index have reported so far and analysts are still predicting a lackluster quarter.
After the market closed yesterday, the Intel Corporation reported that its second-quarter earnings dropped 29 percent, to 66 cents a diluted share, 2 cents below recent estimates. In after-hours trading, Intel's stock dropped to $80.125 after falling $1.6875, to $80.6875, in regular trading.
But it appeared yesterday that the rush of money into the stock market from Americans and foreigners is so strong that it may be enough to overcome less than fabulous earnings growth.
"Foreigners are buying U.S. securities aggressively, stock buybacks are big and mutual fund flows are strong," said Byron R. Wien, United States investment strategist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. "The market is being driven by liquidity."
Mr. Wien marveled at the economy's ability to grow without a resurgence in inflation and the refusal of investors to worry about how far this market can go. "It is sort of like having drink after drink and not getting drunk and waking up the next morning without a hangover and thinking that you can party all the time," he said.
Also buoying investors is the fact that usually -- despite the Intel disappointment -- there are a lot of positive earnings surprises during the reporting season because companies work so hard to manage expectations. Companies jawbone down earnings forecasts until the beginning of the reporting season, making it much easier for the actual reports to surpass those already-lowered expectations.
This is what happened with the positive earnings reports yesterday from Weyerhaeuser, the manufacturer of wood and paper products. The company announced earnings of 34 cents a diluted share, beating the recent consensus estimate of analysts tallied by First Call Corporation of 22 cents a share. But on June 16 the company said that its earnings would be significantly below the then estimate of 38 cents a share.
Johnson & Johnson, the health care company, and Norwest and J. P. Morgan, two major banks, also reported earnings at or above expectations yesterday. General Motors reported a sharp strike-induced drop in earnings that was smaller than expected. And Allied Signal, the aerospace company, reported positive results after the market's close on Monday.
The Dow surged 149.33 points, to 9,245.54, beating its previous high of 9,211.84 on May 13. The Dow's rally back to new highs took just under two months, three times as fast as the return to new highs this February after 1997's August peak and the sharp one-day decline on Oct. 27 of 7.2 percent.
The Nasdaq index, which surpassed its April 22 high on July 8, rose 2.88 points to a record of 1,968.41. The S.& P. 500-stock index, which had surpassed its April 22 high on June 24, climbed 12.39 points, or 1.1 percent, to a record of 1,177.58.
Big Board volume was 700.3 million shares, higher than average. Advancing issues led decliners by 1,773 to 1,190.
The return to record highs, some analysts say, is not surprising because they believe that the underlying fundamentals of the American economy continue to be positive enough to support the stock market, even if earnings growth has slowed well below the double-digit pace that sent stocks higher during the last several years.
These positive fundamentals were reinforced yesterday with the report that the Consumer Price Index for June rose just one-tenth of 1 percent, leaving inflation up just 1.4 percent on an annual rate this year. June retail sales rose one-tenth of 1 percent after a revised 1.2 percent gain in May.
While bond prices fell and interest rates rose yesterday, low inflation and a slowing in economic growth -- signs of which are beginning to pop up -- mean that interest rates could remain low, which also helps the stock market by making equities look more attractive.
"Lower interest rates are more important than the difference between 3 percent and 6 percent earnings growth," said Richard Pucci, the director of research at I.B.E.S. International, a firm that follows earnings estimates. "With inflation and long-term interest rates low and economic activity healthy, I believe that investors are and will remain unfazed by the slowdown in earnings growth."
And with this positive background there just seems to be an urgency among investors to get their money into the stock market.
"The pressure is so great to get the money in," said Marshall Acuff, the equity strategist at Salomon Smith Barney. Earnings still count, he argued, but "current earnings sometimes may not make as much difference as people speculate that they will get better in the future."
Also aiding the market yesterday was the improvement in the outlook for Russia's economy following an agreement on Monday for $17 billion in new international support. But the county's legislature still must approve the domestic economic program that goes along with the bailout.
"Every problem out there that seems to scare us seems to get solved," Mr. Wien said.
