HEADLINE: Records And CD's? How Quaint;
Digital Distribution Of Music Is Spreading

BYLINE: By JON PARELES 

 BODY:
The sound that could transform the music business is the quiet click of a computer mouse.
Right now, anyone with a mid-level computer and an Internet connection can hear music in a multitude of forms, from radiolike Webcasts to snippets of songs. Many of those forms are ephemeral and in low fidelity, intended primarily for promotion. But it is also possible to download, free or for a price, high-fidelity songs and full-length albums that can join a permanent collection. There's no need to visit a store or wait for mail order; in fact, there's no need ever to handle a compact disk. David Bowie, Tori Amos, Duran Duran and other well-known groups have released songs through the Internet. 
 For those who have been sending and receiving music via the Internet, digital distribution is a harbinger of a future when recorded music has been freed entirely from physical form. Sold or disseminated as strings of 1's and 0's rather than disks, music joins the worldwide flow of digital information.
For enthusiasts, digital distribution presents utopian possibilities. Freed of the costs of manufacturing and distributing CD's, digitally distributed music could be cheaper for consumers and more profitable for musicians. Music could be geared to more specialized audiences that may be small but widely scattered; a fan in Helsinki could download tunes from a band in Jakarta.
More radical changes have also been predicted by some industry figures. The possibilities include drastically lower prices for recorded music by all but a commercial elite; other performers might simply give away songs to promote albums or sell concert tickets. Musicians could release music in small or large doses as they see fit, dealing one more blow to the album as pop's standard artistic unit. Stores could see their role reduced as digital distribution allows consumers to skip middlemen. Eventually, home music collections could become obsolete, as recorded music becomes available from central archives on demand.
To travel the Internet, music must be turned into a digital sound file that can be played through a computer. Electronic, or digital, distribution of music is still the province of a small but significant group of computer users. At least five million software "players" in one music format, MP3, have been downloaded, and MP3 is part of the Netshow multimedia package on Windows 98; 3.5 million players in another format, Liquid Audio, have also been installed.
Because high-fidelity music involves large amounts of digital information -- a music CD holds 650 megabytes -- transferring music over the Internet is slow for most computer users; one song can take a half-hour to download on a typical modem. Noting the technical obstacles, Jupiter Media, an on-line market research firm, has predicted that in five years the market for digitally downloaded music will be about $30 million, a minuscule percentage of the $12 billion recorded-music market.
"But we still think it's something that labels should aggressively pursue," said Mark Mooradian, group director of consumer content for Jupiter Media. He said digital distribution could be important for its marketing value, to combat piracy and to reposition labels as retail outlets.
Already, students and others with access to high-speed transmission lines have been sending around enough music to alarm the recording business.
Electronic distribution is a major topic on the agenda at Plug In '98, a conference on music in the digital era, organized by Jupiter Media; Andrew Rasiej, founder of Irving Plaza, and Michael Dorf, owner of the Knitting Factory, that is taking place alongside the Intel New York Music Festival through Saturday.
"You can't keep your head in the sand forever," said Thomas Dolby Robertson, who made new-wave hits in the 1980's and now runs Headspace, a company that adds soundtracks to Web sites.
In 1996, Mr. Bowie offered a single, "Telling Lies," as a file that could be downloaded free; even though it took up to 45 minutes to transfer the five-minute song, 300,000 people downloaded it. But that was a give away from an internationally known star. Getting paid for downloaded music has been more difficult, in part because of the inconvenience of the process and in part because few well-known performers have made it available.
But the advent of faster home Internet connections, including cable modems now being tested that can transfer computer data at rates comparable to the video and sound signals of cable television, music could be downloaded in seconds rather than minutes. And on college campuses, and some in high schools, with fast T-1 lines (special digital telephone connections to the Internet) students are already trading and copying music.
"If you take a look at any dorm at Stanford," said David Weekly, an incoming junior majoring in computer science at Stanford University, "people are listening more to MP3's than to radio."
Independent labels and individual musicians see digital distribution as a way to deliver music directly to listeners. "Record companies have a lock right now on how an artist can get music out to a global audience," said Larry Rosen, the chairman of N2K, which owns the on-line retail site Music Boulevard as well as its own N2K label, which makes some of its songs available for digital downloading. "With electronic distribution of music, there's a break in that kind of power structure."
Digital distribution allows musicians to make their newest work available instantly worldwide. The Jesus and Mary Chain, the English band scheduled to perform last night at Irving Plaza as part of the Intel New York Music Festival, planned to record their set and place a live song on the festival's Internet site (www.intelfest.com) 15 minutes after leaving the stage. The song was also to be available today at Tower Records in Manhattan, transferred to a recordable CD and given as a bonus with the Jesus and Mary Chain's current album.
Mr. Rasiej and Mr. Dorf organized the music festival and have set out to create the Digital Club Network, which would place cameras and recorders in clubs around the world. Performances could be cybercast live or maintained as archives, with royalties going to clubs and performers. "The amount of money is insignificant today, but we're building a new content source," Mr. Rasiej said. "You could create a chat room, collect your old friends from college and watch and participate in a concert. You might not be able to slam dance against one another, though."
Twin-Tone Records, the independent label that introduced the Replacements and Husker Du to rock fans in the 1980's, has announced that it will sell all its new releases through the Internet, preferably through downloading, and will stop manufacturing new CD's in bulk; downloading a song will cost $1.50, with albums at $10.
 
A Music Market That's Evolving
 "The retail market isn't what it used to be," said Paul Stark, the president and co-founder of Twin-Tone Records. "The number of releases has gone from 3,000 to 25,000 or 30,000, all competing for the same shelf space."
"If I wholesale a CD for $10, I'll only see about $3 of that after mailing, returns and advertising," Mr. Stark explained. "It costs me about $1 to manufacture the CD and the group gets $2 in royalties, which leaves me about 10 or 15 cents. On the Internet, with no manufacturing or distributing costs, I can cut my sales to a quarter of what they were and still come out ahead. The economic model of the recording industry is changing very quickly, and the Internet is the only future we have."
Marc Geiger, the founder of Artist Direct, a company that offers some downloadable music through the Ultimate Band List Web site, said: "You might be able to lease music for a certain amount of listenings, like a jukebox. You might pay a different amount to own it for an unlimited number of listenings. Or you might have an arrangement like cable television, where you pay $29.95 to an aggregater and listen to most of the music you want for a month."
Stores won't be directly threatened by digital distribution for some time. Still, the prospect of consumers getting music delivered instantly at home, without visiting a store, is not a happy prospect for them.
"Part of me is scared because we don't own any content," said Mike Farrace, vice president for publishing at Tower Records. "We are not intellectual property holders; we are brokers and agents and aggregaters. But I don't see digital distribution taking over. I can see it becoming a component, absolutely no doubt about it. The art for us is, How do we incorporate this into the business?"
When Capitol Records announced that it would sell a Duran Duran single, "Electric Barbarella," over the Internet, retailers protested, worrying that they were being bypassed. The song was made available simultaneously at stores and as a digital download, with one remix available only from the Internet. "We expect to have digital distribution be a piece of the pie, not to cause retail to disappear," said Liz Heller, executive vice president for Capitol Records.
Major labels, which own manufacturing plants, warehouses and trucks and invest heavily to shape the careers of musicians, are wary of digital distribution. As with all new technologies for transferring and copying music, they see the possibility of widespread piracy.
"The upside of digital distribution is the huge market that you have access to, which you can market and promote to in different ways," said Frank Creighton, senior vice president and director of investigations for the Recording Industry Association of America, the trade association that represents the larger recording companies.
When it comes to electronic distribution, he said, the labels are "moving with some trepidation in light of the fact that currently the majority of uses of distributed sound files are unauthorized. Right now, there is no set standard as to how these sound files are going to be distributed, protected and controlled."
There are three main technologies for digital distribution of music: Liquid Audio, AT&T's a2b and MP3. Liquid Audio and a2b are favored by companies that are worried about unauthorized copying. In both the music is encrypted so that it can be played back only by an authorized user and it is watermarked so that its source can be traced; every download is registered, and royalties can be deducted. Liquid Audio allows a buyer to copy the music once onto a recordable CD; a2b does not.
Scott Burnett, the vice president of marketing for Liquid Audio, said that there are about 10,000 songs available on the Internet in the Liquid Audio format, and that the company will soon establish the Liquid Music Network, a widely linked Web site that will hold 100,000 songs from independent labels including Rykodisc, Rounder and Platinum Entertainment, for $1.50 to $2 a song.
N2K, which sells CD's and tapes through mail order on-line as Music Boulevard, offers songs from its N2K label in a format it calls e-mod, using Liquid Audio; Twin-Tone also uses Liquid Audio. In the year that N2K's system has been in operation, fewer than 10,000 people have downloaded the songs for 99 cents each, said Mr. Rosen on N2K. But the available songs have been by little-known musicians. N2K has just signed David Stewart, formerly of the Eurythmics; he plans to release his next album in downloadable form on the Internet before it appears in stores.

Extensive Traffic On the Internet
Meanwhile, MP3, which is short for MPEG Audio Layer 3, can create endless generations of digital copies once a piece of music has been encoded as an MP3 file. Portable MP3 players, separate from home computers, are being manufactured. And MP3 files can be created from any piece of recorded music through encoders, called rippers, that are downloadable from many Web sites. The combination has led to an extensive Internet traffic in MP3 songs.
The recording-industry association considers any unlicensed copying to be piracy. It recently tracked down someone selling the entire recorded works of the Beatles, compressed into MP3 files on a single CD-ROM disk, and it has been working to shut down Internet sites offering large numbers of songs as MP3 files.
A new company, Goodnoise, plans to sell songs as MP3 files for 99 cents each. "Fans don't have access to legitimate content on MP3," said Gene Hoffman, the president and chief executive of Goodnoise. "MP3 is never going to go away, the technology is there and available, and you might as well make it easier to buy it than to steal."
But in most MP3 uses, no money changes hands. In 1996, Mr. Weekly used Stanford's computer to offer about 200 songs as MP3 files. "I put it up, told a few people about it and it just exploded," he said. "We were not pirates, we were certainly not making money from this; we just thought it was a great technology."
The site was on-line for a week and a half before record-company representatives called Stanford and had it shut down. "On the last day," Mr. Weekly said, "Stanford network services told me that 80 percent of outgoing bandwidth was my music. It shows that Internet music wants to happen, in whatever form, and there are people out there who are ready for it."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Telephone privatization tests economic will of Puerto Rico.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
TO most Americans, the idea of a government-owned telephone system is no doubt as alien, say, as driving on the left side of the road. But to Puerto Ricans the proposed privatization of the state-run telephone company is a fighting issue, with a majority apparently preferring Big Brother to big business. "We're children of the New Deal," explained Marcos Rodriguez-Ema, the president of the Government Development Bank for Puerto Rico.
More is at stake here than political symbolism, or even the efficiency of the telephone system. Puerto Rico is under enormous pressure to hew more closely to the capitalist road, in part because it is losing special tax breaks and welfare subsidies from Washington, and, in part because no island can remain an island in the increasingly integrated global economy. 
 "It's not a matter of whether the Puerto Rican economy will change, but how and when," said Jose Berrocal, a director of BT Wolfensohn.
The Puerto Rico Telephone Company uses modern digital switching equipment and, it is widely agreed, provides good service.
 But it isn't particularly efficient. The company operated 204 lines per employee in 1996, compared with more than 300 at Bell Atlantic. The return on capital is far below that of mainland providers. And ominously, it has rapidly lost share in cellular phones, the fastest-growing part of the business.
So when Congress opened local and intra-island telephone service to competition in 1996, Puerto Rico's Government decided to auction it off. "Our primary concern is that the managers of the Government enterprise didn't have the vision for a deregulated market," Mr. Rodriguez-Ema said.
The agreement to sell the system to the GTE Corporation for $1.85 billion (challenged at the 11th hour by another bidder, Spain's Telefonica Internacional) led to a strike by the telephone workers' unions. Last week, the strike made headlines nationwide when 50 other Puerto Rican unions staged a two-day sympathy walkout that shut the airport in San Juan, along with major shopping centers. And polls show that the strikers enjoy considerable support in their opposition to the sale of the "national patrimony."
(According to news reports, one of the two telephone unions will vote today on ending the strike, though both still oppose privatization.)
"This is a protest against a style of government," argued Heidie Calero, an economic consultant in San Juan who favors privatization but objects to the Government's "high handed" manner in decreeing the sale without bothering to explain the necessity.
The Government of Puerto Rico is apparently holding fast to the decision to sell the phone company -- though the unspecified bid from Telefonica does put in doubt who will end up with the prize. And whoever does buy it will likely go partway to relieve the union's anxiety about job security. "The buyers will need labor peace, and they know it," Mr. Rodriguez-Ema acknowledged.
The more formidable challenge, illustrated by the resistance to telephone privatization, is to shake the economy out of its dependence on government. While the island's gross domestic product per capita is one-third that of the mainland, transfers through Medicaid, Medicare, Social Security and a variety of other social programs keep living standards within hailing distance. Indeed, a combination of the social safety net, the application of the national minimum wage and Federal tax breaks for manufacturing keep competitive wages quite high.
Therein lies a rub. High wages make it difficult for Puerto Rico to compete with the rest of the Caribbean in both tourism and labor-intensive products. Unemployment, now at 14 percent, topped 20 percent for much of the 1980's. Yet the tax breaks, which led to the development of a huge pharmaceutical and electronics manufacturing sector -- not to mention the creation of tens of thousands of white-collar jobs -- will be phased out over the next six years.
Mr. Rodriguez-Ema plays down the impact of losing these so-called Section 936 benefits, which the current, statehood-minded administration of Puerto Rico viewed as a crutch. "The pharmaceutical makers are hiring, not firing," he pointed out.
Indeed, it is hard to look at economic trends and come up an unalloyed pessimist. Total employment, below 700,000 as recently as 1985, now hovers around a million. Per capita income is close to $8,000 and has been growing more rapidly than on the mainland for several generations.
But in Mr. Berrocal's view, Puerto Rico is at a crossroads. The welfare state, he acknowledges, has provided good jobs for a minority and an adequate living standard for the majority. But it has also robbed the island of the opportunity to break out economically. And it has created vested interests with a great deal to lose from change.
The world is not standing still, though, and the repeal of Section 936 suggests that Congress isn't either. "We've just got to declare it isn't going to be business as usual," Mr. Berrocal concluded.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
It's Official: '60 Minutes' Gets Double

BYLINE: By BILL CARTER 

DATELINE: PASADENA, Calif., July 15

 BODY:
CBS made it official today: "60 Minutes," the oldest and most successful news program in the history of television, will expand to a second edition early next year.
The new program, to be called "60 Minutes II," will include many elements of the original, including some appearances by its roster of veteran correspondents and the familiar opening of a ticking stopwatch, while introducing a new lineup of reporters. 
 The decision comes after a long, behind-the-scenes debate over whether a new "60 Minutes" would dilute the appeal of the original by spreading its brand too widely. Andrew Heyward, the president of CBS News, said the new program was intended to be "not a clone, but a respectful offspring" of the original.
The chief connection between the new edition and the original will be updated segments of what CBS is calling "classic" reports from the original show, presented by the cast of the Sunday night "60 Minutes." They may also appear in follow-up segments on the second edition if something reported on Sunday needs updating.
No new correspondents were named yesterday, but the executive producer will be Jeff Fager, currently the executive producer of the "Evening News With Dan Rather," who previously spent six years as a producer on "60 Minutes." Mr. Fager was called the crucial piece in building the new program by several CBS News executives, including Mr. Rather, who said, "I don't think there could be a '60 Minutes II' without Jeff and the credentials he brings to the table."
He will be replaced at the evening news by Al Ortiz, the chief of CBS's Washington bureau.
Mr. Fager said yesterday that he hoped to have the show on the air by mid-January. "One of the great advantages I have is that I don't need to go around looking for new music or building a new set."
The look of the new show will be very much the same as the original, Mr. Fager said, as will the style of reporting. There will be no anchor, he said, just a lineup of correspondents, as on the original "60 Minutes."
The other crucial player in the development of the new program is Don Hewitt, the creator and executive producer of "60 Minutes" for the last 30 years. Mr. Hewitt will serve as a consultant on the new edition, CBS announced.
The role of Mr. Hewitt and the correspondents long associated with the show like Mike Wallace, Morley Safer and Ed Bradley, had been one of the sticking points in what became a long negotiation over the second edition. Mr. Hewitt had said that he had been asked numerous times over the years to expand what has been the CBS network's most valuable franchise, but he always resisted, seeking to protect the almost hallowed status of the original.
In addition, the correspondents had expressed their own reservations about the potential risk to the reputation of the original. But CBS's management pushed the expansion to take advantage of the "60 Minutes" name. News magazines are some of the most dependable profit centers for networks, which are under increasing economic pressure because of a dearth of new hits and escalating costs for entertainment programs produced by Hollywood studios.
Mr. Hewitt, who declined to comment, said in a statement released by CBS: "I think that under Jeff Fager, '60 Minutes II' is a natural to be the second-best broadcast of its kind on television. Inasmuch as I can help, without shortchanging the first- best broadcast of its kind on television, I'm hoping to do that."
Leslie Moonves, the president of CBS and the man responsible for the network's prime-time schedule, had long made clear his enthusiasm for a second edition of the most reliable ratings getter on CBS. "This is very important for us," he said. "If you just look at the summer, '60 Minutes' has been the top-rated show in television three of the last four weeks."
He added that the new edition would likely be scheduled on a weeknight at either 9 or 10 P.M. and might be pitted against an existing news magazine on another network "just because it's so hard to avoid them."
Mr. Heyward declined to speculate on which correspondents might be under consideration for "60 Minutes II" but said of two part-time contributors to the original program, Christiane Amanpour and Bob Simon, "We're looking for experienced broadcasters with superb talent and those are certainly people with those qualifications."

HEADLINE: Caterpillar Reports Small Rise in Profits

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: PEORIA, Ill., July 15

 BODY:
Caterpillar Inc. said today that earnings increased only 2.5 percent in the second quarter, less than expected, as weaker Asian sales and higher costs offset strong demand in the United States. The company's shares fell 7 percent.
Caterpillar, the world's largest manufacturer of construction equipment, said net income rose to $446 million, or $1.20 a diluted share, from $435 million, or $1.13 a share, a year earlier. 
 Analysts had expected earnings of $1.24 a share, and Caterpillar's stock declined $4.25, to $52, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Revenue climbed 15 percent, to $5.60 billion from $4.87 billion.
The economic turmoil in Asia has slowed economic growth in the United States. That slowdown, in turn, has kept down American interest rates, bolstering construction spending.
Still, Caterpillar's operating profit as a percentage of sales slipped to 12.4 percent from 13 percent because of what it said were higher fixed costs, lower productivity and the unfavorable effect of a strong dollar.
Caterpillar reiterated its forecast that 1998 profit will be near 1997's record level.
Higher spending in the latest quarter held down the full benefits from higher sales and revenue, though per-share earnings were helped by the company's stock buyback program.

HEADLINE: Businesses Register an Inventory Decline

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 15

 BODY:
Inventories of unsold merchandise at businesses shrank in May for the first time in almost two years as free-spending consumers swept goods off retailers' shelves.
Total business inventories fell one-tenth of a percent in May, after rising one-tenth of a percent in April, the Commerce Department said today. Retail inventories alone, which account for about a third of all stocks on hand, fell 1 percent in May as retail sales surged. 
 While goods were added to inventories at a slower pace in the second quarter -- suppressing economic growth for those months -- it set the stage for a rebound later this year if retailers increase orders to factories for merchandise, analysts said.
"Consumers are going to continue to demand and purchase goods as prices continue to decline," said Richard Yamarone, a senior economist at the Argus Research Corporation in New York. "The shelves need to be restocked because inventories are being depleted and consumers continue to buy."
Prices are also staying at consumer-friendly levels. A separate report by the Labor Department showed prices for imported goods fell five-tenths of a percent in June, the eighth consecutive monthly decline.
Inventory building bolstered the economy in the first quarter, as businesses added to their stocks at a record annual pace of $105.7 billion. The result was a 5.4 percent annual growth rate in gross domestic product during the quarter.
As those inventories were drawn down in the second quarter, the G.D.P. growth rate probably fell.

HEADLINE: A Number of Banks Report Strong Profits in 2d Quarter

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, July 15

 BODY:
The BankAmerica Corporation and several other large banks met or beat second-quarter earnings expectations as they generated higher fees from consumers and corporations.
Earnings at BankAmerica, the fifth-largest bank, rose 11.4 percent, and Fleet Financial Group Inc., the 10th-largest bank, said its net income increased 13 percent. 
 "They're strong," said Anthony Gray, chairman and chief investment officer of STI Capital Management in Orlando, Fla., which oversees $14 billion. "And they should be for the next couple of quarters" because of a robust United States economy, he said.
Gains from mortgages and credit cards, and profits from investment banking and asset-management units outpaced flat or declining net interest revenue.
The San Francisco-based BankAmerica, said profit in the second quarter rose on higher fee income from investment banking and other businesses. BankAmerica, which is being acquired by the Nationsbank Corporation for $65 billion, said net income was $890 million, or $1.24 a share, including several one-time gains and losses.
Fleet's second-quarter earnings rose as new brokerage and investment businesses thrived. The Boston-based bank said net income rose to $393 million, or $1.29 a diluted share, from $347 million, or $1.17, a year earlier. The results beat estimates of $1.26 a share.
Fleet's purchases of the brokerage firm Quick & Reilly and the Advanta Corporation's credit card unit pushed noninterest income up 35 percent, even as net interest income gained 5 percent.
U.S. Bancorp, the country's 17th-largest bank, with assets of $73.8 billion, said second-quarter earnings rose as the bank generated more fees from investment and trust services. The Minneapolis-based bank said net income, including one-time items in both periods, rose 5.5 percent, to $320.6 million, or 43 cents a diluted share.
The Wachovia Corporation, which has $63.9 billion in total assets, said its operating earnings rose 17 percent, led by gains in fees from capital markets and mortgage services.
The bank, which is based in Winston-Salem, N.C., said net income rose 6.7 percent, to $209.9 million, or $1 a diluted share, from $196.8 million, or 98 cents.
Republic, with $56.4 billion in assets, said second-quarter earnings rose 7.5 percent on foreign exchange and equity gains. The New York bank said net income rose to $118.8 million, or $1.05 a diluted share, from $110.5 million, or 98 cents a share.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
Stepping out a bit from Coke's shadow, a big bottler is basking in its own spotlight these days.

BYLINE: By Constance L. Hays 

 BODY:
COCA-COLA ENTERPRISES INC., the bottling company that is ever the bridesmaid to the giant Coca-Cola Company, is getting a turn in the spotlight after all.
While the Asian economic crisis deepens, stock in the bottler provides a brand name that investors trust without the added exposure to Indonesia, Thailand, Japan and other countries whose bubbles have burst. 
 Foreign sales account for 80 percent of Coca-Cola's total business, and the company's profits have been crimped slightly as falling currencies reduce the value of those sales.
Meanwhile, sales in the United States are skipping along, with growth of about 10 percent annually, impressive for a mature market in which Coke products are already consumed at the rate of slightly more than one eight-ounce serving a day for each man, woman and child.
And Coca-Cola Enterprises, the largest bottler in the Coke system, accounts for 65 percent of Coke's domestic sales volume. The bottler also handles Dr Pepper, the No. 6 soft drink in the United States, and gets about 32 percent of its business from Western Europe and Canada. The last 18 months, it has been on an acquisition binge, snapping up Coca-Cola Bottling of New York, Coca-Cola Bottling of Canada and Coca-Cola Southwest, as well as a $2 billion British bottler. Last month, it announced plans to acquire Great Plains Bottlers and Canners Inc., a Midwest bottler that handles Dr Pepper and Coke products.
Margaret F. Carton, director of investor relations for Coca-Cola Enterprises, says that even without the acquisitions, the company will meet its goal of 10 percent growth in 1998.
All this leads to new-found respect in an industry in which the bottlers, clinking angrily under their breath, have long had to take a back seat to the soft-drink companies.
A year ago, shares in Coke Enterprises were trading at $21, up from a split-adjusted offering price of $5.50 in 1986. In April, the share price popped through the $40 barrier for the first time and leaped higher a few days later after an announcement that Henry A. Schimberg, the company's president, had pledged to stay on two more years as chief executive, and three subsequent years as a consultant. Summerfield K. Johnston Jr., the chief executive and chairman, agreed to remain as chairman for an indefinite period.
In May, two stock analysts speaking at a beverage-industry conference recommended the stock, even over Coca-Cola. And last month, at the Coca-Cola Company's biennial presentation before investment bankers and portfolio managers, officials of the bottling company were included on stage for the first time. Stock in the bottler gained 25 cents yesterday, to close at $40.75, ahead of a scheduled earnings report today from Coca-Cola.
The heightened interest in Coke Enterprises can be attributed to several factors besides concern about of the Asian crisis and management savvy. First of all, a bottler bonded in any way to the Coca-Cola Company ends up looking good, simply because Coke is, as the saying goes, running on all cylinders. Volume is up, both worldwide and in the United States. Marketing has never been better organized; witness this summer's relentless promotion of "Coke Cards," 55 million of which were distributed to teen-agers and college students. The cards combine entertainment discounts and other offers with the purchase of a Coke or Diet Coke.
Second, Coke Enterprises has been through a series of consolidations and aligned its marketing and business strategy with Coke. One of 11 anchor bottlers around the world (Coca-Cola Beverages, which has operations in Central and Eastern Europe, went public in London just this week), Coke Enterprises is a pillar of strength when it comes to local marketing and execution, the twin forces that increase sales.
The Coca-Cola Company, which has a 42 percent stake in the bottler, benefits directly from the bottler's success, and the two have reached a mutual understanding, mostly under the leadership of M. Douglas Ivester, the chairman and chief executive of Coca-Cola, who is a former chairman of Coke Enterprises.
Historically, companies like Coke and Pepsi had a fractious relationship with their bottlers. "You might call it constructive tension," says John D. Sicher, publisher of Beverage Digest, a widely read industry newsletter. He added, however, "In the last couple of years, Coke has really listened well to its big bottlers."
The model looks pretty good, but, much like the Coke that dazzles investors today, it took years to assemble. The bottler staggered for its first five years. A 1991 merger with the Johnston Coca-Cola Bottling Company turned things around. Centralized management was replaced by one based in the field. And the merger brought in Mr. Schimberg and Mr. Johnston, who get rave reviews from money managers and bottlers alike.
"Henry is one of the most gifted executives in this industry," Mr. Sicher said. "He really has few peers. He has such a deep, intuitive understanding of the marketing and distribution of soft drinks."
Despite their linked agendas, Coke Enterprises must be regarded as a totally separate species from Coke, said Emanuel Goldman, a beverage stock analyst with Paine Webber in San Francisco. And if an investor worries about debt, Coke Enterprises may provide cold comfort.
"Coke is a concentrate company with a balance sheet that has effectively no debt," Mr. Goldman said. "Coke Enterprises is extraordinarily top-heavy."
Coke's long-term debt is just $801 million, on shareholder equity of $18 billion, according to its 1997 annual report. The bottler has about $8 billion in debt on shareholder equity of $1.8 billion.
Still, the bottler's stock is trading at more than 100 times earnings, twice the multiple of Coke's stock, Mr. Goldman noted. Dividends aren't much to write home about either, only about 16 cents a share annually.
More important, though, may be the role played by its principal shareholder. "Coke in a sense stands behind the company," Mr. Goldman said. "It's not official. But when you have 60 percent of the volume, you can be pretty sure Coke cares."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Another High for Nasdaq, But Profit News Hurts Dow

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Stocks were mixed yesterday with the technology-heavy Nasdaq index jumping to another new high, while the Dow Jones industrial average and the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks finished lower after rising earlier in a day of volatile trading.
Microsoft, Dell Computer and Intel pushed the Nasdaq higher, with Intel rebounding after its second-quarter earnings, which were reported after the market closed on Tuesday, came in a little under expectations. 
 Eastman Kodak, which jumped 8 3/4, to 82 1/2, added about 37 points to the Dow after it reported that its second-quarter earnings beat forecasts by a striking 25 cents a share. But that was not enough to offset some disappointing earnings news.
Caterpillar said that earnings rose 2.5 percent, to $1.20 a diluted share, 4 cents a share below the forecast by analysts surveyed by the First Call Corporation. The company said that earnings were hurt by weak Asian sales. Caterpillar's stock fell 4 1/4, to 52.
And even strong earnings from Ford Motor did not help it. The company reported profits that beat estimates by 10 cents a share, but the stock dropped 1, to 59 1/2. Even so, the stock is still up 84.5 percent for the year.
The Nasdaq index rose 26.13 points, or 1.33 percent, to 1,994.54, leaving it just a few points shy of the 2,000 level. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 2.77, to 1,174.81, while the Dow dropped 11.07, to 9,234.47. During the day, the Dow topped 9,300 for the first time, but was pulled lower by Caterpillar and by declines in some of Tuesday's better performers, including J. P. Morgan and Procter & Gamble.
In the bond market, the price of the 30-year bond rose 7/32 , to 106 2/32 , snapping a three-day slide. The yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 5.70 percent, from 5.71 percent on Tuesday. The long-term yield is still more than 10 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, higher than it was a week and a half ago.
This is because the outlook for a turnaround in Japan and Russia has improved recently in some investors' eyes. Russia has been helped by a $17 billion bailout from the International Monetary Fund, the United States and Japan. And Japan is searching for a new Prime Minister.
One of the concerns some analysts have about the stock market is that while it is rising, the rally is limited to the bigger-company stocks. This means that the so-called breadth of the rally is not wide. One indicator of the lack of breadth is the number of advancing stocks compared with decliners. On the Big Board yesterday, decliners lead advancers 1,543 to 1,433.
Another indicator is the fact that the main index of smaller-company stocks is still well below its high while the major indexes have all bounced back. The Russell index of 2,000 stocks rose 2.55, to 461.98 yesterday, but it is still 6.4 percent from its high of 491.41 on April 21. And while the Nasdaq is up 27 percent this year and the S.& P. 500 has risen 21 percent, the Russell 2000 index is up just 5.7 percent.
"It's a big-cap rally," said Marshall Acuff, the equity strategist at Salomon Smith Barney. "The lack of breadth makes you scratch your head. You have to build the breadth. You've got to have the earnings to build the breadth and companies like Caterpillar don't have the earnings."
And, he added, "if people really felt good about earnings they would be driving the mid-caps and small-caps higher."
One of the reasons for this disparity in performance is that price/earnings ratios are so high that investors only want to pay up for bigger company stocks that have long-term records of coming close to earnings expectations.
But other analysts argue that the rush of new money from Americans and foreigners into the stock market is going to be enough to offset concerns about the high cost of stocks and the comparatively lackluster earnings performance this year -- low single digits compared with double digits last year.

HEADLINE: Emergency Declared in Dallas As More People Die From Heat

BYLINE: By CAROL MARIE CROPPER 

DATELINE: DALLAS, July 15

 BODY:
With 16 deaths here already tied to the heat this summer and with temperatures of 100 degrees or more for 10 days in a row, Dallas County health officials have declared a state of emergency.
The emergency measures were imposed on Tuesday after eight heat-related deaths were reported in two days, said Betty Culbreath, the director of Dallas County Health and Human Services. Most victims have been elderly people who had other health problems, Ms. Culbreath said, although children 5 and under are also at risk. 
 "People are taking better care of their children than their elderly," she said.
The region's heat wave has been blamed for more than 50 deaths in all, including 23 in Texas and 20 in Louisiana. Oklahoma's state epidemiologist, Mike Crutcher, said he had received reports of six heat-related deaths in the past month, compared with four for last summer.
The county health agency here has set up a special telephone line so the elderly, the disabled and the poor can call to get their air conditioners repaired, to receive a free fan or to get help in paying utility bills, Ms. Culbreath said. City recreation centers and other public buildings were open during business hours to people who needed a place to cool off, and six of the centers were prepared for overnight use if needed, she added.
The 16 deaths here are the most heat-related fatalities in recent memory, Ms. Culbreath said. For all of last year there were 17 heat-related deaths in the entire state, said Doug McBride, apublic information officer with the Texas Department of Health.
The National Weather Service reported that the Dallas area, through today, had had 23 days when the temperature reached or topped 100 degrees. But that is far from the record set in 1980, when there were 69 such days.
Michael Foster, a meteorologist for the National Weather Service in Fort Worth, said the recent heat wave had been caused by an upper-level high pressure system covering the area, preventing cloud formation and rainfall and blocking other weather patterns from moving in.
The heat, combined with a lack of rain, has already cost Texas agriculture $1.5 billion -- which translates into a $4.6 billion loss to the state's overall economy -- as cotton plants shrivel and ranchers are forced to sell hungry livestock, the Texas Agricultural Extension Service reported.
Despite the heat, most Dallas residents, accustomed to summer temperatures in the mid-90's, have been going about their business as usual.
Ramon Rodriguez, a 91-year-old who received national attention last year when a drive-through bank was built around his modest house, said he sat under a shade tree in his backyard on Sunday, watching the bank's time-and-temperature sign as the temperature rose to 110 degrees. The Weather Service said that temperature broke a record for the date, set in 1954.
At Sammy's Bar-B-Q, a smattering of diners sat in the covered area outside today. "We're accustomed to it," said Jane Mills Pearle, 37, who moved to Dallas from Boston in that sizzling summer of 1980. "I remember my first summer in Texas, eating Popsicles and laying on a bed and thinking, 'I'm going to die.'
"Last weekend, I was playing tennis, and it was 105."
Even though a 23-year-old man died here after bicycling in the heat, John Lauck, 42, of suburban Plano took his customary lunchtime run today.
"The trick is to stay well hydrated and stay in the shade to run," Mr. Lauck said. "I haven't missed a day yet because of the heat."

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Kodak Halts Profit Decline, Rising 35%

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
The Eastman Kodak Company reported nearly a 35 percent gain in second-quarter earnings yesterday, reversing a six-quarter-long decline.
The photography giant, based in Rochester, earned $495 million, or $1.51 a diluted share, compared with $368 million, or $1.11, a year earlier. Even excluding a one-time gain of 13 cents a share from the sale of Kodak's stake in Gretag Imaging, the earnings were well above the $1.13 a share that Wall Street analysts had predicted. 
 Although losses from digital photography remained high, and total revenue declined 4.9 percent, to $3.7 billion, investors reacted as though the quarter had been perfect. Kodak's shares soared $8.75, or nearly 12 percent, to $82.50, as analysts pushed up their earnings estimates for all of 1998 and 1999.
"I figured they could beat us, but never by this much," said Jonathan Rosenzweig of Salomon Smith Barney, who had expected the quarter's earnings to reach $1.15. "I am a very happy camper."
Indeed, analysts took the figures as proof that Kodak was making good on its pledge last fall to cut research costs, stanch its hemorrhaging digital portfolio and eliminate almost 20,000 jobs -- a fifth of its work force. The company's stated goal was to reduce $500 million from costs both this year and next. Costs are already down $350 million for the first half of 1998, putting Kodak ahead of schedule. Indeed, even its line of writable compact disks, which lost $100 million last year, is nearing the break-even point.
"Even over $100, this wouldn't be an overvalued stock now," said Peter J. Enderlin, an analyst with the First Albany Corporation.
The quarter did have disappointments. Kodak's domestic film volume in units was up 10 percent, but continued pressure on prices kept revenue growth to just 3 percent. Sales in emerging markets, which had been one of Kodak's fastest-growing areas, plunged 14 percent, in good part because of Asia's economic problems.
Revenue from digital cameras was down about 5 percent, and the company's digital-photography portfolio lost $64 million for the quarter -- much reduced from the $102 million it lost in the second quarter of 1997, but up from a $55 million loss in 1998's first three months.
"Those two growth levers just didn't deliver for us," said Harry Kavetas, Kodak's chief financial officer.
Mr. Kavetas maintains that these are short-term setbacks. Kodak continues to pump money into emerging markets, particularly China, and expects growth to resume there soon.
It is working with the Intel Corporation to create photo-writable CD's, and with America Online to allow the Internet access provider's customers to receive digital versions of photographs by E-mail.
More important to analysts, Kodak is quitting ancillary products and businesses. It sold a chain of photofinishing stores that it had bought less than two years ago, aborting a retail strategy that was pushing it into competition with its photofinishing customers. It trimmed slow-moving products from its digital-photography line, and folded its graphic arts business into Kodak Polychrome Graphics, a joint venture with Dainippon Ink and Chemicals of Japan.
And it bailed out of sundry small businesses -- Cineon, which makes special-effects equipment for movies, is one example -- that served as little more than a distraction.
"They got rid of businesses we never even knew they were in, and they got rid of them fast," said Ulysses Yannas, an analyst with Mercer, Bokert, Buckman & Reider.
Many Kodak-watchers also see happier news in the domestic film picture. Although Kodak continues to reduce prices on packs of slower-speed film, it is maintaining its price on the higher-priced APS and high-speed Max lines. Indeed, Max films accounted for 31 percent of film sales, up from 27 percent in the second quarter last year.
"The Max lines cost a few extra grains of silver to make, but they get more than double the price," Mr. Yannas said.
Still, the general euphoria remains tempered by basic worries about the outlook for the photography business. "It's one thing to stem digital losses or to steal film share from competitors," said Jack L. Kelly, an analyst with Goldman, Sachs. "To really make money, they've got to find a way to get people to take more pictures."
Mr. Kavetas acknowledged that Kodak's revenue needed help. "We can't save our way to long-term growth," he said. "But this quarter has finally confirmed that we're getting our act together."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: The A B C's of Business in Brazil;
Companies Pitch In Where Public Education Leaves Off

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO 

DATELINE: PACAJUS, Brazil

 BODY:
When Antonio Gomes da Silva found school a bore at age 11, there was no grown-up within hollering distance urging him to stay. Not the grandfather rearing him, who raised cattle and saw little use for grammar. Not the father who abandoned him and went to live in Sao Paulo, 2,000 miles away. Not the mother left behind years earlier when his parents separated.
"If just one adult had said to me, 'No, don't drop out, you need an education,' it would have changed my life," Mr. Gomes da Silva said. 
 But in the 15 years since, the landscape in northeastern Brazil -- traditionally the poorest, most precarious swatch of this diverse country, which is bigger than the continental United States -- has begun to change, with subsistence farms giving way to factories. And in the lightning switch from ox carts to the post-industrial age, survival for workers like Mr. Gomes da Silva, a supervisor at a box factory, depends on hitting the books to make up for lost time.
Along with 30 other employees of Rigesa, the Brazilian subsidiary of the Westvaco Corporation, the paper company based in New York, Mr. Gomes da Silva now spends five nights a week in voluntary classes learning the basics of reading, geography and mathematics. A blue jeans factory owned by Vicunha Ltda., a large Brazilian textile manufacturer, that sits across the street from Rigesa also sponsors elementary school classes, as do the other concerns in the Pacajus industrial park, some 25 miles from the Ceara state capital, Fortaleza. It is all part of a tax-incentive package the state government offered to industry to create jobs outside large urban areas in places like this, a city of some 37,000 people.
Though the contrast between old and new is starkest here in Brazil's dusty northeast, the same shift is being played out across the country, from Sao Paulo to Rio Grande do Sul, where the opening of the world's eighth-biggest economy is expected to lure $17 billion in direct foreign investment this year -- the highest of any emerging market. Foreigners are buying up state-owned industries, and putting their money in everything from car factories to pharmaceutical subsidiaries.
But companies investing in Brazil are finding that severe shortcomings in the educational system, and the poverty that forced many workers to quit school early, hamper productivity and efforts at quality control. And as factories come to rely more on advanced, computer-controlled machines, they need fewer workers, but more capable ones: workers who can read the screens and make sense of what they see.
A wide-ranging 1997 study of industry in Brazil found overall productivity running at 27 percent of the United States level, with even the more advanced sectors, like the automobile industry, only 30 percent as productive as in the United States and 21 percent as productive as in Japan, the best in the industry. The report, by the McKinsey Global Institute in Washington in conjunction with its Sao Paulo office, largely blamed Brazil's protectionist legacy and business's lack of reinvestment. But it noted that workers in Brazil had an average of six years of schooling, compared with 11 to 13 years in Korea and Japan, and encouraged companies to invest in basic education.
"Compared to Asia, it's a disaster," said Riordan Roett, chairman of the Latin American studies program at the Johns Hopkins University School of Advanced International Studies. "In terms of globalization and competitiveness, education and job training are absolutely critical, and Brazil falls way behind.
"It's the lack of investment in basic education," Mr. Roett continued, "that is holding, and will hold, Brazil back."
The American Chamber of Commerce in Brazil, which began focusing on education early in the decade, found that the average worker in the Sao Paulo area had only a fourth-grade education. And the quality of even that level of schooling was open to question.
Through diagnostic tests, the chamber found that 90 percent of newly qualified primary school teachers had mastered barely 10 percent of the required curriculum, "which meant the perpetuation of the problem," said Silvio Tichauer, who runs the organization's Institute for Quality of Teaching.
The chamber is now putting together a 50-volume, 15,000-page "School Kit," a blueprint for putting together a properly functioning school. It has also introduced standardized tests for students and continuous remedial classes for teachers at five primary and secondary schools in Sao Paulo.
"We've had instances where we've wanted to start up computer-controlled machines, and we've found workers have a tremendous lack in logic and mathematical skills that we had to supplement with our own specific training," said Mr. Tichauer, executive manager in Brazil for the FMC Corporation, the food packager based in Chicago. Mr. Tichauer, who is based in Sao Paulo, added, "If it's bad here, it's probably worse everywhere else."
Other businesses are doing the same. Banco Bradesco S.A., a major Brazilian bank, finances nearly 50 primary and secondary school classes for workers and children scattered around the country. Fiat S.p.A., the Italian car maker, which built a factory in Minas Gerais state a few years ago, has had to open classes as well.
Jose Guilherme Reis, president of the National Council of Industries, based in Rio de Janeiro, said the longstanding government failure to supply decent public education and health care had increased the burden on industry, raising the price of doing business in Brazil beyond the legendary "Brazil cost," which covers excessively high financing costs, fees for the use of ports and taxes.
"In Brazil, beyond the taxes you pay, you have to pay more, a kind of hidden charge, for education in areas where public services fall short," Mr. Reis said.
While John Mein, president of the American Chamber of Commerce in Brazil, said that companies were not yet avoiding the country because of the low level of education, Mr. Reis said that a "large share" of the industries his council surveyed "expect to have problems in a few years."
Mark R. McMahon, the president of Rigesa, is among those who see difficulties on the horizon. "As we modernize our mill and box plants, the equipment is much more sophisticated," he said. "The whole logic will be based on computers."
Brazil's President, Fernando Henrique Cardoso, who is running for re-election in October, spent the early part of his four-year term focusing largely on privatizing government-owned industries and opening Brazil to foreign investment. Efforts to shore up education began only in the latter part of his term. The Government has taken steps to force municipalities and states, which are responsible for primary and secondary school education, to spend a minimum of about $260 a year for each student in the classroom, up from $208 in 1996.
Historically, however, the problem has not been primarily a lack of money. Though Brazil has spent nearly 20 percent of the federal budget on education, among the highest levels in the world, money has not bought quality. Only one in three students finishes the eighth grade in Brazil, compared with two out of three in Bolivia, which spends two-thirds less than Brazil on education.
Moreover, the investment in education is one whose benefits may take a decade or more to appear. And critics say the showcase of the Government drive to improve education -- installing televisions and computers in each school -- overlooks the core of the problem, which is poor teacher training. In regions like the northeast, public school teachers typically earn $50 a month, less than half the legally established minimum salary.
David Fleischer, a political science professor at the University of Brasilia, who writes a newsletter called Brazil Focus, said televisions and computers "are nice, but in a lot of these schools, the teacher has a second-grade education, at best."
Mr. Tichauer was blunter still. "More than half of those TV sets or computers are just gathering dust," he said. "If you don't have someone in the schools who's going to be helping the school use these tools, it ain't going to work."
In addition, 30 percent of the entire education budget is earmarked for public universities, according to Government statistics. That, said Mr. Roett of Johns Hopkins, comes at the expense of primary education and reinforces the country's already heavily skewed distribution of income. Unless students come from families that can pay for private primary and high schools, they are unlikely to gain admission to the best universities, which are public.
When it started operations in Pacajus nearly three years ago, Rigesa demanded an eighth-grade education for the 160 or so jobs it was offering, most paying the minimum wage of $110 a month. But it quickly had to lower its requirement to the fifth-grade level. The company has spent about $50,000 here on its educational program, which relies on videotapes developed by a Brazilian television network to teach the courses and a "facilitator" to answer questions.
Mr. Gomes da Silva, the school dropout, said he was not among the first to seize the chance to study again. For many months, he said, he stood "on the outside looking in," observing other workers who were attending classes.
"They created a good environment," he said.
Watching them, he stopped drinking and stepping out for parties, and brought peace to his once-turbulent home life, Mr. Gomes da Silva said. He was preparing himself to learn. "If you enter with problems, it's not good, either for you or the people next to you," he said. "I wanted to put out only good energy."
Now, Mr. Gomes da Silva said, he is studying primary equations once again. This time, he understands why he is learning. At the end of the 18-month course, he and the other workers will have completed the eighth grade. The company is planning a sequel to enable the workers to complete high school-level studies.
"I didn't know how important studying was," Mr. Gomes da Silva said. "Now, if somebody explains something to me, I see a reason for it, and it's easier to grasp."

HEADLINE: Dubuque Journal;
Hear Ye! 'Come Back to Your Future.'

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: DUBUQUE, Iowa

 BODY:
From the porch views of the Victorian-era houses high on the limestone bluffs above the Mississippi River, it looked like a sad parade on the streets of Dubuque in the 80's, an exodus of downhearted Iowans fleeing the farm-crisis economy.
In those days, with unemployment rates over 14 percent, young Iowans with roots five or six generations deep came to see their prospects here as hopeless. 
 "There was a saying, 'Would the last person out of Dubuque please turn out the lights,' " said Michelle Rios, a recruiter at the Greater Dubuque Development Corporation.
These days, Dubuque has a new and enviable problem: too many good jobs and not enough workers. With an unemployment rate below 4 percent, and a flurry of new and growing Dubuque companies in computer programming, publishing and marketing, employers lament a shortage of workers.
So Dubuque civic and business officials have begun an aggressive program to bring back the city's sons, daughters and grandchildren. The campaign, "Come back to your future -- come home to Dubuque," has included a site on the Internet and mailings to high school and college graduates. There have also been newspaper and radio advertisements directed at the parents and grandparents of former Dubuquers, urging them to persuade their offspring to return.
"It's wonderful to be home," said John Link, whose wife, Teri, and daughter, Tabitha, 2, are among the more than 30 families who have returned since the campaign began around last Christmas. "When I left, I never thought it would be possible."
The flourishing economy of Dubuque underscores the transformation of the economy in the rural Midwestern states like Iowa, which once depended almost solely on agriculture. Dubuque is now home to three textbook companies, a far cry from when the local economy was dominated by the John Deere tractor factory and a meatpacking plant.
Mr. Link, 30, left Dubuque after graduating from high school in 1986, eventually settling in the Northern Virginia suburbs, with a job in a marketing department in Washington. Ms. Link, 31 and also from Iowa, worked as a paralegal.
For young families that have grown weary of life in congested, expensive suburban settings, small cities and towns in the countryside have lately become appealing, particularly for safe streets and good schools. And employers in Dubuque, as in many other smaller Midwestern cities, need more technologically literate workers.
"We're not talking $6-an-hour jobs here, but jobs that pay $15 and $20 an hour," said Mike Walker, the general manager of Dubuque Data Services, a computer-programming company that has recently grown to 56 people, from 38 in November, including 6 new hires from Dubuque's Web site recruitment campaign.
The Links cherished living in a metropolitan area, especially the sense of excitement and diversity. But they also found it expensive, and more than a bit stressful, especially after the birth of their daughter. With Ms. Link expecting another child in the fall, the couple took a close look at Dubuque after hearing about the job surplus and recruitment efforts. Mr. Link easily found a good job in sales for an advertising company, and they moved back in the spring.
"Life is so much easier now," said Ms. Link, who added that she could afford to be a stay-at-home mother. "Around Washington, it took forever to get anywhere. Now I'm five minutes from the countryside, five minutes from the mall. You just feel like you can relax and breathe here."
The Links acknowledged that there were trade-offs for the slower-paced life: fewer restaurants, stores, less cultural diversity. Some acquaintances around Washington were dumbfounded by their decision to move to Iowa.
"Some would say, 'Oh, I'm so sorry,' " Ms. Link said, referring to people who assumed that her husband was being forced to transfer to a job in Iowa. "A lot of people don't even know where it is. They get it confused with Idaho or Ohio. They think its some desolate region with nothing but cornfields."
With architecture that goes back more than 150 years, Dubuque can be postcard pretty, its steep hills and rugged bluffs overlooking the nation's most storied river. Stylish boutiques and coffee shops line Bluff Street. And it takes less than a half-hour to get to the Illinois tourist town of Galena, 15 miles southeast, with its antique stores and historical sites.
"You wake up in the morning and see a sky that's cobalt blue," Mr. Link said. "You forget about what smog was."
It is also a much more affordable place for a young family. In the Virginia suburbs, a cracker-box town house cost about $150,000, Mr. Link said. Here the couple have a three-bedroom house with three bathrooms, a fireplace, a two-car garage and a nice yard -- for $108,000.
What's more, little Tabitha never goes more than a day or two without seeing a grandparent.
"They spoil her rotten," Ms. Link said. "Now we've got baby sitters whenever we want."

GRAPHIC: Photo: John Link, his wife, Teri, and their daughter, Tabitha, 2, are among the more than 30 families who have returned to the Dubuque area since a campaign was begun late last year to recruit native Iowans for new jobs. (Mark Hirsch for The New York Times)

 BODY:

Nasdaq Sets a New Record, While Dow and S.& P. Fall
The technology-heavy Nasdaq index jumped to its sixth consecutive new high, closing just shy of the 2,000 level at 1,994.54. 
 But the Dow Jones industrial average and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined as investors took profits after Tuesday's rally. During the day, the Dow topped 9,300 for the first time, before closing lower at 9,234.47. The S.& P. index fell to 1,174.81. Page D8.
 
Strong earnings from Ford Motor failed to bolster the stock market. Ford shares fell $1, to $59.50, but are up 84.5 percent so far this year. The company topped earnings estimates by Wall Street analysts by 10 cents. D4.
 
Compaq Tops Earnings Estimates
Compaq Computer reported a second-quarter loss of $3.63 billion, but eked out a tiny operating profit that surpassed analysts' expectations of a break-even quarter. D4.
 
Fed Concerned About Loan Policies
The Federal Reserve is concerned that lending standards at banks are slipping, presenting dangers should the economy stall. A1.
 
Russia Moves on Austerity Plan
With billions in Western loans at stake, the Russian Government urged the lower house of Parliament to pass tax, budget and economic measures that are the strings lenders have attached to any additional money. A6.
 
Big Earnings Gain at Time Warner
Time Warner said second-quarter earnings more than tripled, and its chairman suggested that the company might lease some cable properties to telephone companies. D6.
 
Cable and Wireless Buying MCI Unit
Richard H. Brown, the first American chief executive at Cable and Wireless of Britain, has expanded that company in the United States market and cyberspace with the acquisition of the Internet business of MCI Communications. The Federal Communications Commission is the only major regulatory body that has yet to rule on the acquisition. D7.
 
Details of Sprint's Network Plan
Sprint provided details of how it will revamp its communications network to provide integrated data and video information at high speeds. D7.
 
Bank Profits Meet or Top Estimates
BankAmerica and several other large banks met or beat second-quarter earnings expectations as they generated higher fees from consumers and corporations. D6.

Price-Fixing Trial Begins

Coca-Cola Enterprises Gains
Coca-Cola Enterprises, the largest bottler in the Coke system, has gained respect since it began a buying spree 18 months ago. As a result, shares have climbed to $40.75 from $21 a year ago. Market Place. D9.
 
CBS Adding 2d '60 Minutes'
As expected, CBS said that it would start a second "60 Minutes" next year. D6.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 4; Foreign Desk 

LENGTH: 882 words

HEADLINE: G.O.P., IN SWITCH, BACKS MORE FUNDS TO SHORE UP I.M.F.

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 15

 BODY:
House Republicans took the first step today toward approving all of the added money requested for the International Monetary Fund, out of concern that the economic crises overseas might spread to the United States.
A House panel voted $3.5 billion for the agency, and even though that was far below the $17.9 billion requested by the Clinton Administration, Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the majority leader and a harsh foe of the I.M.F, virtually conceded the fight. 
 "In the end, I suppose they will probably get about as much money as they're looking for," Mr. Armey said in a speech to the United States Chamber of Commerce.
House conservatives have been suspicious of the agency's lending practices and critical of recent loans to prop up Russia and bail out Asia. But with the Asian financial crisis deepening and threatening United States agricultural exports, Wall Street's anxiety is rising and building pressure on House Republicans to drop their objections to the fund.
Speaker Newt Gingrich acknowledged the growing concerns last month when he noted, "A lot of members who were wavering last fall now realize that it's very important for us to pass this."
Other top Republicans concurred privately with Mr. Armey today, while predicting a loud fight when the issue goes to the full Appropriations Committee and then to the House floor later this summer.
And some conservatives are still threatening to attach provisions that would restrict funds for family planning efforts overseas -- a measure that President Clinton opposes.
Even if the conservatives hold sway against the monetary fund on the House floor, some Republican lawmakers indicated the money would probably be made available in a final bill negotiated with the Senate, which approved the full amount last March. That outcome would allow critics to preserve their ideological opposition.
The Clinton Administration denounced what it considers the sluggishness of the House's response to looming economic problems.
"It is time for this Congress to get serious and stop fooling around," Michael D. McCurry, the White House spokesman, said Tuesday. "This is just back to close-down-the-Government time, you know, and they play these games, and there is serious work to do."
Concerns about the I.M.F.'s programs were heightened this week when the agency was forced to dig deep into a little-used fund of last resort to provide up to $13.8 billion in new loans to Russia over the next two years to help stabilize the ruble. The agency has not dipped into this fund in two decades and doing so now severely limits its overall lending ability.
Even though the Foreign Operations subcommittee of the Appropriations Committee approved only one-fifth of the Administration's request for I.M.F. money tonight, members of the panel signaled that they recognized the urgency of the agency's need for more financing.
Representative Nancy Pelosi of California, the top Democrat on the subcommittee, agreed that the monetary fund operated too secretively and made questionable judgments. She said that the agency could eventually be scrapped -- "Dismantle it, erase it, start from scratch." But first, she said, the full amount of money should be approved to stop the Asian crisis from spreading to the United States.
"If your house is burning down, you can't be concerned that the roof is leaking," she said. "We have an emergency at our doorstep."
Republicans, who dominate the panel, said the fund's inadequacies could be discussed later. Representative Ron Packard, Republican of California, said that adding the full $17.9 billion now would be a flippant move.
The subcommittee defeated Ms. Pelosi's proposal by voice vote and then approved the underlying bill, which, because of the small percentage of financing for the monetary agency, provides only about half of the $31.97 billion the President requested for all foreign operations.
The bill still includes tough restrictions on the fund's lending practices that the Administration is resisting. These include ending subsidized interest rates for regular borrowers and releasing edited transcripts of the minutes of the fund's board meetings.
"If they want the money, that's life," said Representative Robert L. Livingston, Republican of Louisiana and chairman of the Appropriations Committee.
The bill faces other hazards. Anti-abortion forces have vowed to attach a proposal restricting money for overseas family planning services. Thus, the final version could offer the money for the I.M.F. that the President wants, but he could still veto it if it restricts the availability of family planning funds.
Abortion-rights forces won a slim victory in the committee meeting tonight on another family-planning issue.
Abortion opponents had written the bill so that it would have allowed groups financed by the United States Agency for International Development that advocate "natural" family planning -- the rhythm method -- to withhold information about other forms of contraception.
But on a vote of 8 to 7, proponents of abortion rights prevailed. They included language that requires "natural" family planning advocates to refer people elsewhere when they seek information on alternative methods of avoiding pregnancy.

HEADLINE: Subway Station to Be Renovated, Keeping Pace With Times Square

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

 BODY:
The Times Square subway station -- a bewildering snarl of grime-encrusted tunnels that is the neglected basement of what has become the city's most animated neighborhood -- is finally about to receive the renovation that has been promised for decades.
Transit officials requested bids this week for the first phase of an eight-year, $180 million project to redesign and refurbish the city's busiest subway station, widening corridors and adding staircases and elevators for the thick crowds of workers, theatergoers and tourists that have begun flooding into the neighborhood. 
 The project will replace the station's filthy tiles and gum-plated floors, seen by 500,000 riders a day, with bright walls and nonslip granite, highlighted with stainless steel accents and restored mosaics. Several major artworks will be installed, including a 53-foot-long porcelain mural of a futuristic subway that Roy Lichtenstein created for the station before he died last year.
The Metropolitan Transportation Authority is scheduled to award the contract for the first phase of the project in October, and construction -- which will disrupt subway service on and off for years -- should begin by next spring.
The project is a scaled-down version of a much more grandiose plan that was unveiled in the early 1990's, before the recession caused real estate developers to pull out of a plan to contribute $90 million for a large rotunda and underground shopping plaza. Now, despite the boom that has transformed the neighborhood into a family-friendly arcade of theaters and shops, the M.T.A. is paying for the entire project itself.
Several good-government groups have criticized the M.T.A. for not requiring developers who are profiting from the boom to build escalators into the station or to contribute to its upkeep. But by using public money for the project, transit officials say, they are at least able to assure riders that this renovation will actually take place, unlike the many false starts that have left the station a decaying monument to the haphazard subway competition of the early 20th century.
"This is really it," said E. Virgil Conway, chairman of the M.T.A. "It's really going to happen. No more diddling around."
The authority has already begun closing off darkened corners of the station to prepare for the construction, and telling underground merchants to prepare for relocation. After 37 years of operation, the Record Mart, a renowned Latino music store near the north end of the N and R line platforms, will have to move to make way for an elevator. It is likely to relocate to a new strip of shops to be built in the station corridor that runs under 42d Street.
"I'm still not sure I believe it's real," said Jesse Moskowitz, who has owned the store since its opening in 1961. "But this time they sound very serious. We're getting ready to move."
The plan will proceed in two phases of about four years each. In the first, the authority will renovate the platforms for the Seventh Avenue Line (the 1, 2, 3 and 9 trains) and part of the Broadway Line (the N and R trains), along with most of the mezzanine above the platforms. The second phase will concentrate on the shuttle to Grand Central and the Flushing Line (the 7 train).
For most riders, the most striking change, in addition to the new walls, ceilings and floors, will be the changes to the mezzanine above the platforms, an area filled throughout the day by impassable streams of riders transferring between the shuttle and the north-south lines.
To ease pedestrian circulation, the project will widen the main corridor under 42d Street, at the north end of the Seventh Avenue platform, by about 15 feet, improving sight lines and removing sharp corners. A cluster of retail shops will open on the north side of that corridor, which will be lined with theater advertising posters.
On the mezzanine above the Broadway line, near the record store's current location, the authority will cut a large oval in the floor, surrounded by a stainless steel railing, that will give the area a more open feeling by permitting a direct view of the trains moving below. That corridor, and another beneath 41st Street, will also be widened and straightened to improve pedestrian flow. Ventilation will be slightly improved, although no fans will be installed.
Elevators will make the station accessible to the handicapped for the first time, and the narrow "finger stairways" that descend from the Seventh Avenue platforms to the Flushing Line will be repositioned and widened. Signs will be clearer, aiding the thousands of tourists whose first venture into subway riding often begins at Times Square and ends abruptly when they become hopelessly disoriented.
"We're finally going to make things the way we always would have liked them," said William J. Madden, the program manager for the project. He noted that the 94-year-old station was an agglomeration of four lines originally run by two competing subway companies, which accounts for its glued-together nature. In the original construction, corridors and staircases were squeezed in to make room for water pipes and huge utility lines running through the station, all of which will have to be painstakingly relocated during the construction.
The materials used in the new station, designed by the Manhattan architectural firm of William Nicholas Bodouva & Associates, will continue the airy, clean-scrubbed theme begun in the new entrance to the station that opened last year at 42d and Seventh Avenue, which has white tile walls and gray granite floors.
To reflect some of the energy of the neon-lighted neighborhood above ground, the station will feature several major artworks, including the Lichtenstein mural, a porcelain enamel work of a space-age subway completed before he died last September and donated to the subway system, which will be placed in the 42d Street corridor. The authority also commissioned major works from three other artists: Jacob Lawrence, who has completed a 36-foot mosaic of subway riders, Jack Beal and Toby Buonagurio.
The design of the project has already won high praise from riders' groups and the Municipal Art Society. "It's very handsome, very intelligent," said Brendan Sexton, the art society's president, who recently saw the completed plans. "They've really taken into account pedestrian travel underground, improving the lines of sight and way-finding. Right now, the station looks like a historical accident, unpleasant and quite confusing."
But Mr. Sexton said he was disappointed that the M.T.A. was letting property owners off the hook by not requiring them to build escalators and large entrances to the station, even though most received tax breaks for building in the area. The plan calls for the eventual closure of the narrow entrance on 43d Street, north of the shuttle, and Mr. Sexton noted that this would leave only one entrance north of 42d Street, the one on the northwest corner of Seventh Avenue. By recently allowing the Rudin Organization to make a $1.3 million payment in lieu of building a grand, canopied entrance there, he said, the M.T.A. was risking crowding at the staircases.
Mr. Conway said he did not think that the extra staircases were important enough to warrant seeking contributions from developers.
"I think the developers have done their job," he said. "We can argue all night whether they should have put this amount or not, but if developers are forced to do things that aren't necessary, they won't want to develop in New York City. What's important is that this project is finally going to begin."
Once it begins, construction will close off parts of platforms and entrances at various times through the course of eight years. Mr. Madden said that most of the work would be done at night and on weekends, and that while there would be some rerouting of trains at times, it would not be on the scale of the current Lenox Avenue project, which has pushed some West Side trains to the East Side during rush hours. The project will also cause lane closings on the streets above the station, mostly for the relocation of utilities.

GRAPHIC: Photo: An oval viewing area to be built over the N and R line tracks, shown in an artist's rendition, is one of several new features intended to make the Times Square subway station more pleasant and easier to navigate. (Don Hogan Charles/The New York Times)(pg. B6)

2. OPEN AREA

3. NEW ELEVATORS

4. NEW ARTWORK

House Eases Opposition To Full I.M.F. Financing
House Republicans signaled an emerging willingness to finance the International Monetary Fund fully, indicating a concern that the economic crises overseas might spread to the United States.
