HEADLINE: Train New Teachers, Don't Import Them

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Your July 11 front-page article "Low on Teachers, New York Scours Austria" says that the board will try to secure these teachers a special classification of visa for "research scholars." A shortage of H-1B visas, the usual classification for high school teachers, may be the reason for this. 
 The effect of the shortage of H-1B visas is not limited to secondary education. High-tech and financial companies, publishers, advertising agencies, colleges and universities all use these visas to employ foreign professionals.
In 1990 Congress created a 65,000 annual cap on H-1B visas. In an economy as robust as ours, this proved inadequate; the cap was reached in early May.
 
THEODORE RUTHIZER
New York, July 13, 1998
 
The writer teaches immigration law and policy at Columbia University Law School.

HEADLINE: World Bank Suspends 3 Employees for Suspected Kickbacks

BYLINE: By DAVID STOUT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 15

 BODY:
The World Bank, which lends billions of dollars a year for development projects in poor countries, is investigating possible kickbacks and other wrongdoing by at least three bank employees, bank officials said tonight.
The three employees have been notified that they are under suspicion and have been suspended, said Klas Bergman, the World Bank's chief of media relations. Mr. Bergman said the three are midlevel employees at the bank's headquarters in Washington. 
 Mark Malloch Brown, the bank's vice president for external affairs, said tonight that more bank aides could come under investigation, but he could not speculate how many.
"We need to confirm the allegations or disprove them," Mr. Malloch Brown said, adding that the bank's "moral authority" was at stake.
One aspect of the investigation involves a water utility project in Algiers. The bank is suing a former bank employee in Federal Court to recover thousands of dollars that it believes he took in kickbacks from a contractor who was a former neighbor and who did not complete the work properly, the bank officials said.
Another aspect of the investigation involves possible misuse of a trust fund set up by the Japanese Government to subsidize bank administrative expenses, according to The Washington Post, which first reported on the investigation in Thursday's editions. Mr. Bergman said he could not comment on that part of the case.
Since the bank funnels as much as $25 billion a year into development projects abroad -- and tries to guard against corruption in the needy countries that get its loans -- the World Bank's integrity is all-important, Mr. Malloch Brown said.
He said the amount of money involved in the investigation might be in the tens of thousands of dollars, or what he called "pretty small beer" compared to the bank's moral stature.
Mr. Bergman said the bank set up a special unit, the Oversight Committee on Fraud and Corruption, this spring after top officials began to get word of possible wrongdoing. The bank has also hired the global accounting firm Price Waterhouse Coopers and two outside fraud specialists.
The World Bank president, James D. Wolfensohn, distributed a message to bank staff members today in which he underlined the seriousness of the accusations, regardless of the amount of money involved.
"The bank has a passionate commitment to fight corruption," Mr. Wolfensohn said, calling it a "cancer."
"While I have no reason to believe there is a widespread problem in the bank, even one case is one too many," he said.
The bank has about 8,600 employees and has its headquarters a short distance from the White House, which Mr. Bergman said is being kept abreast of the investigation through the Treasury Department.
Mr. Bergman said he could not state whether the current accusations, if proven, would constitute the worst wrongdoing in the bank's history.
He recalled that, despite the bank's generally good record, an employee was convicted a few years ago of embezzling about $500,000.

HEADLINE: Congressional Roundup;
Higher Surplus Estimate Stirs G.O.P. Tax Cutters

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 15

 BODY:
The Congressional Budget Office today more than doubled its estimate of the Federal budget surplus over the next decade, emboldening Republicans who want to use some of the money for tax cuts despite President Clinton's insistence that it all be set aside until Social Security's financial problems are solved.
The budget office said it expected the cumulative surplus from 1999 through 2008 to be $1.55 trillion, more than double the $671 billion it projected in March. The new estimate brings the Congressional Budget Office's outlook roughly in line with the Clinton Administration's most recent projection of a $1.8 trillion surplus over the same period. 
 With Washington having hardly had time to adapt to an era of good fiscal news after decades of huge deficits, both parties claimed credit for the good news in the budget office's report.
But it was seized on especially by Republicans, who have been pressing the budget office for months to adopt a more optimistic view of the nation's fiscal condition to further their tax-cutting plans. The Congressional Budget Office said today that it had detected a largely unexplained rise in tax revenues and a slightly stronger economic growth forecast.
Mr. Clinton tried early this year to place the surplus off limits to Republican tax cutters by saying that every penny should be preserved until the two parties could agree on how to shore up Social Security for the retirement of the baby boom generation. White House officials said tonight that they would stick by that policy no matter how big the surplus.
Mr. Clinton's strategy has worked. But as the surplus has grown, Republicans have begun asserting that it will be big enough to accommodate tax cuts and a Social Security fix. With today's estimates, Republican leaders became more explicit in rejecting Mr. Clinton's "Social Security first" demand.
"With a whopping $1.5 trillion surplus over 10 years, we can preserve, protect and strengthen Social Security while also passing significant tax relief for hard-working Americans," Speaker Newt Gingrich said.
House Republicans are seeking $100 billion in tax cuts in the next five years, including reductions in the so-called marriage penalty paid by many two-income couples. Mr. Gingrich has also called for cuts in the capital gains tax and in estate taxes.
Democrats and moderate Republicans in the House and the Senate have said a tax cut of that magnitude is politically unrealistic because it would require painful spending cuts that even Republicans would not want to defend in a Congressional election year.
But dipping into the surplus would at least partly solve that problem and allow Republicans to further their efforts to reduce the size of the Government.
"If the politicians in Washington aren't careful, the surplus will be used to create more Government spending," said Representative Bill Archer, Republican of Texas, the chairman of the Ways and Means Committee. "To stop the politicians from spending the money, I want to use the surplus to pay down the debt, save Social Security and we should use a portion of it to cut taxes this year."
But Democrats warned that dipping into the surplus now would jeopardize any chance of reaching a bipartisan consensus on Social Security and would leave Republicans vulnerable to accusations of putting immediate tax cuts for the wealthy ahead of retirement security for the baby boomers and their children. RICHARD W. STEVENSON

HEADLINE: Congressional Roundup;
G.O.P. Senators Defeat Democrats' Farm Plans

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 15

 BODY:
The Senate voted today along party lines to reject Democratic proposals to give more Federal assistance to struggling farmers.
The main Democratic measure, billed as essential to keep thousands of farms from going under in one of the worst years in more than a decade, would have increased the amount of Federal money farmers could borrow with their crops as collateral and would have extended the time for repayment. 
 The Democratic proposal, an amendment to a $57 billion bill to pay for Government agriculture programs in the next fiscal year, was rejected, 56 to 43. Senator Russell D. Feingold, Democrat of Wisconsin, joined all 55 Republicans in opposition. All those who voted in favor were Democrats.
Democrats hope the vote will work against Republicans running for election in farm states this fall.
The Northern Plains states are a striking exception to the generally booming national economy. Plunging wheat prices caused primarily by reduced exports to Asia and a worldwide glut on the market have crippled many small farms from Minnesota through the Dakotas and west along the Canadian border to Washington.
This is the first big test of the 1996 farm law, which phases out Government crop subsidies, placed a limit on how much farmers can borrow from the Government and ended Government controls over what farmers can plant and when they can plant it.
Republicans believe that farmers, like almost all other Americans, fare best when the Government takes a hands-off approach. Democrats hold that farmers need a strong Government safety net to protect them in bad times.
In the case of the loans, the Democratic proposal would have increased the amount that could be borrowed against a wheat crop, this year alone, to $3.16 a bushel from $2.58, and would have lengthened the maximum repayment period to 15 months from 9 months. Farmers with other crops would have been entitled to similar loans.
In theory, this would help farmers by enabling them to withhold crops from the market until the price rose. DAVID E. ROSENBAUM

LENGTH: 941 words

HEADLINE: U.S. Imposes Curbs on 9 Russian Concerns

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 15

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration said today that it would impose trade sanctions on nine Russian companies and institutions that have been helping Iran with its missile program.
The Administration's action comes as the Russian Government, for the first time, publicly announced an investigation into the nine enterprises for violating new export control laws worked out in cooperation with the United States. 
 These were the first trade restrictions by the Administration on Russian companies helping Iran, though American assistance to seven of the companies had already been suspended. That assistance was largely in the form of research grants and scientific partnership programs originally intended to keep former Soviet scientists working after the collapse of the Soviet Union and not emigrating to help states like Iran with their weapons programs.
The Administration's announcement was timed to head off a Congressional effort to override President Clinton's veto of a bill that would impose sanctions on any company believed -- but not proven -- to be aiding Iran's missile, nuclear or chemical weapons program.
The House put off its vote on overriding the veto, which was scheduled for today. While the House is expected to vote to override, Administration officials say they are working to sustain the veto in the Senate.
The bill, the Iran Missile Proliferation Sanctions Act, was passed overwhelmingly by both houses and would hit Russian and Chinese companies the hardest. It was strongly supported by the pro-Israel lobby, the American Israel Public Affairs Committee.
Mr. Clinton vetoed the bill for many reasons, officials say. First, they feared it would create a nationalist backlash in Russia and make it harder to win Moscow's cooperation on halting these exports. Second, the bill calls for sanctions on the basis of "credible evidence," a low threshold of proof, and allows the President to waive the sanctions only for reasons of national security, a high threshold for waiver.
James P. Rubin, the State Department spokesman, said: "The standard of evidence is far too low. We constantly see evidence that is credible but just turns out to be wrong. That's not a serious way to do business in the international community."
Another senior official said the main issue was the need for Russian and Chinese cooperation to stop dangerous exports. "We can impose a few sanctions and show our outrage and feel better, but in reality, that's often symbolic. The real way you get to the heart of the problem is through the creation and effective enforcement of Russian controls, and you put that at risk with a confrontational sanctions route."
Vice President Gore, who is about to travel to Moscow, today praised the Russian decision to investigate the companies and announce the investigations.
Mr. Gore, who has been promoting United States-Russian scientific and space cooperation, called the Russian move today "an encouraging step forward." Mr. Gore has been politically frustrated by the Russian help to Iran, because he has also been responsive to Israeli concerns about the danger posed by the Iranian nuclear, chemical and missile programs.
"We will continue to work closely with the Russian Government at every level to close off exports of dangerous, destabilizing weapons technology," he said today. "This includes imposing trade restrictions and suspending U.S. Government programs or assistance to entities under investigation."
The trade restrictions will include bans on exports and imports and financial transactions, the officials said, which are more sweeping penalties than those called for under the bill Mr. Clinton vetoed. The bill would ban the export to Russian companies helping Iran's missile program of specific commodities that have potential military uses.
The restrictions announced today cover all the imports or exports of the companies. "This is designed to send a strong message to other Russian companies that want to deal with Iran that the U.S. is prepared to inflict economic pain," an official said.
But officials said they did not believe the new curbs, announced in an apparent hurry, would affect United States-Russian cooperation on the International Space Station or plans to launch American satellites on Russian rockets. One company sanctioned today is Glavkosmos, which is the Russian equivalent of NASA.
American scientific assistance to all Russian enterprises runs about $50 million a year, officials said. They could not provide a figure on the amount of trade these enterprises have with the United States.
"All this is designed to avoid an override," a Congressional staff member said. "Senior officials have been up here a million times trying to explain that the Russians are trying to get this under control. But this is the first time heads have rolled and enterprises have been exposed by the Russians."
Targets of the investigation were identified by the White House as the INOR scientific center, the Grafit and Ployus research institutes, the Tikhomirov institute, Glavkosmos, the Komintern plant in Novosibirsk, the MOSO company, Baltic State Technical University and Europalace 2000. MOSO and Europalace were the brokers for 22 tons of specialized steel, believed by Washington to have been produced for Iranian missiles. The steel was intercepted in Azerbaijan last March on the way to Iran.
INOR and Grafit supplied specialty steels for missile production, Poyus supplied guidance units and the Baltic State Technical University, in St. Petersburg, was helping with rocket-motor technology and training, officials said.
 

CORRECTION-DATE: July 17, 1998, Friday

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about American sanctions against nine Russian enterprises included an outdated description of one company, Glavkosmos. It is private and acts as a broker of space and missile technology; it is no longer a Government space agency.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1786 words

HEADLINE: Worries About Loans Revive Ghost of 1980's Bank Debacle

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY L. O'BRIEN 

 BODY:
Last year, Chase Manhattan, the country's largest bank, lent about $890 million to an Australian utility, Loy Yang B. Typically, to avoid putting too many eggs in one basket, banks try to get other banks to assume part of the risk by taking portions of big loans.
But Chase gave Loy Yang such generous terms -- a maturity of at least 15 years and a rock-bottom interest rate -- that it found few takers. And now, with the Australian economy squeezed by Asia's financial crisis, most of the Loy Yang loan is gathering dust on Chase's books. 
 Neither Chase nor Loy Yang said the loan was troubled. Chase said it was saddled with few loans that it had been unable to divvy up with other banks and that it had ample resources to protect it from loan losses.
But bountiful lending like this -- whether to overseas customers, builders in booming hotel markets like Las Vegas or nuts-and-bolts operators like heavy manufacturers -- still gives some bankers and Federal regulators the jitters. They have criticized freewheeling practices in certain markets, including the trillion-dollar business of splitting up big loans -- a business, known as syndicated lending, that is dominated by Chase, Citicorp, J. P. Morgan, BankAmerica, Nationsbank and other big banks.
The main concern is that banks are lending too freely, either to rack up one-time fees or to generate other business. Banks can do all sorts of things to keep the lending mill churning. They can lend at artificially low interest rates, perhaps too low to reward them for their risks, and they can stretch out repayment schedules, leaving themselves exposed to unforeseen economic tumult. In addition, covenants -- standards borrowers must meet to avoid having the bank demand repayment -- can be loosened or ignored entirely.
Some liken the zealousness to the heady days of the 1980's, when banks chased real estate loans with all the determination and earnestness of lemmings.
"Instead of getting better, it just gets crazier and crazier," said Richard Kovacevich, chief executive of the Norwest Corporation, a big Minneapolis bank. "The basics of banking are just being filtered away in order to grow." John Medlin, former chairman of the Wachovia Corporation, a bank in Winston-Salem, N.C., said in a December speech that lending practices were the worst he had seen in nearly four decades.
A letter the Federal Reserve sent to banks on June 23 offered a rare glimpse into how some banks now do business. The Fed, while noting that there is still little evidence that problem loans are on the rise, said it was concerned that lending standards were slipping -- presenting dangers should the economy stall and borrowers have trouble paying what they owe.
The Fed said that only 20 to 30 percent of several hundred loans it reviewed earlier this year had been thoroughly screened by banks to see how well they would hold up during a slump.
"That's absolutely a startling number," said Charles Peabody, a bank analyst with Mitchell Securities Inc. in New York. "The Fed said the pricing was getting narrower and maturities were being lengthened. If you are cutting the prices of loans and extending the terms, you better be darn sure what the future holds."
Why such hand-wringing when the economy is the most robust it has been in decades, and banks, whose lending is buttressed by newfangled computer safeguards, are enjoying record profits?
Regulators and others are still haunted by the ghost of the 1980's banking debacle, when scores of major banks were brought to their knees by reckless lending. When the Bank of New England collapsed in 1991, most regulators were caught by surprise. By the time the smoke cleared in the early 1990's, 11 of the nation's 50 largest banks had to be closed or sold because of bad loans. As a result, it became harder than at any time since the Depression for businesses and consumers to get loans.
With many analysts now warning that the United States economy cannot surge indefinitely, especially if Asia's woes have more impact here, regulators are concerned that imprudent lending could once again wreak havoc if the economy hits a wall.
Amid the rush to lend, the creditworthiness of borrowers is moving rapidly down scale.
In 1995, only about 12 percent of syndicated loans went to companies already carrying heavy debt and subpar credit ratings, according to the Comptroller of the Currency. By 1997, fully 17 percent of syndicated loans were to such indebted borrowers. And at the end of this year's first quarter, that figure had soared to 31 percent.
Julie L. Williams, the Acting Comptroller, said in an interview that she was "very uneasy" about lending standards at banks, citing lax standards in syndicated lending, lending to midsized companies and commercial real estate lending. She said that the comptroller's office had addressed its concerns in discussions with banks, and that some senior executives had been surprised to learn about questionable lending decisions made by their underlings.
But big banks said they were vigilant about their lending practices and constantly reviewed loans to make sure they were sound. They said the Fed's lending survey was skewed by loans from smaller, regional banks that they said might be less cautious in their lending.
"We think we've appropriately priced and structured the deals," said Robert Strong, Chase's chief credit officer. "We're comfortable with what we do."
Analysts consider Mr. Strong a sober-minded and effective manager. But some current and former Chase employees, and some analysts, worry that James B. Lee Jr., who oversees Chase's syndicated lending business, can override the bank's credit managers when he wants to complete a deal. Chase orchestrated some $474 billion in syndicated loans last year, a small but undisclosed portion of which remained on the bank's books.
Mr. Lee declined to be interviewed. But Mr. Strong said Mr. Lee does not have the authority to approve loans and cannot circumvent the loan review process at Chase.
"There are not a lot of quick, informal handshake kind of deals," Mr. Strong said, adding that Chase regularly takes months to scrutinize and "stress test" large loans. Mr. Strong pointed out that since the 1980's, Chase has diversified its lending and sharply reduced the number of loans it holds.
Other big banks say they are similarly disciplined. Citicorp, which flirted with collapse in the early 1990's because of errant lending and has since instituted tougher lending policies, has expanded its commercial and industrial loan portfolio to $59.3 billion last year from about $36 billion in 1992. But analysts and the bank said they were comfortable with the quality of those loans.
Real estate lending, the perennial bogyman of the banking business, appears to be relatively sound throughout the industry, but analysts said there were early signs that lending guidelines were drooping. A recent study by the accounting firm of Deloitte & Touche observed that construction loans that once had conservative maturities of one, three, or five years now involve "almost permanent lending of 7 to 10 years," thus exposing banks for longer periods to the notoriously boom-and-bust nature of the business.
Banks had about $400 billion in commercial mortgages last year, up from $300 billion in 1993, Deloitte said. Banks' exposure to related forms of lending, including loans to real estate investment trusts and the packaging and selling of mortgage-backed securities, is harder to quantify because no comprehensive, entirely accurate statistics are available.
"There's been a large increase in real estate lending, and when you put it all together -- adding in whole loans, REIT debt, and mortgage-backed securities -- it has grown significantly," said Dennis Yeskey, Deloitte's managing director for real estate services. "Whatever one does today is locked in for the next few years at a minimum, and that's not something that is easy to get off your books."
Las Vegas, the nation's fastest-growing city, has enjoyed a building boom fueled by such huge projects as Mirage Resorts Inc.'s $1.6 billion Bellagio casino. The Bellagio will open this fall, but gambling industry analysts question whether there will be enough demand to support such huge hotels.
The BankAmerica Corporation, the largest lender to Las Vegas operators and a backer of the Bellagio, said it was confident in the Bellagio's prospects and in the quality of outstanding loans to other gambling companies.
"That's not to say we haven't relaxed a covenant here or there," said William Newby, a managing director in charge of BankAmerica's gambling portfolio. "But we're not giving away cheap money with no covenants at all."
Mortgage-backed securities are an example of real estate investing that gives banks greater flexibility in managing risk. After all, the securities, which represent an ownership stake in mortgages made by banks and others, can be sold to investors and swept off a bank's books -- as long as investors want to buy them. Should the economy or interest rates swing against them, banks could be left holding the bag.
The First Union Corporation and Nationsbank, two of the most active participants in this market, have seen their holdings rise sharply.
First Union now holds about $24 billion in mortgage-backed securities, up from about $11 billion in early 1997. First Union said the credit quality of all of those securities was excellent and that the investments were used to manage risk, not to speculate.
Nationsbank declined to discuss the quality of its loans or investments, citing a pending merger with BankAmerica and a coming earnings announcement. It owns $29.5 billion of mortgage-backed securities, up from $9.9 billion early last year, and attributes part of the growth to acquisitions.
For his part, Norwest's Mr. Kovacevich said that historically problems in bank lending first emerged in consumer loans -- like the recent downturn in the credit card market -- and then appeared in large-scale commercial lending. If current lending standards continue to deteriorate, Mr. Kovacevich said he was unsure that big commercial lending snafus could be avoided.
And if serious lending problems do emerge down the road, only a handful of people will be the first to know.
"The industry has learned many lessons from past excesses, and the average bank is exercising more diligence than was the case in the late 1980's," said James M. McCormick, president of the First Manhattan Consulting Group, which specializes in financial institutions. "But ultimately only the regulators will know whether some banks are pushing the lending envelope too far."

SECTION: Section E; Part 1; Page 1; Column 5; Movies, Performing Arts/Weekend Desk 

LENGTH: 2046 words

HEADLINE: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;
A Revolution Made Of Gritty Intimacy

BYLINE: By STEPHEN HOLDEN 

 BODY:
Nearly 20 years ago, a catchy hit song called "Video Killed the Radio Star" by a group called the Buggles eerily presaged the rise of MTV and the revolution in pop-music marketing that the promotional video clip was just beginning to incite. Today, when the mindless star-studded "event movie" has risen to become the economic cornerstone of the film industry, the time is more than ripe for an upstart video artist to concoct a similar fantasy that might be dubbed, "Video Killed the Movie Star."
In the world of the $20-million-a-picture movie-star salary, that's not going to happen any time soon. But as suggested by the work shown in the New York Video Festival, which opens today at the Walter Reade Theater, video art, that unruly stepchild of television and experimental cinema, has flowered into a vast, immensely creative alternative culture. At its most inventive, as in "Flat Is Beautiful," Sadie Benning's 50-minute video evocation of preadolescent angst in a nontraditional Midwest household, experimental form and conventional narrative fuse into something extraordinarily original and touching. 
 Surveying the bewildering array of styles, technologies and attitudes in the festival, which runs through Thursday and is a part of Lincoln Center Festival '98, you almost have a sense of the universe expanding at the speed of light after a spontaneous explosion. Within the territory being mapped, there's nary a movie star to be found.
While it's risky to generalize about the flowering of video art, a few broad trends seem obvious. The home video camera leads people into much more intimate and quirkier spaces than the movie camera. Where movies monumentalize their subjects, video banalizes them, reducing everything to a collection of dancing pixels. Where movies are great at conjuring beautiful dreams, videos tune us in to the gritty day-to-day texture of "the real world," as defined by television. But paradoxically, in the hands of a subversive artist, it is equally adept at challenging the narrow Darwinian vision of life that saturates commercial television.
Video art lends itself to work ofraw, punkish nonsense, as in the program of eight bizarre shorts, "Faultlines in the Psyche," but it can also yield work of rigorously elegant abstraction. In a program called "Persistence of Vision," the seductive images run from the whimsical abstractions of Michael Intriere's "Fish" (schools of fish photographed swimming against a woozy, waterlogged pop instrumental soundtrack) to visually transfixing, even romantic meditations on technology.
As gorgeous as any fireworks display, Van McElwee's "Transfinite Loops" invents dazzling astral patterns and finds a mood of deepening sadness in the swirling, overlapping images of amusement park rides photographed at night and accompanied by the sound of howling wind.
Mark Bain's "Space Probing," which was photographed in a dense tangle of ducts, pipes and machinery beneath the campus of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, creates a shifting, kinetic, kaleidoscopic landscape that suggests a continually re-configuring Cubist painting that at moments seems almost three-dimensional. On a more austere, experimental level, Les LeVeque's "Flight" takes the shimmering low-resolution black-and-white television image of a lunar astronaut and, to the sounds of accompanying static, stretches it into two figures.
 
Unusual Documentaries
 If "The Persistence of Vision" represents one pole of the work shown in the Video Festival, three programs -- "The Good, the Bad and the Converted," "Frontier Meditations" and "Gimme Shelter" -- bring fresh concepts to the documentary form.
Jeanne Finley and John H. Muse's "O Night Without Objects," the centerpiece of "The Good, the Bad and the Converted," tells the true story of a rabidly anti-Semitic grand dragon of the Ku Klux Klan in Lincoln, Neb., who underwent a spiritual and political transformation, converted to Judaism, and was taken in and cared for until his death by a local cantor and his family. The story, which probes deeply into this family's complicated dynamics, is framed by abstract essays on family psychology (the opening segment of this triptych shows a psychological test being given to a child who is asked to describe what's happening in certain ambiguous pictures), society and religious community.
"Frontier Meditations" consists entirely of the Russian director Aleksandr Sokurov's five-and-a-half-hour documentary "Spiritual Voices: The Diaries of War," a rigorous, glacially paced meditation on the personal ravages of war on individual soldiers. The movie opens with a nearly one-hour shot of a desolate snow-covered landscape.
The centerpiece of "Gimme Shelter" is "The Final Insult," a disturbing, quasi-documentary on homelessness and the apathy of the impoverished by the American filmmaker Charles Burnett. Narrated by a fictional character, a low-level bank employee named Box Brown whose financial woes have left him homeless and forced to live in his car, "The Final Insult" blends fiction and truth so craftily that it's impossible to tell the actors from the nonactors. But its portrait of people living on the streets (and under the freeway) of Los Angeles is depressingly realistic. It shows how homelessness could happen to almost anyone.
 
Artistic Ambitions
 Some of the festival's longer works are more notable for what they attempt than for what they achieve. "Tomorrow and Tomorrow," by Dominique Cabrera, is a personal video diary, filmed with a hand-held camera, of a year in which Ms. Cabrera suffered from paralyzing bouts of depression. The work captures the texture of her daily life (with luminous close-up images of household objects) and the roller-coaster mood swings of someone desperately trying to pull her life together. For all its candor, the work still seems fragmentary and noncohesive.
Equally ambitious, although wildly different in intent, the Belgian video artist Johan Grimonprez's "Dial H-I-S-T-O-R-Y," in the program "Secret Histories," is an intellectually pretentious documentary history of airplane hijackings (accompanied by heavy-handed readings from the works of Don DeLillo). Illustrating how televised disasters have forced us to redefine what constitutes a genuine personal drama and to re-think our notions of personal autonomy, the work has a haranguing tone; after a while, the old newsreel and television clips of hijack survivors recounting their ordeals fades into a blur.
Much more satisfying and far scarier is Maria Venuto's half-hour video film, "The Tourist," which is based on a true incident in 1993. Arriving at Kennedy International Airport, a young German tourist who has fled her domineering family is fleeced of her money by a taxi driver and returns to the terminal, where she spends the next three weeks composing unsent postcards home describing her glorious new life in New York. Having subsisted on Pizza Hut leftovers and sleeping in the terminal, she is eventually thrown out into the cold by a security guard. This portrait of helplessness is so merciless it becomes nightmarishly funny.
 
Video's Intimate Quality
 But perhaps the high point of this uneven festival is Ms. Benning's "Flat Is Beautiful," which explores the world of a tomboyish 11-year-old girl named Sammy Steel, who lives with her divorced mother and the mother's gay male roommate. The most inspired conceit of this technically crude video film is to have all the characters wear cartoonish masks. Along with the characters' face gear, the videography, which focuses on billboards, store signs and flat surfaces, creates the feeling of living in a children's cartoon world where reality is simultaneously hidden and revealed in a twisted, more intensely felt stylization.
If the same devices were used in a glossier film, they wouldn't have nearly the same emotional impact. But because "Flat Is Beautiful" has the look, feel and sound of an intimate home video, it draws you into a private world that feels at once strange and profoundly recognizable.
 
New York Video Festival Offerings, From Quirky to Raw and Bizarre to Beautiful
 
The New York Video Festival, featuring more than 40 programs of short and feature-length works, runs through Thursday at the Walter Reade Theater, at Lincoln Center. The festival is part of Lincoln Center Festival '98. Admission to each program is $8.50; $5 for Film Society of Lincoln Center members; $4.50 for the elderly at weekday matinees, unless a different price is given. Unless noted, videos were made in the United States. Information: (212) 875-5600. Here is the schedule.

SECTION: Section A; Page 9; Column 1; Foreign Desk

HEADLINE: Reports of Embezzling at World Bank Jeopardize U.S. Financing

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 16

 BODY:
A key member of Congress said today that financing for some of the World Bank's poverty-fighting efforts had been put in jeopardy by reports that bank employees were suspected of embezzlement and of accepting kickbacks.
Senator Mitch McConnell, a Republican from Kentucky who is chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee's foreign operations subcommittee, said in a letter to James D. Wolfensohn, the World Bank's president, that he found news reports of possible wrongdoing uncovered by the bank's internal investigation "shocking." He said that it was time for an independent review of the institution's management and operations. 
 Mr. McConnell's subcommittee was scheduled to vote next week on providing $800 million for next year to the arm of the World Bank that makes low-interest loans to the world's poorest countries. His aides said he probably would write the bill to require a full explanation of the reports of wrongdoing and the bank's failure to apprise Congress of the problem before he released the money. Mr. McConnell's letter came after newspapers reported that the bank had found evidence of kickbacks being funneled to employees in at least two cases, and was investigating other accusations as part of a broad inquiry into wrongdoing within the bank. The bank's investigations were first disclosed by the Washington Post and the Asahi Shimbun in Tokyo.
When compared to the billions of dollars that the institution routinely lends to rickety, poor and sometimes corrupt governments around the world, the two cases at the center of the bank's investigations are miniscule in financial terms.
In one case, World Bank officials are investigating whether two Japanese employees took $11,000 in kickbacks for steering a consulting contract to a subsidiary of a Japanese securities firm.
In the only other case to have progressed beyond the initial stages of investigation, the bank filed a civil lawsuit seeking to recover tens of thousands of dollars it suspects were funneled to an employee by a technology company he hired to work on a project in Algeria. No criminal charges have been filed in either case.
Analysts who follow the World Bank generally see internal corruption as a far smaller problem than the bank's attempt to wrest full control over the more than $20 billion it channels each year into construction projects, education, health and nutrition projects and other programs in scores of countries across the world.
But since the institution has embarked on a high-profile effort to insure that the money it lends goes to fighting poverty and not to enriching corrupt government officials and business executives, officials at the bank were concerned that the institution be able to live up to its own standards.
And with the bank's poverty-fighting effectiveness under attack in Congress and internationally among economists and development specialists, the investigations brought more criticism that the bank is not sufficiently accountable to taxpayers in the United States and other wealthy nations that help finance its operations.
The Treasury Department said it had encouraged the bank to "investigate fully and then take all appropriate actions."

HEADLINE: New York City's Bond Rating Is Raised by Wall St. Agency

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

 BODY:
A major credit-rating agency raised New York City's bond rating yesterday, and leaders of the City Council said it was the strongest sign yet that the budget they adopted last month was fiscally prudent.
But Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who has assailed the Council's budget plan, said the upgraded bond rating was instead a sign that his conservative financial policies over five years were finally paying off. 
 The agency, Standard & Poor's, increased New York's rating to A-, up one notch from BBB+, citing the city's $2 billion budget surplus, its flourishing economy and its success in reducing projected deficits for the coming years. But analysts at the agency also said they were worried about the city's rising long-term debt and the Council's plan to cut taxes by $200 million this year and $500 million in future years.
By adding tax cuts to the budget plan that Mr. Giuliani proposed in January while also increasing spending, the Council increased the projected deficits for coming years, the analysts said. "The change from the original January plan was slightly in the wrong direction," said Todd Whitestone, a managing director at Standard & Poor's. "We don't feel they're all the way there."
The upgraded rating affects billions of dollars in general-obligation bonds the city has issued over the years to finance construction and renovations of bridges, roads, buildings and other projects. The better rating is important because banks and other financial institutions that do not invest in municipal bonds with a rating lower than the A category, a standard cutoff, would now be able to buy new bonds issued by the city.
In theory, the improved bond rating would save the city millions of dollars by making its bonds attractive to more investors and allowing the city to offer them with less interest. But experts predicted that the upgraded rating would yield hardly any savings this year, because the city's bonds are already trading at prices reflecting the higher rating.
The announcement from Standard & Poor's came one month after Mr. Giuliani vetoed $200 million from the Council's budget plan, saying it included reckless spending that would create deficits. When the Council overrode the vetoes, Mr. Giuliani threatened to use his considerable powers to hold down spending, and he started by asking city agencies to look for ways that they could cut their budgets by 10 percent.
Mr. Whitestone and other analysts at Standard & Poor's praised the Mayor's plan to cut spending yesterday, saying it was one of the reasons they raised the city's bond rating.
But Mr. Giuliani, speaking at a news conference, said he was not yet sure whether cuts would be necessary. He focused more on the warnings that accompanied the improved rating than on the rating itself, saying they proved that the Council's budget was unsound.
"This is an upgrade in spite of the damaging action of the Council's budget in increasing out-year gaps," Mr. Giuliani said, referring to the projected deficits. "Maybe we could have gotten more of an upgrade if they hadn't done that."
But the Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, a Democrat running for governor, pointed out that the Council's budget included money to pay off debt, a plan that Mr. Whitestone said was wise. "The Council passed the most fiscally responsible budget in city history," Mr. Vallone said. "We are better prepared now than any other year for an economic downturn."
The city's general-obligation bonds had been rated BBB+ by Standard & Poor's since it downgraded them from a rating of A- in 1995. The upgrade came five months after another major Wall Street credit-rating agency, Moody's Investors Service, increased the city's rating for the first time since 1991. City bonds have been trading at the higher level since last summer, when that upgrade was first predicted, said Denis Galle, a managing director at Lebenthal & Company, which deals heavily in the city's bonds.
But Mr. Whitestone said New York could still profit from the new rating since it would open up the city's bond market to more banks and other institutional investors who can buy only bonds with ratings in the A range. "Far more institutions can now purchase the bonds," he said.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasuries Slide Despite Signals Of Diminished Inflation Pressure

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury securities fell yesterday despite Government reports pointing toward lower economic growth and diminished inflationary pressure.
Traders attributed the bond market's retreat to a further decline in the dollar's value and a belief that the effects of the General Motors strike had made the latest economic data look deceptively weak. 
 The dollar fell to the lowest level against the yen in more than three weeks on speculation that Japan's next elected prime minister will support radical bank reform.
The dollar also fell for the fifth day against the mark after Russia's Parliament passed austerity measures to secure new loans.
Bonds have tended to track the dollar's value lately. A higher dollar attracts foreign investors to assets denominated in the currency.
The benchmark 30-year bond slipped 12/32, to a price of 105 21/32. The yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 5.72 percent, from 5.70 percent on Wednesday.
The price weakness came despite Government reports showing a decline of six-tenths of a percent in June industrial production and a decline of eight-tenths of a percent in factory use. The reports suggested the economy was cooling, which would tend to help bonds.
But economists said the data reflected the mass shutdown of G.M. factories caused by a strike at two plants in Flint, Mich., that began more than a month ago. The reports would have been stronger without the effects of the labor dispute.
"The G.M. strike has started to wreak havoc with the economic data base and market observers are beginning to weave through the statistical minefield," said Donald Fine, the chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management.

HEADLINE: Mahbub ul Haq, 64, Analyst And Critic of Global Poverty

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

 BODY:
Mahbub ul Haq, a former Finance Minister of Pakistan and an early proponent of economic liberalization who in later years argued that poor countries failed to prosper because they neglected the basic development of their people, died yesterday in New York. He was 64.
The cause of death was pneumonia, said his son, Farhan, a reporter for the Inter Press Service, a news agency. The elder Mr. Haq, who was visiting New York from Pakistan, collapsed early this week and did not respond to treatment, former colleagues said. 
 Mr. Haq, who had also been a governor of the International Monetary Fund and director of policy planning at the World Bank, was the author of several books, including "The Poverty Curtain" (Columbia University Press) and "Strategy of Economic Planning" (Oxford University Press).
But he is best known for his creation in 1990 of an annual Human Development Index, a measure used by the United Nations Development Program to measure the wealth of nations by the level of living standards their citizens have attained.
His views did not make him popular in many developing countries, nor in some Western capitals, where he also criticized foreign aid policies and domestic social programs.
A scrappy and articulate debater, he relished the controversies he provoked. He traveled extensively to speak and gather information and impressions for the United Nations' annual Human Development Report, which was built around his index.
James Gustave Speth, administrator of the United Nations Development Program, said, "I don't think anybody did more or even as much as Mahbub did to bring balance back to development thinking when everyone else was worshiping at the altar of G.N.P. growth."
After leaving the United Nations Development Program in 1995, Mr. Haq returned to Pakistan to establish the Human Development Center for South Asia with the help of his wife, Khadija Khanum, an economist. Measures of human progress in the region, especially in India and Pakistan, had begun to slip badly.
"After producing seven global Human Development Reports, I had to face the sad reality that the real challenge to human development lay back home, in Pakistan and South Asia," he said. "South Asia has been sinking fast into a quagmire of human deprivation and despair, emerging as the most deprived region of the world."
Mr. Haq, who is survived by his daughter, Toneema, as well as his wife and son, studied at Punjab University in Pakistan, King's College in Cambridge, Yale and Harvard.
He was born on Feb. 22, 1934, and while still in his 20's he became the chief economist of Pakistan's national planning commission. In the 1980's, under the late President Mohammad Zia-ul Haq, he served as Minister of Commerce, Planning and Finance. He moved to Washington and the World Bank in 1988.
The founder of the Third World Forum, a panel for discussing development issues, Mr. Haq was also an adviser to the Brandt Commission, which looked into economic relations between the rich and poor nations.
In his spare time, he was a great reader of literature and poetry. In 1985 he wrote a volume of poems titled "An Elusive Dawn."
"I have struggled for a long time with the concept and practice of development," Mr. Haq wrote in the preface to the first Report on Human Development in South Asia, in 1997. "Emerging from the Western citadels of learning -- Cambridge, Yale, Harvard -- in the 1950's, I was armed with the firm neoclassical conviction that the real purpose of development was to increase national income." Over half a century, he increasingly doubted that analysis.
"There is widespread consensus today," he wrote, "that the purpose of development is not just to enlarge incomes but to enlarge people's choices, and that these choices extend to a decent education, good health, political freedom, cultural identity, personal security , community participation, environmental security and many other areas of human well-being.
"A link between growth and human lives must be created through conscious national planning."

HEADLINE: Production Declined in June For First Time in 4 Months

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 16

 BODY:
Industrial production declined during June for the first time in four months, the Government said today, partly reflecting the strike at the General Motors Corporation.
The Federal Reserve said output at the nation's factories, mines and utilities decreased six-tenths of 1 percent last month. Production had risen in each of the three previous months; the Fed today revised May's gain to three-tenths of 1 percent from the half a percent reported earlier. 
 June's decline, which matched a drop in May 1993, was the steepest since output fell nine-tenths of 1 percent in March 1991, the final month of the 1990-91 recession.
Most of last month's decline was attributed to an 11 percent drop in auto production stemming from the strike. Output at factories other than auto and truck plants rose one-tenth of 1 percent in June following a decline of the same amount in May.
Utility output last month increased four-tenths of 1 percent, and production at mines and oil wells fell 2 percent.
The production decline pushed down the operating rate at industrial companies to 81.6 percent of capacity in June, the lowest rate in five years, from 82.4 percent in May. At factories alone, the operating rate declined to 80.3 percent, also the lowest in five years, from 81.1 percent.
Economists attribute some of the drop in output to businesses' desire to reduce the huge inventory of unsold goods that developed during the first three months of the year as export sales fell.
Despite the overall weakness of June's report, there were areas of strength. Production of industrial equipment rose 2.2 percent, with strong increases for construction machinery and computers and other office equipment. Semiconductor and clothing output also rose.

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate;
In TriBeCa, a Condo Building on a Parking Lot Site

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
With many of the remaining old warehouses in TriBeCa being swallowed up by conversions to expensive lofts, plans are moving ahead for one of the first newly constructed condominium buildings in the area in a decade.
Plans call for a nine-story reddish brick structure, designed to blend with its older neighbors, that will contain 26 two- to four-bedroom lofts, including two penthouses. The apartments, some with terraces, are expected to range in size from 1,500 to 3,600 square feet and in price from $600,000 to $3 million. There will also be 4,500 square feet of ground-level retail space in the building, which will rise on a corner site at Hudson Street and Ericsson Place in a spot now occupied by a surface parking lot and a vacant automotive shop. 
 The new building is being developed by 124-130 Hudson Street L.L.C., a firm based in Jersey City, whose principals include members of a family that once operated the parking lot on the site.
The conversion underscores developers' continued interest in capitalizing on Manhattan's strong residential market and what they say is an increasing demand for new housing in neighborhoods like TriBeCa.
Meeting that demand in TriBeCa in the last few years has meant converting existing warehouses. But with the supply of big former manufacturing and warehouse buildings dwindling and the cost of buying and renovating buildings nearing the cost of constructing new ones, developers see now as a good time to build, said Peter Hauspurg, chairman of Eastern Consolidated Properties, a Manhattan-based real estate investment company.
David H. Imrie, a condominium sales broker at the TriBeCa office of Douglas Elliman, a Manhattan brokerage concern, said that sales prices for the area's condominium lofts have risen to a point that supports new construction. In the last two years, the average sales price for such units has gone from $300 a square foot to $500, with penthouses selling in the $700-a-square-foot range, Mr. Imrie said, adding that the increase was reflective of a "new breed of lofts, with all the bells and whistles, like a doorman."
In addition to the Hudson Street project, there are three other new condominium buildings in various stages of the approval process that together could produce about 100 loft apartments, according to estimates from Community Board 1. All are planned on sites now or once used as surface or garage parking. The largest is a 12-story, 68-unit building proposed at 3-9 Hubert Street.
Another project was planned at 32 White Street. But the property was recently sold to Hartz Mountain Industries of Secaucus, N.J., which plans to build a hotel, said Emanuel Stern, the company's president.
"I guess the best thing," said Judy Duffy, assistant district manager of Community Board 1, "is that the new projects have a relatively low density and will not translate into too many units, even though they will replace parking lots, which are still open space."
Anita Murray, a member of the TriBeCa Community Association, added, "Considering what the alternatives could be, the residential reuse of sites is the least offensive."
Finding building sites is getting more difficult, but the developers of the Hudson Street project were in a better position than most. The company's principals are members of the Harwood family, who ran the parking operation on the site, along with 54 others in New York City, until 1997, when it sold its parking company, Square Industries.
Before the sale, the family contracted to buy the Hudson Street property, contingent on all approvals, from the owner and began the development process. The family has been involved with other investors in development of 12 residential buildings, totaling just under 1,000 units, on sites that included parking lots it owned throughout the city.
In terms of timing and location, the site represented "an opportunity," Craig Harwood said, citing the supply-demand imbalance in the TriBeCa housing market as factors for pressing ahead. "The challenge was creating a building the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission felt comfortable with and we felt made economic sense," Mr. Harwood said. The project is expected to cost $26 million to build, including the cost of the site.
Both new buildings and conversions that take place in designated historic districts like parts of TriBeCa must receive approval from the commission. It approved the design of the Hudson Street project, situated in the TriBeCa West historic district, in January after nine months of review and many revisions. The revisions largely had to do with the number of setbacks on the building. The developers wanted more setbacks in order to offer more terraces as amenities. Two setbacks were ultimately approved.
The building, designed by Peter DeWitt Architects of Manhattan, will have features reflective of TriBeCa warehouses, including big recessed windows, molded brick cornices shaped like crowns and three corrugated steel marquees around its one-story base. Decorative cast-stone and brick details are more modern, Erica Tishman, a partner at the architectural firm said. While "no one will be fooled that the building hasn't been here for hundreds of years," she observed, "it harmonizes with its historic surroundings."
Mr. Harwood said construction was to start on the Hudson Street building in October.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Lockheed Calls Off Merger With Northrop Grumman
Faced with continued resistance from the Government, Lockheed Martin has abandoned its planned $8.3 billion acquisition of the Northrop Grumman Corporation.
The decision followed months of negotiations between the companies and the Government to avoid a court fight. The deal's breakup signals the end of a wave of consolidation that swept through the military industry after the cold war ended. Page A1. 

U.S. Pressed I.M.F. on Russian Aid
Seven weeks ago, the International Monetary Fund was playing down the crisis in Russia. This week, in an about-face, the fund and the Russian Government announced a bailout package that will inject $17.1 billion in new loans to the nation. The Clinton Administration was the driving force behind the reversal. Treasury officials were worried that while negotiations with the Russians dragged on, the political peril to President Boris N. Yeltsin's Government was growing. A1.
 
The Russian Parliament agreed to a national sales tax, giving the Government a surprise victory in its effort to pass an economic austerity plan. A8.
 
Unresolved Chiquita Questions
Despite a furor over The Cincinnati Enquirer's retreat from a stinging series on reputed influence peddling by Chiquita Brands International, some of the allegations cannot be dismissed so easily. A1.
 
Industrial Production Falls
The nation's industrial production declined during June for the first time in four months. Most of the drop reflected an 11 percent decline in automotive production because of the General Motors strike. D5.
 
Mixed Results for Cola Giants
Coca-Cola said earnings fell in the second quarter, but Pepsico reported a gain in earnings. Pepisco said it released its results earlier than scheduled because Wall Street had pushed down the price of its shares about 8 percent this week. D3.
 
Delta Posts 20% Rise in Profit
Delta Air Lines reported a 20 percent gain in quarterly earnings on low fuel prices and strong passenger bookings. The results exceeded expectations, but Delta's stock fell 1.2 percent, to $135.50, on disappointment the gains were not even stronger. The stock reached a 52-week high on Wednesday. D4.
 
Gains at SBC and Ameritech
SBC Communications and Ameritech, which plan to merge, posted earnings that were slightly better than expected. Both companies cited strong demand for data services and heavy sales of features like call waiting. D5.
 
Questions on Stock Buyback Plans
Stock buybacks have typically bolstered share prices. But with stock prices at record highs, aggressive buybacks look increasingly dicey. Gretchen Morgenson: Market Place. D4.
 
Postal Service's Cycling Campaign
The United States Postal Service is sponsoring the only American-based team competing in the Tour de France, the 2,400-mile-long bicyle race now under way. Why cycling as a marketing opportunity? For one, the Postal Service is getting a fair amount of exposure, helped by the surprisingly strong showing of George Hincapie of the United States. Advertising. D4.
 
Tapes Heard in Price-Fixing Case
In the price-fixing trial of three former Archer Daniels Midland executives, secret Government recordings of discussions on pricing lysine, a food additive, were played in public for the first time. D17.

HEADLINE: Theater Complex Planned for Brooklyn

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
In a sign that developers are increasingly forced to scout out unlikely locales for new projects, a Manhattan company said yesterday that it would build a huge entertainment complex along the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn that would include the city's largest multiplex movie theater.
The project, to be known as Brooklyn Commons, would be part of a stark modern steel and glass complex contrasting sharply with the surrounding ragtag assemblage of what was once one of the city's busiest manufacturing zones. Besides a 22-screen Loews theater, the complex would include a bowling alley, athletic center, shops, restaurants, a 1,500-car parking garage and an esplanade along the Gowanus Canal. 
 The canal was dug in the 1860's to provide a manufacturing lifeline to the New York Harbor but in recent years become a little used, malodorous liability to Brooklyn.
"This project is an indication that there is great market demand to develop parts of town where, years ago, people would have considered such things idle fantasy," said Joseph Rose, the city's Planning Commissioner, who has been a persistent advocate of luring builders to little-used industrial areas.
The developer, Millennium Partners, has several entertainment complexes across the nation, including the Lincoln Square Complex of movie theaters in Manhattan. The company plans to spend $63 million on the Gowanus project.
"Having built entertainment centers of this kind before, we are confident that New York City residents and visitors will find this an exciting gathering place," Christopher M. Jeffries, president of Millennium Partners, said at a City Hall news conference with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.
Mayor Giuliani said the project, planned for completion by 2000, could be built without zoning changes and would not receive city tax breaks.
Still, plans for the entertainment complex have not received unqualified support from residents of the surrounding neighborhoods of Park Slope and Carroll Gardens. The project is to be built on the west side of Second Avenue, from 10th Street to 12th Street, on land owned by the United States Postal Service. Residents said they worried about the traffic the complex would generate and wanted assurances that it would provide employment opportunities and retail space for local residents.
"If this project is done properly, it can be wonderful," said Ben Meskin, president of Care About the Slope, a community group representing the south end of Park Slope. "We just want the developers to talk to us."
Stephen DiBrienza, a City Council member representing surrounding neighborhoods, said yesterday that the Mayor's news conference announcing the project had come as a shock to many residents who did not think the developers had satisfied their complaints.
"This an example of the Mayor, in making this sound like a done deal, putting his cart way out ahead of the horse," he said, adding that Brooklyn residents may file suit to block the project because of what he called "shoddy and inaccurate" information contained in an environmental review of the property by the Postal Service.
But yesterday's announcement came after a succession of meetings among the developers, neighborhood representatives and elected officials earlier this week at the behest of Nydia M. Velasquez, the Brooklyn Congresswoman. Ms. Velasquez said she had persuaded the Postal Service to postpone signing a lease until discussions took place involving Mr. Meskin, Mr. DiBrienza and other neighborhood representatives.
The discussions clearly did not satisfy everyone. Mr. DiBrienza said yesterday that developers had been "evasive and unresponsive." But Ms. Velasquez said executives of Millennium Partners had "made it clear they want to work with the neighborhood."
In one concession, she said, the developers had agreed to conduct a traffic study before they begin construction, and had indicated that they would provide signs, streetlights or other improvements that would ease congestion.
Jed Marcus, chief executive of Insite, a development company working with Millennium on the project, said late yesterday that a 99-year lease on the Postal Service property had been finalized. Under terms of the agreement, the developers will pay $500,000 a year for the 9.4-acre site, demolish one Postal Service building that until the early 1990's was used as a vehicle maintenance garage, and incorporate another Postal Service building on the site into their complex.
The Brooklyn project comes amid a surge of development at long-derelict sites elsewhere in the city. Just a mile away from the Gowanus site, developers have transformed the long-abandoned area above the Atlantic Terminal railway station into a huge shopping complex.. And at the site of the former Washburn Wire factory in East Harlem, developers announced in March that they would build a retail complex, with Home Depot and Costco as major tenants.
The plans for the Gowanus site were announced a week after the Marriott Corporation opened a 367-room hotel in downtown Brooklyn, which officials hailed as a sign that the borough is bouncing back economically.
"This is an absolutely remarkable investment that will aid in the resurgence of Brooklyn," Mayor Giuliani said of the Gowanus project.
Another investment in the area is being made by the city itself. Mr. Rose said the city is nearly finished with repairs of a 90-year old mechanical flushing system for the canal, designed to pull water from the New York Harbor and keep the waterway largely clear of of sewage.
